speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: And thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: With that, I'll turn it over to Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd like to start by reiterating my appreciation to those of you who participated in our Investor Day last month.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We greatly valued the opportunity to walk you through our refreshed strategy and our plans for the next few years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Given how much time we spent on our strategy that day, today we'll be focusing on the quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Nonetheless, as we committed, we will keep you updated on our progress, and you can see the latest report card on slide 2.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Today is also the first time we're reporting quarterly results under our new segmentation, which will help you track our efforts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I've got to say it feels like an understatement to say that a lot has happened since Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'm going to talk about the macro environment first, and then after I talk about the quarter, I'll discuss how we're handling Russia and Mark's also going to go through it in more detail.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been on the front foot since the potential for war first emerged, and we intend to remain so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Russian invasion of Ukraine and the sanctions it triggered unleashed an enormous supply shock on the world, further fueling inflation and placing global growth under considerable pressure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Back recently from seeing clients in Europe and the Middle East, it is security, yet energy, food, defense, cyber or operational resilience that has risen to the top of their strategic dialog.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The macro outlook for the rest of the year can only be described as complex and uncertain.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And while my job is to prepare for all outcomes, our view is that strong nominal income growth and continuing momentum in the labor market will help support near-term growth in the US economy in the face of inflationary pressures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we expect material regional differences in the impact with economic growth in the individual consumer and businesses in Europe hit hardest.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With central banks responding to inflation, we're entering a period of higher rates and a flatter US yield curve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Energy and commodities are at the center of the storm globally, but we don't believe we're at the start of a new long supercycle, and we do expect prices to fall to more normal levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So with that as a backdrop, I think the firm performed reasonably well this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Earlier today we reported net income of $4.3 billion, EPS of $2.02, and an RoTCE of 10.5%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These numbers include impacts related to the divestitures, so the underlying business performance was stronger to the tune of about 150 basis points of RoTCE.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now let's turn to the performance of our five main reporting units.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, given our emphasis on Services, I'm particularly pleased with our performance in Treasury and Trade Solutions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Fee growth, trade loans, and crossborder transactions – buoyed by higher rates – led to year-over-year revenue growth of 18%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Securities Services also performed well despite the impact of markets with revenues up 6%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In our Markets business, our traders navigated a volatile environment quite well, aided by our mix, with notable performance amongst corporate clients and strong gains in FX and commodities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This led to revenues almost equal to the very active first quarter of 2021.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you might expect, Investment Banking is a different story.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While our performance on the advisory side was respectable, I think we can perform a bit better in equity and debt capital markets going forward, even if the wallet remains smaller.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our pipelines are healthy and loan demand is on the rise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Having said that, we don't expect robust activity in the capital markets to resume in the industry until the geopolitical situation and client sentiments improve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In US Personal Banking, we continue to see signs of how healthy and resilient the consumer is through our cost of credit and their payment rates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see good engagement through key drivers such as card loans and spend volume growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we like where this business is headed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Geopolitics dampened performance in Global Wealth Management this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While revenues improved in the US, our clients in Asia pulled back on new investments and something we saw in our Markets franchise as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, we are hiring bankers and enhancing our client offerings such as Citi Alliance which we launched last month as a unique platform to support independent advisors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As a result of these efforts, we continued to add clients in both the Private Bank and in Citigold.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to capital, we returned $4 billion to our shareholders through stock buybacks and dividends during the first quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We now have about 6% fewer common shares outstanding than we did a year ago.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At the same time, a sharp increase in interest rates negatively impacted our capital through OCI and largely caused our common equity Tier 1 capital ratio to come in at 11.4% this quarter.
Capital Adequacy & Buffers phrase: common equity tier 1, capital ratio, tier 1 capital

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I want to be upfront with you about the fact that the macro and geopolitical environment which I spoke about, combined with the impacts of our divestitures, create both headwinds and tailwinds for our capital ratios this year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, whilst this will impact the level of our stock buybacks this year, we have a path to our year-end target of 12%, and Mark is going to walk you through these details.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And let me be clear, we remain committed to continuing to return excess capital to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you heard at the Investor Day, we're focused on our transformation, and we're making the investments in our infrastructure, risk and controls, and also in our talent and our culture to modernize our bank and to make Citi a winning firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I recognize that these investments impact our expenses and our returns in the short run.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I firmly believe that success here will not only lead to satisfying our regulatory obligations, but also to improving our competitiveness and our returns in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So far this year, we've announced new agreements to sell a further seven consumer businesses in Asia and EMEA, the most recent of which were India and Bahrain.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are beginning the sales process in Mexico, and there is significant interest in this iconic franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you've heard me say, this is not an uncomplicated transaction given we will be separating our operations in order to retain our institutional presence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will take the time necessary to do this the right way and decide which transaction is in the best interest of our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we will keep you posted on any developments concerning the three remaining markets, China, Poland, and of course Russia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We started to carefully reduce our operations in and our exposures to Russia in January, and we benefited from being on the front foot here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been managing down our financial exposures both in level and composition, and they're at a reasonable level, especially given the additional reserves we took during the quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've also increased reserves for the second and third order impact of the war beyond Russia and Ukraine, and our intention to sell significant portions of our local business in Russia remains.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are in continuous communication with the US government, and we continue to do our part to enforce the sanctions regime.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I've run out of words to describe the tragic consequences of the war in Ukraine.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I remain incredibly proud of how our people have risen to the occasion from every corner of our firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our people in Ukraine have kept our bank operating in the country where they can help NGOs deliver aid on the ground and help society function as best as possible.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And many of our colleagues have opened their homes to refugees, and we will continue to help in any way we can.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So with all that is going on in the world, we remain laser-focused on the execution of our strategy and our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I expect macro environment to remain unpredictable, to say the least, in the backdrop of a war which is equally tragic and unnecessary, and a persistent pandemic.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I can speak to the last one personally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Having just recovered from a brief encounter with COVID, much as I would like to, I can't blame Paco for it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, I'd like to turn it over to Mark, and then we will be delighted to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm going to start with the firmwide financial results focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the first quarter, unless I indicate otherwise, then spend a little more time on expenses and Russia, and end with the results of each segment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 4, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned earlier, in the first quarter, we reported net income of $4.3 billion and an EPS of $2.02 with an RoTCE of 10.5% on $19.2 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in these results are Asia Consumer divestiture-related impacts that are detailed in the appendix of the presentation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, total revenues decreased 2% as strength in net interest income driven by Services and PBWM was more than offset by lower non-interest revenue across businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we continue to see strong performance in the key business drivers we shared on Investor Day, which I will walk you through in detail shortly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total expenses of $13.2 billion increased 15%, or 10% excluding the Asia divestiture-related impacts I just mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $755 million, as net credit losses of $872 million were partially offset by a net ACL release.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in the net ACL release is a Russia-related build of approximately $1.9 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This includes $1 billion related to exposure to Russia and about $900 million to account for the broader impact on the macro environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This was more than offset by a release related to a COVID-19 uncertainty reserve, primarily in US Personal Banking, given the continued resilience of the underlying portfolio, specifically in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As of today, we have about $17.9 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loan ratio of 2.35%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 5, we show an expense walk for the first quarter with the key underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, we incurred some divestiture-related costs this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These costs largely related to a goodwill write-down that we incurred in Legacy Franchises, as part of our re-segmentation and divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is important to note the goodwill impact is capital neutral.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the divestiture-related costs, expenses increased by approximately 10%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: 3% of the increase was driven by transformation investments, with about two-thirds related to the risk, controls, data, and finance programs, and approximately 30% of that is related to technology investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About 2% of the increase was driven by business-led investments, as we continue to hire commercial and investment bankers as well as client advisors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition, we are investing in technology across Services, Wealth and Cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: 1% was due to higher revenue and volume-related expenses largely in Markets and Cards, and approximately 4% was driven by inflation and other risk and control investments, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across all of these buckets we continue to invest in technology, which is up 12% for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6 we provide an update on our exposure to Russia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned, as of the end of the quarter, our remaining exposure to Russia stood at about $7.8 billion, down from $9.8 billion at year end.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And importantly, the mix of the remaining exposure has changed and shifted in a positive way.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have reduced our direct Russia country risk exposure from $5.4 billion to about $3.7 billion which consists of loans, AFS, derivatives, and offbalance sheet exposure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The remaining exposure, which previously totaled $4.4 billion now totals $4.1 billion and consists of deposits and cash with the central bank, reverse repos, and cross-border exposure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Additionally, our net investment in our Russian entity is now approximately $700 million, down from about $1 billion at year end.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the currency translation adjustment, or CTA, related to our net investment stands at $1 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as I mentioned previously, we took credit reserves of about $1.9 billion with about $1 billion for direct exposures to Russia and another approximately $900 million for broader impacts given the macro environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we feel we have reserved prudently at this point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the normal course of our planning and risk management, we run a range of stress scenarios, and we've taken this same approach with our exposure to Russia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as a result of the actions that we've taken to reduce our risk, we now believe that under a range of severe stress scenarios, our potential risk of loss is now estimated at approximately $2.5 billion to $3 billion, down meaningfully from what I described at our Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show net interest income, loans, and deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the first quarter, net interest income increased by approximately $50 million on a sequential basis as interest income from loans as well as higher deposit spreads were partially offset by day count.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding day count, net interest income increased by approximately $290 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sequentially, net interest margin increased by 7 basis points as lower average deposits in Services and higher interest income from loans were partially offset by balance sheet growth in Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a year-over-year basis, net interest income increased by approximately $370 million driven by Cards, deposits volumes, and spreads as well as income from the investment portfolio, partially offset by lower net interest income in Markets, and we grew average loans by approximately 3% in both ICG and PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show our summary balance sheet and key capital and liquidity metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintained a very strong balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of our $2.4 trillion balance sheet, about 23% or $551 billion, are high-quality liquid assets, or HQLA, and we maintained total liquidity resources of approximately $960 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: From a capital perspective, we ended the quarter with a CET1 capital ratio of approximately 11.4% under both standardized and advanced approaches, with standardized remaining the binding ratio down from 12.2% at year end.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: During the quarter, we adopted SA-CCR and absorbed a significant impact from the sharp move in interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will go into more detail shortly on the drivers of capital in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, it is important to note that despite these impacts we continued to expect to manage to a CET1 ratio of 12% by the end of the year due to the expected GSIB surcharge increase to 3.5% at the beginning of 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect the combination of net income generation, DTA utilization, and capital generated by the closing of several of the consumer exits in Asia to be sufficient to reach the 12% CET1 ratio by the end of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we said at Investor Day, we're committed to returning excess capital to our shareholders, and as we see a pull to par in the investment portfolio, reversing that $4 billion interest rate-driven impact, we would expect to be able to deploy that capital over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you know, under the SCB framework and given the uncertain macro environment, we assess on a quarter-by-quarter basis the right level of buybacks and we will continue to do so throughout the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the second quarter, we expect only a modest amount of buybacks and we'll evaluate that level throughout the quarter taking into account market conditions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Given the sizeable impact of some of the drivers I wanted to spend a minute to walk through the puts and takes this quarter and how we ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of about 11.4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we generated net income which added 35 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, over $4 billion of dividends and buybacks drove a reduction of about 36 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, the interest rate impact on AOCI through our investment portfolio drove a 35 basis point reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fourth, the increase in disallowed DTA largely driven by the reduction in CET1 due to the interest rate impact I just mentioned, drove another 15-basis-point reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, the remainder was driven by a combination of other factors including a reduction in RWA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With all of that said, as I just mentioned, we have a path to a 12% CET1 capital ratio by year end and remain committed to returning excess capital to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 10 we show the results for our Institutional Clients Group.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues decreased 2% largely driven by Investment Banking, partially offset by an increase in Services revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And Markets declined slightly against a strong quarter last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 13% driven by transformation investments, business-led investments, and volume-related expenses partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was nearly $1 billion, largely driven by a $1.5 billion build related to our exposures in Russia as well as the broader impact on the macro environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And outside of Russia, we continued to see strong credit performance across our portfolio as clients' balance sheets remain healthy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of $2.6 billion, down approximately 51%, largely driven by the higher expenses and an ACL build versus a release in the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We grew average loans by 3% largely driven by trade finance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits grew 2% as we continued to see good momentum and deepening of existing client relationships and new client acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And ICG delivered an RoTCE of 11.2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 11, we show revenue performance by business and the key drivers we laid out at Investor Day, which we will continue to show you each quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Services we continued to see a very strong new client pipeline and a deepening with our existing clients, and we expect that momentum to continue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Treasury and Trade Solutions, revenues were up 18% driven by growth in net interest income as well as strong fee growth with both commercial and large corporate clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we continue to see strong underlying drivers in TTS that indicate continued strong client activity with US dollar clearing volumes up 2%, cross-border flows up 17%, and commercial card volumes up 54%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, these metrics are indicators of client activity and fees and on a combined basis drive approximately 50% of total TTS fee revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Securities Services revenues grew 6% as net interest income grew 17% driven by higher interest rates across currencies, and fee revenues grew 2% due to higher assets under custody.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Overall Markets revenues were down 2% versus a strong quarter last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter activity levels benefited from client repositioning and strong risk management in light of Fed actions and overall geopolitical uncertainty.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income Markets revenues were down 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We saw strong client engagement particularly with our corporate clients in FX and commodities, with our rates business also benefiting from higher volatility.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Spread products were negatively impacted by less client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equity Markets revenues were down 4% compared to a very strong prior-year period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter we saw strong equity derivatives performance and grew prime finance balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking revenues, excluding gains or losses on loan hedges, were down 32% as heightened geopolitical uncertainty and the overall macro backdrop impacted activity in debt and equity capital markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking revenues were down 43% driven by the contraction in capital markets activity, partially offset by growth in M&A.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate Lending revenues were down 6% largely driven by lower average loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to slide 12, we show the results for our Personal Banking and Wealth Management business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 1% as net interest income was more than offset by lower non-interest revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 14%, driven by transformation investments, business-led investments, and higher volume-driven expenses, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a $376 million benefit, as an ACL release more than offset net credit losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We had a net release of over $1 billion of ACL related to COVID-19 uncertainty reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would note that even after this release, we maintain over $9.8 billion in credit reserves against our US cards portfolios, or approximately 7.6% of total loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in a net income decline of 23% and an RoTCE of just over 23%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Adjusting for the ACL release, RoTCE would have been approximately 13%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 13, we show PBWM revenues by product as well as key business drivers and metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues declined 1% on higher average payment rates and higher acquisition and rewards costs as we continued to see attractive investment opportunities and strong customer engagement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are seeing encouraging underlying drivers with new accounts up 24%, card spend volumes also up 24%, and average loans up 7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues were flat as higher net interest income was offset by higher partner payments, driven by improved credit performance, and we are seeing positive underlying drivers with spend up 14% and average loans up 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While payment rates remain elevated, we believe we have finally begun to see some normalization.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a result, interest-earning balances in Branded Cards were relatively flat on a sequential basis while Retail Services grew interest-earning balances by 3% sequentially despite seasonally lower card spending volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues declined 6%, largely driven by lower mortgage originations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues declined 1% driven by less client activity in investments, partially offset by higher deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment revenues declined as geopolitical tension impacted the capital markets which resulted in clients pulling back their trading activity particularly in Asia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, underlying drivers remained strong with average deposits up 14%, average loans up 5%, client assets up 4%, and client advisors up 6%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 14, we show results for the Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 14% driven by lower revenue across the exit markets, largely driven by the Korea wind down as well as the muted investment activity in Asia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 31% largely driven by the goodwill impairment I mentioned earlier but, again, this is neutral to capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $160 million in the quarter, driven by net credit losses, and as a result, net income declined significantly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 15, we show results for Corporate / Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased significantly, largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were down, largely on lower compensation expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And to briefly touch on the full year 2022 outlook, at this point, we still expect to see low-single digit revenue growth and mid-single digit expense growth both excluding divestiture-related impacts this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question is from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: How are you?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So when I first looked at the reserve release, even including the $1.9 billion Russian reserve, we were like, wait, what economic scenario are they writing to, because everybody else added provisions.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But now that you've given us some of the color, I start to understand it.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, it feels to me – and correct me if I'm wrong – you just were slower to release the COVID reserves and it sounds like you still have a lot in the coffers with that 7.6% that you mentioned.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, I just want to see if you can give a little more color between what you took reserves for, what you released reserves for, and if you tweaked your economic scenarios at all to get to the current reserve, if that's not too much to ask.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Hey, there, Glenn.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Why don't I kick off and I'll pass it to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you are absolutely right, we had taken a rather conservative approach to releasing our COVID-related reserves in the US Personal Banking business last year compared to some.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We were comfortable that this quarter that was the appropriate thing to do given the state of COVID and the US economy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you can see from the numbers, with a 2.35% ACL coverage ratio and with the ratio that we have in Cards, 7.6% in particular, I'm very comfortable that we have a prudent and appropriate reserve level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But let me hand it over to Mark for the down and the dirty.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think you've captured it right in the sense we obviously did a meaningful build related to Russia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The majority of the release was in fact tied to the COVID-19 management adjustment that Jane referenced.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we thought about these scenarios, as you know we run a base scenario, we did tweak that a bit in bringing the GDP assumptions down from what they would have been in the fourth quarter, and that obviously also impacted kind of the outer years in our assumption.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the other piece is, when we look the downside scenario – so our analysis for CECL is a combination of a base scenario and a downside scenario.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Under the downside scenario, we did increase the severity of the downside to account for, again, a bit of the current environment that we're all managing through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, those puts and takes kind of netted out to what you see that we've reported, which is a net release, but largely driven by those two drivers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd just add in, as Mark talked about in his prepared remarks, we took an additional reserve of $900 million for the second and third order impacts of the war and the impacts on supply chains and other pieces that as we look forward we were concerned about for the global economy, it's a huge source of uncertainty as to what that will be.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's part of the $1.9 billion, obviously.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would point out that when you look through at the underlying performance of the portfolio, they're still holding up quite nicely.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When you look at the performance of our consumer customers, whether you're looking at the NCL rate and where that's trending, or you look at the 90-day delinquency and where that's trending, still very strong.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Even when you look on the corporate side, if you adjust for the Russia-related build and those drove a bit of the NAL increase, but still very strong performance there, too.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I just wanted to ask you a question, Jane and Mark, on CET1, and wanted to make sure we get – your investors get the message correctly.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So from the 11.4%, you said that net income capital release from divestitures and DTA utilization are going to be the drivers to build to 12% CET1 by year end 2021.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Obviously, AOCI is a wild card, unpredictable, but perhaps give us a sense of should we then think about the buyback as just a fallout in terms of that equation, right, is the first question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Number two, what is the desire to increase the dividend even nominally in this stress test year?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And third, how does the DTA impact that was negative in the first quarter turn to a positive impact?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And Mark, nice job on the RWA.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think that everybody was scared that that was going to be a big negative number this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You got a lot there, Erika, that we've got to unpack, so I'll try to capture it all and you'll point to whatever I may miss.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But let's start with the beginning of your question, just kind of the 12% and how we build back up to the 12%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we ended the quarter at an estimated 11.4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To get to the 12%, that'd be somewhere between $7 billion and $8 billion of capital that would be required.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane mentioned, I mentioned there are a number of puts and takes that play through that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You pointed out a few of them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, you will have estimates for our net income between the second and fourth quarter, so you can forecast what that would be.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There is probably another $1.6 billion or so of a benefit from the DTA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, what I mean by that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's the $800 million that I've referenced in the past of utilization of the DTA, and the balance would be the elimination of the amount that we tripped above the threshold this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, there are two components that carry forwards that impact, the DTA and then there is the timing difference which is equated to about 10% of our capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, this quarter we actually tripped that timing difference portion of the disallowed DTA, in part because of how the OCI reduction played through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So as that bleeds back in, over time, we would expect to have capital build up which increases that threshold and, therefore, be able to back off the increase that we saw in the quarter related to the DTA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The third component would be the capital from exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, you didn't mention that one.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, there are a number of exits that we're looking to close by the end of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They'll contribute about $4 billion of capital to that equation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then there is the bleeding back in of the OCI impact, which will, give or take, give us another $1 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, those are the pluses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Those are the things that kind of play in on the capital-generation side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then on the offsets, you've got preferred dividends, you got common dividends, whatever growth we play out or put to work from an RWA point of view, and that leaves the balance for share repurchases.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we would expect in the second quarter a modest level of buybacks in light of all of those puts and takes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The good news is that the headwinds that we've talked about, all things being equal, so assuming no further rate changes, many of those headwinds bleed back in over time, allowing for us to do what we've committed to, which is returning capital to shareholders over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of dividends, we always look at that as part of the CCAR submission and part of our broader capital planning, but we'll see how the results come out from CCAR.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I would lean in on a point we've had to make a number of times now, which is given where we're trading, it makes a lot of sense to be doing buybacks, and so we'll likely continue to lean that way as opposed to doing a lot to change the dividend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But stay tuned as the capital planning continues to evolve.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Could you talk some about Treasury and Trade Solutions both at the first quarter level – I guess, Securities Services did better, what you're seeing just combination of rates and more corporate demand and the complexity around the global situation.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then just more generally, the joint calling efforts you guys are doing with lending and payments, so from the specific to the general.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, maybe I kick off with a couple of pieces and then hand it over to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think what we've seen, frankly, Mike, across the board, this quarter has been the value of our global network that we talked about, be it in Markets we had a lot of strong corporate activities and FX, that we saw tremendous activity for TTS, growing with our commercial banking clients, and we saw a lot of linkages across, and obviously it was a strong quarter for us in trade because, again, with the global network the ability to provide clients with end-to-end solutions in this interesting world that we're living in is something they really rely upon us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So you saw trade loans up 16%, you saw really many of the drivers that we laid out for you in Investor Day performing particularly strongly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But, Mark, why don't I pass to you?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd make a couple comments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, I'd point out that, again, we had a strong quarter in TTS.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The revenues were up 18% versus the prior quarter up – that was year-over-year – versus the prior quarter up 8%, and, yes, some of that was due to rates playing through, so net interest income was up 18%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But look at the noninterest revenue, that was up 19%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So to your point, Jane, we're seeing good fee revenue growth play through as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Securities Services had a good quarter as well, it was up 6% revenue year-over-year and part of that was through fee revenue growth as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So as you said good, strong engagement with clients and helping them think through some of the uncertainty that's out here, particularly as it relates to supply chains, helping them work through with their partners through the trade lending growth that we're seeing and making good headway with the commercial client offering as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I would say a very good quarter – very strong quarter for TTS, and we expect that momentum to continue.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And, to your question about sort of joint calling effort, we're quite for it – making sure that we're forensically managing the synergies that we talked about cross-calling efforts, and I think Paco and I are both pleased with how those are going, and this quarter was an example of that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: I was hoping to follow up on the Russian slide here – a bit on the Russian slide 6.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I guess, first question, why don't you take just a bigger kind of stab at reserving for maybe the severe stress scenario?

speaker: Connor
sentence: I'm not really an expert on what's going on, but from what I read it – it feels kind of pretty severe and it seems like, broadly speaking, kind of other corporations, not as many banks, but just corporations are taking kind of more material losses versus $1 billion on $10 billion.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And then just a related question, if you could elaborate on what the broader impacts is.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I guess I'm a little surprised that the reserve for that was as big as the direct Russian reserve or roughly the same.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Why don't I take that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the first thing I'd say is that we're not a $10 billion, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we ended the year last year, 2021, at $9.8 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter at $7.8 billion of exposure, so we brought the exposure down by $2 billion inside of the last three months.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd also point out that a number of things were important components of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So if you look at slide 6, you'll see that the loans – and these are both ICG and consumer loans, largely ICG, largely corporate loans – have come down by $600 million, and that's really been a reduction in our risk exposure, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So borrowers paying down, us limiting the extension of new credit, et cetera.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The AFS securities have come down $600 million, and that is really a reduction mostly driven by sales.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we've gotten out of those securities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, there are some market-to-market losses, but they're not material.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That flows through OCI, not material.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You can see that the off-balance sheet unfunded commitments have trended down as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Deposits and cash equivalents have gone up because we've actually seen the repayment of those loans come back, and we've been – we've had to put that cash with the central bank just given some of the restrictions that are there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been actively working down the reverse repo assets which are really secured with sovereign bond exposure, and we've been bringing down the third-party cross-border exposure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So a lot of hard work has gone into bringing that exposure down to $7.8 billion, and if you think about the $1 billion that I referenced, it's kind of net of $6.8 billion, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the second part of your question was how do we think about reserves and what are those different components.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Well, we look at the reserves in terms of the actual name-specific loan exposure we have, how we're rating those entities in this environment, and then we actually run that through our models and we come up with an appropriate reserve tied to that rating.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that $1 billion is related to the direct exposure that we have to these Russian clients and entities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The broader impact takes into consideration the spillover effect that might impact other names or other industries outside of Russia due to things like commodity pricing and what have you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then there's a third component that is tied to the global uncertainty that gets created from a dynamic like this.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we built the reserves considering those multiple components.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The last point I'd make is that when you look at some of the names, there are a significant number of names that are large multinational names that have this exposure in the country, and they provide parental support for some of the exposure that's here as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we really try to take a detailed comprehensive look at this and build the reserves in a way that we think are prudent recognizing that there are other scenarios that could play out that we want to be prepared for and have a view on as well.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question – thank you.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, you did a good job in describing the CET1 ratio walk for us.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What's new that none of us have experienced yet on an ongoing basis is the SA-CCR, the 49 basis points that reduced your CET1 ratio.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you share with us how does that work on an ongoing basis?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Is that a number that's going to stay constant, or does that change every quarter based upon increase or lower risk in this area?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's an increase in our risk-weighted assets that's really tied largely to the derivative exposures that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I'd say is obviously how one manages their exposures and balance sheet and engagement with clients will impact that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But importantly, it's a market dynamic that needs to play out as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So as more RWA and capital is required for these types of positions, there has to – it's going to impact returns and ultimately will impact pricing as the market starts to incorporate this now higher requirement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so it will continue to evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The thing I'd point you to is that as we think about managing our businesses and in particular Markets, you would have heard us mention at Investor Day that we're looking – continually looking for opportunities to optimize the balance sheet – optimize RWA, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we talked about targeting our revenue to RWA for our Markets business and we're actively working at that now.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's going to be important as we continue to manage not only the balance sheet requirements that we have but our intent to try and return more capital to shareholders and improve our returns.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just sticking with capital, a two-part question.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: One, if rates continue to move higher, Mark, is there anything you can do to hedge the AOCI?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And secondly, if you can walk us through around Banamex if you do strike a deal at some point this year, what are the implication on capital at deal announcement versus deal close, would appreciate that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, I mean there – what we've built in – what we've got built into the forecast and the walk back to 12% is the forward curve as of the end of the quarter, so that's what we've built in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we think about that, that was a pretty sudden move through the quarter, 160 basis points on the two-year in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's now in the expectation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have built in an assumption around more rate moves that could happen just as a bit of cushion as I think about the outlook and as I think about the walk.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We do have hedges in place as it relates to some of the positions that we have and as it relates to OCI, and we'll continue to manage that to ensure we reduce the risk from rate increases, which, by the way, we've been actively doing over the past couple years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look at kind of how the balance sheet has evolved, we've been moving from out of AFS and into held to maturity over the past couple years, reducing that risk of a negative impact to OCI.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And if you look at the DV01, we've cut that down from as high as $60 million to about $30 million or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we've been actively managing with an eye towards how do we reduce that sensitivity, if you will.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Why don't I let Jane kind of touch on the Mexico piece?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So as I said, it's quite a complex separation and transaction as we're going to be separating our market leading and sizeable ICG franchise in Mexico from the consumer and the small business – business that we'll be selling.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It will take a bit of time as we work through this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a fantastic franchise, and as we are starting some very preliminary conversations with the buyers, it's attracting a lot of attention, because it is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity here and we have a range of options I'm sure ahead from IPO sale, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But this is going to take time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We want to do it properly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And by time, I mean a few quarters.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think, we're not anticipating at this very early stage whether that would be this year or early next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But, Mark, why don't I pass to you in terms of how we look at the CTA impact of that one.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, I mean, as you said, Jane, the – what's going to be important is that we make the right decision for the people, for the business and equally important for our shareholders, and we're going to absolutely make sure we do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the way this plays out, as I think you're aware, and I've mentioned before that we've got roughly a $2.8 billion, $2.9 billion currency translation adjustment related to our consumer Mexico franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so when we sign the deal, we will have that flow through the P&L.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It ultimately gets offset at closing, and so, again, you'd have another timing difference between the accounting impact and the ultimate economic impact, but that's kind of the component that would play through at signing, whenever that were to occur.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Couple of questions.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: One, a little bit ticky-tacky, but on your NIM sensitivity that you gave in your 10-Q – 10-K, it would be helpful to understand how much of that NIM sensitivity is coming from the non-Legacy businesses, how much that have NIM sensitivity is going to be retained after you sell out the businesses that you've identified?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I don't have that breakout, Betsy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, I – we'll have to kind of get back to you on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I don't have that breakout.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: A quick question, probably more for Mark.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The RWA increase from the higher volatility that you'd have seen in your trading assets in the first quarter, what was the offset to that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, in the first quarter, the major driver that we've seen is really on the credit risk side from an RWA point of view, and that was really tied to SA-CCR.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's the biggest driver of the fourth quarter, the first quarter RWA increase that we've seen.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the RWA from a market risk point of view was mostly flat due to reductions in trading book securitizations that was kind of – those are kind of the main drivers there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And what I'd say is, and you certainly heard this loud and clear from Paco at Investor Day, a lot of the strategy here is also making sure that we're optimizing our capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're very mindful around the returns that we're generating and how we allocate and deploy capital, and this was a quarter that Andy and Paco in running the businesses are being very mindful around that, so that also helped.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So like I said, securitizations would be an offset as would some of the equities derivatives.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So, it was encouraging certainly to hear you guys reaffirm the 2022 guidance for a low-single digit revenue growth, mid-single digit expense growth.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: But just given the positive surprise on revenues in the quarter, the number of rate hikes getting baked into the forward curve has increased since your last update.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Want to get some perspective on just why you didn't revise the revenue forecast higher.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And just given the pace and timing of investments, as we look ahead to 2023 and beyond, how should we think about the timing for when you guys can get back to positive operating leverage?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, let me kind of take that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So on the revenue side, as you would have heard us describe, there have been puts and takes that have played through the quarter and there is still a fair amount of uncertainty that's out there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so while there have been increases as it relates to rates, and we've seen and expect to see some benefit play through for that, there has also been an impact on banking revenues as we see the uncertainty creating a dynamic where corporate clients are pausing particularly as it relates to equity capital markets and debt capital markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so as I mentioned, there are offsets that play out, and so we felt comfortable kind of maintaining the guidance on the revenue top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the expenses, as I mentioned at Investor Day, the spend that we have going on in expenses is critically important, and we're still growing them as it relates to transformation and as it relates to business led investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the business-led investment side, the good news is that we're starting to see some of the top line strength play out, not just driven by rates, but also driven by things like fees, which is what we've forecasted.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the transformation side, we continue to make progress, and we've talked about how critically important that is to our operations going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect that that will peak or arc, if you will, as we talked about at Investor Day, and that will occur in the near term and will be an important offset, if you will, to the structural expense base that we have as the efficiencies from that spending plays through.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And just to chip in as well, we're committed to the arc of the investments on our transformation and on our growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We think they're both critically important.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're equally committed to managing our expense base prudently and forensically.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think the piece – if there is any comfort from our numbers, is we're getting on with it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're not hanging around here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've seen us do that with the divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're doing the same on our transformation and on our investment side, getting very focused on making sure we deliver the results you'd expect from them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll see something similar when we start divesting and closing the different transactions, and we'll talk to you about what we're doing on getting those any stranded expenses out and getting focused on that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you can expect us – to see us going pretty aggressively after different elements of our cost base as the timing is appropriate.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Ken, please check your mute button.

speaker: Operator
sentence: All right.

speaker: Operator
sentence: If I may move along to the next.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Next question is from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe just a question on – just following up on the last question.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Do you have a specific update for NII growth this year given the forward curve is substantially higher than 100 basis points and how you're thinking about NII overall?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then as a subset of that, how do we think about your deposit base, your more institutional deposit base acting in aggressive QT environment?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I'm not giving kind of guidance kind of broken out, if you will, for the revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're standing by the full year guidance that we've talked about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, with rates moving the way that they have, we would expect that we would see some improvement on the NII line, but I haven't given specific guidance broken out for the two lines.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the deposit base we have, as you know, we've got a mix of consumer and corporate client deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We skew a bit more heavily towards the corporate client deposit base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That generally comes with a higher beta, and so they're likely to be more reactive to and reactive sooner to the increase in interest rates, and quantitative tightening will certainly have a longer-term impact on the level of deposits that's out there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But with that said, our plans, both in the near term and as we've played out the Investor Day forecast, don't hinge upon significant growth in deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'd expect some growth, but growth consistent with kind of pre pandemic levels, but that's not outsized growth, and we believe our strategy, which is broader than just going after deposits, but really is around solutions for corporate clients and the full spectrum of financial services for the consumers that we focus on will allow for us to capture an appropriate level consistent with how the economy evolves.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Actually, Chubak and Jim asked my question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think it might be helpful to consider, Mark, for next quarter to break out the NII guide given obviously the uncertainty that we all have on forecasting trading and investment banking.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I just wanted to ask about how you're thinking about the US card business.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: This is an area where it feels like in some areas you've been lagging a bit, and in other areas accelerating.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And I just wanted to get a sense as to how you're thinking about the trajectory this year in particular since it's one of the better margin businesses that you've got and it also, obviously, keys into the reserve ratio a bit.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm surprised you thought we were lagging, because we certainly don't see that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I've been really pleased with how the cards franchise has been performing on multiple different drivers, on client acquisition, on the spend, on some of the new propositions that we've been bringing in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You heard from Anand about the growth on proprietary cards, the installment lending growth, 75% up, albeit from a small base this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So there are multiple different dimensions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think it's – we're very pleased to see the business actually picking up.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I said, Betsy, in my prepared remarks, I like where the business is headed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think part of it is I am more positive around the US economy and the US consumer than really any other geographies around the world, and that helps with so much momentum in the labor market.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing still quite a bit of excess liquidity sitting there in the back pocket of our consumers and very healthy balance sheets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we have peaked in the payment rates, so we're just starting to see the first signs of that coming down, and I think that's good because it's a return to a more – it should be the return this year to more healthy behavior.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The spend has obviously been quite remarkable.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's up in the mid-20%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Also great to see the experience side and that services side coming back in again, and that we've been seeing it in travel, we've been seeing it in apparel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: People like getting dressed up to go to dinner again in a restaurant.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Those different things, it's nice to see things coming back to normality.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I'm pretty positive both from cyclically where this is headed, the recovery from COVID where it's headed, and I'm also pretty happy with the strategy that Anand laid out and the progress we're making against it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think some good things ahead here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the only thing I'd add is a couple of numbers, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the sales were up 24% year-over-year, exceeding pre-pandemic levels across the categories.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Acquisitions were up 23% year-over year, again bringing on new card customers into our family, if you will.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were down 2%, but you really have to look through the investments that we're making in acquisitions and the rewards costs associated with those, that impact that revenue being down 2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you adjust for the acquisition costs, actually our revenues would be up 1% year-over-year, So I agree completely with you, Jane, which is we're very pleased with the progress here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're seeing similar momentum start to play through on the Retail Services side as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The sequential performance on average interest-earning balances is a good signal for how things will play out, and we continue to feel good about the growth we forecasted towards the back half of the year.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Andrew Lim with Société Générale.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: So I get the impression that maybe people are surprised by your NII guidance because in the past you've officially given it as based on a run-off balance sheet whereas it appears based on a static balance sheet.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: And I think you mentioned a few quarters ago that if it was on the same basis, a static balance sheet, that your NII uplift would be about $2.5 billion to $3 billion for a 100-basis point parallel shift.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: Is that something you're still sticking to?

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: And then within the shape of that, how much of that is due to the short-term increasing by 100 basis points?

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: I think you're much more sensitive to the short term going up.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: Is that something that you can disclose a rough figure on?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I'd like to separate kind of NII guidance from the IRE sensitivity and disclosure that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so you're absolutely right and I'm not moving – we're not moving off of our IRE disclosure at all.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The analysis is such that with a parallel shift in rates of about 100 basis points that we see somewhere around $2.5 billion to $3 billion of an increase kind of play through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you know or as I've said before, that's across currencies with about two-thirds of that being to non US currencies and the other third, obviously, being US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that is still our view from an IRE point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're not – we haven't changed that view.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I guess this is not new, but the expenses are just so high, and we haven't heard the 4% inflation number from others, and maybe others were able to offset that a little bit more.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And the 1% due to volume related, when Jane you mentioned, you don't expect this level's capital markets to be sustained.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So I guess I'm just – I'm griping about something that's been around for a while.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I get it, you have the reg order, you have the transformation, you have business sales.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You've said you underinvested in the past and everything else.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But, I mean, you have 1,200 basis points between your expense and revenue growth.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And it just seems so high.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But you're also guiding for what I think is, like, 300 basis points of that spread for the full year.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So does that mean this is as bad as it gets and that spread should be narrowed?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And just some of those other – inflation, volumes, expenses – expenses generally, because it's frustrating for investors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, Mike, why don't I take that and kind of try and talk through it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the first thing I'd say is that the 10% growth that we have in the quarter is consistent with the guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I just want to be clear that in Investor Day that's what we talked about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We would love for the number to be different, but we understand and we know that this is what's required to get the franchise to where it needs to be.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we're taking those hard decisions, we're spending the money where we need to spend it, we're being diligent about that to make sure that we're not being wasteful in that effort, but we don't want to create or go through the things that we've gone through in the past in the way of underinvesting, and so we're going to avoid that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing is – and you acknowledged that kind of in your reference to transformation and business led investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the structural investments spend I should say, about half of that is from inflation, so not the full 4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: A portion of it is also from non-consent order, risk and control spend that we're making, things like the financial crime unit, things like cyber spend, things like the work we're doing around our wholesale credit operations, important things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there are some productivity savings that play through that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the final piece on the volume-related is there are transactional costs that are associated with the activity that we do in the trading side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They're spend that we make in order to drive – in order to drive that activity, and the mix matters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so while revenues kind of play out in one way for the quarter, the mix of the markets activity impacts the level of volume-related expenses that's generated through those transactions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So those are a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, we're consistent with guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We believe we're on track for the guidance we gave for the full year of mid-single digits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're looking forward to generating the efficiencies that come out of this spend and put a dent in our structural expense base over time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And let me jump in as well, Mike, because this is something Mark and I have – we're very, very aware of.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're managing it in excruciating detail on multiple dimensions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are taking the lessons that we've got to take some of the short-term pain here in order to get us into the position we need to be in the medium term and the long term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And from the stranded costs and the divestitures we know we'll have opportunities there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We talked about at Investor Day also being in a position to simplify the management structure and take out some of the structural expenses there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So this is going to be an area of continued focus for Mark and I.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we'll make sure that not only are we managing the arc and ensuring there is one, but also that we generate the benefits from our shareholders from all of this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's something I feel exceedingly high accountability for, as does the management team.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We get it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And there are no more further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will turn the call over to Jen Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you, everyone, for joining us today.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: If you have any follow-up questions, please reach out to IR.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Enjoy the day.

speaker: Jenniferlandis
sentence: Good morning and thank you allforjoiningus.I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jenniferlandis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors, including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jenniferlandis
sentence: With that, I'llturn it overto Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, hello to everyone joining us today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, 2023 is shaping up to be another interesting year, given the tumultuous events of the last few weeks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am going to share some observations, and then we'll turn to what was a good quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First, our banking system as a whole is very strong.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While a small handful of institutions still have challenges to overcome, the U.S. financial system remains unmatched globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I feel confident saying that as someone who has worked in many different systems around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The U.S. system comprises a healthy mix of community banks, regional banks and global banks including Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We all have important but different roles to play, serving different clients with different needs and on different scales.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I would also point to the rapid response by state, federal and international regulators that helped reinforce confidence in the system at a critical juncture.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am pleased that Citi has been a source of stability for the financial system and a source of strength for our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are in a position to play this role because our strategy is delivering a simpler, more focused bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We benefit from a diversified earnings base and resilient business model.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is reinforced by our robust balance sheet management, liquidity position and strong risk management frameworks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are disciplined in how we run the firm, from client selection to capital planning.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it is also thanks to our people.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I want to express my pride in our colleagues around the world who have worked tirelessly last month to serve clients as they turned to Citi as a port in the storm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Recent events have shown that prudent asset and liability management is absolutely paramount.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While Mark is going to walk you through our approach and our focus on interest rate risk, liquidity, and capital, I do want to mention a few things.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of assets, our loans are high-quality and short-duration.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have highly-liquid investment securities and a significant amount of cash.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have over $1 trillion of available liquidity resources, including $584 billion of HQLA and an LCR of 120%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we maintain a diverse set of funding sources, including over $1.3 trillion of deposits across corporates, consumers, industries, and regions, many of which are operational in nature.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The cornerstone is our institutional deposit base, which comprises about 60% of our deposits.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Most of these deposits are particularly sticky because they sit in operating accounts that are fully integrated into how our multinational clients run their businesses around the world from their payrolls to their supply chains to their cash and liquidity management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: 80% of these deposits are with clients who use all three of our integrated services- payments & collections, liquidity management and working capital solutions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The data that we aggregate from these deposits and their related flows is fundamental to how our clients manage their efficiency, risk and compliance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This greatly increases our deposit stickiness.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that is also why nearly 80% of these deposits are from client relationships that are 15 years old or more.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, we operate a strong risk framework that looks at both asset and liability concentrations across client segment, industry, and region, and we are confident in the size and nature of our exposures given our rigorous stress testing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also diligently manage counterparty risk, which is critical given the interconnectedness of financial institutions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are in a strong position to navigate whatever environment we face which is particularly relevant given the degree of uncertainty today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Fed continues to use rate policy to battle inflation, which has been more than stubborn in services, even as we see signs of cooling in labor and manufacturing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect the recent events to be disinflationary and credit to contract.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We believe it is now more likely that the U.S. will enter into a shallow recession later this biggest unknown is the impact on terminal short-term US interest rates and, of course, how the debt ceiling plays out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Europe, the ECB is on a similar, but more difficult, quest to tame inflation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They have had some help from lower-than-expected energy prices and the outlook continues to be a bit brighter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: However, the war in Ukraine sadly shows no sign of ending and Europe faces more structural challenges such as the need for increased defense spending, higher energy costs and fiscal burdens that will make efforts to dampen inflation and stimulate growth more difficult.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Asia, the reopening of China is adding to the momentum in the region although the Chinese consumer has been slower to rebound than expected.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I saw many green shoots firsthand talking to our clients and our bankers in my various trips to India, Japan, and Hong Kong this year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have to keep a close eye on geopolitics as the US-China relationship becomes increasingly strained and is fragmenting economic blocs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see this translate into shifts in flows and heightened cross-border volume across TTS and our global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We had good revenue growth of 6% ex-divestitures and both revenue and expenses were in line with our guidance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
