sentence: Our ROTCE of nearly 11% benefitted from the closing of the sales of our consumer businesses in India and Vietnam and would have been over 9% without those gains.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let me highlight our operating performance in each of our five core businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Services, TTS continued to go from strength to strength, with revenues up 31%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Non-interest revenue was up 11% quarter-on-quarter-on the back of increased cross-border activity and good performance in commercial cards due to the rebound of corporate travel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Securities Servic 23% as we executed on new mandates, onboarded new AUC and benefitted from higher rates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Within Markets, our Fixed Income revenues were up 4% from a year ago.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We benefitted from excellent performance in Rates and continued engagement from our corporate clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The first quarter of 2022 was no slouch, as you may recall, but this quarter was our third-best in a decade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equities was weaker however - down markedly in both derivatives and cash, but still had revenues north of $1 billion.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking was down again, but there were signs of the beginning of a rebound, including increased activity in the investment grade debt market.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In US Personal Banking, our cards businesses gained momentum as all drivers continue to normalize to pre COVID levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Branded Cards and Retail Services saw revenues up 18% and 24% respectively.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Retail Banking saw some growth as we continue to see good momentum in mortgages and installment lending and also experienced a significant increase in digital deposits.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We did see a notable softening in consumer spending growth over the course of the quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Travel and entertainment continued to grow in March, but essentials were flat, and almost all other spend categories were down.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Savings rates are below historic averages.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While the upper quintiles of household income still have roughly a trillion dollars in excess savings, the savings of the lower quintiles have been significantly drawn down.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we are keeping a diligent eye on the lower FICO bands as economic growth and services spend slow.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, we remain confident about the prospects of our Wealth business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Despite the challenging headwinds, growth in Citigold accounts, client acquisition and client advisors were all solid and we expect these drivers to flow through to revenue later this year and beyond.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also saw the early signs of a long awaited Asian recovery.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We built credit reserves this quarter on the back of growth in revolving balances in cards and poorer macro outlooks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: NCLs continued to normalize in Consumer while the health of our corporate base was evident in another quarter of very low NCLs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, we continue to generate capital through our earnings.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With our CET1 ratio now at 13.4%, we have room to absorb the temporary, upfront impact should we sign a deal for Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, we continue to pursue a dual path here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are committed to increasing the amount of capital we return to our shareholders over time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you can see from slide three, in addition to good operating performance from our businesses and, despite everything else going on in the industry, we got a lot done this quarter as we implement the strategy that we shared with you at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We closed the sales of our consumer businesses in India and Vietnam.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Indonesia and Taiwan are next on the list to close later in the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our Asian consumer sales will then be complete, and we are intensifying our efforts to eliminate stranded costs and simplify our organizational structure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We made some significant leadership announcements.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am delighted that Andy Sieg will join Citi at my table as the new head of Wealth Management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy is a widely respected leader in this space and comes to us after running an $18 billion business with $2.8 trillion in client balances.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He is the latest and the most visible example of the excellent talent we have attracted over the last couple of years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With Karen Peetz retiring, we named Anand Selva as our Chief Operating Officer and asked him to take on running our enterprise-wide Transformation program in addition to his current responsibilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Anand has been at Citi for over three decades and has a strong track record of delivering results.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of our Transformation, we are completely focused on executing our plans to address the consent orders and improve our risk and control environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark will walk you through specific examples of how we are modernizing our infrastructure, simplifying processes, and improving data quality.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Importantly, these efforts will impr relentless focus on delivering.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our strategy is clear.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our business model is resilient and diversified.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our balance sheet is strong.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are making good progress on execution.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Amidst considerable turmoil, we are delivering on our guidance and our commitments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our team is determined to continue delivering with excellence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that, I would like to turn it over to Mark and then we would be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the Firmwide financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the first quarter unless I indicate otherwise, and spend a little more time on expenses, our balance sheet and capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Then I will turn to the results of each segment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 4, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the first quarter, we reported net income of approximately $4.6 billion and an EPS of $2.19 and a RoTCE of nearly 11% on $21.4 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in these results are pre-tax divestiture-related impacts of approximately $950 million, largely driven by the gain on sale of the India consumer business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding these items, EPS was $1.86 with an RoTCE of over 9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, total revenues increased by 12% on a reported basis and increased 6% excluding divestiture-related impacts as strength across Services, Fixed Income and .S Personal Banking was partially offset by declines in Investment Banking, Equity Markets and Wealth, as well as the revenue reduction from the closed exits and wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our results include expenses of $13.3 billion, an increase of 1% versus the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divesture related costs in the prior year, expenses increased by 5% largely driven by the transformation, other risk & control investments and inflation, partially offset by productivity savings and the expense reductions from the exits and wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was approximately $2.0 billion, primarily driven by the continued normalization in Card net credit losses and ACL and other provision builds of approximately $700 million, largely related to a deterioration in macroeconomic assumptions and growth in card revolving balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had nearly $20 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of approximately 2.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 5, we show an expense walk for the first quarter, with the key underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Transformation investments drove ~1% of the growth largely in the data, finance and risk and control programs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And 4% of the increase is driven by structural, largely in the form of compensation and benefits including the full-year impact of the people we hired last year as well as those we hired in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in this structural bucket are a few key items.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, other risk and control investments that are enterprise wide and in the businesses make up about 2% of the total expense increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, the impact of additional front and back-office hires.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, inflation and severance costs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of this was partially offset by productivity savings as well as the benefit from foreign exchange translation and the expense reduction from the exits and across the firm, technology-related expenses grew 12%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We recognize these investments have driven a significant increase in expenses, but they are crucial to modernize the firm, address the consent orders and position Citi for success in the years to come.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: investing in and the benefits we will see over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In many cases, these investments will simplify our processes and platforms.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For example, we are retiring and consolidating 20 cash equities platforms to one single modern platform, eliminating costs over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have consolidated 11 platforms to one global sanctions-screening platform, reducing false alerts, improving the client experience and eliminating costs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are also modernizing our infrastructure and the security of our data and information by enhancing cyber security through the use of AI and improving the security of our infrastructure and devices, leading to fewer operating losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are leveraging industry-leading cloud-based solutions to modernize and streamline the connectivity between our front office systems and the general ledger, eliminating manual processes and operating costs over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are driving the strategy by investing in the client experience both in terms of our technology interface and innovative new products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We launched our cloud-based instant payments platform for eCommerce clients in TTS.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are also deploying CitiDirect Commercial Banking, our mobile and digital interface for Commercial clients so they too can open accounts and access all products and services across ICG in the same way our Large Corporate clients do.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, we are investing in data to create advanced decision making, client targeting, and risk management capabilities which has allowed us to enhance our returns through greater RWA efficiency.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we expect many of these investments to generate efficiencies that will allow us to self-fund future investments over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: first quarter, net interest income increased by approximately $80 million, largely driven by interest-earning balances in cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were up slightly as growth in PBWM was largely offset by a decline in ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits were also up slightly, driven by growth in both PBWM and ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our net interest margin increased 2 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 8, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are well reserved for the current environment with nearly $20 billion of reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our reserves-to-funded loans ratio is approximately 2.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And within that, US Cards is 8.1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In PBWM, 44% of our lending exposures are in US cards and of that exposure, nearly 80% is to customers with FICOs of 680 or higher.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And NCL rates, while reflecting some typical seasonality this quarter, are still below pre-COVID levels and are normalizing in line with our expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The remaining 56% of our PBWM lending exposure is largely in Wealth and predominantly mortgages and margin lending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our ICG portfolio, of our total exposure, approximately 85% is investment grade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of the international exposure, approximately 90% is investment grade or exposure to multinational clients or their subsidiaries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And corporate non-accrual loans remain low at about 40 basis points of total loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you can see on the page, we break out our Commercial Real Estate lending exposures across ICG and PBWM which total $66 billion, of which 90% is investment grade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, while the macro and geopolitical environment remains uncertain, we feel very good about our asset quality, exposures and reserve levels and we continuously review and stress the portfolio under a range of scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: additional metrics to the page to provide additional transparency into how we manage the balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintain a very strong $2.5 trillion balance sheet which is funded in part by a well-diversified $1.3 trillion deposit base across regions, industries, customers and account types which is deployed into high quality, diversified assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our balance sheet is a reflection of our strategy and well diversified business model.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We leverage our unique assets and capabilities to serve corporates, financial institutions, investors, and individuals with global needs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, the majority of our deposits, $819 billion, are institutional, and span 90 countries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the majority of these institutional deposits tend to be interest rate sensitive so when rates go up, we reprice the deposits accordingly, but that reprice takes into account the overall client relationship as well as the level of rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But despite this interest rate sensitivity, these deposits tend to be stable as they are tied to the operational services we provide.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And these institutional deposits are complemented by $437 billion of US Retail consumer and global wealth deposits as you can see on the bottom right side of the page.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These deposits are well diversified across the Private Bank, Citigold, Retail and Wealth at Work as well as across regions and products, with 75% of US Citigold clients and approximately 50% of ultra-high net worth clients having been with Citi for more than 10 years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our wealth deposits tend to also be interest rate sensitive, but this usually results in our customers moving to higher-yielding investment and deposit products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to the asset side, at a high-level, you can think about our deposits being largely deployed in three asset buckets loans, investment securities and cash which complement the interest rate sensitivity and liquidity value of our liabilities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And this deployment is also linked to our strategy we use our resources to lend and transact with our clients in ways that deepen the relationship and drive returns for our shareholders while maintaining strong liquidity and capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $652 billion loan portfolio is well diversified across consumer and corporate loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the duration of the total portfolio is approximately 1.3 years as the majority of these loans are variable-rate.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About 35% of our balance sheet is in cash and investment securities which contribute to our $1 trillion of available liquidity resources.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And at the end of the quarter, we had an LCR of 120%, which means we have roughly $100 billion of HQLA in excess of the amount required by the rule to cover stressed outflows.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you can see the details of this on page 27 in the appendix.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But just as important as the quantum of liquidity is the composition and duration of that liquidity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our $513 billion investment portfolio consists largely of highly liquid US Treasury, Agency and other sovereign bonds, and is split evenly between available-for-sale and held-to maintained a short duration of less than three years so we could benefit from higher interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we actively and prudently manage our assets and liabilities by considering a range of possible stress scenarios and how they might impact interest rate risk, liquidity, and capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, in summary, our assets and liabilities are aligned across interest rate sensitivity, liquidity value and duration, and reflect the diversified business model and execution of our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 10, we show a sequential CET1 walk to provide more detail on the drivers this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Walking from the end of fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we generated $4.3 billion of net income to common which added 38 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we returned $1.0 billion in the form of common dividends, which drove a reduction of about 9 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, impact on AOCI through our AFS investment portfolio drove a 7 basis point increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, the remaining 4 basis point increase was largely driven by the RWA benefit from closing our consumer exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter with a 13.4% CET1 capital ratio, approximately 40 basis points higher than last quarter, and this includes a 100 basis point internal management buffer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as it relates to buybacks, we did not buy back any stock this quarter and we will continue to make that decision on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 11, we show the results for our Institutional Clients Group for the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 1% this quarter, largely driven by Services and Fixed income, mostly offset by Investment Banking and Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 4%, driven by transformation, other risk and control investments and volume-related expenses, partially offset by FX translation and productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a $72 million benefit, as an ACL release more than offset net credit losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of approximately $3.3 billion, up 23%, driven by the lower cost of credit and higher revenues, partially offset by higher expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: ICG delivered a 13.8% RoTCE for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And average loans were down 2% reflecting discipline around our strategy and returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits were up 3% as we continued to acquire new clients and deepen relationships with existing ones.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And sequentially, average deposits were up 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And on an end of period basis, ICG deposits were down 3% sequentially, driven by seasonality as our clients tend to make tax payments in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 12, we show revenue performance by business and the key drivers we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Treasury and Trade Solutions, revenues were up 31%, driven by 41% growth in net interest income and 13% in NIR, with growth across all client segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to see healthy underlying drivers in TTS that indicate consistently strong client activity with US Dollar Clearing Volumes up 6%, reflecting continued SWIFT share gains.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cross-border flows up 10%, outpacing global GDP growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Commercial card volumes up roughly 40%, led by spend in travel.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, while the rate environment drove about 60% of the growth this quarter, business actions drove the remaining 40%, as we continued to deepen relationships with existing clients and win new clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, client wins are up approximately 50%, across all segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These include marquee transactions where we In Securities Services, revenues grew 23% as net interest income grew 94%, driven by higher interest rates across currencies, partially offset by a 6% decrease in non-interest revenue due to the impact of market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are pleased with the execution in Securities Services as we continue to onboard assets under custody and administration from significant client wins and we feel very good about the pipeline of new deals.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, the Services businesses are central to our strategy and are two of our higher returning businesses with strong linkages across the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets revenues were down 4% as growth in Fixed Income was more than offset by Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income revenues were up 4%, relative to a very strong quarter last year, as strength in our Rates franchise was partially offset by a decline in FX and Commodities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equities revenues were down 25%, also relative to a strong quarter last year, primarily reflecting reduced client activity in Cash and Equity Derivatives.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate client flows remained strong and stable and we continued to make solid progress on our revenue-to-RWA target And finally, Banking revenues, excluding gains and losses on loan hedges, were down 21%, driven by Investment Banking, as heightened macro uncertainty and volatility continued to impact client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Having said that, we do see revenue growth sequentially largely driven by the investment grade market opening up.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So overall, while the market environment remains challenging, we feel good about the progress we are making in ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to Slide 13, we show the results for our Personal Banking & Wealth Management business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 9%, driven by net interest income growth of 10%, partially offset by a 1% decline in non interest revenue, driven by lower investment product revenues in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were also up 9%, predominantly driven by investments in transformation and other risk and control initiatives.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.6 billion, driven by higher net credit losses as we continue to see normalization in our card portfolios and a reserve build of approximately $500 million, largely driven by a deterioration in macroeconomic assumptions and card revolving balance growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 7% driven by cards, mortgages and installment lending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits decreased 3%, largely reflecting our Wealth clients putting cash to work in fixed income investments on our platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And PBWM delivered an RoTCE of 5.5%, largely driven by higher credit costs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 14, we show PBWM revenues by product as well as key business drivers and metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues were up 18%, driven by higher net interest income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to see strong underlying drivers with new account acquisitions up 17%, card spend volumes up 9% and average loans up 15%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues were up 24%, also driven by higher net interest income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For both Card portfolios, we continue to see payment rates decline, and that combined with the investments we have been making contributed to growth in interest-earning balances of 18% in Branded Cards and 11% in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues were up 3%, primarily driven by higher mortgage revenue and strong growth in personal installment lending, partially offset by the impact of the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits to our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, consistent with the strategy, we continued to leverage our retail network to drive over 13,000 Wealth referrals in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues were down 9%, driven by continued investment fee headwinds and higher deposit costs particularly in the Private Bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, we did see notable improvement in revenues in Asia which were up approximately 20% on a sequential basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Client advisors were up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are seeing net new investment inflows and strong new client acquisitions across our Wealth business, with new clients in the Private Bank and Wealth at Work up 62% and 81%, respectively.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While the environment continues to remain challenging for Wealth, we are seeing strong underlying business drivers as we execute against our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 15, we show results for Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues grew 48%, driven by a gain on the sale of our consumer business in India, partially offset by the wind-downs and closed consumer exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 24%, largely driven by the absence of a goodwill impairment we had in the prior year as well as the impact of the wind-downs and closed consumer exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 16, we show results for Corporate Other for the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased, largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased, driven by transformation and other risk and control investments, partially offset by a reduction in consulting fees.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Despite recent events and the economic uncertainty that remains, our full-year outlook for revenue and expenses remains unchanged.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have a very strong balance sheet with a diversified set of assets and funding sources with ample capital and liquidity, which positions us well to serve clients and navigate any number of scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are seeing solid momentum in the underlying drivers of the majority of our businesses and continue to execute on our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The financial path will not be linear, but we are confident we can achieve our medium-term targets in a variety of scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: help our clients navigate the recent environment and support the health of the overall banking system And with that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question Andanswer
Operator
sentence: Ourfirst question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker:
Question Andanswer
Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Hi, thank you, a simple one.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate the many, many moving parts, but your first quarter NII and revenue production was great, and if you just annualize it, you're handily ahead of your full year guide.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So I'm just curious on how you're thinking about maintaining the guide but running ahead of schedule.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thanks, Glenn, and good morning.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Appreciate the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, we did have a very solid first quarter, but as Jane mentioned in her prepared remarks, there are a number of things that are still out there in the global macro environment that are uncertain and unclear, including, frankly, as we contemplate the direction of rates and what's required to tame inflation, let alone the uncertainty that we've seen in parts of the sector here through the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so when I think about that and I think about how frankly betas have evolved and the likelihood of a recession in the back half of the year, which we have built into our outlook, I remain comfortable with the guidance that we've set here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And when you think about where that comes from, the strength in TTS, the strength in Securities Services, both benefiting from the rate hikes we saw last year, but also deepening relationships with new and existing clients, the Card momentum, which is really about seeing more revolving activity as payment rates start to slow, and the recovery in Investment Banking and Wealth is not as swift as we would like and so we have to see how that plays out too.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So when I put those things together, there's certainly some puts and takes that speaks to the diversification of our business model, but it leaves me in a place where I'm comfortable with the guidance that we've set, and if that changes, we'll certainly update you, but that's where we are.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Maybe if I could follow-up on your comments,the previous ones on TTS and Securities Services.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I try to learn from all my mistakes, I make a lot of them, but in 2008 we thought housing prices couldn't go down much, and then they went down a lot, and we all adapt.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: The same thing in March, thought deposits couldn't leave a bank so quickly, but they did.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, slide 25 and 26 people should look at because they're great and they show the stability of your deposit franchise, but I'm curious if history can change at all.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Meaning right now, those are cash and operating deposits that clients keep with you and they need you, and you're fully integrated, but do you have client concentrations we should know about or are you thinking about any big changes that can happen in terms of client behavior relative to the past in terms of what they keep at any given bank?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I know it's a tough one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Glenn, I'll kick it off and pass it over to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I feel very comfortable about how very well diversified our deposit base is across different countries, industries, clients, and currencies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's extremely strong in that respect, and as you say, the majority of the Institutional deposits are integrated into the operating accounts all around the world to enable the clients to run their day-to-day operations, the payroll, the working capital, the supplier financing, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think what's changed in the more digital world is frankly these have become even stickier because the amount of data, the extent of integration into the technology platforms and systems of the clients and the value that we extract and present back to the clients from the combination of our FX trade, cash, et cetera, flows, is incredibly important in driving their efficiency, their risk management, and their financial performance as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So both the extent of that diversification and the increasing stickiness versus history is something that we're certainly not complacent about, but I think is why you see from the pages we've put into the deck as well including in the back on just the consistency of this base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, what would you add?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that's exactly right, Jane, and Glenn, I'm glad you pointed out pages 25 and 26 which clearly lay out that diversification but also the scale and stability of those deposits over an extended period of time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add additional to that would be obviously we're in an environment where there's quantitative tightening that's occurring.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's going to have a broad industry impact as we've started to see already, but we're also in an environment where rates are increasing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'll see how that plays out through the balance of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That has an impact on betas, but we shouldn't mistake price-sensitivity or interest rate sensitivity with the stickiness of the deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we've obviously talked about betas increasing particularly in our TTS portfolio, more so in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It obviously will continue to increase outside of the US, but we'll work the relationship that we have with those clients and the breadth of services that we bring to influence and impact pricing, and more importantly, because of the operating nature of them, we do see them as very stable.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Can you talk about for the fee growth?

speaker: Operator
sentence: I mean, we kind of understand the NII growth, but the fee growth is double-digits also, so I guess that's money in motion and I think you described this as the world's largest wholesale global payments system.

speaker: Operator
sentence: What's happening to give you double-digit top line growth there?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Oh, thank you, Mike, and a great question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think one of the numbers I'm almost more happy about than the stellar revenue growth was the fee growth quarter-over-quarter here because obviously, we've been benefiting in TTS from the rates environment but we've also been benefiting from the drivers behind the franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the fee revenues are coming from multiple different products and different offerings that we have here, and we're typically looking and have consistently looked at growing our fee revenue as a percentage of the underlying growth in TTS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It got masked a bit when the rates environment was growing so much, but the different areas there around the world are making a big difference to the strength of our earnings and the quality of our earnings in these areas.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then as it relates to rates generally, what is it, like, over 90% of your rate sensitivity is outside the US, and so shouldn't you be benefiting more than you originally thought given some of these rate hikes?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I guess, Mark, are you just sandbagging a little bit?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I get the uncertainties and the IB backlog pushed out, and, no I mean, we want you to have a reasonable bar to jump over and I'm just wondering if you set the bar high enough for yourself for this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so again, I think that there is certainly more opportunity in terms of how rates move and capturing NII as you pointed out outside of the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We articulate our interest rate exposure for a parallel shift and that mix at the end of last year was the 90/10 that you mentioned for non-US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I sit here in March, it probably is going to skew a little bit less non-US and a little bit more towards the US, and you'll see that in the 10-Q.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, I mentioned earlier, there's still a bit of uncertainty in terms of how rates continue to evolve here in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'll see how betas evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've reached terminal betas in the US with our clients kind of at the end of last year, and so we'll see kind of what happens in terms of pricing through the balance of 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Betas are not quite at terminal levels outside of the US, and so we'll see the pacing of that, again, in light of how the interest rate curve may be evolving and frankly in light of how we've seen the broader sector turmoil play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That could in fact play to our benefit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we are also, again, in an environment where there's quantitative tightening that is still at play.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the final point I'd make, Mike, that often people forget is that in that NII is Legacy NII, and so as we continue with our wind-downs, our divestitures, et cetera, that's going to be a headwind that we will have to deal with.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I know during the prepared remarks you talked a bit about Andy Sieg coming on board, and I just wanted to understand how to think about the outlook for what you're doing with Wealth, not only in the US but the non-US locations, and also try to understand how much capital you think you could apply to that business relative to what you have today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Hey there Betsy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're obviously delighted that Andy is joining as our new Global Head of Wealth around my table, and he's a tremendous leader with a great track record driving growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's got deep product and digital expertise; a proven people leader and we'll certainly be taking full advantage of his expertise and experience in the US.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're not shifting our strategy in Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: His mandate is consistent with the strategy we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see a lot of potential of growth in Asia as we fill in the coverage across the full wealth spectrum there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll be scaling up in the US by building out the investment offering and cross-selling into our existing and new clients across the country.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see tremendous potential of growth in our Private Bank and the family office franchise really around the world, and there's a lot of synergies to be realized as we point out in the different KPIs and drivers between the other four core businesses in terms of referrals and other business that we're able to generate across the franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So the core of the strategy will not be changing with him coming on board.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, what else would you add in?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add is that, we are, I think, well-positioned for as the market recovers and it plays towards Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When you look at kind of the client advisors, as you know, we've been investing in bringing on new client advisors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been increasing the number of new clients that we've been onboarding as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've invested in some of the investment products that we have, and so I feel like we are positioning ourselves for when this turns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as it relates to your question regarding capital, this in a normal cycle is a very healthy returning business, and as the market turns and as we recover, we would look to deploy capital appropriate with the growth and return prospects that we see in front of us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's also not as much of a capital-intensive business as other businesses, and so I think you've got to keep both of those things in mind.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I think it's remarkable that your first two questions were essentially saying that your revenues are too conservative, so that's very notable for a Citi call.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: My first question is a follow-up to Betsy.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think everybody were certainly impressed, Jane, at the Andy Sieg hire, and clearly, he was running a much larger business than what Citi has today.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And this is sort of a tricky question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Clearly, you're still working through some of the transformation.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: There's still a consent order, but given your strength as a global player, could Citi participate in perhaps inorganic opportunities that could be out there, having a result perhaps of the liquidity crisis that we saw that could potentially enhance your Wealth Management footprint more quickly?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see plenty of potential for organic growth potential, and I think that's really where we're going to be focusing, Erika, because I look at the Private Bank and the family office, there is so much wealth creation supplemented by our Commercial Banking relationships with a lot of the enterprises and the owners of those enterprises who are really generating the new industry champions in country after country, and we're extremely well-positioned to capture that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I don't see an inorganic play that would actually help us on it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also benefit because we don't have our own proprietary products and a sales force pushing those proprietary products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're an open architecture, and therefore, we're a very desirable partner for many of our key partners on the Institutional side of the business to be able to provide very interesting value propositions, investment opportunities and the like to our clients around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And finally, we can see certainly areas in interesting digital plays, different partnerships, areas like that that are of interest.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'll never say never in the longer-run.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm sure if something very attractive comes up, we'll be very interested and looking at it, but it's not something right now that I think makes sense, given where we're focused.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Actually almost independent of the consent orders, I think what we're looking at doing right now is getting this organic play right and then we'll see from there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: 00 referralsfrom our Retail Bank to the Wealth space or to our Wealth business, and there's a lot of embedded opportunity and it really speaks to the integrated model that we've been talking about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think the other bit I'd also just point to is I think one of the things we do benefit from is that we aren't constrained by being dominated by a brokerage model in a particular way of doing Wealth, so part of the mandate for Andy and the ones that we've been working on to date is really looking at what is modern Wealth Management and making sure that we are really well-positioned that way, because I do think that will be more of the way of the future.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey, good morning.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe just a question on capital.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Appreciate the fact that the potential sale of the Mexico franchise would be a negative impact, but you're sitting at a pretty comfortable cushion now above your target.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Obviously your expected future retained earnings growth should be more than an offset, so how do we think about, how are you thinking about the timing of restarting buybacks with your stock as cheap as it is?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thanks, Jim, and good morning.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you point out, we grew capital pretty sizably this quarter, up to 13.4% from a CET1 ratio point of view and up significantly from a year ago, some 200 basis points or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And a good portion of that, a significant portion of that, was really net income earnings generation, which is important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the way we think about it is that 13.4%, we certainly have well-above what's required from a regulatory point of view and it includes our internal management buffer of about 100 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as we've said in the past, there is certainly the Mexico transaction and that would be a temporary drag to CET1 at signing, the difference between signing and closing if it were a sale to take place.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then there are a couple of other factors that are out there as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So think about the Basel III end game that's out there and the capital requirements that could come out of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Think about the CCAR DFAST that has been submitted and currently under review, and what that might mean for stress capital buffers, and also think about just where we are in the broader economy and broader global macro environment that we're playing in and needing to see how that kind of evolves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so when I think about all of those factors, we're in a place where we will continue to take it quarter-by-quarter, but I'd end by saying our bias is kind of where yours is, which is given where we're trading, all things being equal, we'd like to be buying back shares, but we have to be responsible about that and the timing of that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we'll have more clarity fairly soon around a number of the factors, so we'll be able to give you better clarity on timing before too long.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Yeah, all fair.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then maybe as a follow-up, just, you mentioned increased macro assumptions embedded in reserves.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Where are you now on the macro assumptions in the reserve book?

speaker: Markmason
sentence: So in terms of the reserve, again, remember we have a couple of different scenarios that we run when we calculate the CECL reserves.

speaker: Markmason
sentence: Our current reserves are based on those three macroeconomic scenarios.

speaker: Markmason
sentence: It reflects a 5.1% or so unemployment rate on a weighted basis over eight quarters, so that's relatively flat versus last quarter.

speaker: Markmason
sentence: The other point worth mentioning is that in this particular calculation for the quarter, we did skew a little bit more towards the downside in terms of the probability weighting than last quarter, in light of the macro environment and the combination of that as well as some normalization in the portfolio including an increase in revolver activity contributed to the increase in reserves we saw.

speaker: Markmason
sentence: But to answer your question, unemployment at about 5.1% for the weighted basis over the eight quarters.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Hey, good morning.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So I wanted to start off with a question just on the IB and trading outlook.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: On the trading side, just given some of the recent macro shocks, have you seen any evidence of bad volatility and are you still confident that you can sustain that mid-single-digit growth target?

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And just on the Investment Banking side, I wanted to see if there's any evidence of green shoots.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: It's been a challenging backdrop, as you noted, Mark, but I was hoping you could offer some color just across some of the different product lines, across M&A, ECM, DCM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Why don't I start, and then, Jane, feel free to jump in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, we saw better performance in the quarter in Markets than when I talked at the conference earlier in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And really that played through in our Fixed Income business which was up about 4% year-over-year driven largely by strength in Rates and we saw rate volatility in the back end of the quarter and we were well-positioned to take advantage of that and serve clients and that aided getting us to down 4% in aggregate across Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What we talked about for the full year is kind of relatively flat performance, and I still think that based on what we see today and subject to how the macro continues to evolve that we'll be able to deliver on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as you know, volatility in many instances plays to the favor of Markets businesses, and so there's a bit of an unknown as to how that evolves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I feel confident in the guidance that we've given thus far on that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, I'd jump in before you turn to Banking as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think one of the differences with our franchise compared to some others is that we are the go-to bank for corporates, and that provides a highly attractive but pretty steady flow of activity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is obviously in the volatile markets we've been seeing is from our perspective very good volatility because we're able to support our clients in rates, FX, commodity hedging, and it makes our risk flows much more diversified than our competitors particularly in volatile markets like this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're not taking positions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is really attractive client flow business right at the heart of the global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The other piece that I think is important in the mix here too is just the partnership with TTS, cross-border payments, these other elements and cornerstone of the FX franchise, so there's some pieces here of the volatility that one doesn't usually think of this as being so client-heavy, but that's what's differentiating on the Citi franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, back to you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: No, thank you, I think that's exactly right in terms of the corporate client base there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, in Investment Banking, obviously the wallets were down meaningfully last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We saw some good performance in debt capital markets this quarter, up 66% versus the prior quarter, particularly as we saw activity in the investment grade names, which is an area of strength for us for sure, and I think there was a bit of momentum behind a bit more clarity on the direction of rates, and so we'll see how that continues to evolve and play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other thing I'd add is that we continue to have very good dialogue with clients as they manage through the environment and try to anticipate what the balance of the year looks like, and at some point, it's clear that clients are going to need to get back into the markets, but that trajectory is going to largely depend on the geopolitical and macro environment and how we all manage and navigate that uncertainty.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So very engaged, healthy pipeline, but subject to how the environment continues to evolve.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: That's great.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And for my follow-up, just on PBWM fee income trends, I'm not going to ask you about the broader Wealth strategy, but we're big fans of Andy here, so congrats on the hire.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: The one thing I did want to get a better sense of is how much of the sequential improvement that we saw in fees is a function of just partner payments being higher as credit continues to normalize, and how we should be thinking about the trajectory in fees within PBWM over the remainder of this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think there are a couple of things to kind of keep in mind in terms of PBWM fees, and I think part of it is that PBWM is a combination of both the Cards business as well as the Wealth business, and a good amount of the pressure that we've seen in fees and that is still subject to how the environment evolves is in the Wealth space, because we continue to see fee pressure on investment activity and revenues there, and we'll have to see how the market valuations move on some of the assets that we manage on behalf of clients and what momentum it drives in terms of more investment activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I think that's a big part of the drag in fees.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The upside that we've seen in fees in Banking and Cards, again, I think will be subject to how activity and volume evolves across our Cards business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We do expect revolving levels to continue, but purchase sales while they're up year-over-year, when we look at kind of the latter months of the quarter, the growth has been slowing, and has been quite concentrated in travel and entertainment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we'll have to see how some of that volume activity evolves, and that'll be a factor to keep in mind.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala from Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Hey, good afternoon.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just a couple of quick questions.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: One, in terms of the Banamex sale, I think, Jane, you mentioned that maybe we might hear something relatively soon and you still are pursuing the dual track process.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: One, if you do decide to go the IPO route, does that change the accounting dynamics, Mark, with regards to taking that hit early on if given just the time it might take to go through an IPO.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And the outlook for the Mexican economy, the banks continue to be robust.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Is that impacting or influencing how you're thinking about the value that you should get from this transaction?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're in a very active dialogue right now in Mexico, so neither Mark nor I are going to comment in a lot of detail there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you say, we're continuing to pursue a dual path, both a sale and an IPO, so we'll have an exit strategy either way, and we'll take the path that is in the best interest of our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we've got an enormous body of work going on in Mexico to separate out the Institutional business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm pleased with the progress they're making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we're seeing, when we look at the performance of our Mexican franchise, a lot of the really strong performance is happening in our ICG business where Mexico is such a beneficiary of the supply chain dynamics that are happening around the world, and its location is obviously very beneficial given the proximity to the US as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think a lot of the dynamic and the big benefits here coming in the institutional franchise that we're keeping within Citi as a core part of our business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So the current Mexican economy doesn't really have so much of an impact on our current decision-making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The principle is we will take the path that is in the best interest of our shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, and just to put some numbers to that, for the quarter, Mexico was up 16% revenue year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Quarter-over-quarter up 5%, cards growth, deposit growth, so performing well I would say.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in terms of the latter part of your question, Jane's exactly right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Everything we're doing is positioning us for both a private sale and/or an IPO, and we'll choose the path that's best for shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: An IPO would take longer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It would likely take longer as we would want a set of full audited financials, et cetera.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would say that in terms of what the implications would be from an accounting point of view, CTA accounting is different for an IPO so we would not recognize that CTA through the P&L in an IPO.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We wouldn't have at signing that impact that is different from that closing and so that would not be an issue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The impact would be a matter of how much we IPO-ed at that time, so a lot of moving pieces there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We would need to figure out if we ended up down that path, but hopefully that gives you some sense of the scenarios there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I'd end with just one final point that Jane has made already, which is that the outcome that we choose will be the best outcome for our shareholders, our clients, and employees.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that will be an exit.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: :Hello.

speaker: Operator
sentence: You guys have talked about bending the curve on costs I think in the latter part of 2024, and I wanted to see if that's still the case.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And I guess maybe just some clarification on what bending the curve means.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Is that slowing expense growth, absolute drop, any kind of clarity on that, and costs in general kind of medium-term would be helpful.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank, Matt.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To answer your question very directly, yes, it is still the case.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are going to bend the curve, as I mentioned, towards the end of 2024.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It does mean an absolute dollar reduction in expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's helpful.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, I think in the past you've kind of insinuated that's like the start of hopefully a more material drop in costs beyond, obviously this is far away, but just any additional color there too.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, look, again, look, the expense base is a key area of focus for us, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We recognize that expenses have been growing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They've been growing because we've been investing in the franchise both transformation-wise as well as business-led growth to support the competitive advantages that we have in many of our franchises, but we're managing that very actively and very deliberately, and that means that we're looking to ensure that we're spending the money in the right way in the right places and that we're going to yield the benefits that we expect from that over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that was all factored into the targets that we set at our Investor Day for the medium-term, and what that requires is that we start bending the curve in 2024 as I stated and that we end in that medium-term at a place where we have an operating efficiency of about 60% and we're positioned to have returns that are in that 11% to 12% RoTCE point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are a couple of factors that are going to contribute to lowering that expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, the divestitures that we've been talking about, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second is the benefits from the transformation and other investments that I've just referenced.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the third is further organizational and management simplification efforts that we have underway that are enabled by the idea that we're exiting 14 consumer countries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those three factors, if you will, become very important to ensure that we get to that lower cost structure and that we're able to deliver on the broader commitments that we're making with regards to returns.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Thank you.Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: A couple questions.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Jane, maybe starting with you first, or Mark, both of you can answer it.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: In view of what the disruptions we've seen in the banking system in the month of March with what went on with the regional banks here in the US and obviously the large investment bank over in Switzerland, do you guys see changes coming, or what changes do you see coming in terms of regulatory whether it's more capital, more liquidity, and it may not be directed at a company like yours because you're a global SIFI already and it might be more regionally orientated in the United States.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And as part of this question, Jane, can you guys give us some color on the deposit you and your peers made into First Republic?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What was the thinking behind that as well?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you for the question, Gerard.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, I'd say that we hope that there will be a thoughtful and targeted approach to any changes in the regulatory and capital framework and that they address the root causes of what actually happened here, and what happened is a combination of macro impacts from the sharp, rapid rate increases and some idiosyncratic situations, namely a lack of proper asset and liability management at a small handful of banks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't see these issues as pervasive throughout the broader banking industry, but the events certainly highlight the importance of prudent asset and liability management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We still believe that there is plenty of capital amongst the large banks, and if capital requirements were to increase for the large banks by the regulators it would exacerbate any credit tightening that might go on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And related to that, what continues to keep me most awake at night is the quantity and quality of activity in the shadow banking industry.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It does not benefit from the same regulatory frameworks and protections for participants, and I, amongst others, fear that more activity getting driven into it, if the banking capital requirements increase, will be to the detriment of system strength and stability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we hope that this approach will be thoughtful and targeted to where the issues actually were.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I said in my opening comments, we thought that the regulators both at the local and national and the international level were swift and effective in making sure that they tackled the issues that were in front and we were absolutely delighted that the large banks acted as a source of strength.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And let's just step back for a minute.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the face of tremendous market uncertainty, 11 of the largest US banks were able to come together to inject $30 billion of deposits into First Republic in a little over one day, and that speaks volumes for our capital and balance sheet positions, and I think the responsibility of large institutions in recognizing that we also play an important role here in helping stabilize situations like this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We thought it was very important to help buy some time and also demonstrate our confidence in the overall US banking system.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I hope that gives you a bit of a flavor.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Very good.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then as a follow-up question, I noticed in your Card, I think it was slide 8, you give us the prime, 80% of the portfolio is prime, which is FICO scores greater than 680.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: I don't know if you would agree with this statement, but we're hearing that there was some FICO score inflation as a result of the pandemic.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: A lot of consumers saw their FICO scores go up, and I've seen numbers as high as 70 points, that may be on the high side, but can you guys, do you agree with that, and if you do, would you then expect the 700 FICO score customer at some point to behave like a 650 score customer?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the short answer is no, but let me let Mark answer that one.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think what's really important here, Gerard, is kind of what we're seeing in the way of the performance of the portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So again, I've heard that sentiment regarding FICO score inflation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We feel very confident in how we've assessed our customers and what it means to have 80% of our customers prime and greater than 680.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think importantly, what we're seeing is we're seeing payment rates start to slow.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're seeing average interest-earning balances start to increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're seeing NCL rates increase, but particularly driven by the lower FICO score customers across the portfolio which is where you would expect to start to see that drag occur, and the NCL rates that we're seeing are still well below what we would see in a normal cycle and they're in line with what we've been forecasting for performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So there are no surprises that we're seeing in terms of how that curve is evolving.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'd expect that it will get back to those normal levels towards the beginning of next year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It will likely play through those normal levels a bit before tapering.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But my point here is that we understand our customers, the portfolio, and how it reacts to the environment enough to forecast that out, and so far, that's been performing in line with that forecast and those estimates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And importantly, we continue to stress it to make sure we're not missing anything and importantly, we carry a sizable reserve, as you know, as part of that $20 billion.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'd also add that we don't just rely on FICO scores for assessing the credit of our customers and our portfolio.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's a tremendous amount of data that we draw upon that goes well, well beyond that, and that's also, as you can imagine, something that gives a lot more confidence is it's not just prior history, it's a wealth of data that is used.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Thanks for taking my questions, Mark and Jane.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Mark, I want to go to your revenue, I hear you, you're keeping the revenue guidance unchanged.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: What is in your revenue assumption, just want to unpeel that onion a little bit.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: What's in your revenue assumption for rates, US and internationally, and what is going on with deposit betas particularly following the inflows you've seen recently in the US with the crisis?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The second point I'd make is around non-US rates.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: We're assuming, I don't have specifics in front of me in terms of the rate curves around the globe, but we are assuming continued rate increases there.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Not of a significant magnitude, but some assumptions there depending on where we're talking about.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The beta assumptions that we have built in are for betas to continue to increase outside of the US, but again, they run lower than the US in general for our multinational clients.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: We expect that we will see in the PBWM Retail Banking, or the PBWM client segment space that clients are likely to move towards either higher-yielding deposit products or investment products, and so we've factored those things into how we think about the outlook.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And could that change or evolve?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Absolutely.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: But that's kind of what's behind what we've assumed here.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And just as a clarification, with the inflows you've seen recently in deposits with the crisis, this is in the US, obviously, are the betas tempering a little bit, how much those are going up?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Is that slowing down, or not any change so far?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So a couple things I mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one, we did see inflows in the quarter associated with some of the sector turmoil.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've looked at kind of deposit levels from call it March 7th, March 8th through close to the end of March, and we certainly did see an uptick, call it probably a little bit under $30 billion or so of inflows in that period of time, with a good portion of that in our CCB, our Commercial Middle-Market client base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's too soon to tell kind of how betas evolve, but we do think that a good portion of those deposits will likely be sticky.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think what's important here is that part of our strategy here is in fact growing operating deposits with our large multinational clients and our middle-market clients, and so we're going to continue to be focused on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What's a little bit unclear is how the rate environment continues to evolve and what that means for how betas actually evolve, and we'll have to kind of wait and see.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's too soon to tell as it relates to that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Hey, Mark, just a follow-up on the credit.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: So you mentioned obviously that you moved your part of your CECL adjustment a little bit in your weightings, and you had previously talked about getting towards normalized card losses, I think you'd said by around the end of the year.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: So can you just given the changes that we're seeing ahead of us and definitely saw some normalization happen this quarter, can you just, are you still on line for that getting to that 3-3.5% and 5-5.5% in the respective card businesses by around year-end this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, year-end, early next year, yes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're still kind of on track, on trend for that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, I'd expect that they pick up a little bit after that before they start tapering down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But the answer to your question, Ken, is yes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's still the timeline, fourth quarter, early 2024 reaching those normalized levels.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And then one more just follow-up.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: End-of-period deposits down 3%, you mentioned the taxes.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Are the taxes, is the tax impact felt across the business?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: When I look at the deposits page, there are a lot of ins and there are a lot of outs on an end-of-period basis, and just trying to get a sense of like what areas might have been impacted by that tax seasonality and where there was just some of the other pieces that you've already talked through in terms of inflows, outflows, and everything else in between.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, it's a good question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, again, when you look at our deposits on an average basis, you see on page 26 that they tick up a little bit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look at it on an end of period basis, they're down about 3%, and essentially, intra-quarter, particularly in March as I mentioned earlier, we did see a sizable increase in flows.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, if you remember in the fourth quarter, we saw a nice run-up in deposits, and then we have the seasonality point that I referenced in my prepared remarks where we have both operational payments from our large TTS clients as well as tax payments with our TTS clients, also with Wealth clients to some extent kind of playing through the end-of-period deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, that for the most part is normal operating payments that we'd expect to see at this time of year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So no surprises in what happened.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our last question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Just one clarification on that last answer.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You said you had intra-quarter flows.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Did you gain more deposits in the month of March, and was that in the US?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, that's what I was talking about, Mike, in terms of those flows.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They did come largely in the US in the month of March, call it March 8th through kind of the end of March.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They were overshadowed by these normal payments that I referenced, and we did, we still see good activity kind of even as we came through March and into early parts of April.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that was both in the Institutional business that we saw the inflows as well as in PBWM.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And if you define deposits this way, I mean, if I'm oversimplifying, correct me, but, look, you have 5,000 multinationals you really target for payments, Capital Markets and Banking.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Those companies have a lot of deposits, a lot of Services.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: That's the stickiness and that's where you said 80% of your clients in TTS have been with you for over 15 years.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: What if the deposits for those 5,000 multinationals, and I know I'm asking you to slice and dice in a little bit different way, but even just a general sense, because the reason I'm asking this is because I think there's a disconnect between showing percent of uninsured deposits as a measure of stickiness, and I don't think that's valid, and you've showed higher deposits even though you have a big percentage of uninsured deposits or maybe that doesn't matter as much as some front pages of newspapers are suggesting, so if you could address that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thanks, Mike.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I'd tell you to turn to page 26 in the earnings presentation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've broken down the deposits for each of the businesses that we have, and at the bottom, you see the TTS deposits, and this is where the 5,000 or so large multinational client deposits reside, and you can see the stability, as well as the steady growth in those deposits over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And to your point, these are largely operational deposits that these clients have with us, and we shouldn't mistake rate sensitivity or betas with stickiness, right, and it's because these deposits tend to be quite sticky with us, as you can see here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, they're price-sensitive in the sense that as rates go up, we often have to reprice those.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But remember, the relationships we have with these clients are broader than just deposit relationships, and that's what gives us the opportunity to adjust pricing accordingly with our deposits both in the US and outside of the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so the other page, in your own time you can look at it is the page prior to that which again speaks to the diversification of the portfolio but it also speaks to the length of time that many of these clients have been with us and have grown with us, and so nearly 80% of our deposits are from clients that have a greater than 15 year relationship with us, and that says a lot.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so anyway, those are the two points I'd make.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Hopefully that addresses your question around the stickiness.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, I often say it takes a root canal to extract us from the operations of our clients just because of exactly what we're talking about here, and that's also we see it even with the mid-market clients that are a growing portion here as well because we're helping them expand internationally, and that stickiness comes through and the LCR of 120% is a very high-quality LCR ratio.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And there are no further questions at this time.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will now turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you everyone for joining us today.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
