sentence: If you have any follow-up questions, please reach out to IR.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: - regulations of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: These statements are current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results and capital and otherfinancial condition may differ materially from those included in these statements due to a variety of factors, including the precautionary statements includedin this document and those contained in 2 Annual Report on Form 10-K.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and good morning to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Today I am going to touch on the macroeco quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While global economic performance was surprisingly desynchronized last year, the overall story has been consistent of late: one of economic resiliency supported by tight labor markets and the consumer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Growth this year looks poised to slow in many markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And conditions are generally disinflationary - you are already seeing some central banks in the emerging markets starting to cut rates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the U.S., a soft landing is viewed as increasingly likely.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we continue to see a tale of two Europes with Germany hurt by the weak demand for goods while southern European countries such as Spain and Greece benefit from stronger demand in services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Asia, although its property market remains a concern.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Amidst all these dynamics, we continue to focus on executing against our strategy and delivering the best of Citi to all our stakeholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I said 2024 will be a pivotal year for us as we put our business and organizational simplification largely behind us and we focus on two main priorities: the Transformation and the performance of our businesses and the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Last month marked the end to the organizational simplification we announced in September.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The result is a cleaner, simpler management structure that fully aligns to and facilitates our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are now more client-centric clear lines of accountability, starting with my management team, fewer layers, increased spans of control, and frankly much less bureaucracy and needless complexity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This will all help us run the company more efficiently, it will enhance our client experience, and improve more roles were ultimately impacted than the 5,000 we discussed in January.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also took a number of other steps to sharpen our business focus and improve returns by right placing strategy; and right sizing the workforce in Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As a result of all these combined steps, which include the simplification, we are eliminating approximately 7,000 positions which will generate $1.5 billion of annualized run-rate expense saves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The combination of these actions and the measures we are taking to eliminate our remaining stranded costs will drive $2 to $2.5 billion in cumulative annualized run-rate saves in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are keeping a close eye on the execution of these efforts and overall resourcing to ensure we safeguard our commitment to the Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, given its magnitude and scale, the Transformation is a multi-year effort to address issues that have spanned over two decades.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have made steady progress as we retire multiple legacy platforms, streamline end-to-end processes, and strengthen our risk and control environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: All of which are necessary, not only to meet the expectations of our regulators, but also to serve our clients more effectively.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A transformation of this magnitude is never linear.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So while we have made good progress in many areas, there are a few where we are intensifying our efforts, such as automating certain regulatory processes and the data related to regulatory reporting.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are committed to getting these right and will look to self-fund the necessary investments to do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to the quarter, we had a good start to a pivotal year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We reported net income of approximately $3.4 billion, EPS of $1.58 and an RoTCE of 7.6% on over $21 billion of revenues.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our revenues were up over 3% year-over-year, excluding divestitures, which was primarily the billion-dollar gain from the India consumer sale last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our expenses were slightly down quarter-over-quarter, excluding the FDIC special assessments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services continues to perform well and generate very attractive returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Revenue was up 8% for the quarter as both businesses won new mandates and deepened relationships with existing clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Fees were up a pleasing 10% for Services year over year, driven by the investments we have made across our product offering, platforms and client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Securities Services, we took share again this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in TTS, cross-border activity continued to outpace global GDP growth, and commercial card spend remained robust.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We look forward to diving deeper into these two businesses at our Investor Presentation on Services in June.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: impacted Rates and Currencies, that was off a very strong first quarter last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We saw good client activity in Equities and in Spread Products, where both new issuance and securitization activity were particularly robust.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We fully integrated our Financing and Securitization capabilities within our Markets business and we started to see the benefits of having a unified spread product offering for our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The rebound in Banking gained speed during the quarter, led by near-record levels of investment grade debt issuance as improved market conditions enabled issuers to pull forward activity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And after a bit of a slow start, ECM picked up in the second half of the quarter, notably in convertibles.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our strong performance in both DCM and ECM drove Investment Banking revenue growth of 35% and overall Banking revenue growth of 49%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While M&A revenues are still low across the street, I was pleased We are cautiously optimistic that we could see a measured reopening of the IPO market in the second quarter in light of improved market valuations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Corporate sentiment is quite positive, especially in the U.S., and our clients around the world have very sound balance sheets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We very much look forward to welcoming Vis Raghavan to Citi to lead our Banking franchise in early June.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Like other new top talent who have joined In Wealth, while revenues were down in the quarter, we grew fees and gathered an estimated $22 billion of net new assets over the past 12 months.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you have seen, Andy continues to form his team and is focused on three areas: first, rationalizing the expense base, second, turning on the growth engine by focusing on investment revenues, and third, enhancing our platforms and capabilities to elevate the client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now t , but getting these things right will help us get more than our fair share of the $5 trillion of assets that they need to be in this business in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: USPB had double-digit revenue growth for the sixth straight quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We feel good about our position and our resiliency as a prime, lend-centric issuer and are seeing positive momentum across proprietary card and partner card businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Healthy spend growth persists in Branded Cards, primarily driven by our more affluent customers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Across both portfolios, increased demand for credit continues to drive strong growth in interest-earning balances.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And while they are only a small part of our portfolio, we are keeping an eye on the customers in the lower FICO bands.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also continue to see strong engagement in digital payment offerings such as Citi Pay, a point-of-sale more value from our Retail Branches as well as getting the expense base right to increase returns there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our balance sheet is strong across the board, an intentional result of our high-quality assets, robust capital and liquidity positions, and rigorous risk management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the first quarter, we returned $1.5 billion in capital to our common shareholders, including $500 million through share buybacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our CET1 ratio ticked up to a preliminary 13.5% and we grew our Tangible Book Value per share to $86.67.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a great franchise around the world, with great clients who are served by great colleagues.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am simplification behind us, and a good quarter under our belt, we have started this critical year on the right foot.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While there will be bumps in the road, no doubt, we will continue to execute with discipline and we are committed to reaching our medium-term targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: o Mark and then we will both be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the firmwide financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the first quarter unless I indicate otherwise, and then spend a little more time on the businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the first quarter, we reported net income of approximately $3.4 billion, EPS of $1.58 and an RoTCE of 7.6% on $21.1 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total revenues were down 2% on a reported basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divestiture-related impacts, largely consisting of the $1 billion gain from the sale of the India consumer business in the prior year, revenues were up more than 3%, driven by growth across Banking, USPB and Services, partially offset by declines in Markets and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were $14.2 billion, up 7%, on a reported basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divestiture-related impacts and the incremental FDIC special assessment, expenses were up 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was approximately $2.4 billion, primarily driven by higher Card net credit losses, which were partially offset by ACL releases in Wealth, Banking and Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had nearly $22 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to funded loans ratio of approximately 2.8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show the expense trend over the past five quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We reported expenses of $14.2 billion, which included the incremental FDIC special assessment of roughly $250 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Also included in this number are $225 million of restructuring charges largely related to the organizational simplification.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In total, actions, we expect approximately $1.5 billion of annualized run-rate saves over the medium term related to a headcount reduction of approximately 7,000.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition to the restructuring, we took approximately $260 million of repositioning costs largely related to our efficiency efforts across the firm, including the reduction of stranded costs associated with the consumer divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The expected savings from these actions will allow us to continue to fund additional investments in the Transformation this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And relative to the prior year, the remainder of the expense growth was largely driven by inflation and volume-related expenses, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the remainder of the year, we expect a more normalized level of repositioning, which is already embedded in our guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Therefore, you can expect our quarterly expense trend to go down from here in line with our $53.5-$53.8 billion ex-FDIC expense guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show net interest income, deposits, and loans, sequential variances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the first quarter, net interest income decreased by $317 million, largely driven by Markets, which resulted in a 4 basis point decrease in net interest margin.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding Markets, net interest income was relatively flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were up $4 billion, primarily driven by Loans in Spread Products in Markets, as well as Card and Mortgage loans in US Personal Banking, partially offset by declines in Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And average deposits were up nearly $7 billion, primarily driven by Services, as we continue to grow high-quality operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This quarter, we adjusted our FICO distribution to be more aligned with industry reporting practices and now show our FICO mix using a 660 threshold.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across Branded Cards and Retail Services, approximately 85% of our card loans are to consumers with FICO scores of 660 or higher.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we remain well reserved with a reserve-to-funded loan ratio of 8.2% for our total card portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our Corporate portfolio, the majority of our exposure is investment grade, which is reflected in our low level of non-accrual loans at 0.5% of total corporate loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, our loan loss reserves incorporate a scenario-weighted average unemployment rate of approximately 5%, which includes a downside scenario unemployment rate of close to 7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As such, we feel very comfortable with the nearly $22 billion of reserves we have in the current environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: highlight the strength of our balance sheet, capital and liquidity.We maintain a very strong $2.4 trillion high-quality balance sheet, which increased 1% sequentially.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Despite this increase, we were able to decrease our risk-weighted assets reflecting our continued optimization efforts and focus on capital efficiency.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our balance sheet is a reflection of our risk appetite, strategy and diversified business model.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The foundation of our funding is a $1.3 trillion deposit base, which is well diversified across regions, industries, customers and account types.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The majority of our deposits, $812 billion, are corporate and span 90 countries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Most of our corporate deposits reside in operating accounts that are crucial to how our clients fund their daily operations around the world.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In most cases, we integrated services payments & collections, liquidity management and working capital solutions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of which greatly increase the stickiness of these deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The majority of our remaining deposits, about $423 billion, are well diversified across the Private Bank, Citigold, Retail and Wealth at Work, as well as across regions and products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to the asset side, over the last several years, we have maintained a strong risk appetite framework and have been very deliberate about how we deploy our deposits and other liabilities into high-quality assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This starts with our $675 billion loan portfolio which is well diversified across consumer and corporate loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the duration of the total portfolio is approximately 1.2 years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About one third of our balance sheet is held in cash and high-quality, short-duration investment securities that contribute to our nearly $1 trillion of available liquidity resources.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And for the quarter, we had an LCR of 117%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So to wrap it up, we are active and deliberate in the management of our balance sheet, which is reflected in our high-quality assets and strong capital and liquidity position.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 11, we show the sequential CET1 walk to provide more detail on the drivers this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we generated $3.1 billion of net income to common shareholders, which added 27 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we returned $1.5 billion in the form of common dividends and share repurchases, which drove a reduction of about 13 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, we saw an increase in our disallowed DTA, which resulted in a 10 basis point decrease.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, the remaining 6 basis point benefit was largely driven by a reduction in RWA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter with a preliminary 13.5% CET1 capital ratio, approximately 120 basis points, or over $13 billion, above our regulatory capital requirement of 12.3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, our capital requirement does not yet reflect our simplification efforts, the benefits of our Transformation or the full execution of our strategy, all of which we expect to bring down capital requirements over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So now turning to slide 12.

sentence: As Jane mentioned, this will take time but over the medium to longer-term, we view this as a greater- than-20% return business.

sentence: US Personal Banking revenues increased 10%, driven by NII growth of 8% and lower partner payments.

sentence: In Branded Cards, the NCL rate came in at 3.65%, in line with our expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Retail Services, the NCL rate of 6.32% was slightly above the high end of our guidance range for the full year and will likely remain above the range in the second quarter, reflecting historical seasonality patterns.

speaker: Mark Mason

sentence: This expectation, along with the continued mix shift from transactors to revolvers across both portfolios, led to an ACL build of approximately $340 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will continue to take mitigating actions to manage through the headwinds, lap the credit cycle, and drive more value from Retail Banking and Retail Services while improving the overall operating efficiency of the business all of which will ultimately result in a higher returning business over the medium term.

sentence: We have accomplished a lot over the past few years and have made substantial progress on simplifying our business and organizational structure.

speaker: Mark Mason

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These two priorities will not only enable us to be a more efficient, agile company, but a client-centric one that brings together the best of Citi to drive revenue growth and improve returns.

speaker: Mark Mason

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I will be happy to take your questions.

Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Well, you just finished your seventh month of your org simplification and you said 7,000 positions go away, with $1.5 billion of expense savings.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So that's very concrete, but more generally, after 20, 30, 40 years of matrix structure down to five lines of business, you're reporting these differently, you're talking about them differently, but the question that I think a lot of people have is, are you simply reporting these lines of business differently, or are you actually running them differently?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Mike, for the question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The simplification that we've just gone through, it is what we said it is.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is the most consequential set of changes, not only to the organization model that we have but how we run the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's aligned the structure with the strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's simplified the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's eliminated needless complexity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's created greater transparency into the five businesses and their performance as you can see.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's increased accountability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And very simply, it's just easier for our people to focus on our clients, but also getting things done and the execution that we have ahead of us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So maybe if I try and bring this a bit more alive, the first thing we did was we elevated the five businesses and that eliminated the ICG and PBWM layer, and we brought all the elements that the businesses needed to run end-to-end under the direct management of those five business heads, an example being operations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's enabled transparency, greater accountability, and this end-to-end and total P&L focus, so focus on the bottom line and the returns driving growth, expense discipline, etcetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also right-placed businesses to align with the strategy, so Banking all being under one umbrella, the Investment Bank, the Corporate Bank, Commercial Bank, really helping us drive synergies there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Putting F&S and Securitization into Markets, so that we have a unified spread product there, also beginning to see the benefits of that this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that's an example in the businesses, but I do want to highlight a couple of other areas around this change.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, by eliminating the regional layer and putting in a far slimmer, lighter management structure in place in the geographies, that's enabled us to make sure that our countries are focused on client delivery and legal entity management, and we've eliminated the whole shadow geographic P&L.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've eliminated a large number of committees in the geographies, and this is where a lot of the functional and management roles were streamlined and eliminated through the last seven months.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we also broke the regions into smaller, lighter clusters, and that allows us to much better capture the big changes in trade flows and financial flows, etcetera we're seeing around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's just much nimbler.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The third piece, we created the client organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that organization makes sure that our core capabilities and disciplines are being applied firm-wide to drive revenue synergies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then the governance has got a lot easier, it took up a lot of time, and we've given much clearer mandates and we've more than halved the number of committees.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's 200 committees-plus that we've eliminated in the firm, either by consolidating them or eliminating them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The spans and layers, if you exclude me, 98% of the firm now operates within eight layers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That is a much, much faster decision-making, it's much quicker to get execution done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It also means that you can very quickly get close to where the engine room of the firm is.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got clearer accountabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've eliminated most co-heads.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've reduced matrix reporting.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got the producer to non-producer ratio improved.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So all of this really means, as I've said, a clearer deck, so we can be laser-focused on business performance in those five businesses and the Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It already feels different.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Around my table, I'm much closer to the businesses and the clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It makes it much easier for Mark and I and the rest of the team to run the bank like an operator versus the head of a holding company.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You don't have to go through these aggregated layers to get things done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're done, as we said we would be at this point, we're wrapping up the final consultation periods.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Not an easy few months for the organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've had to say goodbye to some very good people.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've put a lot of change through the organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And now, as we close the chapter on this, we look forward to being back in BAU mode again, continuing to drive improvements and simplification and processes and the like, but now the focus is going to be really getting the full benefit from all the changes we've made in business and organization and moving forward.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Glenn Schorr at Evercore.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So I think it shows how much you've helped us see the simpler organization.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I think people have totally bought into the expense story, so a lot of credit to you guys.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I think where I, personally, and others still have questions on is on the revenue side and getting to those 4% to 5% medium-term targets.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, could you take us just conceptually where we're going to where you think you'll drive that growth from, from this baseline where we're at now?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And if you want, you can totally use my second question in there and tell us what good things you're doing inside the Investment Banking line.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You snuck that one in, Glenn.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'll kick off with some of this, pass it to Mark and then I'll come back to Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So look, we are laser-focused on the growth and improving the returns of these businesses to where they should and will be in the medium term, and it's not just the growth story, but let me anchor it in those medium-term return targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Services, we want to continue around the mid-20s in RoTCE.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking should be getting to around 15%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Markets 10% to 13%, so we'd like to see it at the higher end of that range.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: USPB getting that back to the mid teens and then moving on to the high-teens in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then lastly, as Andy and Mark have talked about, getting Wealth to a 15% to 20% return in the medium term, but the goal is to the mid-20s in the longer-term here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're confident that our strategy is going to drive the revenue growth of 4% to 5% CAGR in the medium term and that's a combination of maintaining our leadership in certain businesses, gaining share in others.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have good client growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look at our win rate, for example, in TTS at over 80%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got our Commercial Bank also bringing in new clients in the mid-market and helping them accelerate their growth and success around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But, Mark, let me pass it over to you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And good morning, Glenn, and we appreciate the acknowledgment around the expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, we've been quite focused on that and working hard to ensure that we deliver on what we say we're going to do there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd point on the revenue line, I'd first point to, if you look back, since Investor Day, we've in fact been able to deliver on the guidance that we've given for the medium term, so that 4% to 5% top line growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And, yes, it was a different rate environment, but that growth that we delivered over the past couple of years has been a mix of both revenue and underlying business strength.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you think about the guidance we talked about for this year, we talked about the NII ex-Markets being down modestly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so what that means is that the momentum and the growth that we expect is going to come from the non-interest revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think this quarter is a good example of where and how that's likely to play through, so the revenue top line being up 3-plus percent, but when you look through each of the businesses, and if you look on each of the pages where we disclose the revenue, you can see the underlying NIR growth in the bottom left hand corner of each of those pages, that's coming through as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So Services up 14% with growth in both TTS, between cross-border, clearing, commercial cards, but also and Securities Services, right, with the growth that we're seeing from continued momentum in assets under custody.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect that trend to continue with existing clients and new clients as well as how we do more with our commercial market commercial middle market business, excuse me.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So NIR growth there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The Investment Banking piece is the other driver of fees.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're seeing that wallet start to rebound.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're part of that rebound.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The announced transactions, we're part of those in sectors that we've been investing in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're bringing in new talent to help us realize and experience that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And even in Wealth, where we're not pleased with the top line performance this quarter of down 4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When you look through that, we do have good underlying NIR1 growth in the quarter in Wealth and that's up 11% year-over-year and it's in the area that Andy and the team is leaning in on which is investments and not just in one region, but across all the regions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then finally, the USPB piece which is showing good NIR1 growth as well, so the long and short of it is that the 4% growth that's implied in $80 billion to $81 billion is going to be continued momentum, largely in fees, helping us to deliver for our clients and make continued progress towards that medium-term target.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me pick up, I'm sure Jenn Landis will give us the evil eye for sneaking in a second question there, Glenn, but let me pick up on Banking and what's going on there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we have a very clear strategy that we've been executing over the last couple of years, really to lay the foundation for growth in Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: North America is our key priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's the biggest contributor to the global IB wallet.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Tech, healthcare and industrials are likely to constitute over 50% of the fee wallet going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we have better aligned our resources to position the franchise for this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Defending areas of traditional strength in industrials and the like, energy, whilst investing in high-growth sectors such as healthcare and technology with some strong talent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Financial sponsors are sitting on $3 trillion of estimated fire power, which they are incentivized to deploy, so they're likely to be between 20% to 30% of global Investment Banking fees.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've great relationships with this community, we've built that over years and decades.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You're going to see us more active in the LevFin space, in the right situations for our key clients, and we'll continue to ensure we're well-positioned and active around this important opportunity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll likely see us seeking to remain competitive in the private capital asset class.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's going to be an important source of liquidity for many clients and the middle market will be fertile hunting ground for corporates and private equity and our Investment Bank and Commercial Bank are going to be closely coordinated to harvest the deal flow around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And indeed, the new org structure that I was just talking about really enables us to drive a more joined-up, client-centric, strategic coverage across Corporate, Commercial and Investment Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So over and above the wallet recovery, Mark and I are going to be very laser-focused on ensuring that we're driving revenue growth from a more holistic focus on the wallet share across flow and episodic activity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Vis Raghavan is the right person to take over at this important moment for our Banking franchise, the momentum that we've been generating with the foundations we've been laying.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, the intention here from him is to accelerate that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He will focus on increasing our performance intensity, driving productivity and disciplined growth, and he will keep us firmly on the path towards delivering on our commitments, fundamentally improving the operating margin, generating high returns and that all-important fee revenue.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Betsy Graseck at Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Good morning or yes, we're almost pinging into the afternoon here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Great to hear you, Betsy.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I guess a couple of questions.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Well, so I know we talked through the Institutional Securities business already on moving that expense ratio a little bit.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Could we dig in a little bit on the Wealth side, because the expense ratio there is running a little higher, and so, it'd be useful just to understand the pace or speed or timeframe when we should expect to see that start to inflect.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And some of it, just as a reminder, the actions that we've been taking on org simplification and that Andy has also been taking in the Wealth business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will work through notice periods in the coming weeks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, you'll start you'll see the impact coming through in our head count numbers, and in Wealth, in the expense base next quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, as Mark said in his opening and Andy has been talking about, this should be a sort of up to a 30% pre-tax margin business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy is focused on rationalizing the expense base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's also, as Mark said, turning on the growth engine.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's enhancing our platforms and capabilities to elevate the client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The heart of the opportunity for us lies with our existing clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They are an extraordinary client base, but they're underpenetrated.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, a lot of the operating efficiency is frankly going to be is going to come on the revenue side here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That said, Andy's taken a number of pretty decisive moves this quarter on the expense side.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, let me toss it over to you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, look, I think that the quarter expenses that you see of growth of 3% is not yet reflective of the work that Andy has been steadfast at.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There is still some investment in there in technology and in the platform that's important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think coming out of the first quarter, you'll start to see some of the reduction in expenses that's a by-product of that work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the work has been across the entire expense base in the Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, that includes non-client-facing roles and support staff.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It includes looking at the productivity of existing bankers and advisors, and those kind of reductions will start to play out in the subsequent quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I do want to point out, as Jane mentioned, this is a growth business for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, you can see on some of the metrics on page 15 in the bottom left, some of those good signs of investment momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I highlight that because as the expenses come down from some of those efficiencies, there will be a need for us to continue to invest and replenish low-performing or low-producing bankers and advisors with resources that actually can generate the revenues we expect and take advantage of the client opportunity that's in front of us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, long-winded way of saying there's some operating efficiency upside for us for sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's a combination of the top line and the expense work playing through the balance of the quarters and the year here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Jim Mitchell at Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Jane and Mark, I very much appreciate the comments on your growth opportunities and driving growth.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: But revenues are often dictated by the macro that is a little bit out of your control.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, can you talk a little bit about the flexibility on the expenses?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You have a range in 2026 of $51 billion to $53 billion.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, if revenues are coming in below the targets, is it, I guess, A, fair to assume you'd be at the very low-end of that range or is and I think there is some revenue growth built in there.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, is there some flexibility to the downside to try to get to your targets in a tougher revenue environment?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the top line growth, as you've heard us say, is a CAGR of 4% to 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've put that target out there of $51 billion to $53 billion as a range of what we're working towards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've given you a good sense of how we expect to get there with the $2 billion to $2.5 billion reduction by then.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've already signaled $1.5 billion that's in front of us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The reality is that if there's softness in revenues, that's why we have a range, obviously, the volume-related expenses would come down with any softness in revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And depending on the drivers of why that revenue is softening, we'd look at the investments that we're making across the business and make sure that those are appropriately calibrated for where we are in the cycle and what we're seeing on the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, we've got to continue to invest in the Transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're not going to compromise that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's going to be something that we have to spend on to ensure we continue to get right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But that's kind of how the dynamic works.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's a top we've got a mix of businesses that I think we've demonstrated resiliency around if you think about the past couple of years, and we expect for those to continue to drive some top line momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we've got levers in case they don't.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Ebrahim Poonawala at Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess just one question, Mark, around capital.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: So, you talked about $13 billion over the reg minimum.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Like you could easily be doing 2x the buyback you did in one quarter, if not more.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I know you don't like to talk about out-quarters, but give us a sense of the case this quarter.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Should we expect the pace of buybacks to increase?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And if you could provide additional color as we think about the rest of the year would be greatly appreciated.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, you know and I've said it repeatedly, Jane has said it repeatedly, given where we trade, we think buying back is smart and we'd like to do as much as we possibly can and as much as makes sense in light of the uncertainty that's out there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have run at about 13.5% this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That does give us capacity above the 13.3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But it's important to keep in mind that there's client demand that will continue to evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We want to make sure we can support the clients that want to do business with us, whether that be in Markets or other parts of the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, there's still uncertainty out there about how the capital regulation evolves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The good news is we are hearing kind of favorable things about how the Basel III Endgame proposal could evolve, but that hasn't happened yet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's not finalized.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's not in place yet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we want to see how that continues to play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're obviously in the midst of a CCAR process.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We want to see how that evolves, and we'll continue to take the buyback decision on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we recognize that there's an opportunity there, and we'll get after it just as soon as it makes good sense for us.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Erika Najarian at UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please unmute your line and ask your question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, clearly, the theme of this that's emerging on the Q&A is a healthy skepticism about the revenue targets in line with the in light of the expense declines, which is not really us analysts, we're sort of a little bit parroting what we're hearing from long-only investors that haven't yet jumped into the stock.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, to that end, I guess I'm going to ask Ebrahim's question differently, and then ask a question about card late fees.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: How are you balancing clearly, your valuation would demand that the buybacks be ramped up from $500 million.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: But growing revenues at a 4% to 5% CAGR would mean potentially some capital plowed back into the business.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I guess how are you balancing that, especially given that the demand for buyback is louder at Citi than any other money center peer?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And could you give us a sense of what card late fees are and how that would impact the $80 billion to $81 billion for the year if we do get an earlier implementation than October?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the first part of the question, I'd just remind you and everyone else that we're playing for the long-term here, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we have set some medium-term targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, Jane has recasted the vision and the strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think we're making very good progress against that, but we're playing for the long-term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what that means is that we have to continue to invest in the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's why I've given you a range around the expenses, at least in part.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's why I've continued to stress the importance of protecting the Transformation and risk and control spend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it's why I started the answer to Ebrahim's question by saying that we want to be sure that we can match the client demand out there, where the returns to do so makes sense.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we are having to balance kind of the use of capital and other resources against that longer term strategic objective and utilize it where it makes sense and generates good returns against the idea of returning that to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we'll continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's an everyday assessment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's an everyday discussion with the teams.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Frankly, it's why things like the revenue sharing has been put in place to intensify the discussion around the clients that we're using balance sheet with and ensuring that we're driving broader revenues across the platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that's kind of how we're operating in terms of making that trade-off on a regular basis, in addition to obviously the broader regulatory environment that we're in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the second part of your question around late fees, we haven't disclosed kind of the dollar amount of the late fees.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I would say is that we did and have factored that into the $80 billion to $81 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the only thing I'd add to that is it did kind of it's being implemented a bit earlier than what we had assumed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, it's inside of the range of the guidance that I've given you for top line revenue for the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: s a reminder, 85% of our two card portfolios are prime, and in CRS, where you tend to see some of the lower income households, we do have that the economics of the fee change will be shared with our partners in CRS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we want our customers to pay on time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a number of mechanisms to do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But in terms of the economics, I think we, along with the rest of the industry, will be putting in mitigating actions over time, some of which we've already begun to implement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Good add, thank you.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from John McDonald at Autonomous Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, I was hoping you'd give a little more color on how you're feeling about the credit card charge-offs.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: You maintained the outlook for the year.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: You mentioned the higher end on Retail Services.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Do you still feel like you'll see a peak this year?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And what kind of metrics are you looking at in terms of delinquency formation and seasoning to inform that view that you might see the peak in card charge-offs this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have obviously continued to manage this portfolio very actively.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen continued top line growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen continued average interest-earning balance growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've talked about how we expect for the cost of credit to normalize, and we've seen that continue to happen.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The range that we've given on Branded Cards, we're inside of that range.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When you look at the spend across the portfolios, the spend is really happening with the affluent customers more so than anything else.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we're watching the lower income customer profile or customers that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, as Jane mentioned, we tend to skew to the higher end to begin with.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Where we're really seeing the pressure is where I mentioned in terms of Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, there, the current NCLs are higher than the high-end of the full year range that I've given.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But if you look back, that is not inconsistent with seasonality that we've seen in the past in that portfolio, where the first two quarters are higher than the back half of the year, in part because of coming out of the holiday season and how losses tend to mature or materialize through that process.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I'd expect to not only see them be higher than the average range in Q1, but also in Q2 before coming down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, I still expect that in 2025, you tend to see them further normalize and come down a bit off of these ranges.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But look, the reality is that we continue to watch it, and the factors that are out there that are important include how unemployment evolves, what happens with inflation, what happens with interest rates, and those will be important factors as to how the loss rates continue to evolve over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the final point I'd make and I mentioned it in the prepared remarks is that we have to remember that the loss rates in both portfolios reflect kind of multiple vintages maturing at the same time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you'll recall, and this is an industry dynamic, through the COVID pandemic period, losses were at an all-time low, payment rates at all-time highs, supported by government stimulus.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And now coming out of that, we're seeing the COVID vintages mature, albeit at a lagged pace from what would be normal, and we're seeing the incremental acquisitions that we've done start to mature at their normal pace.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, these loss rates are exacerbated by that impact and that's an important factor we can't lose sight of.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But the bottom line is that we're watching it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The macro factors matter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We feel good about the quality mix that we have, and we'll kind of see how things evolve from here.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Okay and on the Branded side, you still expect kind of the peak-ish?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Are you still inside of the range for the full year and expect 2025, you could move lower on the Branded charge-offs?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, I still kind of expect that trend line of peaking and then kind of moving a bit lower in Branded.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Ken Usdin at Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Great.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Can I follow up on the card line of thinking and just ask you, Mark, to talk a little bit about just cost of credit?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: We did still see some card related build this quarter even with the comments you just made and seasonal softer loan growth So, just from a bigger picture perspective, how do you think, continue to think about reserve builds from here and how that informs your outlook for cost of credit?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I think that when I think about the reserve builds, I think it's the same factors that come into play.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, obviously, the view on the macro is important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And right now, if you think about some of the key macro factors that impact the cards portfolio, the unemployment assumptions weighted is about 5%, the downside is about 7% kind of weighted over the period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, how that evolves will be an important factor.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: How HPI evolves would be an important consideration here for this portfolio, but also what happens with volumes becomes a factor on reserve builds and how important or how much they increase or decrease.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the final piece is mix, and it's kind of related to that revolver point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we see the mix evolve from transactors to revolvers, that's going to play into how much of a reserve from a lifetime point of view we have to continue to build.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, it's why I mentioned on John's question the importance of looking at the interest rates, looking at what's happening with inflation, watching the lower income customer base, because all of those things combined with how we think about the scenarios and the weighting will be a factor on the reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I will say, Ken, as I sit here and think about what we have in the quarter, I feel very good about the reserve levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The 8.2% for combined kind of ACL-to-loan ratio feels right for the mix of this portfolio and we'll continue to watch it.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And a separate question on TTS.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: That NII related to TTS has been remarkable with rising rates.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: This quarter, granted there was a lesser day and there could be currency stuff in there, the first quarter that it stepped back, I'm just wondering like where is that in its asset liability sensitivity, the TTS NII, and what are your thoughts about that piece of the NII puzzle going forward?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, I think I'd say a couple things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We do have kind of some Argentina playing through the NII line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I will say that the best way to think about it is kind of the underlying beta activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have seen, this is the corporate client, it is an institutional client.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have seen betas, particularly in the US, at kind of normalized or terminal levels and playing a bit through that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are seeing betas outside of the US continue to increase as it relates to the TTS client base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But all of that again is inside of the range that we've talked about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I don't expect to see kind of year-over-year growth on the NII line anywhere close to kind of what we've seen in prior years, prior quarters, just in light of kind of how the rate environment s evolved, and in light of kind of quantitative tightening and the impact on deposit levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The last point I'd make on this is, we will continue to drive and see growth as it relates to the operating deposits, and that will be an important tailwind that kind of plays through.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Vivek Juneja at JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Jane, Mark, just a question maybe on Argentina, you've shown $100 million in NII.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Total net income benefit of $500 million after-tax, so probably implying about $500 million, $600 million of non-interest income benefit.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Which line item sorry, which segment did that come through, and is that sustainable?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, look, there's a mix obviously of things that are driving that net income, including a tax impact on the heels of last year Argentina devaluation activity that's in that line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But the short answer is that if you think about the nature of the business that we do in Argentina, it is a big part of our institutional client relationships.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the primary activities include some of the TTS-type of activities that we've talked about, so liquidity management, payments, custody within the Services business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, you'd see a good portion of the activity in Argentina playing through the Services business, some of it in Markets as well, but again, the majority of the activity in Services.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Scott Siefers at Piper Sandler.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: Hey, everyone.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: Mark, I think you touched on at least a component of this a couple questions ago, but maybe just broadly an update on your rate positioning.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: I guess I only ask, because it looks like we might be starting to diverge in terms of global rate trajectories, if we potentially go lower in Europe, but higher here for a while.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: In the aggregate, do these kind of complicate your management or make you feel better or worse about the overall NII momentum for the company?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, let me try and take it in, in two pieces, I guess.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one is, if I think about how the rate implieds have evolved from the 3 to 6 to now something a little bit north of 1 in the context of what I expect for our performance, it doesn't have a material impact on the guidance that I've given of $80 billion to $81 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in part, that's because as I think about the timing for the planned cuts, which was generally back-loaded, as well as some of the other factors that play through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, you know, Argentina just announced a policy rate reduction yesterday or a couple of days ago.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If rates are a bit higher for longer, we'll watch how the betas continue to evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mentioned earlier, the late fees for the cards business happened a bit sooner.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Late fees are actually booked in our NII line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, those factors put me in a place where I feel like there will certainly be puts and takes around how that rate curve evolves, and therefore I'm very comfortable kind of leaving the guidance where it is.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To answer your broader question, in terms of kind of how we are positioned, I'd point you to the 10-K that we have that's out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in that 10-K, we offer as we have before a number of IRE scenarios for plus or minus 100 basis points and what it means for our business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And if you look at it, you'll see that for the aggregate firm, for Citi, US dollar and non-US dollar, that we're asset-sensitive.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, as rates increase, we should see an increase in our NII performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But if you look at the breakdown and that's about I think it was about $1.4 billion or something in terms of the impact of that move.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But if you look at the breakdown, what the breakdown will show is that for US dollar, at this point we're neutral.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, if rates were to go up, rates were to go down, no material impact as it relates to our revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the non-US dollar, we're still quite asset-sensitive, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that should give you some sense for and we recognize the limitations with IRE, it assumes 100 basis point parallel shift across the curve to a static balance sheet, etcetera, but that should give you some sense for the implications of the rate curve moves as it relates to our book of business.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Gerard Cassidy at RBC Capital Markets.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, can you share with us, there's been obviously a lot of conversation around the credit card charge-offs and the credit quality there.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: If we could shift over to the corporate side, which obviously is very strong, we have seen spreads narrow in the markets on high-yield corporate debt, leverage debt, etcetera.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: It's very robust out there, but around the global geopolitical risk, do you think the spreads would be widening?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you guys share with us what you're seeing on the corporate side in terms of competition?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Are underwriting standards getting a little bit weaker now as people are trying to grow their books, what are you seeing on that front?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, we're still seeing good demand for corporate credit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what I'd say is that we've been very disciplined about where we want to play on the risk profile here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been very disciplined in terms of the investment-grade large multinationals that we serve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that hasn't shifted from an underwriting point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have seen spaces like private credit pick up quite a bit, and that I think will continue to evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think importantly, as we think about our Corporate Lending activity, you'll note that actually we've been very disciplined about how we want to deploy balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And part of that again is a by-product of the revenue sharing that we've implemented, where there's been healthy debate and discussion around the names that we want to continue to serve, and whether they're positioned to take advantage of the broader platform that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I think the space will continue to evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think there's been good, healthy demand, despite continued strong balance sheets and part of that demand has been because of where rates are likely to go and continue to evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think we're well-positioned to be thoughtful about that, but Jane, you may want to add a couple points to it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, look, around the world, the corporate client base and our Commercial Banking mid market client base have very healthy balance sheets and we're also seeing market access gradually opening up as well, which is also helpful for to the quality issuers across all asset classes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing both the issuers taking advantage as well as the investors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The deals are well over-subscribed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, that's also been beneficial as corporates think about their financing needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The other piece I just pop out there as well is the recent large M&A announcements in multiple industries is a sign of rising confidence from CEOs and boards and active discussions are increasing, as supportive capital markets create confidence, as people think about larger strategic transactions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is going to feed acquisition finance, bridge financing and some of the higher-margin capital markets and lending activity as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, as we look forward, I think it's recognizing the shift in some of the drivers from company just investing, refinancing, looking at where they can diversify their capital raising in different quarters.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I'd just close by saying I couldn't agree with you more about geopolitical risks and fragility.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the market's too benign in its risk pricing on some of these factors.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Matt O'Connor at Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Operator
sentence: : Hi.

speaker: Operator
sentence: In your prepared remarks, you talked about intensifying certain efforts regarding regulatory processes and data on slide 4 here and was just wondering if you could elaborate on I guess what you're doing or trying to do differently on that front and if there's any meaningful financial impact.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, look.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think, Matt, as we've talked about many times, the Transformation is our top priority, it will be for the next few years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is foundational for our future success, both in terms of delivering the strategy and the medium-term financial path and we've been making significant investments behind it, as well as not only on the consent order, but also making sure we've got this modern efficient infrastructure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're currently deep into a very large body of work, upgrading our data architecture, automating manual controls and processes, consolidating fragmented tech platforms, and all of these help enhance our business performance more broadly, not just the risk and control in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I've said though, there are a few areas where we are intensifying our efforts, such as the automation of certain regulatory processes and data remediation, particularly related to regulatory reporting.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're committed to getting these right.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The org changes will help us with execution and making sure that we have the impetus and everything that we need behind it, the investments that we need.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We keep a close eye on execution, making sure we've got the right level of resourcing and expertise and we'll invest what we need to do to make sure that we address these different concerns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I can't go into much more detail in terms of CSI obviously, but something of this magnitude you'd expect us to have some areas where we have good progress and others where we need to intensify efforts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I mean I think that's exactly right, but you'd also expect that in this type of environment, and on the heels of the regional bank stress last year that we're looking at stress scenarios, we're enhancing our CCAR processes, we're enhancing our resolution to recovery processes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of those things just to kind of make sure that we're shoring up capabilities and you'd expect that across the industry quite frankly.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Saul Martinez at HSBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I'll change tacks a little bit here, but I'm curious if there's any update on the Mexican IPO and more specifically, I'm kind of curious how set in stone the IPO process is.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: You will have a new administration and even if it's a candidate from the same party, she may have a less confrontational view of the private sector, perhaps be more allowing of a local bank to extract value from buying a bank.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I guess if the facts on the ground were to change, would you be open to a sale potentially being back on the table, because it does seem like this is a situation where a private market valuation could be higher and even materially higher than the public market valuation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The guiding principle that we have and we've had all along is making sure that we make a decision here that is in the best interest of our shareholders and makes the most sense for them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are we never say never, but we are very focused on the IPO path here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We believe it is the right one for our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're well on track in the path in Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're very pleased to bring Ignacio Deschamps in as the Banamex Chairman to help guide the IPO process.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We announced the management teams for the two banks earlier this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're far down the path of the technological separation of both banks, and then the full legal separation in the second half of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, the election Is coming up fairly shortly, but we're not anticipating that we would be deviating from the IPO path.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That is the path that we are on at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'll never say never but we do believe that this is the right one, but we'll keep an eye on what's happening in Mexico as we always do.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Chris Kotowski at Oppenheimer.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Chris Kotowski
sentence: Just a quick one for Mark.

speaker: Chris Kotowski
sentence: Previously, you had talked about "bending the cost curve" between the third and the fourth quarter of this year, and on this call I thought I heard you say it's basically bent, that second quarter should be down and we should be sequentially lower from here, so did it just happen six months earlier or is there still some other bending that comes late this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'll take it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'll take that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I wanted that one.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean I'll take the win.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: A downward trajectory from here through the end of the year, in line with the guidance of $53.5 billion to $53.8 billion and so yes.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Steven Chubak at Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Hey, Jane.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Hey, Mark.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Did want to ask on DFAST and SCB just recognizing this will be the last opportunity before the results come out.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: The macro scenario, Fed assumptions look quite similar to last year but just given the significant transformation that's underway, repositioning actions, which admittedly depressed earnings last year, want to get a sense as to whether there are any idio-factors that could result in greater SCB volatility in the coming exam and just broader thoughts on longer-term trajectory for the SCB, just given the org simplification efforts that are underway.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, Steven the first part of your question is just impossible to answer to be candid with you, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean it's we obviously have an internal based scenario we've run.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have a severely adverse scenario that we've run.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've provided a balance sheet as part of the submission, but ultimately, the regulators have to run through their models, the information that we've provided and that informs what happens with the stress capital buffer, and we don't have as much transparency to that as we'd like and so really hard to call at this stage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second part of your question I think is spot-on and I kind of alluded to in my prepared remarks in that we have the medium-term targets that we've set and we're still in the midst of kind of the execution of our strategy, the evolution of the business mix and the business model.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The mix towards more consistent, predictable and repeatable revenue streams that would impact PPNR, the simplification which obviously plays through an expense base that'll be lower when we get to that medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So all of those things, the divestitures and kind of what that means and how that might impact the G-SIB score and the like and the freeing up of capital which we've already freed up $6 billion or so, and so all of those things have kind of yet to have been factored in and we believe will be beneficial to the SCB over the medium-term.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Mike Mayo at Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: A follow-up, Mark, you said TTS, you said we will have growth in operational deposits, and I was just wondering what gives you such confidence that you will, or is that accelerating or the same pace or what?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have seen growth in the quarter, in operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The confidence comes from the focus that we've had with our existing clients as well as the growth we've seen with new clients, doing more with existing in more countries, more deeply penetrating the commercial middle-market space, and so we've been very thoughtfully focused on deposits that obviously give us the most value and also, provide the most stickiness as it relates to that relationship and so yes, the confidence is rooted in what we're seeing in the way of underlying operating deposit growth including inside this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's also a lot of the investments that we've been making, fuel a lot of the growth we've got.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a market- leading product innovations and those continue to drive good returns, good growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If it's Citi Token Services, Citi Payment Express, 24/7 Clearing, all of these different elements really mean that this business is utterly invaluable and indispensable to our clients and the stickiness of the deposits, the operating deposits comes with that, so we feel good about that growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you'll hear more about this as well, Mike, in the Investor Day in mid-June which will be I think we hope will be very helpful to everyone so you really get your arms around how this business operates, makes money, and see why we call it a crown jewel.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question is from Vivek Juneja at JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Mark, completely different topic, because I think I understood your answer to be just from my previous question to be the tax benefits so we'll leave it at that.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: If it's different then I need to go down that path, but the question I signed on to ask was, you talked about the percentage of revolvers increasing from transactors in the private-label and the retail partner cards.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: What is that percentage and how does it compare with what it was pre-pandemic?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I don't we haven't broken down the transactor versus revolver mix, and so I'm not going to get into that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I will say that the revolver levels are at least back to where they were pre-pandemic and leave it at that, but we are seeing kind of continued revolver activity which you'd expect kind of given the way the cycle has evolved and given payment rates have started to moderate and the stimulus has kind of unwound, and so all of that is kind of consistent with expectations but obviously, is a factor in reserve levels as I mentioned earlier.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our final question is from Betsy Graseck at Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Oh, hi, thanks so much.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I just wanted to make sure of one thing on the expenses.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I know in the past you've talked about the fact that 1Q will be a little elevated with the restructuring.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And you showed that was the $225 million in the quarter, and then when we look to 2Q, we should should we still be expecting a step-down in 2Q?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And is that step-down just the elimination of the $225 million or is there some restructuring that we're likely to see in 2Q as well?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: In other words, should I just fade sequentially 2Q, 3Q, 4Q to hit your annual number or is there a bigger step-down in 2Q that I should still be expecting here?

speaker: Mark Mason
