sentence: I think you should just fade it, to answer your question very directly, but I'd also point out that in Q1, if you really look through to it, it has the $250 million of FDIC charge in it, and so when you back that out, we effectively are coming in lower than what we had guided right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Despite that I'm telling you the same I'm making the same point, which is you can expect a downward trend from here through to the end of the year and while there won't be additional restructuring charge, there will be the normal BAU activity around repositioning that plays through, so hopefully that answers your question, Betsy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The guidance still holds, and the downward trend is what we are managing towards, as we kind of play out the balance of the year.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you, all, for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: If you have any follow-up questions, please call us and we look forward to talking to you.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Footnote 1 -interest revenue)

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and a very good morning to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First, I am going to discuss our first quarter results and then talk about the environment we are operating in and how we are positioning the bank for it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This morning, we reported net income of $4.1 billion and earnings per share of $1.96 with an RoTCE of 9.1%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, it was a strong quarter, marked by continued momentum in each of our five businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We maintained a disciplined approach to our expenses, which declined by 5% year-over-year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We delivered our third consecutive quarter of positive operating leverage for each of our five lines of business and the fourth consecutive quarter for the firm overall.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We increased both our return on tangible common equity in each business and our return of capital to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This quarter is a further proof point of how the consistent execution of our strategy is improving our performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services recorded its highest first quarter revenue in a decade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: TTS continues to demonstrate momentum in the key underlying drivers across U.S. dollar clearing and cross-border activity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Securities Services gained share and grew its Assets Under Custody and Administration to $26 trillion.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Markets had a good quarter with revenue up 12%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The three most significant Fixed Income businesses – Rates, Spread Products and FX – each contributed to an overall 8% increase over last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in a good macro quarter for Equities, we were up 23% as we continued with our long-term strategy to augment our high derivatives share with a larger prime business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking was up 12%, as we continue to gain share in Investment Banking across most industry sectors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Most notably M&A revenue nearly doubled.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are seeing the benefits of our talent investments – as you can see by the leading role we played in some of the year’s biggest transactions such as advising Altair on the Siemens acquisition and on the recently announced Intra-Cellular transaction by J&J.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to Wealth, all three businesses contributed to overall growth of 24% and fee revenue drove non interest revenue growth of 16%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We remain focused on capturing assets our clients have “off” us as demonstrated by the roughly 11% organic growth in client investment assets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy and his new team are making excellent progress executing our strategy, with the business delivering record revenue this quarter and improved efficiency and returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: USPB was up 2%, driven mainly by increased loan balances and spending in Branded Cards.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The high credit quality of our cards portfolio reflects the focus we have put on prime consumers and our portfolio continued to perform in line with our expectations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, USPB’s return increased to nearly 13%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we returned $2.8 billion in capital to our shareholders including $1.75 billion of buybacks as part of our $20 billion plan, which is about $250 million more than we had originally guided.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That’s our highest quarterly amount since 2022 and demonstrates our commitment to returning capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of 13.4% and our tangible book value per share crossed $90.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to our strategic priorities, our transformation investments continue to modernize our infrastructure, simplify our processes, and reduce manual touchpoints.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we retired legacy applications and automated reconciliations to name but a few accomplishments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are also integrating AI directly into our business operations to improve the client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The latest example is “Agent Assist,” our first generative AI tool for customer service in U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is designed to help our team resolve inquiries faster and it is now being piloted in credit cards.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: From quarter to quarter, we are building on our track record of progress, and I am confident in our ability to continue delivering despite the uncertainty of the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the macro environment, I am not going to try to predict the unpredictable.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While our corporate and consumer clients are resilient and in good financial health, the world is in a wait-and-see mode and is facing a more negative macro-outlook than anyone had anticipated at the beginning of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we know that prolonged uncertainty generally hurts confidence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The changes underway globally will go beyond trade and tariffs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the U.S. for example, regulation and tax policy are all likely to look different in a year’s time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These changes will not only have economic impacts but geopolitical and cultural ones as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We appreciate the Administration taking a fresh look at regulations across all industries to unlock growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We welcome the changes being discussed in our own industry to place more focus on material financial risks and to make it easier for banks to contribute to economic growth and to improve client service.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When all is said and done, and these long-standing trade imbalances and other structural shifts are behind us, the U.S. will still be the world’s leading economy, and the dollar will remain the reserve currency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The deep knowledge and breadth of capabilities that we have from decades on the ground in so many local markets are real points of distinction when serving our clients, from reconfiguring their supply chains, to addressing their hedging and funding approaches, to advising on their strategic agendas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am very confident that we have built a strategy based on a diversified business mix that will perform in a wide variety of macro scenarios and is differentiating in times like these.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With capital strength, plentiful liquidity and strong reserves, we can navigate through any environment from a position of strength.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In periods of stress, we have shown that we are a port during the storm for our clients, the global markets, and the economy, and this time is no different.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are ready to lean in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I look forward to the rest of the year, we shall remain disciplined about returning capital and managing our expenses whilst protecting necessary investments in our businesses as well as our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we shall not allow the uncertainty to distract us from executing our strategy and improving our returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, over to Mark and then we would be happy to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the firmwide financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons unless I indicate otherwise, and then review the performance of our businesses in greater detail.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This quarter we reported net income of $4.1 billion, EPS of $1.96 and an RoTCE of 9.1% on $21.6 billion of revenues, generating positive operating leverage for the firm and in each of our five businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total revenues were up 3%, driven by growth in each of our businesses largely offset by a decline in All Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net interest income excluding Markets was up 2%, driven by USPB, Wealth and Services, largely offset by declines in All Other and Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Non-interest revenues excluding Markets were down 6%, as better results in Banking and Wealth were more than offset by declines in All Other, USPB and Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And total Markets revenues were up 12%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses of $13.4 billion, were down 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $2.7 billion, primarily consisting of net credit losses in Cards as well as a firmwide net ACL build, reflecting the uncertainty and deterioration in the macroeconomic outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Before I move on, I would like to note that certain card transaction processing fees paid primarily to networks were previously presented in operating expenses and are now presented as a contra-revenue in non-interest revenue, primarily impacting USPB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This change does not impact net income, and prior periods have been aligned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We’ve provided additional detail in the appendix of the presentation on slide 22.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show the expense trend over the past five quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we’ve said in the past, we are very focused on bringing down our expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the same time, the transformation remains our #1 priority, and we will continue to make the investments needed, specifically as it relates to data and regulatory reporting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Having said that, the drivers of our expense reduction going forward remain consistent with those that we have referenced in the past.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Savings related to stranded cost reduction, productivity from our prior investments and our organizational simplification, all of which allow us to self-fund our investments in transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we look at this quarter, expenses declined by 5%, which included a favorable FX impact.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The decline was driven by a smaller FDIC special assessment, absence of a restructuring charge and lower compensation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Partially offset by increases in technology and communications, professional fees related to transformation, as well as advertising and marketing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And looking at the rest of the year, we remain on track to meet our full year expense target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned, the firm’s cost of credit was $2.7 billion, primarily consisting of net credit losses in cards as well as a firmwide net ACL build.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The ACL build reflects uncertainty and deterioration in the macroeconomic outlook, including a further skew to the downside scenario in our CECL framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our reserves now incorporate an eight-quarter weighted average unemployment rate of 5.1%, which includes a downside scenario average unemployment rate of 6.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Largely offsetting this build was a release related to lower balances in our card portfolios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had $22.8 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of 2.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to consumer credit on the left-hand side of the page, approximately 85% of our card portfolios are to consumers with FICO scores of 660 or higher.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NCL rates increased sequentially in both card portfolios, consistent with historical seasonal patterns, and we continue to see stabilization in delinquency rates across both portfolios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our reserve to funded loan ratio in our card portfolio is 8.2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And corporate non-accrual loans remain low, reflecting the investment grade nature of our portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Based on the quality and mix of our portfolio we believe we are well-reserved, but as always, we continue to monitor the evolving macroeconomic outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 9, where I will speak to sequential variances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Citi’s $2.6 trillion balance sheet increased 9% driven by growth in trading-related assets, which is typical given the seasonal increase in Markets activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also built our cash position as we let investment securities roll off and opportunistically issued long-term debt.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Loans increased 1%, driven by Services and Markets, largely offset by lower balances in cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $1.3 trillion deposit base remains well-diversified across regions, industries, customers and account types, and increased 2%, primarily driven by Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We reported 117% average LCR and maintained $960 billion of available liquidity resources.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter with a preliminary 13.4% CET1 Capital ratio, down approximately 20 basis points, as net income was more than offset by capital distributions, RWA growth and higher DTA deductions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to feel very good about the strength and quality of our balance sheet, and our robust capital and liquidity position us well to support our clients in a range of economic environments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to the businesses on slide 10, we show the results for Services in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services revenues were up 3%, driven by growth in TTS.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NII increased 5%, driven by higher deposit spreads as well as an increase in deposit and loan balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NIR declined 4%, driven by the absence of certain episodic fees in Securities Services as well as higher revenue share and the impact of FX across both TTS and Securities Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we continue to see strength in underlying fee drivers across the business, as you can see on the bottom right-hand side of the page.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses declined 3%, largely driven by lower deposit insurance costs, severance and legal expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 6%, driven by continued demand for export agency finance as well as working capital loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits increased 2% as we continue to see growth in operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services generated positive operating leverage for the third consecutive quarter and delivered net income of $1.6 billion, and continued to deliver a high RoTCE of 26.2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 11, we show the results for Markets in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets revenues were up 12%, driven by growth across both Fixed Income and Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income revenues increased 8%, with Rates and Currencies up 9%, reflecting increased client activity and monetization.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And Spread Products and Other Fixed Income, up 7%, driven by higher client activity and loan growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equities revenues increased 23%, primarily driven by Equity Derivatives, on increased market volatility and higher client activity, and momentum in Prime Services, with Prime balances up approximately 16%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 2%, driven by higher volume and other revenue-related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $201 million, primarily related to Spread Products, driven by net credit losses and a net ACL build.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 7%, driven by financing activity in Spread Products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets generated positive operating leverage for the fourth consecutive quarter and delivered net income of $1.8 billion and an RoTCE of 14.3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 12, we show the results for Banking in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking revenues were up 12%, driven by growth in Investment Banking as well as the impact of mark-to-market on loan hedges, partially offset by a decline in Corporate Lending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking fees increased 14%, with growth in M&A partially offset by declines in DCM and ECM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: M&A was up 84%, as we gained share overall and across numerous sectors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: DCM was down 3% compared to a near-record first quarter last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And ECM was down 26%, amid a pullback in the wallet for follow-ons and convertibles.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate Lending revenues, excluding mark-to market on loan hedges, declined 1%, as increases in revenue share were more than offset by the combined impact of lower loan balances and higher recoveries in the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses declined 12%, largely driven by lower compensation, as we see the benefits of our prior actions to right-size the workforce and expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $214 million, consisting of an ACL build of $180 million, driven by changes in the macroeconomic outlook, and net credit losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking generated positive operating leverage for the fifth consecutive quarter, and delivered net income of $543 million and an RoTCE of 10.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 13, we show the results for Wealth in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues were up 24%, with growth across Citigold, the Private Bank and Wealth at Work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NII increased 30%, driven by higher deposit spreads partially offset by lower deposit balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And NIR increased 16%, primarily driven by growth in investment fee revenues, as we grew client investment assets by 16%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This includes net new investment assets of $16.5 billion in the quarter and over $56 billion in the last 12 months, representing approximately 11% organic growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were roughly flat, as the benefits of our prior actions to right-size the workforce and expense base as well as lower technology expenses were offset by higher revenue-related expenses and severance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: End-of-period client balances increased 7%, driven by higher net new investment asset flows and market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans declined 2%, as we continue to be strategic in deploying the balance sheet to support growth in client investment assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits also declined 2%, driven by a shift in deposits to higher-yielding investments on Citi’s platform and other operating outflows, largely offset by client transfers from USPB, reflecting our ability to support clients as their wealth and investment needs evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth had a pre-tax margin of 17% and generated positive operating leverage for the fourth consecutive quarter, and delivered net income of $284 million and an RoTCE of 9.4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 14, we show the results for U.S.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Personal Banking in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Personal Banking revenues were up 2%, driven by growth in Branded Cards and Retail Banking, largely offset by a decline in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues increased 9%, with interest-earning balance growth of 8% and we continue to see spend growth, which was up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues increased 17%, driven by the impact of higher deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Retail Services revenues declined 11%, primarily driven by higher partner payment accruals.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were roughly flat, due to continued productivity savings offset by higher advertising and marketing as well as legal expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.8 billion, consisting of net credit losses, partially offset by a net ACL release of $172 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This included a build related to changes in the portfolio composition and macroeconomic outlook, which was more than offset by a release due to lower card balances, largely in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Notwithstanding this release, our cards reserve to funded loan ratio increased to 8.2% from 7.9% last quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits declined 11%, driven by client transfers to Wealth that I just mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: USPB generated positive operating leverage for the tenth consecutive quarter and delivered net income of $745 million and an RoTCE of 12.9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 15, we show results for All Other on a managed basis, which includes Corporate/Other and Legacy Franchises and excludes divestiture-related items.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 39%, with declines across both Corporate/Other and Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate/Other was largely driven by lower NII as well as the impact of mark-to-market valuation changes on certain investments on NIR.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Legacy Franchises was driven by the impact of Mexican peso depreciation, expiration of TSAs in our closed exit markets and continued reduction from our wind-down markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses declined 17%, driven by a smaller FDIC special assessment, absence of a restructuring charge, reduction from exit markets and wind-downs and the impact of Mexican peso depreciation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And cost of credit was $359 million, largely driven by net credit losses of $256 million, driven by consumer loans in Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 16, I’ll briefly touch on our full year 2025 outlook, which we’ve adjusted for the impact of the card transaction processing fee presentation change that I mentioned earlier, but is otherwise unchanged.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, in January, we provided guidance for full year revenue and expenses as well as card NCLs – and that guidance was informed by a number of scenarios and assumptions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Based on what we know today, and assuming markets remain open and constructive, we still expect to deliver full year revenues of approximately $83.1 to $84.1 billion, with net interest income excluding Markets up approximately 2% to 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we expect full year expenses to be slightly lower than $53.4 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Clearly there remains a lot of uncertainty, but we are confident that our diversified business model and resilient strategy can withstand many environments, and we remain well-positioned to support our clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, while a lot is changing around us, we remain steadfast and focused on continuing to execute on our transformation and strategy while remaining disciplined with our expenses and capital with an eye towards improving returns over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, I know it's early, but I'm curious if you could help us with a refresher on Treasury and Trade Solutions and Services in general.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: In terms of what opportunities there's risk, but also opportunities in helping clients manage through this re-tariffing and redrawing of economic lines.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I think about nationalization and vertical integration as bad things, but a lot of shifting, and maybe you can help clients deal with all that shifting.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But anything any help there would be great.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Glenn, I would be delighted to do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, our diversified business mix is very well positioned for a variety of scenarios.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We think we've got a very broad suite of products and services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And they are the ones that clients need if they're going to be repositioning for a new order in trade or broader impacts here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And think about what you've seen over the last few years where we played a very central role: the Ukraine Russia war, China, the COVID-related supply chains.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We saw a lot of growth from deepening with clients and acquiring new ones because they need us, because we have exactly the expertise and the products and services that multinational institutions need, and we have them in the places that they need it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now,the mix of those different revenues, different products and services we have could be different depending on which scenario prevails.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And what I have to say at the moment, the level of engagement that we have with our clients all around the world, is just off the charts, given the unique depth of our presence and the insights we have in all the markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, if I dig down a bit more, what would the persistence of high tariffs, what would it mean?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, it would dampen economic activity here in the in the U.S. and abroad.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Cross-border trade flows will change, we'll be in the middle of facilitating that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we expect to be very busy there along with the hedging and associated financing activity that goes with it because it's not just about TTS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is about the bundle of different capabilities we bring to bear.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And take some comfort, look at what happened with the Ukraine war.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew a lot in that time period.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equally, most of our business is very local.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Think of what Services is, it's payroll, it's supplier management, it's liquidity, it's payables, it's receivables.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're very deeply embedded into our clients' day-to-day operations in every market they work in as well as across market flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that's not going to change.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not nearly as sensitive to tariffs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would say, I think all of us recognize the environment is very fluid right now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me also just say for clarity sake, at the firmwide level, our RoTCE targets for 2026 are still 10% to 11%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The drivers behind them are the same, but the revenue mix might be different.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll certainly know more as things get clearer as to how that plays out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think actually the other thing you mentioned about nationalization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Most of our clients have been clients for decades.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, a number of them have been clients for over a century.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it would not be British understatement to say that we are deeply embedded into them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, it is extraordinary how deep we are.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been on the ground for over a century, and we are viewed as quasi-local in most of these markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Citi is not a bunch of suitcase bankers that fly in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're not transactional.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're very unique in the footprint.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And these factors do make us less vulnerable to the different geopolitical dynamics that are going on.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey good morning.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe Jane, just following up on that conversation, and you talked about leaning into, as being a port in the storm and leaning into it.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, I guess in the near term, are you seeing sort of demand already in terms of your balance sheet, whether it's raising liquidity and deposit flow like sort of flight to safety deposit flows and sort of the trading aspect of it from this volatility in April, have you sort of already seen greater demand from clients?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What I'd say about the clients at the moment, you're seeing deals still happening.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've done a number of them, as we've talked about, even over this last weekend, we were pretty busy, but I would say that most clients are pausing their plans.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now no one is taking bets in the market right now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing them prep for more headwinds.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're seeing some bolstering of already strong balance sheets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Remember, our client base aren't the smaller companies in the mid-market that are going to get more pummeled in this type of environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that our clients are getting ready.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing some accelerating of imports to stockpile inventories.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are seeing a pausing on significant CapEx, while everyone waits to get clarity on the full agenda.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in that full agenda, remember, there's tax bill, there's deregulation actions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These are some positives that will be coming.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a very big agenda.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Clients appreciate it's going to take time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the trading side, what we're seeing is it is pretty orderly out there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's a lot of complicated dynamics happening, but it's not being catalyzed by liquidity crisis or other things going on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let's not fight the war, the last war.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The issue we're tackling at the moment is something different.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're seeing clients taking the opportunity to de-risk.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are, others are, so that if we have more turbulence ahead, everyone is in a stronger position for it, and that is a good thing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's early days, Jim.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got to see how this unfolds.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then maybe for Mark, I mean, you highlighted at least on a period-end basis, deposit growth and commercial loan growth looked pretty good on a period-end basis quarter-over-quarter.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, I guess when we think about the NII assumptions, deposit and loan growth looks good, but anything different given the strong start to the NII ex-Markets story and seemingly some good momentum in deposit and loan growth.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Do you feel good, better, worse on sort of your NII outlook for this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I continue to feel good about the NII outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's obviously uncertainty that Jane has referenced, but that 2% to 3% ex-Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've talked in the past about what the tailwinds and headwinds are.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you referenced, we saw some of that play through in the quarter in terms of deposit volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We saw a good operating momentum in our Services business in TTS in particular.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The loan growth saw not just in average interest-earning balances on the Branded Cards side, but also saw trade loan growth as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those are going to be important tailwinds as I think about the balance of the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've heard me reference as well, reinvestment from maturing securities in our investment portfolio into higher-yielding assets, including cash, and you can see that on the balance sheet that some of that started to take place as well in helping deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the team has been very, very engaged as it relates to deposit repricing and managing beta through the current environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the combination of those things, along with the removal of the reduction of late fees are really tailwinds that contribute to that 2% to 3% growth, and then there's some headwinds.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So lower rates on floating rate assets would be a [headwind].

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The potential of FX translation, primarily in Mexico would be a [headwind], but net-net, I feel good about the 2% to 3% growth in NII ex-Markets.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Hi, I just wanted to continue the discussion about, on one hand you’re a port in the storm.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You've been embedded decades and you're not a bunch of suitcase bankers.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So that message has landed.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: On the other hand, I mean, you are the bank that facilitates global trade in the middle of a global trade war.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And so, I think the concern is not just the possibility that that revenues will nosedive, but credit will implode or as I've heard many, many times that Citigroup is going to stub its toe, just 100 countries in the mix of it all.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: What else can you say in addition to what you said to either reassure investors that the oversight is strong or that you have your arms around the situation, the best that that you can, again, recognizing it's a fluid situation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you've seen us perform extremely well over the last few years in the face of pretty wrenching changes in the global economy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You’ve seen it with say, shifts in supply chains after COVID and then between the geopolitical tensions that are going on, you saw it in pretty significant changes that were happening from the Russia and Ukraine war.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you see us exactly as that, we are where the clients come, it's hedging for foreign exchange, interest rates, commodities, you see it for how they're looking at changing their financing around, and we tend to be the ones that are helping them reconfigure the flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, from that point of view, we are the active agent in a lot this mix.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are a port in the storm as I said, Mike, we've got very strong balance sheet, capital and liquidity to deploy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have the big strategic changes and organization changes behind us, and they're enabling us to be on the front foot.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this is a firm that is much more agile and able to respond and be much more focused on clients right now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I feel good about this.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add, I mean, Jane, you're spot on, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We come in with a strong balance sheet, strong capital, strong liquidity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you think about your point around credit, Mike, we've said repeatedly, and you can see it in the numbers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We skew towards the higher investment grade, larger multinationals who also come into this with strong balance sheets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been very disciplined about that risk framework, our risk appetite, both on the corporate side as well as it relates to our consumers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then what we tend to see in times of stress is a flight to quality as it relates to deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so again, depending on how this evolves, we're well positioned to manage whatever the needs are of our clients, whether that be lending needs or the storing of liquidity, and we're very well reserved to manage whatever credit risk may come with that despite us being skewed towards higher quality names in both of those demographics.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: The flip side of this is you did say the drivers are same.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: They might be different in magnitude to take you from where you are now you had over 9% RoTCE in the quarter.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You said you're on track to get to 10% to 11% next year.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Can you put a little meat on the bones kind of verbal waterfall chart, if you would, or maybe some numbers around org simplification stranded costs, productivity savings.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: How do we get from 9% in the first quarter to that magical double-digit return target for next year?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd just remind everyone, we're a very different bank than the one we were a few years ago in terms of our business mix, our risk profile and all the investments we've made into the business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think you can see us managing the bank doing what we say we'll do and please take some confidence in that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from the line of Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess Mark, just wanted to on Slide 9 and the capital waterfall.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess we are all thinking about what buybacks can do in the second half of this year.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: So, if you don't mind, one, the RWA sort of drag, the 32 basis points.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Is that normal as we think about what the RWA consumption should look like?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just talk about that in the context of getting to a 13.1% CET1 by the end of the year.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And how we can back into the pace of buybacks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I'd say a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one, last quarter, we announced a $20 billion share repurchase program.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we continue to feel good about that program, as you would expect.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we increased our buybacks this year, or this quarter, I should say, to the $1.75 billion, seeing the strength of the performance that was playing out through the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those are both, I think, indications of our continued commitment to returning capital to the shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're clear on where we're trading, and we're clear that, that is a smart thing to do once we've funded demand from a client point of view across our businesses, that's accretive to returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, the RWA consumption is tied to that demand that we see.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We think we've seen good client demand across the platform that's helped drive the top line momentum that you see in each and every one of our businesses that's helped to drive the improved returns that you see in the quarter in each and every one of our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we see that demand, again, accretive in returns, we'll be looking to meet that as a first priority.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are targeting the 13.1% [CET1 Capital ratio] by the end of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as you know, we'll get a new stressed capital buffer in June on the heels of the DFAST/CCAR work that's just been submitted, and we'll have to see what that tells us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's hard to forecast as you well know.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so based on what that tells us will inform that downward trajectory, but that is what we're focused on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The combination of funding growth that's accretive to returns and returning capital to shareholders in a way that's consistent with that repurchase program.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Understood.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And I guess you mentioned, I think, in your prepared remarks, the reserves on the card book went up to 8.2%.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Remind us, I mean, I think, and the genesis of both questions is I think there's a fragility to your RoTCE guidance for next year that I think makes investors nervous.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And I'm just trying to get to the pieces around buybacks?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And then in terms of credit, like how what's it baking in around the unemployment rate?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: What would cause you to ratchet up provisioning in the near term?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: What kind of an implied job market deterioration do we need to see for the credit outlook to deteriorate fast and materially?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Let me take that in a couple of different pieces.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the first thing I'd say is that as I look at our credit exposure and I look at the consumer, the consumer continues to be resilient and discerning in their spend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in fact, we did see spend hold up in the quarter, and we saw spend actually increase in our Branded Cards portfolio, up about 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The consumer has - we've seen a shift towards essentials and away from travel and entertainment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's certainly a general performance that's consistent with what we've expected when we look at delinquencies, when we look at the loss rates that played to through the quarter, there are no surprises there as we think about that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And April is performing in line with that as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And April has been consistent that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we think about reserves, we ended the quarter at about $23 billion of reserves across the entire business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's about a 2.7% reserve-to-loan ratio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When I look at the drivers of that, as you know, when we establish when we do our [CECL] analysis on a quarterly basis, we have three scenarios that we run.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: A host of other stress scenarios, but that inform the [CECL] analysis, there are three scenarios, the base case scenario, there's a downside scenario and there's an upside scenario.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we looked at the macroeconomic outlook and key variables that go into those scenarios, we assumed a deterioration in that macro-outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we increased the probability or the weighting towards the downside scenario in light of what we were seeing in the macro environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When you look through to some of the of the key variables, or one variables you referenced, unemployment, the average unemployment rate was 5.1% across those three scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The unemployment rate in the downside scenario, the average was 6.7% across those eight quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we've assumed some pretty meaningful shifts in unemployment, particularly on that downside our analysis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That informed the increase in our ACL reserves that's referenced in the deck.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that increase was offset a bit by the sequential reduction in volumes that is somewhat seasonal.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So hopefully, that helps.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We feel good about those reserves based on what we know and our current view of the macroeconomic environment, and we'll obviously do that on a quarterly basis as things continue to evolve.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of John McDonald with Truist Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Hi Mark, I wanted to ask you about capital optimization levers that you have to you've done, made some good progress in RWA mitigation.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Is there still some room to go there.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And then also, could you maybe increase the pace of DTA utilization to reduce the TCE density in a way to help the RoTCE goal.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, we're always looking at opportunities to further optimize the use of capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Markets we've talked about last year a lot about the revenue to RWA as a tool that we've been using there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's continued to increase that metric and ratio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to look at, are we optimizing balance sheet and getting the broader revenue streams we'd expect from our client base, when we do our corporate lending work and some of that is showing up in how we've now introduced the revenue sharing as a tool to ensure we're capturing broader revenues from clients when we are using balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we're constantly working through this and identifying opportunities to ensure we're getting the highest return on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, as you look through the material we provided, you'll see that in light of the improvement we've seen across all of our businesses last year as well as our forecast for growth this year, there, in fact, is a shift in the TCE.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so,the allocated TCE has gone down for many of these businesses because they have shown good PPNR growth, good profitability.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, as we stress test it internally, the stressed losses with the businesses have, in fact, come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now obviously, we have to adhere to the regulator stress test, and so that shifted from the businesses into Corporate/Other, but it is a positive sign as we think about how the stressed capital buffer might evolve and as we exit different parts of the franchise, the underlying segments are already showing that that improvement would suggest lower levels of stressed losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's another important point that we diligently manage even if we can't control the impact at the top of the house.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Your point around DTA, we continue to focus on bringing the DTA down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, that is largely driven by our ability to generate more U.S. income, which we're also very focused on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did see a pickup this quarter, which is really just a timing difference pickup.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It happens in the first quarter of every year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is tied to deferred compensation and loan loss reserves as timing difference DTA and as we earn more income through the balance of the year and obviously create income tax liability, it will utilize that increase we saw or offset that that increase we saw in the first quarter here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are targeting bringing down in 2025 and in 2026 in order to contribute optimizing capital.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: I wanted to ask Jane about the Banamex IPO planning.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Just an update on where that stands, assuming that market conditions create some risk to the timing.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Is it fair to say that there were pros and cons from the shareholder perspective to holding on to that business longer given that it's a profitable entity?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, first of all, we continue to be on track with the preparation for the IPO, John.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I was just down in Mexico last week.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the team is fully focused on driving Banamex's business performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I was very pleased to see improvements and not the underlying drivers of their performance when is down there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And they're also focused on getting the work done to be able to go public, things like the prepared audited financial statements or filling the various regulatory requirements.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we told them we want to see the business performance improving and we want to make sure that we are doing everything in our control to be in a position to IPO by the year-end.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And to the second part of your question, we will always look at what we believe to be in the best interest of our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We believe that the best interest of our shareholders is to be able to IPO this business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We think that is the right thing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It fits with Citi's strategy for all the reasons we've talked about in the past, we're the best owner of the corporate franchise we have there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are not the best owner of a domestic bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, the timing of when we IPO will be driven by market conditions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It will be driven by the timing of regulatory approvals.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that could move that from 2025 into 2026.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we will always be guided by what we think will maximize value for our shareholders.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Autonomous.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I wanted to follow up on the points you made about the consumer hanging in there through April.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And Mark, you mentioned that there could be more uncertainty as we get later.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: But I believe you're still intact with your charge-off guides for the year.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I think just noticing Retail Services was, I think, expectedly higher than high end at 6.43%.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Can you just remind us again how you're expecting the cadence of credit card losses to trajected for both Branded Cards and Retail Services as you go forward?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, we do obviously feel that we are well reserved here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did expect to see a pickup in the first half of the year before trending down in the back half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's kind of the cadence that we'd expect between now and the end of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The first half is usually seasonally higher than the back half of the year, and you see that in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would also point out that and you can see it in the deck and I think it's the second page of the appendix but also in the supplement, you are starting to see that delinquency buckets, we show the 90-day plus delinquency bucket starting to trend down in Retail Services, that is also an important indicator in terms of how we look at the expected losses, if you will, in the go forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that seasonality as well as that trend is a good sign.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've also, I think one of the pieces Gonzalo and the team have done a good job with is, they've been proactive and tightening risk and acquisitions and existing programs in the last couple of years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think that also puts us into another reason where we feel in a good position as we head into whatever lies ahead.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Very good.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And one just a follow-up on NII and your outlook.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Did you make any changes to including card fee still in the NII guide?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Is that now removed?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Does that fill in there?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I know there's a lot of puts and takes given the change in the forward curve, if you can help us understand which curve you're using and some of the balancing act there, that would be great.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, the late fee impact is, for us, is important, and we included it in the range that we had given, and we still feel good.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've now removed it, obviously, with the changes that have taken place, but we have not changed our range because there's obviously going to be puts and takes that occur.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It does have an impact on the Retail Services print that we have in the quarter and more importantly, the year-over-year that you see there of down 11% because, as you know, we share profits with those partners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that that that down 11% we see in the quarter is informed by last year where we had an assumption that the late fee rule was going to come into play and therefore, we had less profit to share with our partners versus this year first quarter where we've assumed it would not come into play and, therefore, have more profits to share with our partners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so important to point that out on Retail Services, which jumps out in USPB, that it's unlikely that we see that downward percentage in the remaining quarters because it's really a byproduct of what we assumed last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: versus this year on late fees.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the curve and the NII guidance we gave, we assumed two to three [U.S. interest rate] cuts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're now assuming a fourth but given the timing and that it would be back-loaded in the year, it doesn't have a significant impact on the NII guidance that we've given, the 2% to 3% ex-Markets.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Two questions.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Just first on the buyback.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I noticed you came in at $1.75 billion.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Is that right this quarter?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And I know you indicated that you're looking to keep pace.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And I'm wondering, does that mean at $1.75 billion or does that mean keep pace with the increased Q-on-Q, which was $250 million?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And so, I know you're laughing, just trying to understand how you're thinking about that, given what we discussed last quarter, which is you have so much opportunity here for buyback and the accretion is so powerful.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So, if you don't mind.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, we're targeting a similar level.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, we've been working to bring the CET1 [Capital ratio] down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We brought it down 20 basis points this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're still focused on bringing it down to 13.1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There is uncertainty.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The uncertainty is multifaceted.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And to some extent, you think about the uncertainty with the SCB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'll hopefully get some clarity on that as we often do in the summer, and that will inform the pace at which we bring that that down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then there's the broader market uncertainty, and we want to obviously be there to support clients, and the demand may come on the heels of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, this quarter, like I said, similar level of share repurchases.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: $20 billion program that we will continue to work through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: SCB clarity soon, hopefully, favorable clarity, and we're steadfast focused on it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane, I don't know if you want to add anything to that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We like buying back and giving capital back to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's a priority for us and will continue to be.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Excellent.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And then, Jane, just separately, on Slide 2, you identify the main priorities for 2025 and 2026, many of which we've talked about here this call.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I just wanted to understand from your perspective on the transformation, how far along do you feel you are in the modernizing your infrastructure?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And what kind of time frame do we have to go from here to check the box on that one, if you ever can check the box.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And then separately on the Commercial Banking segment, if you could just give us some insights there, too.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's a lot in there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, as you remember, the transformation is a very large body of work.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're overhauling our infrastructure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're reducing and modernizing our applications.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're simplifying our processes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, we're addressing the different root causes of what held us back, thoroughly and once and for all.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I feel good about the progress we've made.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing more and more of the benefit into how we run bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, we fell behind in data, particularly regarding regulatory reporting.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've taken action to get that into shape, and we're confident in how that's now progressing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In many parts, the risk management compliance programs, we're already operating at or close to the target state.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, our focus is now ensuring we're delivering the risk reductions and the outcomes in a sustainable way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'm excited about the work we've been doing in making sure that our technology and our overall control environment is what we call modern and simple.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're simplifying and standardizing controls across common activities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've put a lot more preventative and detective controls in place.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're upgrading others that weren't effective enough.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're driving automation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're driving straight-through processing of our end-to-end processes across the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you've heard us talk pretty consistently over the last couple of years about the work to make the technology infrastructure onto consolidating on to single platforms, retiring legacy applications.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I'd say where we are as many of the efforts are now impacting how we run the bank better and more efficiently and in a much more controlled way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's still work to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you say, I'm not sure any bank finishes its modernization because the pace of innovation is there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're still innovating and investing in supporting our businesses, with new innovations in different areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Talk briefly about AI, a lot of work in Services there, USPB and Andy in Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, there's a lot going on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think you can tell I'm pretty excited about it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm pleased where we're headed and at the pace we're heading.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I forgot to do the Commercial Bank side.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We can come back to it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Sorry, Betsy, I forgot to mention the Commercial Bank in my enthusiasm on our modernization efforts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think we are positioned to be the go-to bank for commercial clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, these are ones with cross-border needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got these unique capabilities that, particularly the born-digital clients who are then going global very quickly, they can just sit on top of our existing capabilities in Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we help them go global.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Then we help them think about their IPO or M&A or financing opportunities and the banking wallet builds on top of it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got quite a unique value proposition.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I've been very pleased to see the growth we've been seeing in acquiring new companies, who will be the future major players as they grow in global economies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this is happening in many of the big bright spots around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's in India.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's in Australia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's happening in Japan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's happening through Europe as well as in North America.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, a lot of good future growth activities there, good returns.

speaker: Operator
sentence: We will now take our next question from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Just a follow-up question here on the buyback pacing.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Your message has been pretty clear about the first half versus the second half.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: That said, with the stock at $65 versus tangible book at $90, I guess, are you just so scared from the volatility of the SCB result that, that just must be hurdle before you can accelerate the buyback?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And Mark, perhaps if you could sort of dispel some of the notion that sometimes happens in some of these chats with buy-siders about your inability to dividend from the bank sub to the holding company in order to increase your buybacks over the near term.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: If you could address that, too, that would be great.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, we have accelerated the pace of buybacks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think this quarter is a good example where I had guided for $1.5 billion, and we kicked it up to $1.75 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think you should expect that as we see opportunities to continue to do that, then we're going to do it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you should expect that given where we are trading relative to book value that we're constantly focused on those opportunities to take it up more than we had planned or more than expected.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I think we are, we have seen a lot of volatility in the SCB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're not the only ones.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Other players in the industry have as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think we're encouraged by the dialogue that we're hearing, but there is still some risk to the SCB coming in different this year versus last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think, I don't think we should lose sight.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're not losing sight of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we'll get more clarity when the SCB comes, I think that will be important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We obviously are generating good earnings quarter after quarter, which obviously creates the capacity for us to do more here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think we've evidenced a willingness to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think in terms of your other question with regard, your question implying whether there are any restrictions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We don't have any restrictions on the buybacks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We would not have announced a $20 billion buyback program if we didn't think we could execute the program in a reasonable amount of time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so obviously, we disclosed what we dividend out from the bank, and you can look at that over the last three years, we've dividend somewhere in the range of $0 to $5 billion in any given quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, there are no restrictions imposed by the FRB, which governs the parent on the ability to pay dividends and buy back stock.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition to that, we have multiple sources of funding, including loans to subsidiaries, which could be remitted as well as debt issuance programs as well as the earnings that are generated that put - we are well positioned to do, to execute on the program that we've described and to continue our desired pace of buybacks.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And just my second question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Mark, you mentioned the four cuts that's now embedded in your NII outlook, I'm guessing that's for the U.S. How should we think about how you're thinking of global rates?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Obviously, it's a basket of countries and currencies that we have to think about.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And if your top exposures are exposed to lower rates, how should we think about deposit spreads in Services from here?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think I'd say, I guess the easiest way to answer the question is to point to the IRE analysis that we show on a quarterly basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there are a lot of - that's obviously a risk measure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are a lot of limitations associated with taking it too deeply or taking it too literally, but as you know, it is a view on how lower rates could impact Citi over a 12-month period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It assumes a static balance sheet, no growth, no change in composition or mix or changes in our hedging actions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it is an instantaneous shock to the entire curve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, we do break out the impact for U.S. dollar versus non-U.S. dollar.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Remember, as you just referenced, there are over 60 currencies, but that asset sensitivity would suggest with a - in the fourth quarter - with a 100-basis point move across the currencies that the non-U.S. dollar impact would be $1 billion over a 12-month period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that take that with a grain of salt, but that gives you some sense as to the sensitivity to rates, that would assume all of those currencies and rates in those countries moved at the same time across the curve, and we did nothing to actively manage or dynamically manage the balance sheet.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: A couple of them as follow-ups to questions that have been asked.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: First one for you, Mark.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The doing buybacks of the dividending from the bank to the holding company that we just asked.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: How much are you willing to let your double leverage go up?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Is there any sort of internal limits that you follow, what would be the implications of that from a funding cost standpoint?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, we have internal limits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have management action triggers internally.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're not anywhere close to those limits or triggers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's not something that I'm worried about as it relates to the buyback program that I have and/or the buybacks that we forecasted over the balance of the year.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Jane, sharing about all turmoil and reading some new stories about mandates being shifted from U.S. broker-dealers to local players.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Jane, are you concerned about that?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Is that a shift that's starting outside the U.S. for big players like yourselves and others who are widespread globally, does this start to create stronger competitors or move some business away over time?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We haven't seen any shifts of business away from us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And just remember the nature of our business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These are many of these markets around the world we've been in for over a century.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We were the first bank in, sometimes we're the only international bank in, and we truly have a unique footprint that we are everywhere, and we're able to connect everything everywhere, and there aren’t other banks that have this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They don’t have the scale, they don't have the depth of local capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They don't have the risk management skills.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You don't have all of these different elements that the clients need now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And they need in this type of environment where things are shifting around.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's very easy to move your supply chains around on our platform, to shift the mix of different businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You're doing different geographies you're in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I said, a lot of the work we do is very local, and we're at the cutting-edge leading edge, in Services, both in TTS, custody, in particular, our corporate bankers have got very strong, deep relationships.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got balance sheet strength.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you tend to see flights to quality in these environments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when you're in the emerging markets, there is only one word for quality, and that's Citi.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, you touched on in your opening comments about the seasonal increase in trading-related assets.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then the growth was very strong.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Was there any types of strategies that you guys employed?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Because when you go back in other seasonal periods, first quarter of prior years, we've not seen this kind of growth.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: So, what led to this kind of success of growing your trading assets so well this quarter?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, it's the growth you've seen across the platform in both fixed income as well as equities and so that equities growth of 23% strong performance in derivatives in prime and prime balance growth tied to that particularly with hedge funds and asset managers as they looked at regional reallocation, strong contribution there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, rates and currencies, good increased client activity in portfolio trading.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, we saw a lot of good spread product momentum driven by higher client activity and loan growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, the nature of the activity, the structure of the products and what have you were all contributing factors there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Really strong performance across the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it obviously shows up in both the assets and the – the trading assets and the trading liabilities and the funding mechanisms associated with that.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Very good.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then as a quick follow-up, you guys gave us good details about the allocation of equity.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: I think it was Slide 23.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: I was curious, I noticed that you've lowered some.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: The total equity doesn't change, of course, but you did lower the allocation of the equity for different lines like Wealth and Banking.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What was the thinking behind lowering it in the first quarter relative to 2024?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, as you probably know, Gerard, we kind of look at this on an annual basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's a process that we run, and we run it at the end of the year with an eye towards how we want to make adjustments in the year that's following.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we looked at the performance of the business, overall, our five businesses have improved their PPNR and their profitability and therefore, improving their resiliency in stress scenarios and reducing their stress losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, as we thought about that that underlying strength we saw as well as our forecast for what demand would be through 2025, those were important factors in that allocation or that attribution to the businesses for TCE.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, in a way, they're getting the benefit of that improved resiliency even before it shows up in our Stress Capital Buffer, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, each of the businesses, we talked about Markets as a great example.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been talking about optimizing use of capital, revenue to RWA, and the improvement all last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We talked about that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you see that showed up in their performance, but also showed up therefore, in the amount of TCE allocation that they have this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So hopefully, that helps.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, regulatory capital hasn't changed in the aggregate, that's comprised of the RWA, GSIB and Stress Capital Buffers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But over time, we'd expect, as we've talked about our strategy, we'd expect exits to obviously continue to come off the balance sheet, and we'd expect our strategy and the resiliency of our PPNR and the steadiness of those earnings to ultimately show up in our Stressed Capital Buffer.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: Hi, just a follow-up on the expenses, came in a bit lower than expected 1Q even ex the accounting change.

speaker: Connor
sentence: What's your thought process for the rest of the year?

speaker: Connor
sentence: Because I'm getting at is off in 1Q the high-water mark.

speaker: Connor
sentence: So, if you trickle down a little bit from here, that would imply costs coming in a below what you're expecting.

speaker: Connor
sentence: Can you just talk about the trajectory here?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So again, I gave kind of stuck to the guidance that we had given in January.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So expenses $53.4 [billion] for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did come in at $13.4 [billion] in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I kind of went through the puts and takes around that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd expect probably a bit of a tick up in Q2 when I think about the things in front of us and some of the continued investments that we plan to make in transformation and some of the other things underneath that, like data and regulatory reporting.

speaker: Mark Mason
