sentence: And then I'd expect it to trend down so that we get to the target of the $53.4 [billion] that I referenced for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so likely see a tick up and then a trend down and landing the full year at the guidance here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, revenue moves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sorry, go ahead.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd say, obviously, if revenue moves in either direction, we'll adjust accordingly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If we have upside to revenue, you'd expect to see some of that variable in transaction costs move in that direction as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And if we see pressure on revenues, we'll be focused on ensuring that we are bringing our expenses down as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: And then just any way to frame how much cost will go up from 1Q to 2Q based on what you're thinking there?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not giving second quarter guidance kind of beyond what I've factored into the full year at this stage.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Saul Martinez with HSBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Just following up on the expenses.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Your 2026 target of a 10% to 11% RoTCE, I think you're targeting expenses being below $53 billion.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I assume with the accounting change that should recalibrate to being below, call it, $53.5 billion, is that, or $52.5 billion, sorry.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Is that a fair assumption or a conclusion from that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: $52.6 [billion].

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I was just rounding down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But yes, I mean it's a change in line-item terms of that association fee.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And sure, I targeted 2026 as less than $53 [billion].

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that $400 million, you sure you can deduct that from the $53 [billion].

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Just wanted to clarify that.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And then I guess, secondly, on wealth management.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: The net new assets are pretty impressive then they trend, $16.5 billion, I think, something like 11% of beginning period of client assets over the last couple of quarters.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: So, it seems like Andy is really delivering there.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Just anything in strength across the different products, but anything you want to highlight there as to what's driving that?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And any comments just on the durability of that kind of momentum?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, the strategy that Andy has laid out and talked about is working.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got the franchise very focused around net new investment assets, bringing those in from the $5 trillion of assets that are off us with existing clients, as well as new wealth that that is being created and new clients we're bringing to the franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, I'm very pleased as well with the caliber of the team that he has brought to bear here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got real horsepower and firepower in our investment capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And he is also investing to improve client experience, a new relationship with Palantir here as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's a team that's on the front foot.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in this environment, around the world, clients are really looking to us for advice because there are not many global wealth managers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They're looking to us for a global perspective, the capabilities we've got on the ground all around the globe and helping put them into good position amidst the uncertainty.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we are a destination of choice right now, and we're taking full advantage of it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I don't see that changing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is the strength of Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The strategy is working.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Liz, and good morning to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm delighted to join you again today and first, I'm going to discuss the results of my first full quarter as CEO and then update you on the progress against our strategic priorities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: For the quarter, we reported $6.2 billion in net income or $2.85 per share.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to benefit from an improving macro environment as evidenced by another significant release of our allowances for credit losses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Indeed, the pace of the macro recovery is exceeding earlier expectations across the globe and with it comes growing consumer and corporate confidence, and this also came through loud and clear in my conversations with clients over the course of the week I just spent in London.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, clearly, we have to remain mindful of the unevenness in that global recovery due to continued contagion and challenges in vaccine distribution in several parts of the world, but we are optimistic about the momentum ahead and as a result, we deliberately accelerated some of our investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In our Institutional businesses, we saw the expected normalization of fixed income trading compared to the striking volatility of Q2 last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And our Equities franchise had a particularly strong quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Looking forward, we do expect the volatile markets to be higher than pre-COVID levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Performance in our Investment Banking franchise remained healthy with good momentum in M&A and a very solid pipeline ahead for the rest of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We saw very good progress in our strategies to increase fee revenues with double-digit growth in our ICG fee revenues and specifically over 20% year-over-year fee growth in Treasury and Trade Solutions, in Securities Services and in the Private Bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, TTS is the backbone of the unique global network we deliver for our clients and while the business continues to be impacted by low rates, we particularly like how we are positioned here from a market share perspective as the post-pandemic recovery takes shape.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Consumer Banking, while our loan book and revenues were impacted by the elevated payment rates in Cards, spending is well above pre-COVID levels now with a 38% increase in global purchase sales year over-year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect this to translate into loan growth in the second half of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we continue to have good momentum in both deposit growth and AUMs across our Consumer franchises.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the US, as we discussed, we're investing in our home market as demonstrated by the well-received launch of our innovative Custom Cash Card in June.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Internationally, the picture for our Consumer businesses diverges.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So while there is still the softness in the Mexican economy, in Asia, loan growth returned and that's despite new COVID outbreaks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to capital, for the first two quarters of 2021, we returned close to $7 billion to our shareholders, which was the maximum amount permitted under the Federal Reserve's rules.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Going forward, we're committed to returning any excess capital over and above the amount necessary to invest in our franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, while our stress capital buffer increased to 3% as a result of the Fed's recent stress test, that won't impact the Common Equity Tier 1 target we've been managing to of approximately 11.5%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We ended the quarter at 11.9% on a standardized basis and have excess capital to return to our shareholders through a healthy dividend and ongoing stock repurchase program.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Lastly, our tangible book value per share increased to $77.87, up over 9% from a year ago.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, let's turn to three of our strategic priorities: strategy, transformation and talent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm very pleased with the progress we've made on our strategy refresh.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have moved swiftly to begin the sales process for the 13 Consumer markets we plan to exit in Asia and EMEA.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The first round of this was very encouraging and competitive, which isn't a surprise, because these are terrific businesses for the right owners.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In those regions, we're off to a running start in our Wealth strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're making significant strategic investments in product capabilities, technology and talent and have already seen this in increased client acquisition.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to do thorough and rigorous work to refresh our strategy across our Consumer Institutional businesses, guided by the four principles I outlined to you earlier in the year: being clinical, being focused, and ensuring both connectivity and simplification.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our overarching goal is to increase the returns we generate and close the gap with our peers by investing in the franchises that will drive the most growth – the three most notable of which are TTS, Wealth and Commercial Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'm very confident in the growth and return prospects these connected franchises will afford us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we have done so far, we will share our decisions with you as we make them on the strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are also looking forward to presenting our plans to you more comprehensively during an Investor Day, which we intend to hold in the first quarter of next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're going to put our entire vision for the firm in front of you, so you can then hold us accountable for executing against it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we discussed in the call last quarter, we're also working very hard and diligently on our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is a significant, it's also an exciting body of work and we're working closely with our regulators to meet their expectations and we intend to submit our plans to them this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, while addressing the consent orders is an intense focus of the transformation, our work here goes well beyond the orders themselves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've set out to modernize our bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We want to achieve nothing less than excellence and this means investing in our risk and control environment but also in the infrastructure we need to serve our clients in an increasingly digital world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me give you an example in TTS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These investments will improve the scalability of our platform.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Automation will drive efficiency and client experience, and investments in data will enhance revenues.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the investments we're making will help position us to retain our leading position as the preeminent global corporate bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that leads me finally to talent, where we have made material progress over the last few months.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm delighted with the caliber of talent we have been attracting to the firm to grow our businesses and support our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've enhanced our existing ranks with best-in-market hires in data, risk, strategy and controls as well as in the front lines of Wealth, the Commercial Bank and BCMA in particular.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to invest in a culture of excellence and our own people, providing them with new leadership and growth opportunities, and it's this combination of new perspectives and our existing high caliber talent pool that will enable us to take the firm forward with excellence, urgency and accountability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, before I turn it over to Mark, I would like to thank Liz Lynn for her great work leading our investor relation efforts over the past several years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you know and as she mentioned, she is going to be our finance lead for BCMA where we all know that she is going to do a wonderful job.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that, Mark will go through our presentation and then we'll both be happy to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Starting on slide 3, Citigroup reported second quarter net income of $6.2 billion, EPS of $2.85, and a 15.2% RoTCE.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 12% from the prior year, reflecting a normalization in Fixed Income Markets along with lower card loans in Consumer as well as the impact of lower interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 7% year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In constant dollars, expenses were up 4%, reflecting a normalization relative to the low print last year, along with continued investments in our transformation as well as other strategic investments, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit performance remained strong with net credit losses of $1.3 billion, more than offset by an ACL release of $2.4 billion, reflecting portfolio improvements as well as the continued improvement in our macroeconomic outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In constant dollars, end of period loans declined 3% year-over-year, reflecting higher repayment rates across Institutional and Consumer, although I would note that we are starting to see some pockets of loan growth emerge, and for the first time in over a year, loans were up sequentially.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Deposits grew modestly, up 4% year-over-year, reflecting continued engagement with our Consumer and Corporate clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking at the first half of 2021, total revenues declined 9% year-over-year and 10% in constant dollars, mainly driven by the normalization in Fixed Income Markets and lower card balances in Consumer, although we did see strong fee revenue growth across Consumer and in ICG, excluding Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total expenses were up 6% on a reported basis and 3% in constant dollars, midway through the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'll talk more about our outlook for the remainder of the year in a moment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a benefit of roughly $3 billion as we released over $6 billion in reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we delivered roughly $14 billion in net income and an RoTCE of 17.6%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, as Jane noted earlier, we returned roughly $7 billion in capital so far this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we remain committed to continuing to invest in our franchise as well as returning any excess capital to shareholders given the flexibility provided by the SCB framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning now to each business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 4 shows the results for the Institutional Clients Group.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the quarter, ICG delivered EBT of $4.9 billion, up significantly from last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues decreased 14%, driven mainly by the decline in Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 4% and were up 2% in constant dollars as investments in transformation along with other strategic investments were mostly offset by lower incentive compensation and efficiency savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit costs were down considerably given a roughly $900 million ACL release as well as lower net credit losses, and ICG delivered a 16.4% return on allocated capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 5 shows revenues for the Institutional Clients Group in more detail.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Product revenues were down 17% in the second quarter, primarily reflecting a comparison to a strong prior year period, particularly in Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, we are continuing to see robust client engagement and strong underlying growth in our fee businesses across the franchise, including TTS, Investment Banking, Securities Services, Commercial Banking and the Private Bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And excluding the markets related component, non-interest revenues were up 24% this quarter and we are confident in our outlook for continued strong fee growth in the back half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking at the results in greater detail, on the Banking side, revenues decreased 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Treasury and Trade Solutions, significant growth in fee revenues of roughly 25% reflecting solid client engagement as well as growth in trade were more than offset by the impact of lower interest rates, with revenues down 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're continuing to see momentum across our Payments business with 13% growth in cross-border flows and 10% growth in clearing volumes over the past year, as well as the early days of a recovery in Commercial Cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as of the end of the quarter, TTS loans grew roughly 5%, reflecting increasing client demand and improving macroeconomic conditions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking revenues were up 1% as higher M&A and equity underwriting revenues were largely offset by a decline in debt underwriting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While the overall DCM wallet was up in the second quarter, all the growth was in non-investment grade, which did not benefit our results given our skew to investment grade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But looking at results versus a more normal year, revenues were up 38% versus the second quarter of 2019 with strong growth across all products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Private Bank revenues grew 4% driven by higher fees and lending volumes, reflecting momentum with both new and existing clients, partially offset by the impact of lower interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate Lending revenues were down 15%, primarily driven by lower volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total Markets and Securities Services revenues decreased 30% from last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income revenues decreased 43%, reflecting a comparison to a strong prior year period in both rates and spread products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, we remained engaged with our clients with steady growth in both corporate and investor client revenues relative to the historical average.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equities revenues were up 37% versus last year, primarily driven by good performance in both derivatives and prime finance, reflecting robust client activity and favorable market conditions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Securities Services, revenues were up 9% on a reported basis and 5% in constant dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Here we saw a strong growth in fee revenues with both new and existing clients, driven by growth in assets under custody and settlement volumes, partially offset by lower spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, looking at first half results in ICG, we've seen a strong contribution from Investment Banking as well as good results in the Private Bank and Securities Services, which helped to offset the expected normalization in Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would also note that Equity Markets revenues are up over 30%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning now to the results for Global Consumer Banking in constant dollars on slide 6.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the quarter, GCB delivered EBT of $2.4 billion, up significantly from last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 10% as continued strong deposit growth, albeit with lower spreads and momentum in investment management, were more than offset by lower card balances across all three regions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Cards, while we are encouraged by the continued improvement in consumer spending, with purchase sales up close to 40% versus last year and almost 20% versus last quarter, we are still seeing the impact of high payment rates on revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 7%, reflecting continued investments in our transformation as well as other strategic investments, along with an acceleration in marketing and higher volume related costs from the low point a year ago, partially offset by efficiency savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit remains healthy and credit costs decreased significantly, driven by the $1.4 billion ACL reserve release and lower net credit losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And GCB delivered a 20.8% return on allocated capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, looking at results for the first half of the year, we've seen steady improvement in our drivers, which gives us confidence in our outlook as we move into the back half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 7 shows the results for North America Consumer in more detail.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second quarter revenues were down 11% from last year, primarily driven by lower Cards revenues, but better than the 15% decline last quarter on a year-over-year basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined in both Branded Cards and Retail Services by 12% and 14%, respectively, reflecting continued headwinds from higher payment rates as consumers have continued to use liquidity from stimulus and other relief programs to pay down debt, driving lower loans and a shift in mix towards transactor balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This is creating pressure on our net interest revenues, but it's also benefiting our delinquency and loss trends.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, we are continuing to see a recovery in sales activity, with purchase sales now above pre-pandemic levels led by discretionary spend, including travel and dining.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Branded Cards, total purchase sales were up 40% versus last year, and importantly, up 11% versus the second quarter of 2019.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Retail Services, purchase sales also grew versus both second quarter 2019 and 2020.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the good news is that we're continuing to see the recovery in spend and we're also returning to pre-COVID acquisition levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking ahead, we expect the growth in purchase sales to translate into loan growth by the end of the year, as stimulus moderates and consumers return to more normal payment patterns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to Retail Banking, revenues were down 7% year-over-year reflecting pressure from lower deposit spreads and lower mortgage revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we are continuing to see good momentum as we grow and deepen our retail bank relationships as well as improve the quality and stickiness of these relationships.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits were up 18%, including 24% growth in checking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the number of Citigold households increased by 16%, contributing to a 23% increase in AUMs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show results for International Consumer Banking in constant dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 6% year- over-year in the second quarter with an 11% decline in Latin America and a 3% decline in Asia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking at International Consumer overall, we are seeing good momentum in investment management with 15% growth in assets under management, primarily driven by Asia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the numbers are meaningfully higher if you look specifically at the four international wealth hubs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposit growth remains strong at 8%, albeit at lower deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And similar to the US, we saw a 26% increase in purchase sales year-over-year, but Cards loan growth remained a challenge this quarter, with average card loans down 8% due to elevated payment rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 9 provides additional detail on Global Consumer credit trends.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the US, both NCL and delinquency rates remain favorable driven by the significant amount of customer liquidity due to stimulus and other relief programs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Given the delinquency trends we're seeing today, we do not expect credit deterioration in the US portfolio in 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the ultimate timing and level of losses as we look into next year will depend on whether or not the stimulus results in a permanent benefit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as expected, credit losses and delinquency rates trended downward in both Mexico and Asia, following a peak in the first quarter of 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, overall, we're seeing a rebound in activity along with a consumer who is in a very healthy financial position, suggesting good momentum as we move into the back half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 10 shows the results for Corporate/Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were down slightly in dollar terms as episodic gains this quarter were more than offset by previously disclosed one-time items in the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up slightly in dollar terms, mainly reflecting the impact of FX.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And similar to last quarter, we have further allocated costs to the businesses related to investments in infrastructure, risk and controls.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we mentioned previously, this change had no impact to EBT at the Citi level.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, we have re-cast prior periods to enable better comparability of results.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit costs declined year-over-year driven by a release this quarter compared to a build in the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, EBT was breakeven this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking ahead, we would expect a quarterly pre-tax loss in the range of $200 million to $300 million for the remainder of 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 11 shows our net interest revenue and margin trends as well as non-interest revenues on a reported basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've also provided net interest revenues in constant dollars on slide 19 in the appendix for a comparison to prior periods.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the second quarter, net interest revenue of $10.2 billion declined $880 million year-over-year, reflecting lower loan balances and the impact of lower rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sequentially, net interest revenue continued to stabilize as the extra day in the quarter was offset by lower Cards revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And net interest margin declined 3 basis points, driven by lower Cards NIR and modest growth in the balance sheet due to deposits, partially offset by the increase in Markets NIR in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to non-interest revenues on the bottom of the slide, in the second quarter, non-NIR declined $1.4 billion driven by normalization in Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, outside of Markets, we did see strong broad-based fee growth of over $600 million across GCB and ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And for the past two quarters, we've seen these fee revenues return to pre-pandemic levels of roughly $4.4 billion per quarter, pointing to a somewhat faster-than-expected recovery.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking at these results midway through the year, we are comfortable with our prior outlook and continue to expect total Citi revenues to be down in the mid-single digit range on a full year basis, although the composition is likely to be somewhat different, which I will talk more about in a moment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 12, we show our key capital metrics, which remain strong and stable again this quarter, allowing us to support clients and return capital to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our CET1 Capital ratio increased to 11.9% as net income was mostly offset by buybacks and dividends.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: During the quarter, Citi returned a total of $4.1 billion to common shareholders in the form of $1.1 billion in dividends and share repurchases of $3 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our Supplementary Leverage Ratio was 5.9%, a decline from the prior quarter, largely driven by the expiration of a temporary SLR relief.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our tangible book value per share grew by 9% to $77.87, driven by net income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Before we move on to Q&A, let me spend a few minutes on our outlook for 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the top line, for total Citigroup, we still expect revenues to be down mid-single digits on a reported basis, but as I mentioned, the composition is likely to be somewhat different than we originally anticipated.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Year-to-date, we've seen stronger than expected growth in non-interest revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we do expect the strength in fee growth to continue in the back half of the year, driven primarily by ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Meanwhile, for net interest revenues, we expect continued stabilization in the back half.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we should start to see some loan growth by the end of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So while net interest revenues are down roughly $2.2 billion year-to-date, just outside our original outlook for the full year, assuming this base case holds, we do not expect a significant further decline in net interest revenues from here on a full year basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, again, in aggregate, for total Citigroup, we still expect revenues to be down mid-single digits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the expense side, based on our latest work on the strategic refresh, we've made the decision to further accelerate certain strategic investments, in part in reaction to what is shaping up to be a faster than expected recovery.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a result, we now expect total Citigroup expenses to be up mid-single digits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These are strategic investments that we are making to strengthen our franchise and drive long-term growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For example, we've accelerated investments where we believe there are significant opportunities for growth, including holistically across Wealth and the Commercial Bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've also doubled down on our existing strengths in businesses like TTS, Securities Services and the Investment Banking business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, given the faster recovery we are seeing today, we are accelerating investments in areas like cards marketing to capture this upside.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of these investments will have significant benefits over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Meanwhile, expenses related directly to the transformation, which we had expected to drive the 2% to 3% increase in total Citi expenses this year, are coming in largely as expected.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These investments include the work around the consent order as well as the broader work to modernize the bank, which will improve our risk and control environment as well as allow us to better meet the needs of our customers and clients through an improved operating environment, leading to faster decision-making, better efficiency and improved client experience.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I'd point out that the mix of this spend is 30% technology and 70% non tech related investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, this outlook includes the realization of productivity savings as a by-product of the investments we've been making over the past few years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And to be clear, we will continue, as we have done in the past, to look for ways to operate as efficiently as possible during this investment period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And one additional note.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We could also see some episodic impacts this year related to the market exits we are pursuing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as I've mentioned previously, we will be very transparent about the impact of these actions on our financials.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, in summary, we feel good about the investments that we are making and firmly believe these investments will position us well to close our return gap to peers over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your first question is from the line of John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Please go ahead with your questions.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, thanks for the comments at the end there about the expense outlook and the revision to your outlook for this year.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Just wondering if you could just unpack that a little bit more.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: You're not the only bank that's been kind of raising expense guidance.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: So I was wondering how much of this might be inflationary due to the cost of doing business as a big bank here and how much is Citi specific?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And does the run rate that you're expecting to be at on expenses in the back half of this year feel like that's the run rate you'd go into next year with or are there things that are elevated this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I start by saying and repeating a little bit of what I said in my remarks, which is that we are taking a very deliberate decision on how we manage the franchise, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so what I spoke to was Jane and I along with the leadership team are going through a very thoughtful strategy refresh.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we go through that, we are identifying, particularly given the pace of the recovery, some real strategic opportunities to invest in the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we don't want to – we're not going to miss this window of opportunity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've heard me mention that before.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it's in parts of the franchise that will undoubtedly grow and are high returning.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So when we talk about TTS, we talk about the Commercial Banking business, we talk about Wealth, those are businesses that have strong growth prospects and have returns that are north of 20% in a normal environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so like I said, we're jumping at that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the transformation side, I've been very clear and consistent that we expected that to drive the 2% to 3% increase year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's coming in largely as expected and again, the right thing to do, and important thing to do to modernize this bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Inflation, of course, is going to be a factor, particularly as we look at labor and the competition for talent but again, that's – we deal with that on a regular basis and we continue to look for productivity and efficiency savings that largely tend to offset that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of 2022, I'm not going to give any guidance on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, this is, I think, an important period of time as we come out of this to ensure we're putting money to work in a smart fashion that prepares the firm for the future.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Research.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe the first question – hey, good morning.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe first question on Branded Cards in North America.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Average balances were pretty flat, but there was a little pressure on spread.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Can you just maybe clear that up?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Is that just sort of greater user rate activity or does that bounce back?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How do we think about the revenue trajectory there and the spread compression we saw this quarter?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, again, the dynamic on Cards revenues, Branded Cards in particular in North America which were down 12%, is largely driven by what we're seeing in the way of loan balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And if you look at average interest earning balances, our average interest earning balances for Branded Cards are down about 11%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, the good news is, as we've said, purchase sale activity is up meaningfully year-over-year and relative to the prior quarter, but it's really those payment rates are remaining quite high, quite elevated.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The good news is that plays through in the form of a benefit as it relates to cost of credit, lower losses than expected, and now lower reserves as we see releases.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But it's really that dynamic of payment rates high, lower loan volumes - average interest earning in particular - that is putting pressure on that top line.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: All right.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: That's helpful for the clarification on the transactor balances.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then maybe just more broadly on the Wealth business, you guys put out a press release saying you made some significant investments in new hires in Asia Wealth with a pretty substantial and aggressive target to grow head count.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Where do you stand on that build-out?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And are you making similar investments in other markets?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think as we said, we're pretty excited about the Wealth opportunity for us because we have all the different pieces to be successful here: the brand, the client relationships, the platform, the Commercial Banking franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're already a sizable player.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're number three in Asia, for example, where a lot of the growth is coming from.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The opportunity for us is pulling all of the pieces together into a single integrated offering across the full spectrum of clients and so we've been investing in that platform, the technology.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll have seen the announcement yesterday in the US about a self-directed digital offering there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been expanding and growing talent in the front line as well and are very pleased as well with the investment product revenue growth which is where from a mix point of view we see the greatest upside for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So early days in the execution of this, but I think pleasing progress as we pull this together into this single integrated offering, invest behind it and you'll see the benefits in terms of growth as well as obviously return and revenue mix going forward for the bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane, only thing I would add to that, we are already seeing good performance in the quarter, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So Private Bank revenues up 4%, continued strong growth in client assets up 26% including AUMs that were up 29% and deposit strength, et cetera.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as Jane mentioned, even as we invest in strengthening the platform, we just announced yesterday that we were launching the self-directed investment digital offering which, again, is targeted towards US Consumer and Wealth Management clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so good progress while we invest and position ourselves to capture further opportunity here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please proceed.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Wanted to ask you a little bit just on capital.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: When we got the SCB results, you had indicated a dividend of at least $0.51 and implied that you'd be buying back stock, but just wondering if you could help us just flush that out a little bit more in terms of how we should be thinking about the type of capital return or any increases that you might consider on the dividend from here?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And how to put that into context with prospective changes in the SCB and your minimums?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the first thing I'd say is that as you can tell through the second quarter, we bought back as much as the regulatory rules would allow for in the way of the average four quarters of net income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we continue to be very excited about the prospect of continued capital return.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As it relates to the SCB and the recent results, as you know, we have a target of approximately 11.5% from a CET1 ratio point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The target includes an estimate for the stress capital buffer that's somewhere between 2.5% and 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Up until this recent set of results, the prior couple had been at the 2.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The 3% will go into effect at the end of the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And more importantly, we will actively manage the drivers that impact that stress capital buffer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is to say, PPNR as well as the balance sheet, risk weighted assets, and we intend to do so with an eye towards how we bring that stress capital buffer back down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we think about capital actions, as you know, with the SCB in place, we have the flexibility to take those decisions in a given quarter in line with the reg minimums and we intend to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Given where the stock trades, it makes a lot of sense for us to be buying back shares and so we'll continue to skew towards that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as of right now, our dividend is going to remain at the $0.51, but as I mentioned, we will continue to lookat that quarter-to-quarter, given the flexibility from the SCB.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the only piece I'd add in is as we're doing this work on the strategy and the plans going forward, both Mark and I have a high degree of confidence around the capital generating capability of the franchise and look forward to returning excess capital to you over and above what we'll be doing to invest and close that return gap with our peers.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: I just wanted to follow up on the dividend commentary.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I understand the preference to buy back stock and you're very explicit about wanting to do that below tangible book, so that makes sense.

speaker: Connor
sentence: But I guess just kind of signaling the market, keeping a stable dividend, is there like a message there about the underlying earnings power or limited ability to increase the dividend?

speaker: Connor
sentence: Because I'd think you'd want to at least top it up by a couple of pennies, just to kind of signal a positive trend, because it doesn't take that much capital to do that.

speaker: Connor
sentence: So maybe you can elaborate a little bit on the dividend, again specifically on should we read into implied underlying earnings power?

speaker: Connor
sentence: Are there any limits on increasing the dividend?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Let me be very clear.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's no underlying message there at all.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's as I stated in terms of where the stock is trading and it making sense to do buybacks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our dividend yield is quite comparable to that of peers at close to 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so – and there's no constraint on our ability to take capital actions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we don't have any concerns about the earning power of the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in fact, many of the areas, as I mentioned earlier and as Jane has mentioned, we know are going to contribute to continued strength in our earnings power.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, well capitalized.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We feel good about our earnings power and no concerns or no underlying message to the capital actions and direction of them that we spoke to.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, we have the flexibility given the stress capital buffer as we go quarter-to-quarter to adjust as we see fit in the best interest of our investors.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Hello, Steven, your line is open.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Mark, I was hoping to unpack just some of the NII guidance.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: I think there was just a little bit of confusion how it should be interpreted.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So, it sounds like we're down $2.2 billion year-to-date and that the full year we shouldn't see any incremental declines from there.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So that would imply about $10.5 billion NII run rate in the back half.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: I just want to make sure that's the right way to interpret the remarks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, again, we do see kind of the NIR stabilizing and you see some of that particularly ex-markets but also in total on the page.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, the guidance for total revenue is unchanged at down mid-single digits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You're right, as of the half, we're at down $2.2 billion as relates to net interest revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the markets component of that can often be hard to predict, but what I'm suggesting is that any offset or any further pressure there will be offset likely in the fee momentum that we expect to see given the strength coming through this quarter.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Hey, Betsy.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Oh, hey.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I did have a question for Jane and you, Mark.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: The question has to do with how you're thinking about the importance of scale in the business refresh, I guess, I could call it that you're doing?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And Jane, really, maybe you could help us understand how important scale is in what you're looking to execute here?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I ask because many times I get questions from investors around what is Citi doing on the pieces of the business that don't have as much scale as the standout areas like Global, Fixed or Treasury Services or Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First of all, scale is clearly very, very important here, particularly in a more digital world and as you point out, Betsy, TTS, for example, has – we're moving $4 trillion of volume a day around the world and we've got a number of franchises that have material scale and we only expect them to be growing and this is where the transformation program will be very helpful in ensuring the scalability of our platforms.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We made the decision on Asia Pac and EMEA to exit the 13 markets where we didn't believe that we would be able to achieve the scale needed to compete in those very local part of the business so that we can focus our firepower in those areas where we're either ensuring we retain a leading market position or in other areas where we want to be investing to attain the scale that we think is going to be needed going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: US Consumer is an obvious example of that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think as we – you'll hear from us going forward, more and more focus around what are our plans for those businesses for retaining the leading positions in this, aided by the transformation program, or in the areas where we'll be investing to attain greater scale and as I say, US Consumer is the obvious one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There are pockets in Commercial Bank we're excited by.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Securities Services is one where we think it is very readily attainable, particularly given our pre and post trade capabilities and part of that scale, finally, will come from the linkages between our businesses as we create more connectivity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That will also provide us scale, so collectively the different franchises we have will be competitively advantaged and not just individually strong.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please proceed.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just a follow-up – understand you're being deliberately in strategy leading up to, I guess, the Investor Day you mentioned next – first quarter next year.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: But as we think about just the investment spend and the expense outlook, handicap, Mark, if you could, the risk that we could see a little bit of an expense creep as you dig further deeper into this, both in terms of your guidance for mid-single digit expense growth this year and as we think about just the duration of that investment cycle over the next few years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, again, this is something that we control, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, again, I want to reiterate that we are making very deliberate decisions around the opportunities that we see across the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it's the right thing to do, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of kind of risk to it, I don't think there are any surprises here, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If revenues come in meaningfully different, there's a certain component of our expense base that's tied to revenues and so that would obviously move around.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But aside from those volume-related expenses, transaction, compensation, et cetera, you should expect what I've guided towards in terms of the very deliberate decisions to put the money to work in this fashion and we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If we see more investment opportunities in 2021 or 2022, we're going to go after them because, again, we know that we can deliver on the benefits and the returns that are associated with putting that money to work.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, you said something interesting about the Investment Banking business revenues.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: I think you said that they were 39% or 38% higher than 2019.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: I'm checking my notes here.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: So your business is still nicely above the 2019 levels and we came through a period up until the pandemic that you're well aware of that it was somewhat challenging, the growth in Investment Banking and Trading businesses.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: As you look forward when you talk to your people in Investment Banking and in Global Markets, where do they see this?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Because there seems to be an elevated amount of business due to what we just came through in the last 18 months.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Do they think it's sustainable or do we get back to a 2019?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What are those guys telling you about the next 12 to 24 months in those businesses?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd start by saying we continue to have very, very good dialogue with our clients across the franchise and specifically in Investment Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And if you think about it, many businesses, many companies across industries are really having to take a look at their business model and think about how they want to transform their businesses coming out of this pandemic.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Everything from how to think about digitization, how to think about going direct to consumers, what the pandemic means for supply chains, how people work remotely, how they manage their liquidity levels, what to do with that excess liquidity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Should they be buying or what?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we're part of that dialogue, which is incredibly representative, I think – it represents strongly the franchise that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The general view from our clients is optimistic in terms of the go-forward environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, there's some things to kind of manage to, but there's a general level of optimism.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so what I represented relative to 2019 is while we are seeing normalization, we're normalizing at a higher level than where we ended in 2019 and we'd expect continued momentum and we'd expect to continue to take share over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane, anything you want to add to that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, I think you covered it very well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's a high level of client engagement with us at the moment really around the world and a lot of demand.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing in addition to the Investment Banking side, this shift to e- commerce with clients needing our TTS services, our cross-border flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing this translating into demand in trade starting to pick up nicely.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Commercial Banking side is another area that we're seeing a lot of new demand coming through from clients both from strategic activity with our investment bank as well as their own expansion globally that we're supporting them through our Treasury Services and the like.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think there's a general sense of optimism.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a fabulous pipeline.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One never wants to jinx these things, but we really have a fabulous pipeline heading into the second half of the year around the world and it does give you a good sense of confidence of continued momentum.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I'm going to ask my question here and then re-queue.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: The real question is just on capital.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I mean, you're not blind to the fact that your tangible book value is $78 and your stock price is $68.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, we should probably be selling your desk chairs and your silverware and anything you can to buy back your stock, I would think.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, along those lines, the first question is when you're looking at these sales of assets, 13 Consumer markets, do you expect to have a gain on those or a loss on those relative to where they're marked currently?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, I mean, I think I'd tell you, Mike, that we, as Jane mentioned, we've seen strong interest from buyers as it relates to those assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there's no surprise, just given we think those are good businesses, just not of scale as Jane mentioned for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got to run that process through and see what that results in and I'll continue to be transparent with you as to where gains and losses or how it flows through our financials, but I'm not going to sit here and tell you whether it's gains or losses or what it means specifically for those 13 markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I will tell you is that as capital is freed up from those transactions, we'll continue to make very deliberate decisions around what to do with that capital, first, looking at growth opportunities that can deliver returns above our cost of capital, and then looking towards how we can return as much of it to shareholders as it makes sense in the form of buybacks, dividends, et cetera.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we've been disciplined about that to date and we're going to continue to be disciplined about that.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, to clarify, if I got this right, your CET1 ratio is 11.9% and your return on capital above 11.5%.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, if you were to quantify the dollar amount of that, how much would that mean in potential buybacks at this point and then I assume that would not include any capital freed up from any sale?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, you could have potential to buy back a lot of stock if you were willing and able, is that correct?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: A little bit over $4 billion of excess capital between the 11.5% and the 11.9% and so that's what that equates to.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next and final question will come from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please proceed.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: A couple.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Mark, any comments on promotional trends that you're seeing in card pricing, given everybody is back focusing on the business?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: You mentioned marketing spend, but can you talk a little about what you're seeing in promotional pricing in that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I guess, what I'd say is simply that as expenses would suggest and as we stated, we are legging back into bringing on new card customers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so – and what we're seeing is that our acquisitions are largely at pre- COVID, pre-crisis or pre-pandemic levels and, frankly, we're seeing normal behaviors as those card customers come on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as has always been the case, it's going to be a mix in terms of the acquisition strategy, but thus far, we're seeing normal behaviors, if you will.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And look, the new account acquisitions skewed towards Branded Cards and they're in products that are less reliant on the 0% offers and products like Flex Pay and Flex Loan, which will generate interest immediately as those balances grow.

speaker: Operator
sentence: We do have one more question in queue from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: An unrelated question.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Just, Jane, as you think about the technology approach, doing it yourself through Citigroup and pairing up with partners, what's the status of the relationship with Google and Google Plex and your desire to use third-parties to gather new customers at lower initial cost, but maybe not as much lifetime value?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: If you think of that trade-off, what's your current thinking today?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And we haven't heard much about the Google relationship despite some initial headlines.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, hey there, Mike.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Excellent question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The partnership with big tech is an important part of our disrupter strategy in the US as we're looking at both how do we enhance value propositions to customers, the customer base itself, and then these new ecosystems that are evolving.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think there's no question that COVID has accelerated the embedded finance model in the US, just think of the travel ecosystem, think of home improvement ecosystems.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The benefit we've got is that for us, it's not a new space to us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been very much engaged with partners in Asia, Grab, Paytm, and WeBank as well as our traditional partners.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What we find with these partnerships is that we learn a lot because it's still early days in the development of these new ecosystems.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We learn a lot about marketing, about user experiences, around the tech stacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's certainly enables us to tap into next generation customer bases, but also importantly, it goes beyond consumer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so if we look on the corporate side, our partnership with Stripe, the work that we're doing in TTS with Project Spring of enabling payments is a core piece, particularly as wholesale and retail kind of collapses some of these payment chains into one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So with Google Plex and several other tech partnerships that we have in the States and elsewhere in the world, we're very deliberately going about creating a broad suite of APIs and partner integration capabilities so that we're able to integrate other partners into our offerings, develop more innovative solutions without necessarily having to build it or buy it all ourselves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And Citi Plex with Google is an example of that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are actively testing features with our own employees at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll be finalizing dates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll share that with you when available.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's one of many different partnerships that we have and an important partner for us, but far from the only one here in the States to help us disrupt and grow going forward.

speaker: Operator
sentence: We do have a follow-up question from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Sorry.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: But I kind of have a second question and that's on capital.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Given that you're headed towards a higher GSIB bucket, Mark, Jane, what you're all thinking in terms of that, in terms of not just capital targets, anything you can do about that, because I know that's a year – a little over a year away from going into effect, but obviously, you're thinking about target capital, we'll have to keep in mind what's coming down the pipe for you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And look, as you know, with all of the liquidity in the market, many of us have seen pressure on our GSIB score.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That certainly has been the case for us and it wouldn't go into effect, the higher GSIB score of 3.5% until the beginning of 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we look at the entire capital stack holistically, the 11.5% target in our case, which is well above reg minimums, but certainly does consider that in it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there are elements of that, as I mentioned earlier, that we can influence and control.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the stress capital buffer is part of that, and I talked earlier about our ability to influence those levers without having full understanding of the Fed models, we know we can influence PPNR, we know we can influence the balance sheet and how it gets allocated and ultimately, what stress losses come out of it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we will continue to manage that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will still have a buffer obviously, even with a higher GSIB score.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you know, regulators continue to talk about capital as being at about the right levels in the system and they'll continue to look at drivers that influence the stack as well, including GSIB and balance sheet size, et cetera, and we'll see how that evolves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, we feel good about where we are.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're well capitalized.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have a good sense for the drivers going forward that will create capital capacity for us and we intend to, again, invest that where it makes sense and return that otherwise to our shareholders.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I would now like to turn the call back over to Elizabeth Lynn for closing remarks.

speaker: Elizabeth Lynn
sentence: Thank you all for joining today's call.

speaker: Elizabeth Lynn
sentence: Please feel free to reach out to us in IR with any follow-up questions and thank you again and have a nice day.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: And thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: With that, I'll turn it over to Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn and thank you everyone for joining us today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When we last spoke, we said the macro and geopolitical outlook was complex and uncertain, so in one sense, little has changed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: However, the headwinds have certainly crystallized.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's against that backdrop that I'm proud of the results our team delivered this quarter as we execute on our strategy and transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There are mounting costs to the series of supply shocks we've experienced, and now we need to pay attention to an additional S in ESG, and that is security.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In addition to energy and cybersecurity, food security has also come into sharper focus, threatening to spread the humanitarian cost of the war well beyond Europe.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Resiliency is the new priority for governments and corporates alike.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And all of this is adding to inflationary pressures which are in turn being met with a more hawkish response from the Fed and other central banks, all contributing to sharply lower US consumer confidence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Higher rates and QT will keep volatility high.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That said, while sentiment has shifted, little of the data I see tells me the US is on the cusp of a recession.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Consumer spending remains well above pre-COVID levels, with household savings providing a cushion for future stress, and as any employer will tell you, the job market remains very tight.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, our corporate clients see robust demand and healthy balance sheets, with revenue softness attributed to supply chain constraints so far.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, while a recession could indeed take place over the next two years in the US, it's highly unlikely to be a sharper downturn as others in recent memory.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm just back from Europe, where it's a different story.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect a very difficult winter is coming, and that's due to disruptions in the energy supply.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There is also increasing concern about the second-order effects on industrial production and how that will affect economic activity across the continent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the mood is, of course, further darkened by the belief that the war in Ukraine will not end anytime soon.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Asia, a rebound in China also faces some constraints, given the potential for future lockdowns, the amount of leverage in the Chinese economy, and stress in their property sector.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Given this uncertain environment, I'm quite pleased with our overall performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We reported net income of $4.5 billion, an EPS of $2.19, and an RoTCE of 11.2%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew revenues at 11% year-over-year, whilst remaining on track to meet our expense guidance for the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services continued to show excellent momentum, with revenues up 28% year-over-year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While some of that growth is a result of the rate environment, we had double-digit fee growth, consistent with the strategy we presented to you in March.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: TTS in particular fired on all cylinders as clients took advantage of our global network, leading to the best quarter this business has had in a decade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The market volatility that we saw in the first quarter continued into the second, driving corporate clients in particular to be more active in risk management, contributing to revenue growth of 25% in Markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The volatility we saw in foreign exchange rates, commodities, and equity derivatives favored our mix, and we were more efficient in our capital usage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, while this level of activity is related to where we are in the current cycle rather than a new baseline end market, I believe we are helping our clients navigate this environment quite well, and it shows how our emphasis on our corporate clients globally, given their consistent trading needs, is a differentiating one for us in Markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: On the flip side, that same environment continues to put a great deal of pressure on the investment banking wallet, with our revenues down 46%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: However, we are seeing an increase of lending as our clients are being less inclined to obtain financing through the debt markets given the recent swings.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In US Personal Banking, the positive drivers we saw in our two credit card businesses over the last few quarters converted into solid revenue growth this quarter, most notably, 10% growth in Branded Cards.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see how resilient the consumer is in US through the elevated payment rates and the low level of credit losses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They have, however, shifted their spend far more to travel and entertainment, which are now outpacing 2019 levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While volatility can be an opportunity for our trading desks, lower asset prices are a headwind for Wealth Management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Asia again was hit harder than other regions leading to flat year-over-year Wealth Management revenues overall.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That said, we continue to execute our wealth strategy across a number of fronts, including building our base of client advisors, expanding our Private Bank's physical footprint to reach 20 countries, with the additions of Germany and France, and increasing referrals from our branch network in the US.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, the underlying strategic drivers for the long-term growth of this business continue to advance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, while we did have a slight build in reserves, given the increasing possibility of a recession, we are operating from a position of strength.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our capital, liquidity, credit quality, and reserve levels are strong, and our diversified business mix also positions us well for the choppy waters on the horizon.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, while the world has changed since we presented our Investor Day to you in March, our strategy has not.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have continued to execute it with discipline and with urgency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The quarterly report card on slide 3 should help you hold us accountable for our progress.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are laser-focused on the long-termgoals we set out in March, and I see this quarter's performance as validating that we are indeed on the right path.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Simplifying the firm is a high priority, and we made good progress executing on our divestitures such as closing the sale of Australia during the quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are well into the sales process in Mexico, working through the regulatory and legal dynamics that can be expected in a transaction of this nature.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of Russia, we continue to shrink the size of our business and take steps to reduce our financial exposure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Given the complex environment, we are considering the full range of possibilities to exit our consumer and commercial banking businesses, including portfolio sales.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As divestitures such as Australia progress, we are beginning to eliminate stranded costs and simplify our model, and this discipline is critical to ensuring we have the resources to invest in the businesses where we want to gain or maintain a competitive advantage and to ensure the success of our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: To that point, we were particularly pleased that our AML Consent Order was lifted by the OCC in April.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are committed to ensuring our technology, controls, and processes are up to the standards our regulators expect of us and we expect of ourselves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let me end on capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We increased our CET1 ratio to 11.9% this quarter, whilst returning $1.3 billion in capital, including a rather modest level of buybacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our tangible book value per share now exceeds $80.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Despite the strength of our balance sheet and reserves, our stress capital buffer is set to increase to 4% in the fourth quarter as a result of this year's stress test scenario.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, over the near-term, we plan to build to a CET1 ratio of approximately 13%, including a 100 basis point management buffer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Over the medium term, our CET1 target remains at 11.5% to 12%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are prioritizing our dividend and are pausing our share repurchases as we build capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a management buffer which we can use to help ensure a smooth path to our required levels, and Mark will walk you through our approach in a few minutes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will generate significant capital given our earnings power and the completion of pending divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We know how important buybacks are to shareholder value creation, in particular when we are trading at these levels, and are committed to restarting them as soon as it is prudent to do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will make every effort to optimize our capital especially in businesses such as Markets so we balance the needs of our clients, our investors, and our regulators.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, in a challenging macro and geopolitical environment, our team delivered solid results, and the bank is in a very strong position to weather uncertain times whilst playing to our strengths.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm confident about the path ahead, and I'm pleased with our early progress.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, I'd like to turn it over to Mark, and then we'd be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane and good morning everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm going to start with the firm-wide financial results focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the second quarter unless I indicate otherwise, then spend a little more time on expenses, capital, and Russia, and then turn to the results of each segment and end with 2022 guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 4, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned earlier, in the second quarter we reported net income of $4.5 billion, an EPS of $2.19, with an RoTCE of 11.2% on $19.6 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, total revenues increased 11%, with growth in both net interest income as well as non-interest revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net interest income grew 14% driven by higher rates as well as strong volumes across ICG and PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Non- interest revenue grew 5% driven by Fixed Income and Services, which more than offset lower non-interest revenue in Investment Banking and PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total expenses of $12.4 billion increased 8%, largely driven by transformation, business-led investments, and volume-related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a year-to-date basis, expenses were up 12%, but excluding divestiture related impacts were up 9%, also driven by the factors I just mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.3 billion, driven by net credit losses of $850 million and an ACL build of approximately $400 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had approximately $18.3 billion in total reserves, with a reserve-to-funded loan ratio of 2.44%, and are well capitalized with a CET1 ratio of 11.9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 5, we show an expense walk for the second quarter with the key underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, expenses increased by 8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
