sentence: 3% of the increase was driven by transformation investments, with about two- thirds related to risks, controls, data, and the finance programs, and approximately 25% of the investments in those programs are related to technology.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as of today, we have over 9,000 people dedicated to the transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About 2% of the expense increase was driven by business-led investments as we continue to hire commercial and investment bankers as well as client advisors in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we continue to invest in the client experience as well as front office onboarding and platforms.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: 2% was due to higher revenue and volume-related expenses largely in Markets and cards, and approximately 1% was driven by compensation as well as other risk and control investments, partially offset by productivity savings and the impact of foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across all these buckets, we continue to invest in technology, which is up 14% for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Before we move on from expenses, we wanted to provide some tangible examples of what we are working on regarding our transformation and some of the benefits we expect to see over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The transformation is designed to improve our governance and processes, enhance our policies, and leverage technology to strengthen our controls.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been actively investing in technology to improve automation and hiring people to stand up these efforts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To this end, we are enhancing our risk management processes and capabilities across a number of areas.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For example, in Banking, we've gone live with a new platform and now begun to consolidate our 37 loan processing systems to one loan servicing platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have continued to build out our infrastructure to enhance our stress testing capabilities across the firm, particularly useful in this market.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Given the power and importance of data, we are redesigning our data governance and data organization, which will help us improve the timeliness and quality of our data.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These foundational data-related changes will allow us to simplify and improve client onboarding and deepening, product development, as well as enhance our data analytics for every function.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are streamlining our financial planning process to allow for multiple scenarios with greater frequency, including more agile capital planning.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we signed with a major software provider to begin a multiyear process of modernizing and moving our 16 ledger platforms deployed across 121 instances to one cloud-based ledger.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And while we are in the early stages of these initiatives, we expect the efficiencies from these investments to be key in helping us meet our Investor Day commitments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6, we show net interest income, loans, and deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the second quarter, net interest income increased by approximately $1.1 billion on a sequential basis, driven by higher rates, day count, growth in loans, as well as the impact of the European dividend season on our Markets business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a year over-year basis, net interest income increased by approximately $1.5 billion, driven by higher interest rates as well as volumes across businesses, and we grew average loans by approximately 3% in ICG, mainly in trade finance, and 4% in PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Legacy Franchises loans declined, largely driven by the reclassification of loans to held-for-sale.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And sequentially, the gross yield on our loans increased by 35 basis points and the cost of our interest-bearing deposits increased by 20 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show our summary balance sheet and key capital and liquidity metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintained a very strong balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of our $2.4 trillion of assets, about 22% or $531 billion are high-quality liquid assets, or HQLAs, and we maintained total liquidity resources of approximately $964 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our end-of-period deposits increased by 1%, largely driven by TTS and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a sequential basis, deposits decreased by 1%, including the impact of seasonality in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: From an RWA perspective, we saw both advanced and standardized RWA come down both year-over-year and sequentially as we continued to optimize RWA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter with a standardized CET1 ratio of approximately 11.9% and standardized remains the binding requirement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our tangible book value per share was $80.25, up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show a sequential CET1 ratio walk to provide more detail on the drivers this quarter and our goals over the next few quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we generated $4.3 billion of net income to common, which added 34 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we returned $1.3 billion in the form of dividends and buybacks, which drove a reduction of about 10 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, the interest rate impact on AOCI through our investment portfolio drove a 12 basis point reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fourth, the decrease in disallowed DTA drove a five basis point increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, the remainder was driven by a combination of our net RWA optimization efforts as well as a 12 basis point benefit from the closing of the Australia sale.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The combination of our earnings generation, closing of divestitures, and continued RWA optimization efforts will be important tools as we manage towards our CET1 requirements.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our management buffer, which was designed to temporarily address volatility, will allow us to build gradually, while continuing to support our clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Given all that, we do expect to build to a CET1 target of approximately 13% by midyear 2023, which accounts for the increased regulatory requirement and assumes a 100 basis point management buffer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, consistent with what we said at Investor Day, our medium-term target remains at 11.5% to 12%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And while we are pausing buybacks for now, as I've said before, we remain committed to returning excess capital to our shareholders over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we provide an update on our exposure to Russia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2Q, we reduced our exposure by $3.1 billion in local currency terms, which was more than offset by the ruble appreciation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As of today, the mix of our exposure has changed and is now reflecting a higher proportion of stronger credit names.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Additionally, our net investment in our Russian entity is now approximately $1.2 billion, up from about $700 million due to the ruble appreciation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a result of the actions that we've taken to reduce our risks, we now believe that under a range of severe stress scenarios, our potential capital impact is estimated to be approximately $2 billion, down from the $2.5 billion to $3 billion last quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 10, we show the results for our Institutional Clients Group.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased by 20%, largely driven by TTS, Markets, Security Services, as well as a gain on loan hedges, partially offset by a decrease in Investment Banking revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 10%, driven by transformation, business-led investments, and volume- related expenses, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a benefit of $202 million, with a net ACL release of $220 million and net credit losses of only $18 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The release was largely driven by a reduction in Russia-related risks, partially offset by a build due to increased global macro uncertainty.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of approximately $4 billion, up 16%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We grew average loans by 3%, largely driven by TTS loans which were up 17%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits grew 1%, driven by the deepening of existing client relationships and new client acquisitions, and ICG delivered an RoTCE of 16.6%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 11, we show revenue performance by business and the key drivers we laid out at Investor Day, which we will show you each quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Services, we continue to see a very strong new client pipeline and deepening with our existing clients and expect that momentum to continue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Treasury and Trade Solutions, revenues were up 33%, driven by 42% growth in net interest income as well as 17% growth in NIR, as we saw strong growth with both mid and large corporate clients, and we continue to see healthy underlying drivers in TTS that indicate continued strong client activity with US dollar clearing volumes up 2%, cross-border flows up 17%, and commercial card volumes up 61%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, these metrics are indicators of client activity and fees, and on a combined basis drive approximately 50% of total TTS fee revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Security Services revenues grew 16% as net interest income grew 41%, driven by higher interest rates across currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And NIR grew 8%, largely reflecting elevated activity levels in issuer services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Overall, Markets revenues were up 25%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The macro-environment played to our strengths, with the volatility leading to elevated corporate client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income Markets revenues were up 31%, driven by FX, rates, and commodities due to active engagement with our corporate clients, as we helped them manage risk associated with volatile markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equity Markets revenues were up 8%, driven by strong equity derivative performance, partially offset by less client activity in cash and a net decrease in prime balances, as lower asset valuations more than offset new client balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking revenues, excluding gains and losses on loan hedges, were down 28% driven by Investment Banking, as heightened geopolitical uncertainty and the overall macro backdrop impacted client activity, partially offset by higher revenue in Corporate Lending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we feel very good about the progress we are making here as we continue to deepen existing client relationships as well as acquire new clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to slide 12, we show the results for our Personal Banking and Wealth Management businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 6%, as net interest income growth was partially offset by a decline in non interest revenue, largely driven by partner payments in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 12%, driven by transformation, business-led investments, and higher volume-driven expenses partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit of $1.4 billion was up as we added reserves, given the increase in overall uncertainty in the macro environment compared to a net ACL release last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And NCLs were down 19% as we continue to see strong credit performance across portfolios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans grew 4%, driven by strong growth in Branded Cards as well as growth across Retail Services and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits grew 6%, driven by growth across Retail and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to maintain a strong reserve-to-loan ratio of 7.5% in our US cards businesses, and PBWM delivered an RoTCE of 6.8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While a low return, this was driven by the ACL build and an increase in expenses in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 13, we show PBWM revenues by product as well as key business drivers and metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues were up 10%, driven by higher interest on higher loan balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are seeing encouraging underlying drivers with new accounts and card spend volumes, both up 18%, and average loans up 11%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues were up 7%, also driven by higher interest on higher loan balances, partially offset by higher partner payments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So despite payment rates remaining elevated, the investments we have been making have driven growth in interest-earning balances of 3% in Branded Cards and 2% in Retail Services, and we believe we will continue to grow these balances in the second half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues were up 6%, primarily driven by deposit spreads and volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues were flat as investment fee headwinds offset NII growth, driven by deposits and loan volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding Asia, revenues were up 4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're starting to see the leading indicators pick up with average deposits up 7% and client advisors up 8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are seeing strong new client acquisitions having added 800 Private Bank clients and over 50,000 Citigold clients since last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 14, we show results for Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 15%, largely driven by the closing of the Australia consumer sale, the Korea wind-down, and muted investment activity in Asia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we mentioned, this quarter we closed the sale of the Australia consumer business, which was a benefit of up to $1.5 billion of capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 15, we show results for Corporate/Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased, largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio, and expenses were down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 16, we briefly touch on the full year 2022 outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At this point, we continue to expect full-year revenues to be up in the low-single digit range.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Relative to Investor Day, the rate curve is certainly giving us a tailwind from an NII perspective and Markets revenues are up for the first half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, as we mentioned earlier, we are seeing much lower levels of Investment Banking activity, and this will likely continue for the remainder of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of expenses, we still expect to grow expenses by 7% to 8% excluding the impact of divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While we are seeing some impact from inflation, we believe the efficiencies that we're executing against and the impact of foreign exchange translation should offset these headwinds.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: JOHN E. Mc

speaker: Donald
sentence: Mark, was hoping that maybe you could unpack the guidance for 2022 a little bit more.

speaker: Donald
sentence: It seems like you've got more good guys than bad guys maintain the guidance, but maybe within that, could you give us a little bit more color on what you're expecting on net interest income, where the trend seems strong, and then maybe what you're assuming from Markets in the back half of the year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thank you, John.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you said, we have seen the benefit certainly in the quarter here of the pickup in rates and certainly all indicators are that the rate increases will likely continue through the balance of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you've heard me say before, I do expect that we will see continued growth in loans, particularly on the card side, and we saw some of that start to play in sooner than expected, because I had talked about it being in the back half of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We saw some of that even here in the second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we do continue to think we'll get some lift there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also expect to see continued momentum on the Services side, both in TTS and likely in Security Services as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that growth is more than just rates, but certainly a portion of that does come from rates as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Where the pressure is going to come is in the non-interest revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we saw that certainly in the quarter here on the Investment Banking side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We saw that obviously in some of the Wealth businesses, particularly in Asia, and that's where some of the offset is that we'd expect against that NII momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, the reality I think is that we'll have to see how this plays out as it relates to markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All the uncertainty that's out there in the environment thus far has played to our favor, given our focus on corporate clients and what have you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I'd tell you that as I look at the full year based on what we know now and with the uncertainty that's out there, I continue to feel comfortable with that guidance probably to the higher end of that low-single digit growth that I've talked about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: JOHN E. Mc

speaker: Donald
sentence: And then maybe as a follow-up, just remind us where you are on net interest income sensitivity?

speaker: Donald
sentence: You've updated the way I think you look at it relative to...

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: JOHN E. Mc

speaker: Donald
sentence: ...peers and relative to rates.

speaker: Donald
sentence: Just remind us where you are on that and what kind of deposit pricing assumptions are embedded in that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, important to kind of just level set, John, great question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We got – I think there are a couple of drivers that kind of come into play when we think about the sensitivity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one is obviously the mix.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, in our case we've got about two-thirds of our deposits are wholesale, about a third are consumer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got, obviously, 70% of ours are in US denominated and the rest are kind of non-US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that mix is important when you think about betas, when you think about sensitivity and how they play out particularly in a rising rate environment at the pace that we've seen.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that pace varies for both the US versus the non-US currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that's all going to be a factor in kind of how we think about it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You're right, in our disclosure, we forecast our IRE disclosure based on a run-off balance sheet assumption.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what I've been describing in the past couple of quarters is an approach that's more consistent with peers, which assumes a static balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And under that analysis, if we were to look at an assumption for 100 basis point parallel shift in rates, cross currencies, we think that would generate roughly a $2.5 billion increase in NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, for us, that's going to skew towards non-US dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About 80% of that would be non-US dollar, about 20% US dollar.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that shift is in part because we've seen already a significant increase in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen some increase in non-US, but nowhere near the magnitude that we've seen in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I'll stop there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Hopefully that addresses your question.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Mark, I wonder if you could just elaborate on the headwinds in non interest revenue within PBWM and Retail Services.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: It sounds to me like you extended a contract for a partner or something like that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And then maybe bigger picture, in cards, you just mentioned rising card loans.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: We all want rising loans, but in the backdrop and the economic outlook we're facing, how do you decipher what's good rise in card loans versus a little concerning rise in card loans?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sure, let me take them in that order.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So on the Retail Services side, it has nothing to do with kind of an extension of a contract or anything like that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I'm describing is that it is a partner business that we have there in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what that means is that there's a sharing of the profits associated with the business that we generate.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so what happens is in this rising rate environment and the activity from a volume point of view, we've seen an increase in the net interest income that we've generated, and what that means is that there's more – fortunately, more profits to share with our partners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The sharing of those profits play through the non-interest revenue line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So it comes out as a fee, as a contra revenue, as we share those with clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's the driver of the swing that you see happening there or the pressure that we have in PBWM as it relates to Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the cards growth, the cards growth we feel very good about it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There certainly is an environmental dynamic that's playing out as it relates to consumers and corporates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what I would say is that you've also heard us describing more marketing spend, more advertising spend, more acquisitions, 18% growth in acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been targeting growing our customer base there, while staying within our risk appetite, and the parameters that we've set and been very disciplined about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's started to pay off.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that is part of what I'd describe in terms of the loan growth that is materializing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's nothing that we see of significance as we grow these loans, that would suggest, one, that they're outside of the focus that we've had to-date, because they're not, nor that there's any material risk in terms of outsized losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look at our loss rates, our loss rates are for Branded Cards 1.5%, Retail Services 2.6%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Those are 50% of what we would normally what we used to describe as a normal loss rate, NCL rate, through a cycle.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we feel very good about the loans that we're growing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's obviously risk, but we also feel very good about the reserves that we have.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: My first question is actually a follow-up to John's question, Mark.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think that, it's always been more challenging to forecast net interest income for Citigroup.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And the net interest income and net interest margin certainly surprised to the upside.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, I guess, let me re-ask the question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Appreciate the $2.5 billion for each 100 basis point in parallel shift, but as we think about the US forward curve, how should we think about the trajectory of net interest income from that $10.58 billion from here?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And clearly, as we think about a deposit base that's two-thirds wholesale, how should we think about both deposit flow, deposit growth, and deposit beta as we think about the second half of the year?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: In other words, does the rate of change quarter-over-quarter accelerate, flatten out, or decelerate?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, there's a lot there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But, I mean, I think what I'd say is a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is, we've obviously seen a rapid increase in rates, and that the speed at which rates increases matters a lot as it relates to the betas, and so particularly on the wholesale corporate side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we have seen betas increase there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They're probably at about to slightly a little bit better than we would have expected.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we would expect that momentum to continue in the back half of the year given the forecast for continued rate increases.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other thing that I'd point out just given your point around the ability to forecast from a Citi point of view, if you look at the first half of the year, we did about, I think it was $1.8 billion or so over the prior year, ex-Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, NII ex-Markets, $1.8 billion year-over-year first half.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To give you a bit more guidance on how we're thinking about it in light of the rate curve and in light of our mix, I'd tell you that I expect about another $1.8 billion or so in the back half.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's probably year-over-year 8-ish percent or so on a full-year basis based on, again, our mix, our assumption around betas and our current assumptions around how the curve would likely play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Let me pause there and see if Jane wants to add anything to that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, I'd also add in, our institutional deposits account for about 65% of Citi's deposit base, but 55% of them are operational deposits.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the TTS deposits have increased by $134 billion since pre-COVID, but the operational deposits increased by $141 billion, and the non-operating decreased.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, with QT on the horizon, we'd certainly expect the amounts of deposits in the system to shrink.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We anticipate this would primarily impact non-operating balances, and I think we feel very good about the stickiness of the deposit base we've got, and particularly internationally where these are operating accounts that are extremely sticky, frankly, in all environments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Good point.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And just my follow-up question is that was really an impressive capital build this quarter, particularly since it's been an issue with investors, and especially since the SCB came out.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think a piece that we may be missing as we think about the continued build to 13% is sort of what the CET1 benefit is from slide 19.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, similar to sort of the, I guess it was 12 basis points accreted from the Australia sale.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Is there any way you could give us a range on, as the deal close for the Philippines, Thailand, Bahrain, Malaysia in the second half of the year, how that could boost your CET1 and get you closer to that 13% bogey?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I guess let me kind of answer it in a more fulsome way, if you don't mind, and then I'll certainly make sure that I give you a sense for the contribution of what we expect from divestitures to the capital impact.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, again, there are a couple of drivers that are going to be important to us building to ultimately the 13% for as long as that is place given the SCB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is obviously the income generation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with a very strong quarter as it relates to income generation, I feel good about the back half of the year as I've just given you some guidance on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other is, don't forget we've had 160 basis points on the two-year since the beginning of the year to the end of the first quarter in terms of rate increases, another 60 bps in the second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it's going to be – there were AOCI impacts from that, 34 bps in the first quarter, and as we point out here, another 12 bps in the second.There's a pull to par that we expect to start to play out and continue to play out in the balance of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's going to be an important factor.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The third, as you've heard us mention is, we've been working very hard to optimize our RWA and we'll continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've paused the buybacks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's a factor.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then as you mentioned, the divestitures, the close to $1.5 billion or so in Australia, I've talked about in the past about $4 billion for the year in terms of capital impact, I'm at about $3.5 billion with Australia is what I'm currently expecting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, a little bit less than what I had talked about before, in part because of some of the movement in terms of the timing of some of these closings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Still feel good about it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Just it's a difficult market that we're managing through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that $3.5 billion total should give you a sense for how that translates into a CET1 impact that we're expecting, at least through the balance of this year, and obviously there'd be more to come as we continue to close out – and sign and close out some of the remaining deals.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, I mean, I rather suspect that at the end of all of this, we're going to have an overabundance of capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I really feel good that Citi is already very well-positioned for any environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark said, we have a confluence of various factors going on, I mean, some of which are temporary, that are causing this rapid buildup of capital for the industry.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I think we're extremely well-positioned for what lies ahead in terms of strong capital ratios, total liquidity resources.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Portfolio credit quality is extremely high, well reserved.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, we are very much looking forward to resuming share buybacks as I said once we've achieved this build, particularly given where we're trading, and I want you to hear loud and clear that commitment.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I'm trying to figure out if you're lucky or smart.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And the reason I say that is, at your Investor Day, I mean, right upfront you said you have five core interconnected businesses led by Services, led by TTS, and then a few months later you have your best quarter in a decade.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And it just seems so coincidental that you highlight that as a growth area and then just a couple of quarters later, boom, here we are.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, how much of that TTS growth is simply because of one-off factors in the markets, in other words it won't repeat?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: How much of it is due to a higher baseline, because of, say, interest rates?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And how much of that is due to market share gains?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And just remind us what TTS and Security Services is again, because I think you got everyone's attention with this quarter?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, why don't I kick off and then I'll pass it to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's a danger here of how long you have, Mike, because there's a lot to talk about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I would encourage you to sit at the beach this weekend and have an excellent read of the supplement because we've provided you with a lot of good facts and proof points and information both around the Services businesses and the others about the early progress on the strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: TTS was able to fire, as I said, on all cylinders this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: About two-thirds of the performance was driven by business actions and one-third was by rates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark said, very active management of the deposit base, beta discipline across all the regions, and the NIR growth that you saw was driven by cards, by payments, by receivables, and by trade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When you look in the strategic drivers we laid out at Investor Day this quarter, cross- border transaction value up 17% year-over-year, clearing volume up 2% in US dollar, commercial comp spend up 62% as that business recovered, average trade loan balances up 14%, average deposit balances up 2%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that two-thirds that was not rates related has a very broad and substantive set of drivers behind it, that as Mark said, puts us into a very strong position for continued momentum here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This level of year-over-year growth is very pleasing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we would expect to see it revert to the medium term guidance we gave you at Investor Day over time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But, no, this was across the board all elements firing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I will give a shout out to Shahmir, the Head of TTS, as well as to our Security Services team.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But he has really instituted a culture of intensity, of tremendous focus, of discipline in how he is running the business as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think that is also a contributing factor to the confidence that you're hearing from us about this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, do you want to explain what TTS and Security Services is?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, as you've heard us describe, the TTS franchise is core to our business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It provides obviously a network to the large multinational clients in over 90 countries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We manage the full swath of their working capital and cash management needs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also provide trade financing for them and their vendors and partners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And this is essentially in many ways what differentiates our franchise from others.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And not only is it in and of itself a core growing high-returning business, but it's one of the businesses that is well connected to the rest of the franchise when you think about the Markets business that we have and the FX that we manage on behalf of clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so – and this is a particularly relevant time for us to be engaged with those partners as they manage through supply chain issues and we're there to again help them work through those things and provide them alternatives to their production and operations, and similar type services we provide to our investor client base from a Security Services point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the strategy here did not start with Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is, we obviously spent time with you talking about that, but this has been a part of the franchise that we've been investing in on an ongoing basis, and it's important that we continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investments in technology, investments in onboarding of new clients and the services we provide, in enhanced digital capabilities, in the operations, so all of those things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And some of that what you see here is those investments starting to pay off.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the same is exactly true in Security Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think the answer to your question is, no, we're just being very disciplined.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Well said.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Just a...

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: ...follow-up on the RWA.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: When you talk about the premium of the $3.5 billion, and can you help us just discern between what is a numerator impact and what's the RWA impact of the sales that have been announced?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And just as a related, just how far are you through the RWA optimization efforts, how much more could you really see doing there?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so the – thank you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The $3.5 billion I referenced is all capital, so all numerator impact is what I'm describing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's both the, you know, any premium that we get or impact gained from sale as well as the RWA that we have allocated as part of that business, and so that all kind of flows through from a numerator point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the case of Australia, for example, that would include both the RWA that we had attributed to that business as well as the CTA impact coming back into capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, remember, we took a hit when we signed the deal associated with the CTA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I kept communicating that that would neutralize when the deal was closed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, it did.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that contributes to the roughly $1.5 billion there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of RWA optimization efforts, it's a continuous effort.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are constantly working through the balance sheet to make sure that it's allocated to clients who generate the highest prospect for growth and leverage the breadth of the franchise, and we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think the team did a very good job in ICG and particularly in Markets this quarter in making sure that we made progress against the revenue to RWA metric that they've been using, which is a proxy for returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They worked very closely with clients to manage the recycling of trading inventory in a optimal way to optimize collateral positions and postings that we have to increase initial margins on derivative trading where that makes sense.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, they've been actively working the balance sheet, and we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We want to be there to serve our clients, but we want to make sure that we are generating an appropriate return for the use of capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's part of the shift that we've been instituting, Paco and Andy, in Markets and across ICG and across the firm in our commitment to our shareholders to be more returns focused and to be managing the business differently that way, and this is a very obvious example of that, because it's multi dimensional.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess just around capital, Mark, this is a two-part question.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: One, am I hearing you right that you're not going to leave the door open for buybacks until you get to 13%?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Appreciating what Jane said about some of the transitory impact from AOCI, why not be a bit more opportunistic?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And just tied to that, what's the risk that some of these deals get pushed out?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I see slide 19 where you've extended the timeline for a few deals.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Given just the macro backdrop, like, is that a real risk or do you feel pretty good about the updated timelines?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, I mean, we are obviously going to take it quarter-by-quarter as it relates to buybacks and from a capital point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, without going through all of the things that reflect the environment that we're in, you can see the uncertainty that's out there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, the capital requirements with this SCB for the industry are higher.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's unfortunate.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We feel as well the right amount of capital was in the industry already.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got to manage through that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's a reg requirement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're going to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we'll – SCB gives us the opportunity to take those decisions quarter-by quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're pausing for now.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And next year there will be another DFAST process, and there will be an SCB that comes out of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And frankly we should have the strength of higher PPNR that we've been generating to help contribute to what that outcome looks like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we'll take that quarter-by-quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of risk related to divestitures, again, we did highlight we're being very, very transparent with you all and with the world, and we do see some delays that we highlighted from our original schedule that's in the back of the presentation there, but we feel very good about getting to closure there, and it's not an if, it's a when, and we feel like we're on track with the schedule that we've highlighted for you.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And your next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: One more capital question.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So on slide 8, you do give the medium-term outlook here for what you see as your long-term goals for capital, the 11.5% to 12%.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And so, implicit within that is an expectation that your reg minimums would fall to somewhere 200 basis points or so, and I get that the exits will be part of that.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Is there a sense you can tell us, as you get more simplified, what the SCB benefit would be?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I thought it was something like 25 basis points, but I must be off there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I mean, the 11.5% to 12% is consistent with what we talked about at Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the medium-term, as you know, Betsy, for us is three to five years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got a couple of things that we're working through, not the least of which are the divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They will certainly contribute to that, but so will some of the other things that I've mentioned including utilization of the DTA, the AOCI pullback and things of that sort.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The divestitures certainly will help from an SCB point of view, but I think the stronger performance that we're seeing will aid in that as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And importantly, the mix change that we expect to come from executing on our strategy, a mix towards more sustainable, predictable earnings, earnings that are coming from some of the areas of growth that we demonstrated this quarter like TTS and Security Services, et cetera, et cetera.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, there's time there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's obviously a management buffer component of that that I think is certainly an important factor and consideration as we evolve our mix, and then there's the GSIB score with not only a reduction in the divestitures that will impact peak-to-trough losses, there's also deposits that will go away with those and balance sheet evolution that will contribute to a reduction in the GSIB score as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, let me just underline a couple of points.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When we built our strategy, it wasn't only to generate greater returns, but it was to lower our capital requirements over time as Mark said.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see how we're executing that both in terms of the shift in mix and the divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, we don't control the regulatory capital framework, but we're not managing for short-term shifts in SCB.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, the banks experience considerable variability in the SCB each year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's very much depending on the scenario chosen.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that's why we continue with our commitment and confidence around the medium-term.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Hey Steven.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So, I had a follow-up question for, arguably for Mark on NII.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: As the Fed continues down the path of balance sheet normalization, I just wanted to clarify whether that $1.8 billion increase in NII you cited for the back half assumes stable deposits or some QT-related attrition.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And within ICG specifically, are there any insights you can share on what drove the increase in Markets NII and how that should traject just given the historical liability sensitivity within the Markets business?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the first point, when I think about the back half of the year and quantitative tightening, I do expect that we will see some continued deposit growth, as I mentioned earlier.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The pressure from quantitative tightening I think will certainly play out over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, our focus is on growing the operating deposits that we have with clients, and we think we've got good traction and ability to continue momentum with those operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, they put us in a position to really broaden the relationship with both those multi-national clients as well as with some of our commercial clients where we've been getting good growth and momentum from.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, yes, likely would be an impact across the industry, but we believe we can get some continued momentum particularly on the operating deposits that we have with clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of Markets NII, I mean, you've got the European dividend that plays out in the second quarter, so that obviously is a factor there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, I'd point you to – when we talk about Markets, I really like to talk about total revenues, because the nature of the security and the trading and the activity that we do there can have an impact on NII and NIR, and what really matters is the total revenues that we're driving and generating out of that franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you can see, we did 25% growth in Markets revenue year over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So a very good quarter for the Markets team for sure.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: Can you elaborate on your comment about why the Russia exposure is kind of less of a risk or it's a better mix than it was a few months ago?

speaker: Connor
sentence: And then maybe related to that, quantify how much of the $8.4 billion is to subsidiaries of MNCs which does seem like it'd be much, much lower risk?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, what we've been doing very actively since the beginning of the year and certainly in the quarter as well has been working – we've been working to bring down our exposure in Russia and specifically with the clients that we serve there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that direct exposure in a local currency dollars, we brought down by some $900 million or so in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We brought down and reduced the cash and deposits that we have by another $1.7 billion or so, and then continued to bring down third-party related exposure by another $400 million, and that's been through working with clients to pay those exposures and loans down, and in some instances giving them incentives to do so and incentives to move their deposits out as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, very active engagement from the team as it relates to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What's happened with that is the mix of the exposure that we have or that remains has skewed towards the higher-quality names and towards the global subsidiaries that we have in the country.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, with that mix shift to better quality names and the reduction in exposure, that's allowed for us to take down the reserves that we had related to the direct exposure in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that has been, I think, very good progress in terms of that reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It gets overshadowed a bit with the ruble impact, but we've made good progress and we're going to continue to actively do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Approximately – Jane, do you want to jump in on that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, yeah, no, I was going to jump in in terms of just sort of overall, let's be very clear.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are systematically crunching down the size of our franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark says, the severe stress loss scenario is probably the best indicator of that, which is now roundabout the $2 billion, and materially reduced down.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we completely changed the nature of our exposure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Particularly when you think about today, most of our clients are multinationals, and many of the exposures there have parent guarantees against them, which is very helpful.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What are we doing with them?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Many of them, that we're helping them with their exit from the countries.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that obviously, as you can all appreciate, takes some time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, for those that are able to exit swiftly, that's another factor that can help us reduce down our exposure presence and indeed our operations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There are also others, though, that it is harder.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we've all seen how difficult it is to disconnect the Russian economy from the West in a couple of key sectors, in particular food and in particular energy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you can imagine, given the nature of our bank, we've been in the middle of some of those flows that are essential for the West and the multinationals that are supporting it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, you have a bit of a blended story here in terms of, yes, we're helping those that connects to exit, but we're also still playing the role that we have to and have been asked to in maintaining some of those flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We anticipate that they will continue to reduce over time as the energy and food security issues get addressed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's a complex environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And bottom line, you can hear us, we're pleased with how this has been managed by our teams.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Hey, Gerard.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, can you share with us, both of you addressed in your opening remarks about the impact the market conditions had on Investment Banking and your peers have seen it as well.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: If the market conditions remain this way in the second half of the year and into 2023, just for Investment Banking, not Markets, your trading business, when do you guys have to take a sharper pencil to the expenses in that division, or do you just let it run?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Maybe I kick off and then pass it over to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, strategic advice is central to the vision to being the preeminent banking partner for multinational firms.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are continuing to strategically invest in talent and in the platform.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You can expect us to continue doing so, with a particular focus on the tech, healthcare, and financial services sectors, because those are ones where it is a decade-long shift that we're going to see in their importance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've brought in some very strong bankers there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It obviously takes a few years to build share, build out the client relationships, and to see the full fruits of those investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're also focused on the broader opportunity by leveraging investments in commercial banking, I'm sure Mark will talk about that as well, and in Markets and the connectivity there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think you're going to see us take a strategic look at this and a long-term look rather than just a shooting from the hip on the expenses side, because we're building the firm for the long-term here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll certainly be incredibly disciplined around expenses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've seen that with us this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've talked about what we'll do on expenses across the board in the firm as we become simpler in tackling stranded costs, our organization structure, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we're very serious about the investments that we're making into some of the core talent in these areas, and you shouldn't be expecting us to make any significant material shifts right or left on this one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're deadly serious.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane, I think that's well said.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I would add is that the business is capital light and is high returning through the cycle, and so we see a lot of value there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We want to be prepared to ramp up when activity starts again, and as you've said, it's quite strategic for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Since you kind of wound me up on the commercial banking activity, I have to jump at it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We had, as you know, Jane, a very strong quarter in commercial banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When I look at the revenue momentum there, just kind of leveraging the breadth of the franchise, we're probably up 25% to 30% in revenues in that part of the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I know that's part of our – as you know, that's part of our core growth strategy that we talked about at Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, good momentum in that part of the franchise as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And obviously they're benefits for our Investment Banking colleagues as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Those synergies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Important synergies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Jane, a question for you on Mexico.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Given the comments of the Mexican President, would that limit the price that a buyer would be willing to pay, and what's your sort of minimum price that you're willing to accept?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And what's Plan B if the prices being bid don't meet that hurdle?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Oh, Vivek, I'm not going to answer your question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I'll give you a few comments on Mexico nonetheless.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're pleased with the interest in our Mexican franchise based on the discussions with the buyers, and the franchise is performing well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's more than maintaining its value.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's contributing nicely to our financial results.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's still very early in this process.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So when we have news for you, we will obviously convey that to you swiftly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's early days.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you'd expect with a transaction of this nature, we need to work through a variety of regulatory and legal proceedings.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're actively doing so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're working hard on separating our market-leading institutional franchise, which is a key part of our global network, taking the time necessary to do that the right way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we have a variety of different options that we can always look at.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's far too early in the process here to speculate, but so far so good.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Andrew Lim with Société Générale.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: I guess I'd like to have a better view from you on your outlook on recession.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: It is difficult to reconcile how investors feel about recession.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: It is obviously quite negative, and seemingly a lot more negative than it was about a quarter ago.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: But when we look at you and at some of your peers, the delta on the recession outlook seems only a little bit worse than it was one quarter ago.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: So, I was just wondering how you think about recession, because some of the investors that we talk to, they look at the savings ratio, it's back to pre-pandemic levels.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: They look at mortgage affordability and it's really quite dire.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: And the perception they have is obviously perhaps inconsistent with the way you're looking at recession.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: So perhaps you can give us a bit of color as to how you're thinking about things.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, I'll kick it off, pass it to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, as we've talked about, the current macro environment is kind of shaped by the three Rs; Russia, rates and recession.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it depends where in the world you are as to which one's prevailing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the US, we're more concerned about rates than imminent recession.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The consumer and the corporate are healthy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The labor market is exceedingly tight.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are increasingly concerned about the possibility of a recession next year.
