speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So overall, while the market environment remains challenging and there is more work to be done, we are making progress against our strategy in ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to Slide 12, we show the results for our Personal Banking & Wealth Management business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 6%, driven by net interest income growth of 7%, partially offset by a 6% decline in non interest revenue, driven by lower investment product revenues in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 5%, predominantly driven by risk and control investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.6 billion, driven by higher net credit losses as we continue to see normalization in our card portfolios and a reserve build of $335 million, primarily driven by card balance growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 7% driven by cards, mortgages and installment lending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits decreased 1%, largely reflecting our Wealth clients putting cash to work in fixed income investments on our platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And PBWM delivered an RoTCE of 5.5%, both for this quarter and through the first half of 2023, largely reflecting the challenging environment for Wealth and higher credit costs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 13, we show PBWM revenues by product as well as key business drivers and metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues were up 8%, primarily driven by higher net interest income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to see strong underlying drivers with new account acquisitions up 6%, card spend volumes up 4% and average loans up 14%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues were up 27%, driven by higher net interest income and lower partner payments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For both Card portfolios, we continue to see payment rates decline, and that combined with the investments we have been making contributed to growth in interest-earning balances of 17% in Branded Cards and 12% in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues decreased 9%, reflecting the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits to our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, consistent with our strategy, we continued to leverage our retail network to drive 25,000 Wealth referrals year-to-date through May, up 18% YoY.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues were down 5%, driven by continued investment fee headwinds and higher deposit costs, particularly in the Private Bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, Wealth at Work revenues were up over 30%, driven by strong lending results, primarily in mortgages.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Client advisors were down 1%, reflecting the re-pacing of strategic hiring.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And new client acquisitions were up nearly 40% in the Private Bank and approximately 60% in Wealth-at momentum in underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 14, we show results for Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were down 1%, as the benefit of higher rates and volumes in Mexico was more than offset by the reductions from closed consumer exits and wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is worth noting that -FX.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 2%, primarily driven by closed consumer exits and wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divestiture-related impacts, expenses decreased 8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 15, we show results for Corporate Other for the second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased, largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses also increased, driven by inflation and severance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: maintaining our full-year revenue guidance of $78 - $79 billion, excluding 2023 divestiture-related impacts, although the mix has shifted somewhat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are increasing our net interest income guidance from $45 billion to slightly above $46 billion for the full year excluding Markets, offset by lower non-interest revenue, largely driven by Investment Banking and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are also maintaining our expense guidance of roughly $54 billion, excluding 2023 divestiture-related impacts and the FDIC special assessment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net credit losses in Cards should continue to normalize in the remainder of the year, with both portfolios reaching normalized levels by year-end.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we now expect the full-year tax rate to be approximately 25%, excluding discrete items and divestiture-related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As it relates to the third quarter, we expect continued momentum with clients, including fees, and benefits from US and non-US rates on NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also anticipate a sequential increase in expenses, driven by continued investments in Transformation and risk and controls.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net credit losses in Cards should continue to normalize in line with expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our effective tax rate for the quarter should be approximately 25%, excluding discrete items and divestiture-related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as it relates to buybacks, we will continue to make that decision on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to execute on the strategy to simplify our firm, improve our revenue mix and bring both expenses and capital down over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are seeing solid momentum in the underlying drivers of the majority of our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we said at Investor Day, the financial path will not be linear, but we remain focused on achieving our medium-term RoTCE target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, I'm very curious on the whole revenue to RWA topic, especially with some of the changes coming in.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So maybe you could give a little more color on -- let's take, for instance, the further reduction in subscription credit facilities.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I think I read somewhere that was like an $80 billion book down to $20 billion.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: You can correct that if that's wrong.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But just usually, those things are big important clients that have relationship lending, things attached to them.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, I'm curious on how you balance the capital benefit, the clear capital benefit, versus client impact and how you think about that?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Are there other blocks of business that are in motion right now?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks Glenn and good morning, and thanks for the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, a couple of points on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is we've been very focused on the revenue to RWA metric in our Markets business in the ICG more broadly as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we've made considerable progress on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's important because how we use the balance sheet and ensuring that we're optimizing the use of the balance sheet contributes to how we improve returns over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You're right to point out the subscription facility, credit facility, lending that we do.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We brought that down pretty significantly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The numbers you highlight are a lot higher than the portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what's important here is that as we look at that, we look at a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, the nature of relationship and whether clients are taking advantage of the breadth of what we have to offer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Two, the profitability and returns associated with the product to the extent that it is in a broader relationship, and where those returns are low, subpar, and the prospect for doing more has proven to be fruitless, we take it down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's what we've done with a large part of that book, just as we juxtapose it against other opportunities to use balance sheet where clients are taking advantage of the broader franchise and therefore, are generating higher returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've done that to drive the revenue to RWA metric.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've done it selectively on pieces of the portfolio like SCF.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've also looked at our broader corporate lending portfolio and where those promises for higher relationship returns aren't manifesting themselves, we've not renewed those loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we think about pending regulatory changes, proactively making these efforts becomes critically important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When I look back on the activity that we've done over the past couple of years, we've reduced RWA by approximately $120 billion over the last 2 years, and about 75% of that is predominantly driven by balance sheet optimization and looking at client activity that has low margin business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so,this is important for us to do and to keep doing.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate that, Mark.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Maybe just a quick follow-up.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: On NII, I asked this last quarter too.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And your first half annualized ex-Markets is running about $1.5 billion ahead of the guide.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Is that just unpredictable nature all the moving parts, trying to be conservative or anything else in the back half that you're thinking about?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did take guidance up to slightly above $46 billion from the $45 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I guess there are a couple of things ex-Markets, of course.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are a couple of things to think about in terms of headwinds and tailwinds that play through there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is you've heard me mention before that we've reached terminal betas in the U.S. Two, deposit volumes and the shift mix as we see consumers kind of move into higher-returning type, higher-yielding type products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And three, really the wind-downs and the exits and the reduction that they will play out in terms of NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So those are kind of 3 headwinds as we think about the forecast and the balance of year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are obviously some potential tailwinds that play to the other side, including rate movements in non-U.S. dollar as well as Card volume growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we look at those headwinds and tailwinds, our current read is to take it up, but $46 billion or slightly above that feels like the right level in the context of total revenues at $78 billion to $79 billion.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global Securities.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe just getting on the expense side.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You're keeping Mexico until 2025 now at the earliest.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So that will be on the books longer.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How do we think about that bend the curve discussion?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And maybe specifically, you can help us think about bending the curve for the non-legacy businesses.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Do we start to see is the fourth quarter just a slowing or quarterly decline?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Is it a year-over-year kind of a discussion?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I just want to make sure I understand the whole bend the curve notion and how to think about that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Let me take that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd say a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, I'd reiterate the expense guidance that we've given for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's the roughly $54 billion ex-divestitures, or the impact of divestitures, ex-any impact from FDIC special assessment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Two, as we think about bending the curve, I look into 2024 and we're looking to bring the absolute expense dollars down from Q3 to Q4.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that bending of the curve will occur.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It will occur despite having Mexico still part of the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And obviously still having Mexico impacts the magnitude of the bend, but it will bend Q3 to Q4.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then beyond that and through the medium term, we will see the curve continue to bend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, Mexico impacts the magnitude of the bend, but we're very, very focused on bringing our costs down and bending that curve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you've heard us reference the aspects or the elements of our business that help contribute to that, not the least of which are the exits, one of which is Mexico, and you referenced the timing there, but also the benefits from investments that we've been making in transformation and risk controls and shifting from manual processes to technology-enabled ones.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the final one is around simplifying our organization.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you heard in Jane's prepared remarks, as we continue to make progress on these exits, it opens up the opportunity for us to lean more heavily into that simplification.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we are focused on not only the guidance, but the bending of the curve as you point out and looking forward to delivering that and taking actions to ensure we do.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So just as a follow-up, is the way to think about sort of 2025 and beyond as you get through a lot the automation on the sort of the non-legacy businesses and start to get much more efficient there.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Is there an absolute expense decline story in the core business?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Or is that more that you need the top line growth to get the improved returns?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, it's going to be a combination of continuing to bend the curve and bring our expenses down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, we've given you guidance on operating efficiency of less than 60%, which will be some of that top line growth, but it's the combination of the two.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I just wanted to confirm on the CET1.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: You know you have the 100-basis point buffer on top of regulatory minimums.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So that would suggest that the 13.3% that you got this quarter is in-line with where you're planning on holding it going forward, is that fair?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, you're right, we hit 13.3% this quarter, down a tad bit from the 13.4% last quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Effective October 1, the 4.3% SCB comes into play.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that would equate to, assuming the 100-basis point management buffer, a 12.3% regulatory requirement and a 13.3% kind of target that we would manage to.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd highlight a couple of things that I'm sure are obvious to you, Betsy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is this is the stress capital buffer for the 12-month period starting October 1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And two is the strategy that we've described and talked about and have started to execute against is intentionally designed to help morph the business towards a more steady, predictable, consistent stream of revenues, fee revenue growth as well bring our expenses down over time, and exit these markets, and those things should contribute to reducing our stress capital buffer over time and improving our returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But the answer to your question very directly is, yes, the 13.3% would reflect where we'd be targeting as of October 1 for now.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And since you mentioned you're evaluating buybacks quarter-by-quarter.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I guess the question here is, how should I think about that relative to, we get Basel endgame coming out soon because clearly, when you re at 13.3% against the new reg cap SCB, you know it signals a bigger opportunity for buybacks over the coming quarters.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So how should I think about that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think that consistent with what we've been talking about, there's a lot of uncertainty out there about the new capital requirements, both in terms of the nature of them and the timing of implementation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the industry is expecting to get more clarity about that with the comment period that will be coming up.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Plus, it's a fairly uncertain macroeconomic environment at the moment, so both Mark and I feel it's prudent to continue making that assessment until some of this uncertainty is clarified as to what precisely do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You should take confidence that we're at the levels, including the management buffer that we expect to be for the rest of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've proven a good case of being able to build capital that's for sure over the last 2 years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you take comfort as well we increased the dividend, we had $2 billion of capital returned last quarter, so our intentions are clear to return capital where we can, but also to be prudent in how we do so, given environment and current regulatory uncertainty.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: One negative question, one positive question.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, on the negative side, you talked about bending the cost curve, but I think second quarter year-over-year, it's bending the wrong way, and 6 quarters from now, you're saying it should bend the other way.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, what are we not seeing in the financials that gives you such confidence?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Because it seems, based on this quarter's results, a little bit more of a trust me story.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And on the positive side, TTS, continued double-digit growth, you continue to invest more in that business, how are you monetizing greater money in motion among your multinational and other clients?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thanks Mike, I'll kick it off and then send it back to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the expense side, I think we've been very transparent about the arc of our investment spend related both to the transformation and beyond.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll continue to give you that transparency, Mike.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Note last year, we hit our expense guidance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This year, we're on track for the guidance of roughly the $54 billion, ex-FDIC and divestitures and looking forward, we continue to guide what are the 3 levers that will drive the reduction in the expense curve starting at the end of '24.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's from exits and I think you've got a clear sense around the progress that we have been making on the divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And therefore, we're pivoting, as we talked about, to focus now on really tackling the stranded expenses as we close off the final couple of sales there in Asia in the next few months.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll realize the benefits from our investments in transformation and controls over the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll also have the benefit of the remediation work getting done and expenses going away from that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then the third one will be simplifying the organization, as we talked about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we'll continue to walk you, step by step, what are the different actions we're taking, what are we doing, and hopefully we are building up that track record of doing what we will say we are going to do every quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, anything to add?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: n the expense side, and then you may want to touch on the TTS, but the only add on the expense side is, we are taking repositioning charges, Mike.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean we're not sitting still as we go through this uncertain period of time where wallets across certain parts of the industry are under significant pressure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in taking those repositioning charges, there are going to be expense reductions that ultimately play out over the next 12-month period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's the other factor in addition to what Jane mentioned in the way of exits and benefits from the transformation that will play into the cost base over the next 12 months.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then on TTS, I think we all share your enthusiasm for this business in terms of the growth potential that we've been realizing and expect to continue, albeit converging now to the medium-term guidance over the next few quarters where we see it's a high to medium single-digit growth going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a very high-returning business and some of the indicators of how we're monetizing those relationships.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing it both in terms of new client wins, they were up 41% this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a sustained win-loss ratio of 80% on the new deals across different client segments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're also seeing growth that's starting to really kick in from our commercial bank and the expansion of clients in the middle market around the world as we grow out that franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've got some very good fee-growth, which as Mark points out, and I point out all the time, we're very focused around, so cross-border up 11% U.S. dollar clearing up 6%, commercial cards up 15%, etc.. And we continue to invest in the business as well, so to make sure that 80%-win ratio continues.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, first bank to launch 24/7, 365 dollar clearing, U.S. dollar clearing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got the instant payments platform we just launched for e-commerce clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have Payments Express that is now live in the U.S., on track for 5 markets by the year-end.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's a story of innovation investment, it's got great returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a good growth story, and it just, it keeps on going.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I don't want to diminish Securities Services in there either.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's another business that's, similarly, continuing to see significant client wins, up 65% versus last year as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And a lot of our strategy there has been focused on gaining share with the asset managers in North America.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Couple of years ago, we're down at 2.6% share.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're up about 4.3%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our target is about 5.5% there in 2025 in that key growth area.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I know there's a lot to like here too.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, I apologize having to ask the expense question again, but I think it's just very important because there's really two potential long-only investment thesis on Citi, right?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: One is the buyback given your tangible book values at $85 and the and the stock at $46 other is the spending the curve on expenses.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So let me just ask Jim's question another way.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: In looking back to 2017, and I'm just looking at 2017 because I can break out legacy and core that way.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And fast forward to 2022, you produced revenues ex Legacy Franchises about $61 billion in 2017 and about $67 billion in 2022.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: The associated expenses, again, without Legacy Franchises was about $34.5 billion in billion in 2017 versus $43.5 billion 2022, so you're surpassing the revenue uplift during that period by $3 billion.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I guess the question is, you have so much certainty about the timing of this expense and I'm wondering how much of this $9 billion can go away?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: We understand that there's a lot of opportunity for reinvestment in the core business, but I think all of us are struggling to really understand that magnitude.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I think that the investor base in the market fully understands the Legacy Franchise story and how the exits will take time.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: But I think they're most interested in the core business and how much of that can come out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, no need to apologize for asking the question again, it's an important topic.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd say a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one is that we can certainly look back in time, but I would highlight that we're here because we needed to have invested more in our franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so undoubtedly, there's going to be an increase in our expense base that reflects the underinvestment from the past and in shoring up safety and soundness and actually moving towards a more automated operational, more modernized operations and infrastructure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, there's certainly going to be that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, with those investments come efficiencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, with the move from manual to automation over time, those types of investments will yield benefits in our cost structure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's part of what is going to bend the curve over that medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other thing that I'd highlight is, obviously, with the Legacy Franchises, there's $7 billion of expense associated with those, and that will come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But because of the Mexico transaction, we're going to be stuck with that a little bit longer given the IPO process.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It doesn't put a big dent in our ability to bring stranded costs down and by the way, it does come with top line revenues and historically has been accretive to our profitability and returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I'm not going to give you kind of new guidance on where our expenses will end up.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what I will point you to is not only the $54 billion this year, roughly $54 billion this year, not only the bending of the curve in the third and fourth quarter or the third to the fourth quarter next year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we've given guidance on top line growth, revenue of 5% call it CAGR through that medium-term period, and we've given you kind of operating efficiency targets that we've said as well, and we intend to deliver on those things that reflect the bending of that curve through all of those drivers that we've mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I hope that helps, Erika.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I appreciate the focus on both capital and expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are equally focused on it and know just how important it is to achieving those targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're not only kind of doing the things that we've highlighted in that strategy articulation, but we're also being responsive to the current environment that we're in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We think that aids in our ability to deliver the targets and the bending of the curve, and we know there's an additional opportunity that Jane has referenced to the simplification of the organization as we make -- what I would argue is considerable progress on the exits towards the end of this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And all of those things will be important to ensuring we get to that lower cost base, which we will do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's a laser micro focus from us to make sure that we have the plans in place and the execution to be able to achieve it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is something we're extremely hands-on around and making sure that, going to get done on each of the different drivers that Mark talked about.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And just a follow-up on that.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I guess, you guys have been you guys have been pretty clear on the timing, and pretty clear on why the curve will bend.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I guess I'm wondering, is it just a timing issue that you're not giving us the sort of the dollar numbers that could go away from the transformation?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Is it just a timing issue?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Or are you still at a point where you don't know how much of that you would need to reinvest to arrive at that 5% revenue CAGR?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sorry, your question was around expenses or the revenue?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Expenses.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, we get loud and clear why the curve will bend.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: We get loud and clear when the curve will bend, right?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And there's clearly just expenses there that are catch-up expenses that are transformational expenses to everything that Jane talked about.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And that message has been loud and clear.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I'm wondering if you haven't told us what could come out of those expenses because it's just a timing issue, it's July 14th versus 4Q'24?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Or have you not yet made decisions in terms of how you may allocate those expenses in terms of do you need some of those expenses that could come out to grow your revenue base to that 5% CAGR versus having it fall to the bottom line?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Sorry, that's the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I'd say a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, Erika, is obviously, with that revenue CAGR will be volume-related expenses that play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we're also focused, obviously, on the non-volume-related expenses and not giving you a precise number because the magnitude of that bend, right, is a factor, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So obviously, Mexico, for example, as I mentioned earlier, impacts the magnitude of the bend, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're going to, and have, in fact, when you look at our expense base even for the quarter, we've spent money in Mexico to drive that top line 22% revenue growth, 10% ex-FX.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, there are going to be nuances in the running of the business in a way that ensures we're maximizing shareholder value that impacts the magnitude of the bending of that that expense curve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investments that I got to continue to make in in TTS order to maintain that #1 position and that that competitive advantage we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those things will impact that magnitude of the bend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been, I think, very transparent as we get into each year, giving you concrete numbers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I'm telling you is the curve will bend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we get closer to 2024, we'll give you more direction on the magnitude for that year and beyond.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Wanted to ask a question on capital.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Just given the recent increase in your SCB, I was hoping to better understand why the 11.5% to 12% remains the appropriate long-term objective in your mind?

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And as we prepare for Basel III endgame, think through the capital benefit from future asset sales, can you speak to whether that will translate into operational risk capital relief specifically as it's less clear whether those benefits will accrete even as those asset sales are consummated?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'll kick it off, Mark, and then pass it to you.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we're confident we're going to meet 11% to 12% RoTCE target over the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The core drivers of how we get there remains unchanged.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One, it's the revenues that we expect to grow by 4% to 5% CAGR as we continue to execute on the strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: On expenses, it's the clear path to bend the curve by the end 2024, bringing those expenses down over the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And third and importantly, it's continuing to optimize our balance sheet, including improving RWA and capital efficiency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as we referenced earlier in the prepared remarks, different drivers in that, that are helpful, exiting 14 international consumer markets, changing our business mix.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd also note that the transformation has benefits not only for our efficiency, but it will also support RWA and capital optimization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That said, there's uncertainty around the future capital requirements in the industry and importantly, the timing of their implementation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We like everyone again to have to work through those implications once we know what they are.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But as we said, keep in mind, we've got some other levers to pull over time, capital allocation, DTA allocation and utilization, our G-SIB score and our management buffer of 100 basis points.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that's where you hear the confidence from us around the path to executing and that remaining consistent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But Mark, why don't I hand over to you just around consumer market sales and operational RWA relief.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, I think that if you look at the transactions that we've closed to date, they've generated or freed up about $4.6 billion of capital the two that remain to be closed and the balance of year will generate another $1.2 billion or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That will be important to our capital base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that we obviously have to see the proposal as it comes out and the NPR.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we'll have a window to respond to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're hopeful that the regulators hear our response and views on it as it comes out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's clearly going to be reference to increases in RWA and operational risk implications potentially as part of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I do think that exiting, without having seen the proposal, and without obviously knowing how those rules might evolve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I do believe that the exiting of these 14 markets does play towards not only reducing our SCB in stress scenarios or as it comes out of stress analysis and tests, but also should play through helping to reduce risk-weighted assets and potentially operational risk as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we have to see what the proposal looks like and go through that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think what's important here is that whenever it comes out, whatever it looks like, as we dissect it and go through it, we'll figure out how to manage through it, right, whether that be through exiting certain products, seeking price adjustments as it relates to customers, clients and the markets or continuing to optimize RWAs and we have been doing very proactively, we'll figure out how to manage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I feel compelled to jump in here as well because as the spring and the recent test results showed the large U.S. banks are not only in a strong capital position, but we've been able to play an important stabilizing role for the system as a whole.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a role that we take very seriously.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we certainly hope that as the details of the capital frameworks get unveiled, this is fully taken into consideration, including the impact on U.S. competitiveness, and we need a level playing field with Europe, not a gold-plated one, and we share the concern that higher capital levels will undoubtedly increase the cost of capital for medium- and smaller sized enterprises and consumers in particular and will drive more activity to non-regulated and lesser capitalized players that isn't in the system's interest.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we hope that that's fully taken into consideration here because we will take actions on businesses, and we will take pricing actions as will the entire industry.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Really important point.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Thanks for that perspective, Jane, very well said.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Just one quick follow-up for me.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: PBWM fee income trends, given the lower partner payments, I mean clearly the Wealth fee trends would suggest that they were quite subdued in the quarter.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And I just wanted to understand your outlook over the near medium term what drove some of the weakness this quarter?

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Is it something that you expect will likely persist, especially given some of the market tailwinds that we've been seeing, would have expected to see a little bit more resiliency in Wealth fee income in particular.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I think as we mentioned, Wealth was down about 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's really hard to talk the rebound in Wealth in the midst of such an uncertain environment and the one that we're in, it's hard to disconnect those macro factors like rates, inflation, the prospect of a recession from what we're seeing in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think there are two dynamics that have played out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One has been the shift from our customers, from customers more broadly into higher-yielding products from out of deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the other has been the fee revenue from an investment management fee point of view, and as you might think about it, it is a higher rate environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are opportunities for clients to earn more.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And not until there's greater certainty in the broader macro factors will I think we start to see some real momentum tick up there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now with that said, and a couple of things worth reiterating, which is we're seeing very strong referral momentum from the Retail Banking business up through wealth continuum, if you will.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we've had about 25,000 referrals May year-to-date from our retail branches into our broader Wealth business, that's a good thing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen the number of clients that we've onboarded tick up pretty meaningfully, both in the Private Bank and more broadly across Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's a good thing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Those are things that that position us well for when greater certainty does play out and these clients start to put monies back to work in the broader investment platform and offering that we have.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just one quick question, Mark, for you.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: On the consumer cards book, you gave some metrics.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: One, remind us of what you reserved for in terms of unemployment rate, macro, and if we do see a worsening in the markets, does that necessarily mean that we'll see big ratcheting up of credit reserves from where you already are?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just some color around that would be helpful.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sorry, just the last part of your question, I'm sorry, if we do see what?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: So, one, like where are you in terms of your unemployment rate assumption?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And if the unemployment outlook worsens, let's say, over the next 6 to 12 months, does that mean that you are already reserved?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Or will we see another big pickup in provisioning as a result of that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, our current reserves, as you know, as we think about CECL, we've got 3 different scenarios, we've got a base case in upside, a downside.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our current reserves are based on the mix of those 3 macroeconomic scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It reflects about a 5.1% unemployment rate on a weighted basis over the 8 quarters, and it's roughly flat to what it was last quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What that means is, obviously, our downside scenario has unemployment that's much higher than that, closer to 7% or call it 6.8% or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But that's kind of how we've thought about unemployment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we think about the reserves each quarter, obviously, we take a look at the macroeconomic factors and how they're evolving.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our base case today assumes a mild recession and reserves in the future will consider how are weighting towards downside, upside and baseline may morph subject to our outlook and volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Those are the 2 factors that influence whether we're increasing reserves or not.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would point out though that in addition to unemployment and because has been as stubborn as it has been, if you will, we also look at debt service coverage ratio as an important factor as we think about our consumers, as we think about their balance sheet, as we think about the risk that they may or may not be facing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So unemployment is an important factor, but we've flexed our thinking in light of the environment and in light of how behaviors have been shifting, and that's an important factor in how we think about our reserves as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I feel very good about the level of our reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You heard us mention earlier, we've got $20 billion of reserves, we're well reserved across the portfolio, but those are all important elements to it.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: That's helpful.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And just one very simplistic question.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: When you talk to some of your largest shareholders, those who are optimistic think you can hit your RoTCE target medium term by 2025.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Is that a realistic expectation given I appreciate Basel changes, you answered like 10 questions on expenses.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: But should we expect the groundwork through '24 that we hit that medium-term target in w25 or just your degree of confidence.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, the thing I'd point out and Jane, feel free to chime in here, is that what we talked about was getting to our medium-term returns, 11% to 12% and the medium term is 25 to 26, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So it's not just 25, just to be clear.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we do continue to feel very confident around our ability to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You heard us mention the levers that we think will contribute to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, capital is important and how that evolves, and we continue to kind of work to optimize the balance sheet while serving our clients effectively and importantly, growing the strong businesses that we have that are high returning as well.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: You have mentioned continued normalization of credit card in the back half of the year.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And just wondering, you've got the normalized loss rates on Slide 22.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Are you still thinking you'll hit those, I think, exiting this year or early next year.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And then I think at one point, you said they might go a little bit above that before they kind of come back to a normal level?

speaker: Operator
sentence: And is that still the case?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The answer is yes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We still expect for both portfolios to hit those normal levels sometime at the end of the year, the normal level, as you pointed out, on the page for both Branded as well as for Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We would expect, again, subject to how and when this mild recession kind of plays out, we would expect that they would tick higher than that before getting back inside of that range.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, all of this is tied into how we've calculated our reserves, the delinquencies that we're seeing, the mix of the portfolio, which again skews towards your higher FICO scores and the customer behaviors that we're seeing, which play through not only that cost of credit line, but also plays through the growth that we referenced earlier in the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But short answer is yes, that's still our thinking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark said, I think we feel good about our positioning as a prime, but also a strong credit proposition that we have.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing stronger demand for the credit-led products such as value cards, bulk on installment loans as well the service-led engagement for the more prime customers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so that's also going to be a valuable factor driving growth and profitability as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then the follow-up, and this is not really Citi-specific, but for the card industry, a lot of the banks that are in card.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Everyone is talking about kind of getting to normalized levels, just call it in the near term here next couple of quarters.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I guess, just thoughts on getting this normalized level of losses when unemployment is all-time low, wages are growing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, there's inflationary pressures, but it's just a little surprising, again, not to Citi-specific, but it's a little surprising that we're getting to this normalized state when things seem like they're pretty good.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yes, I think well, also normalized state back in 2019 was also pretty good.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you're not hearing any alarm bells ringing from Mark or myself at all here on the U.S. consumer, I think we see the U.S. consumer as resilient, we've talked about them being cautious but they're not recessionary.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are seeing more pressure on the lower FICOs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't have a large number of that in our portfolio, but that is where we're seeing more of the normalization happening on the payment rates, for example, and other behaviors in there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's quite localized, but I don't think we should be overly concerned here about the health of the U.S. consumer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark said, we're in a very unusual environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Higher inflation, these rate levels and a strong labor market.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And under those conditions, it's the debt service ratio, as he said, that is, we think, is a more useful leading indicator that we keep a close eye on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Just remember, it's a return to normal.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, can you share with us, in your financial supplement, obviously, you give us good details on your credit picture and we're talking about credit right now.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: The nonaccrual loans have been flat as a pancake for the last 12 months for you folks and the industry as well.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And this is in light of the Fed funds rates, as we all know, have been up over 500 basis points.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you guys share with us why we haven't seen more, this is mostly corporate of course, but everybody has been hanging in there very well in view of the fact that rates have gone up so much.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What are your customers telling you or are you seeing that has enabled them to remain very healthy in light of a 500-basis point increase in interest rates?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think I'd point to a couple of things, Gerard.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is, remember, we focus on the large multinational, largely investment-grade quality names.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's one important factor when you think about our ICG and corporate exposure there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing I'd point out is we have to remember that many of these companies had and still have very strong balance sheets and that they've managed that through the COVID and pandemic situation and that has positioned them well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the third thing is that and you've heard us mention how we're proactively managing the prospect of a recession.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think when I talk to other CFOs, I know that when Jane talks to other CEOs, they too are looking at their expense line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They too are looking at the efficiency of their organizations and opportunity to increase that efficiency in light of a potential slowdown or recessionary environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the final point is, I think a lot of firms have been that were proactive in the low-rate environment, in shoring up that balance sheet strength.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now with that said, you've heard us also mention the prospect of a rebound in capital market activities, and that has to happen at some point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But sticking to your point around credit, I really think it's those factors that you see play through in not only our very low NAL, but also our very low credit losses, credit cost that you've seen in our business.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then as a follow-up, when you think about what we've seen with the Fed's tightening over the last 12 months, banks like your own have positioned the balance sheet accordingly and I know the Bank Analysts Association of Boston, Michael [Verdeschi] did a good job explaining how you guys manage the balance sheet.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And when you look at it going forward, do you think changes are coming because the Fed if they end in Fed funds rate increase as we get to a terminal rate, how are you guys positioned the balance sheet, do you think going forward?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, we're constantly actively managing the balance sheet in light of not only our client needs, but also how we see the broader macro environment evolving and changing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you know, and I know you've seen and we've talked about before, we share in our Qs, our view on our estimate for interest rate exposure and what happens with 100 basis points swing in rates in one direction or another across the curve across currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've seen that shift over the last number of quarters to last quarter where that estimate for IRE was about $1.7 billion or so, but heavily skewed towards non-U.S. dollar rates and currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think as we think about the view on how rates will evolve, you'll see a continued shift there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that that when we look to print this quarter, number will probably come down a bit in terms of interest rate exposure and skew even more towards non-U.S. dollar currencies in light of where rates are in those markets and the U.S. dollar will likely be somewhat neutral in light of that curve currently looks like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, something we actively manage, first with an eye towards what client demand and needs are likely to be for use of our liquidity but also with a view for how the macro environment might evolve and what we're hearing from central banks around the world.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I meant to follow up earlier on the bending of the cost curve, but if you were to put different initiatives in terms of how far along you are maybe like your exits might be in the eighth inning, and your transformation might be in the sixth inning, and your remediation in the fifth inning, the simplification in the first inning or second inning.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Are those numbers correct?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: How would you put those numbers?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And in terms of bending the cost curve, where are you further along and where are you just getting started?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Well, Mike, you know I love you, but I'm not going to play that game.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I will say is that we clearly have work that we're doing as it relates to the exits, but making very good progress on that, not just on the closing of the exits but also on putting a dent in the stranded costs associated with those exits that we have closed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, as Jane mentioned in her prepared remarks, by the time we get to end of the year, ex-Mexico, we would have made a considerable amount of progress on there, and that creates an opportunity to do more around the simplification of the organization and so that simplification is obviously in an earlier inning, call it, the exits in a later inning.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that the transformation spend investments and those things, look we are squarely into execution, as you've heard us mention before.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as I've mentioned, the expense base around that is going to continue to morph from spend that we've made around third-party consultants and that helped in the crafting of the plan towards technology, towards people that are critically involved in the execution of it and then a downward trajectory towards the benefits we get from that technology and reduced operational expense.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, it's a multi-year journey, we've talked about that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got a number of years to continue to execute against it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what's important is we know what we have to do, both in how we're investing that money and as it relates to being disciplined about our cost structure and bending the curve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, that's what we're going to do.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And one more attempt, can you remind us how many people are working on the transformation remediation and how much that's costing you?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes think the number I shared was somewhere around 13,000 people or so that are broadly working on the efforts here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We haven't gotten into specific costs; you know it's in the total number.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what I would say again is that we're clear on what we've got to deliver and execute against and we're managing that cost very tightly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're constantly looking at opportunities to deliver on those transformation deliverables, more efficiently, leveraging technology, leveraging AI in some instances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we're not just taking those execution plans as they were crafted and delivering against them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we're looking for efficiencies and even the execution plans as they're constructed today.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's important for us to keep doing.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I know this is going long here.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Just a quick one, just, Mark, just wanted to get your sense on the sentiment around client activity in both the Markets group and what the pipelines are looking like in Investment Banking and the feel for that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I'll jump in here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Corporates are pretty cautious.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They've got another Fed hike in the offing, tensions in China and the West, OPEC and all, and a general sense of more limited growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I think clients have been trying to understand and get their arms around both the macro and the market outlook for a while.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think they now seem to accept the current environment is new normal and are beginning to position themselves globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So globally, we're seeing less anxiety around funding as most large corps are biting the bullet and paying higher rates to take advantage of issuance windows, balance sheet is getting reinforced, we certainly don't see a large cap credit prices on the horizon.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And on the IB side, it remains, the pipeline is robust.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's a lot of pent-up demand for M&A but it's hard to predict when that pipeline will unlock.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: ECM had tangible momentum over Q1, and we're also seeing sponsor lev fin showing signs of improvement, but both of those are from a very, very low base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And on the investor side, most of the investors stayed on the sidelines in Q2.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The debt ceiling was a bigger topic than economic news was, and then it was a very low vol environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We saw a bit of a pickup at the beginning with the light bump in volatility in the last few days, but I wouldn't call that a trend yet.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Charles Peabody with Portales.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: A question about your Markets related net interest income.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: And before I ask the question, I do appreciate that you run those businesses on a holistic basis and that NII is probably more of a residual outcome.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: But a couple of questions related to Markets-related NII.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: First is, you had a pretty nice jump up in the second quarter versus the first quarter.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: And I just wanted to understand, is that largely related to seasonal dividend issues?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: And then secondly, you have a positive NII outcome, where a lot of your money center in brethren will have a negative NII outcome for Markets and I was just wondering what the difference is?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: Is it the outsized FICC business relative to Equities?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: Or is it the international?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: Or is it how you hedge?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: What's the difference on that?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: So those are the 2 questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks for the question, and thanks for the acknowledgment that we do manage our Markets revenues in total, so I appreciate that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I would say in terms of the Markets NII is, you've captured it right, which is the dynamic that's playing out between first quarter and second quarter is, in fact, dividend season.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, given the globality of our franchise, the dividend is not just a dividend in any one region, but dividend in multiple regions playing out over the course of the first and second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I can't speak to the peers at this particular stage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what I would say is that you know that our book skews more so than peers to corporates, and that's important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we obviously have a very, very strong FICC business more broadly as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So dividend season, major driver here in that increase.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: And just as a follow-up, is there any sort of directional guidance you can give on Markets related to NII?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: I mean does it mean to the extent second quarter was bolstered by dividend, it comes down in the third quarter, but then does it go back up in the fourth quarter?

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: So would the second half be kind of equivalent to the first half?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Charles, I really appreciate the attempt there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I'm not going to give any further guidance on the breakout of the NII, I will reiterate the ex-Markets NII increase, by the way, to plus $46 billion but thanks for question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I appreciate that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Vivek Juneja with JP Morgan.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Couple of questions.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Number one, so capital, Jane and Mark, going back to that, should we expect that given what you've mentioned, given everything going on in the regulatory environment, ratio you're at currently, it should grow in anticipation of what may come or likely to come with all the regulatory stuff?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Or are you going to try and keep that closer to the 13.3%?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we're going to see exactly what the framework is that comes out and then the implementation time frame for it and then look at making adjustments to plan, also hoping that the comment period is taken seriously and the different considerations I talked about earlier are taken into effect.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Then we'll work through what are adjustments we make, pricing capital reallocation, etc., the playbook that you would expect the same one that we've done with SA-CCR and we've done with a number of other pieces.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we would also hope to see our SCB in a different place for the same reasons we talked about earlier Vivek, because there's a lot of volatility in that SCB dependent on the scenario that comes out every year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would say, given the shifts we're making in the business model, we'd expect to see that one come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add is again, the CET1 ratio of the 13.3% as of October 1, would be a 12.3% reg of October 1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned, the NPR as it comes out, we'll take a look at that and see if there are implications on the CET1 stack, but more likely implications on the risk-weighted assets, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what's really important there aside from the very important points Jane made in terms of considering broader factors is the timing of the implementation of whatever that final rule includes and obviously, the more timing for implementation, the more of an ability it gets for the industry to think about how to absorb the implications there.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: But I'm presuming you want to go sooner rather than later because the market is going to expect that rather than take a full 3 years or whatever the Fed might give you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You know what, I'm really interested at this point in seeing the proposal, and then we'll have a chance to kind of, to really react as an industry and as a firm.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Completely unrelated, if I may.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Noninterest-bearing deposits, what are you seeing given you're very heavily corporate driven.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: When I look at your point-to-point because you don't give a full average balance sheet, it's only interest-bearing related.

speaker: Vivek Juneja

sentence: Well, again, I think the point I'd make here is that we continue to see clients shift from kind of noninterest-bearing deposits and into both interest-bearing and CDs and other higher-yielding products in light of the rate environment that we're in.
