sentence: But in terms of the noninterest-bearing, we are seeing that dynamic play out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and good morning to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Before I discuss the results of the quarter, let me first address the regulatory actions by the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency which were announced on Wednesday.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These actions pertain to the consent orders we entered into with both agencies in 2020 and those orders covered four primary areas: risk management, data governance, controls and compliance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Addressing these areas is the primary goal of our Transformation, our number one priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is a multi-year effort to modernize our infrastructure, unify disparate tech management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have been public this year about the fact that we were behind in this particular area and that we had increased our investment as a result.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The regulatory actions consisted of two civil money penalties and, under the amended consent order with the OCC, a new process designed to ensure we are allocating sufficient resources to meet our remediation milestones, called the Resource Review Plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are currently developing the Plan for submission to the OCC.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: By way of background, while the Federal Reserve is the primary regulator for Citigroup, our bank holding company, the OCC is the primary regulator for Citibank, N.A.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: or CBNA, which is our largest banking vehicle with approximately 70% of our assets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The amended consent order with the OCC allows CBNA, to continue paying to Citigroup, at a minimum, the dividends necessary for debt service, preferred dividends, and other non-discretionary obligations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While we are developing and seeking OCC consent for our Resource Review -objection.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These dividends are intercompany payments that are made from CBNA ultimately to the parent, Citigroup.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They should not be confused with the common dividends Citigroup pays to its shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Indeed, there is no restriction on k shares.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And let me be very clear, even with the investments needed for our Transformation, Citigroup has more than sufficient resources to also invest in our businesses, and make the planned return of capital to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will increase our dividend from 53 to 56 cents a share, as we announced in late June, and will resume modest buybacks this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While these actions were not entirely unexpected to us, it is no doubt disappointing for our investors and our people.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We completely understand that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At the same time, we are confident in our ability to get these specific areas where they need to be, as we have been able to do in other areas of the Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are pleased that it was acknowledged on Wednesday that we have made meaningful progress in executing our Transformation, and simplifying our firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A multi-year undertaking such as this was never going to be linear.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The investments we have been making are starting to come together to reduce risk, improve controls and deliver tangible outcomes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The tech investments we have made are making a difference.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have reduced the time it takes to book loans; automated controls for our traders to reduce errors; moved risk analytics to a cloud-based infrastructure; and increased the resiliency of our platforms to reduce downtime.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The changes to our organization and our culture are making a difference.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have eliminated managerial constructs and layers whilst empowering our leaders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We introduced new tools to better manage human capital needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our focus on culture has increased accountability and attracted great commitment that we will address any area of the consent order where we are behind by putting the necessary resources and focus behind it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will get this work where it needs to be, as we have with the execution of our strategy and the simplification of our organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, turning to what was another good quarter, our results show the relentless focus we have in executing our strategy as we continue to drive towards our medium-term return targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We reported net income of $3.2 billion with an earnings per share of $1.52 and an ROTCE of 7.2%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Revenues were up 4% overall, as well as up in each of our five core businesses, where all but one had positive operating leverage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Expenses were down 2% year-over-year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The steps we are taking to simplify our organization, right-size businesses such as Markets and Wealth, and reduce stranded costs are beginning to take hold, even as we increase investment in our Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Over the medium term, we expect these simplification and stranded cost actions to drive the $2 to $2.5 billion in annual run-rate saves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services grew 3% driven by solid fee growth, which we have prioritized.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: TTS saw increased activity in cross border payments and in commercial cards.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Securities Services was up 10%, with new client onboardings, deepening with existing clients, and market valuations helping increase our assets under custody by a preliminary 9%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At our recent Services Investor Day, we very much enjoyed the opportunity to talk to you in-depth about how we are going to continue to grow this high-returning business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are very pleased that people are starting to recognize why we describe it as our crown jewel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, Markets had a strong finish to the quarter leading to better performance than we had anticipated.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Fixed Income was slightly down year-on-year due to lower FX and Rates, but we had good issuance and loan growth in Financing & Securitization, an area which generates attractive returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equities was up 37%, driven by strong performance in derivatives which includes a gain on the Visa B exchange offer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking was up 38% as the wallet rebound gained some momentum and we again grew share.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our clients continued to access the debt capital markets with investment grade issuance near record levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equity issuance increased, particularly in convertibles, as companies wait for a fuller opening of the IPO window.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Investment Banking fees were up 63% versus the prior year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have seen some healthy volumes associated with announced deals year to date, particularly in Natural Resources and Technology.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Combined with a strong pipeline, advisory activity looks promising as we think about the rest of the year and into next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Wealth is starting to improve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Growth in client investment assets drove stronger Investment revenue, especially in Citigold, and was up a preliminary 15%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our focus on rationalizing the expense base is starting to pay off, with expenses down 4%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy and his team continue to attract top talent from the industry as they focus on our investments business and on enhancing the client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking saw revenue growth of 6%, with all three businesses again contributing to the topline.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There was good revolving balance and loan growth in both branded cards and retail services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to see differentiation in the credit segments with the lower income customers seeing pressure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Retail Banking benefitted from higher mortgage loans and improved deposit spreads, while delivering strong referrals to Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, while we saw operating margin expansion, our poor returns were pressured by the combination of credit seasonality and the normalization of certain vintages.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We certainly The recent stress tests again showcased the strength of our balance sheet.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our CET1 ratio now stands at 13.6%, and we expect our regulatory capital requirement to decrease to 12.1% as of October 1st given the reduction of our stress capital buffer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our tangible book value per share grew to $87.53.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we returned $1 billion in capital to our common shareholders, and we are increasing our dividend by 6%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect to buyback $1 billion in common shares this quarter and we will continue to assess the level of buybacks on a quarterly basis, particularly given the uncertainty around the Basel III endgame.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: structurally sound economy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: After a break in progress, inflation now appears back on a downward trajectory.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services spending has remained on an upward trend although there are clear signs of a softening labor market and the tightening of the consumer budget.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And of course, you might have heard there is an mpetitiveness continues to be a drag on growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Asia, China is growing moderately, albeit with government stimulus, and their pivot to high-tech manufacturing is being challenged by tariffs on EVs and semi-conductors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Despite this uncertainty, as you saw at our Services Investor Day, when we went through our performance over the last two years, our business model can produce good results in a variety of macro environments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And there is plenty of upside for us across our five businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have made an incredible amount of progress in simplification- both strategically and organizationally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have completed most of the exits of our international consumer markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We streamlined our organization to catalyze agility and faster decision making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are modernizing our infrastructure to improve our client service and automating processes to strengthen controls.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are on a deliberate path.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will continue to execute our Transformation and our strategy so we can meet our medium-term targets and then continue to further improve our returns over time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that, I would like to turn it over to Mark and then we would be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the firmwide financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the second quarter unless I indicate otherwise, and then spend a little more time on the businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the quarter, we reported net income of approximately $3.2 billion, EPS of $1.52 and an RoTCE of 7.2% on $20.1 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total revenues were up 4%, driven by growth across all businesses as well as an approximate $400 million gain related to the Visa B exchange offer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: A significant portion of this gain is reflected in Equity Markets, with the remainder reflected in All Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were $13.4 billion, down 2%, and 6% on a sequential basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The combination of revenue growth and expense decline drove positive operating leverage for the firm and the majority of our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $2.5 billion, primarily driven by higher Card net credit losses, which were partially offset by ACL releases in all businesses except USPB, where we built for loan growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had nearly $22 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of approximately 2.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show the expense trend over the past five quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This quarter we reported expenses of $13.4 billion, down 2%, and 6% sequentially, which includes the $136 million civil money penalties imposed by the Fed and OCC earlier this week.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The decrease in expenses was primarily driven by savings associated with our organizational simplification, stranded cost reductions, and lower repositioning costs, partially offset by continued investment in Transformation and the Fed and the OCC penalties.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we said over the past few months, we will continue to invest in the Transformation and technology to modernize our operations and risk and control infrastructure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect these investments to offset some of our saves and headcount reduction going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, based on what we now know today, we will likely be at the higher end of the expense guidance range, excluding the FDIC special assessment and the civil money penalties.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, we will, of course, look for opportunities to absorb the CMP.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: on the Transformation and address what the Fed and OCC announced Wednesday.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have made good progress on our Transformation in certain areas over the last few years, and I want to highlight some of those areas before discussing the announcement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, Wholesale Credit and Loan operations, where we implemented a consistent end to end operating model and consolidated multiple systems with enhanced technology.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This has not only reduced risk but enhanced operating efficiency and the client experience.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have also made improvements in risk and compliance as we enhanced our risk assessments and technology capabilities to increase automation for monitoring.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Data, while there is a lot more to do, we have stood up a data governance process and streamlined our data architecture to ultimately facilitate straight through processing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Overall, we have improved risk management, and consolidated and upgraded systems and platforms to improve our resiliency.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These efforts represent meaningful examples of how we are making progress against our Transformation milestones.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we have fallen short in data quality management particularly related to regulatory reporting, which we have acknowledged publicly since the beginning of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As such, we have begun to put additional investments and resources in place to not only address data quality management related to regulatory reporting and data governance, but also related to stress testing capabilities, including DFAST and Resolution Recovery.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also re-prioritized our efforts to ensure we are focused on data that impacts these reports first.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We take this feedback from our regulators very seriously and we are committed to allocating all the resources necessary to meet their expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning back to the quarterly results.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we show net interest income, deposits, and loans where In the second quarter, net interest income was roughly flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding Markets, net interest income was down 3%, largely driven by the impact of foreign exchange translation, seasonally lower revolving card balances and lower interest rates in Argentina, partially offset by higher deposit spreads in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were roughly flat, as growth in Cards and Mexico Consumer was largely offset by slight declines across businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And average deposits decreased by 1%, largely driven by seasonal outflows and transfers to investments in Wealth as well as non-operational outflows in TTS.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 10, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics, which reflect our disciplined risk appetite framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across our card portfolios, approximately 86% of our card loans are to consumers with FICO scores of 660 or higher.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And while we continue to see an overall resilient US consumer, we also continue to see a divergence in performance and behavior across FICO and income bands.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When we look across our consumer clients, only the highest income quartile has more savings than they did at the beginning of 2019.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it is the over 740 FICO customers that are driving the spend growth and maintaining high payment rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Lower FICO band customers are seeing sharper drops in payment rates and borrowing more as they are more acutely impacted by high inflation and interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, as we will discuss later, we are seeing signs of stabilization in delinquency performance across our cards portfolios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have taken this all into account in our reserving and we remain well reserved with a reserve-to-funded loan ratio of 8.1% for our total card portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our Corporate portfolio is largely investment grade, at approximately 82% as of the second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we saw a nearly $500 million sequential decrease in corporate non-accrual loans, largely driven by upgrades and repayments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Additionally, this quarter we saw an improvement in our macro assumptions driven by HPI, oil prices and equity market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our credit loss reserves continue to incorporate a scenario-weighted average unemployment rate of nearly 5%, and a downside scenario unemployment rate of nearly 7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As such, we feel very comfortable with the nearly $22 billion of reserves that we have in the current environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: t to highlight the strength of our balance sheet, capital and liquidity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is this strength that allows us to support clients through periods of uncertainty and volatility.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our balance sheet is a reflection of our risk appetite, strategy and diversified business model.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $1.3 trillion deposit base is well diversified across regions, industries, customers and account types.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The majority of our deposits are corporate, at $807 billion, and span 90 countries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you heard at the Services ID, most of these deposits are held in operating accounts that are crucial to how our clients fund their daily operations around the world, making them operational in nature and therefore very stable.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The majority of our remaining deposits, about $404 billion, are well diversified across the Private Bank, Citigold, Retail and Wealth at Work offerings, as well as across regions and products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of our total deposits, 68% are US dollar denominated with the remainder spanning over 60 currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our asset mix also reflects our strong risk appetite framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $688 billion loan portfolio is well diversified across consumer and corporate loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And about one-third of our balance sheet is held in cash and high-quality, short duration investment securities that contribute to our approximately $900 billion of available liquidity resources.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to feel very good about the strength of our balance sheet and the quality of our assets and liabilities, which position us to be a source of strength for the industry and, importantly, for our clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 12, we show a sequential walk to provide more detail on the drivers of our CET1 ratio this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter with a preliminary 13.6% CET1 capital ratio, approximately 130 basis points, or approximately $15 billion, above our current regulatory capital requirement of 12.3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect our regulatory capital requirement to decrease to 12.1% as of October 1st, which incorporates the reduction in our Stress Capital Buffer from 4.3% to the indicative SCB of 4.1% we announced a couple weeks ago.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We were pleased to see the improvement in our DFAST results, and the corresponding reduction in our SCB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, even with the reduction, our capital requirement does not yet fully reflect our simplification efforts, the benefits of our transformation or the full execution of our strategy, all of which we expect to reduce our capital requirements over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as a reminder, we announced an increase to our common dividend from $0.53 per share to $0.56 per share following the SCB results.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as Jane mentioned earlier, we plan on doing $1 billion of buybacks this quarter.

sentence: We continue to remain laser focused on executing on our transformation and enhancing the businesses performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And while we recognize there is a lot more to do on Transformation, we are pleased with the progress we are making towards our 2024 and Medium-term targets and remain committed to these targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I will be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Could you elaborate more on the amended consent order, Jane?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You said it was disappointing to have gotten that this week.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: It's almost four years into the consent order.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And a little bit why it hasn't been resolved and what's on, that's the loss column and maybe a little bit more on the win column too.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I mean, you have what 12,000 people thrown at the problem.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Billions of dollars.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Is it not enough people?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Is it not enough money?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Do you need to look at it in a different way?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Are you not talking the same language?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I mean, you have John Dugan as your lead independent director, ex head of the OCC, and it seems like you got your report card.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I guess you passed overall.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: They went out of their way to say some nice things, but it looks like you got failing grades in data and regulatory management.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, you're confident it's going to be resolved, but it's already been four years and it hasn't been resolved.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So what is it going to take from here and how can you resolve the regulatory concerns while continuing or serving shareholders better?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then in the win column, since it's so nebulous this back office, what are you achieving?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You mentioned some items, but if you could put more meat on those bones.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's a few different parts to that, so let's start by just taking a step back.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our transformation is addressing decades of under-investment in large parts of Citi's infrastructure and in our risk and control environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when you unpack that, those areas where we had an absence of enforced enterprise-wide standards and governance, we've had a siloed organization that's prevented scale, a culture where a lot of groups were allowed to solve problem the same problem in different ways, fragmented tech platforms, manual processes and controls, and a weak first line of defense, too few subject matter experts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, this is a massive body of work that goes well beyond the consent order and this is not old Citi putting in Band-Aids.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is Citi tackling the root issues head on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a multiyear undertaking as we've talked about and you saw the statement by one of our regulators this week, we have made meaningful progress on our transformation and on our simplification.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, and so as Jane says, the progress that we've made, it spans multiple parts of the consent order and transformation work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Remember, that consent order and transformation work includes risk, it includes controls, it includes compliance, it includes data and data related to the regulatory reporting, and we've got evidence and proof points of progress against all of those things.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So transforming, to answer your question about how do we fix it and serve our investors at the same time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Transforming Citi will drive benefits for our shareholders, our clients, and our regulators.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is not mutually exclusive.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At the beginning of the year, we honed in on two priorities, the transformation and improving our business performance, and we're able to do so because we've largely cleared the decks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a clear focus strategy, we've executed the divestitures, we've got a much simpler organization, so we can focus on these two priorities and we are able to do both.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You can see that in our results again this quarter, multiple, solid proof points on the execution of the strategy and we know what we need to do on both fronts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have plans in place on the transformation and on the strategy and we're executing against them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have been and we will be transparent when we have issues and how we're addressing them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And just to add a couple of data points to that, Mike.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've heard us mention some of these before, but we've retired platforms.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've reduced the number of data centers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Platforms are down some 300.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've moved from 39 corporate loan platforms down to south of 20.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got 20 cash equities execution platforms down to 1; we've reduced the 6 reporting ledgers down to 1; 11 sanctions platforms down to 1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we've been making considerable progress over the past couple of years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, there's a lot more work to be done around the data regulatory reporting work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you think about Citi, we've got 11,000 global total reg reports, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we've got to make sure that the data that's going into those reports is the quality of the data that we want it to be, but more importantly, that we're doing it efficiently, that it doesn't take thousands of people to reconcile that information and so this is an end-to end process in the way we're approaching it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One example is the 2052a liquidity report that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It has 750,000 lines of data and that data is, it's important again that we're efficiently collecting it from multiple systems with standards and governance that ensures it's of the quality that we want it to be without again having to have manual activity supporting it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Glenn Schorr at Evercore.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, Mark, I heard your comments on credit this year.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I'm talking the US Personal Banking.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I heard your comments for credit the rest of this year and I think in a position that you're very conservatively reserved.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But right now, you put up a 3% margin and credit costs are almost half of what revenues are in this space.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I guess, my question is this: As we roll forward, in a slowing economy with likely a little bit lower some rate cuts, how does the P&L evolve?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: How does it improve from here?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Because can we be expecting credit costs to come in, in a slowing economy?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I'm just trying to figure out the path forward because it could be impactful if USPB obviously marches to where you need it to be.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, look, like I said, we do think that there is certainly upside to USPB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're looking for that upside in the medium-term targets that we've set for ourselves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've got to remember that when you look at the quarter and you look at the half, frankly, that we're still in a period where we're seeing the normalization of the cost of credit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, you have kind of a compounding effect of multiple vintages now maturing at the same time that's playing through the P&L.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's not just true for us, that's true for others as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we'd expect and we are we do believe we're seeing some signs of a cresting when you look at delinquencies now and so we would expect that those losses start to normalize and loss rates start to come down as we go towards the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the same time, we're investing in the business and we're looking to see continued growth in volume and on the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the combination of those things, as we drive towards the medium term, will help us to deliver both the top line growth and certainly improve returns from where we sit today and in line with what we've guided to.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, it's a combination of top line performance from volume and obviously the environment plays into that, but we feel like we've got a reasonable assumption around top line growth there, cost of credit normalizing, continued discipline on the expense line, allowing for us to get improved returns across that USPB business.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Appreciate all that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: One quickie on DCM.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: You had amazingly good performance.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: There's been plenty of conversation about pull forward this year on just refi driving like three-quarters of the activity.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Could you just help us think through the second half when thinking about DCM just to make sure that we don't like start modelling this into perpetuity?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think when we think about the back half of 2024, we're going to see a different mix of activity in Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We do still expect demand to be quite strong across our capital market products because you've got a wall of maturing debt securities coming up in the second half that carry on for a couple of years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But, we did see some clients accelerating issuances into the first half getting ahead of potential market volatility.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, if you put it all together, I think we expect the rate environment and the financing markets to continue to be accommodative as well as to continue deal making with M&A being a bit larger in the overall mix, although some of the regulatory elements have put a damper on part of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Only thing I'd add to that is, look, the wallet for the year is obviously going to depend on a couple things, so, one, the return of a more normalized IPO market, two, the direction and volatility of interest rates, the ongoing global conflicts that we're all kind of seeing and witnessing, and then finally, as Jane mentioned in her remarks, the elections and what those outcomes look like, not just in the US, but abroad.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so there are a number of factors there that will play to the wallet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as we said, we believe we're well-positioned to be there to serve our clients and to do so in a way that makes good economic sense.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Jim Mitchell at Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Just, Mark, maybe on NII, down almost 4% year-over-year.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Seems a little bit more than the guidance was down modestly for the year.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, can you discuss sort of the puts and takes this quarter and how we should think about the quarterly trajectory for the rest of the year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I'd say a couple things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, as I mentioned, in the quarter and you see it on slide 9, ex-Markets, we're down about 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's largely driven by some FX translation that played through, but also some seasonally lower revolving card balances and then lower interest rates in Argentina.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what that is in Argentina, we have capital there, the policy rate was adjusted downward and as that happened, we obviously earned less on that capital that flows through the NII line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I think about the back half of the year and the guidance we have of modestly down, there are a couple of puts and takes to keep in mind.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one is going to be rates, right, so as I think about the higher yield that we can earn on reinvestment, that'll be a tailwind that plays through from an NII point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second would be volume growth, particularly in our card loans portfolio and we do expect to see continued volume growth across certainly the Branded portfolio and so that'll be another tailwind for us on the NII line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the headwinds, you've got the lower NII earned in Argentina from rates, that'll continue to play through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got assumed higher average betas in 2024, specifically on the non-US side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We still have in our forecast the impact of CFPB late fees, so assuming that that goes into effect for this year, that will have an impact and it's in the forecast, and then the impact of lost NII from the exits that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, the combination of those things will probably mean that NII in the back half of the year is a little bit higher than the first half, but again, consistent with the guidance that we gave of modestly down.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: That's helpful.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And maybe just quickly, kind of a similar question on expenses.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Better-than expected this quarter, but there was no restructuring or repositioning charges.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I think to get to the high end of your range, you'd have to be up a little bit in the back half from 2Q run rate.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Is that because you expect more repositioning, restructuring in the second half or maybe just talk through expense trajectory from here?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so that's right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When I talk about it at the first quarter, I talked about kind of a downward trend for each of the quarters after Q1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second quarter came in a bit lower than we were expecting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm sticking with the guidance and it does mean that the back half of the year will likely come in will come in higher than the second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's a combination of a couple of things, including the pace of hiring and investment that we will do in the transformation work that has to be done.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It also includes repositioning charges that we might take or need to take as we continue to work through our businesses across the firm and the franchise and then the second quarter did or yeah, the second quarter did have a one-time or so and some delayed spending that will pick up in the third and fourth quarter around advertising and marketing and some of the other line items.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, yes, the third and fourth quarter, the back half will be higher than the second quarter, but consistent with the guidance that I've given.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Erika Najarian at UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I had two questions and I'll ask the first one on expenses first since it's a good follow up to the previous.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Mark, just to clarify.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Let's just say, take the highest end of your range at $53.8 billion.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Just trying to think about how consensus will move.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, we take that $53.8 billion and then add the $285 million of FDIC expenses year-to-date so far and add the civil money penalties of $136 million, so that gets us to $54.2 billion for the year and any other repositioning charges in the second half of the year would already be included in the $53.8 billion?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, yes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The answer to the last part of your question is yes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So in the range that I've given, $53.5 billion to $53.8 billion, that includes our estimate for the full year of repositioning and any restructuring charges.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That range excludes the FDIC Special Assessment that we saw earlier in the year and it excludes the CMP of $136 million.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And my second question is for Jane and I'm sure you're getting tired of the question on capital return.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, you're buying back $1 billion, you plan to buy back $1 billion this quarter.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: It looks like you didn't buy back any in the second quarter.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I'm asking this question in this context because consensus has a buyback of nearly $1 billion in the fourth quarter and staying at this rate for the first half of next year and ramping higher.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I guess, is the $1 billion number a catch-up pace because you didn't buy back any in the second quarter?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I fully appreciate that you also have the Banamex IPO coming, which is different from peers that are also waiting for Basel clarification.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: But I'm just wondering, do we need to wait for that Banamex IPO for the company to feel comfortable moving away from that quarter-to-quarter guidance?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And also, of course, I just want to readdress the beginning of the question when I asked specifically about the pace.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we are not going to be giving guidance going forward around our buybacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are going to continue to give quarterly and make it a quarterly determination as to the level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And a lot of that is to do with the uncertainty about the forthcoming regulatory changes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we were delighted to see a slight reduction in our Stress Capital Buffer, reflecting the financial strength and resiliency of our business model and also good to see the benefits of our strategy playing out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But with the regulatory changes uncertain, that's one of the major factors for us to continue with the quarterly guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, that's right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And on the first part of your question, Erika, I'd say, look, we were in discussions with our regulators and we made a prudent call as it relates to buybacks in the quarter for Q2.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, Q3, as we talked about, would be at $1 billion and that should not be necessarily viewed as a run rate level.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned, we'll take it quarter by quarter from here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Thank you, Hi Jane, Hi Mark.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, regarding the comments you made about the higher credit losses, the three factors that you gave us, can you also talk about, if this was a factor at all for you folks, was there any FICO score inflation back during the pandemic that might be playing into these kind of credit losses?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And as part of the credit card question, you mentioned the CFPB, the fees that you have factored in, the lower fees you factored that into your forward-look.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Where do we stand on that?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Do you guys have any color on that as well?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so, on the first part of the question, look, we all kind of have talked about in the past, the prospect of FICO inflation back during the COVID period of time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been very focused on ensuring that acquisitions that we've made have been appropriately kind of analyzed in the underwriting of that to get comfortable with the quality of new customers that we've been bringing on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In light of the environment, we have looked at moving towards higher FICO scores for new account acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as I think about what we're seeing now, there is that dichotomy that I mentioned where we have the higher FICO score customers that are driving the spend growth and that frankly have still continued strong balances and savings and it's really the lower FICO band customers, where we're seeing the sharper drop in payment rates and more borrowing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, the FICO inflation has effectively kind of fizzled out when we look at the mix and dynamic of the customer portfolio that we have at this point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in terms of the CFPB late fees, well, I don't have an update on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Like I said, we've built in an assumption in our forecast.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But in terms of the timing, I don't have a formal update on the certainty of it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Ken Usdin at Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Hey, thanks, good morning.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Hey, Mark.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Talking about the NII outlook and the fact that now we've got a little bit of a discrepancy starting between US rates, maybe higher for longer, and then the beginnings of some of the non-US curve starting to, at least put fourth their first cut.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I know we've got that good chart that you have in the Qs about the relative contributions.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Can you just help us understand a little bit of like just generally how you're thinking through that discrepancy and how that informs the difference between US-related NII and non-US-related NII as you go forward?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thank you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So look, I think that as we look at it, out through the certainly through the medium term, we expect to see continued NII growth at obviously a modest level, certainly lower than what we've seen historically and that's in large part because or in part I should say because of how we've been managing the balance sheet and that has allowed for us to reinvest as securities have rolled off and earn a higher yield on them relative to what we were earning, in some instances, they were five-year terms on some of these investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we still think there's some upside from a reinvestment point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The point you make around kind of non-US dollar or US rates kind of coming off, that'll play through a little bit as we think about the beta increases that we're expecting outside of the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we've assumed that we have higher betas pick up outside of the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If rates kind of come off in a more substantive way, then we could see kind of a little less NII pressure than we're forecasting there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But net-net, as I think about the combination of volume growth that we're expecting between loans and deposits over that medium term, the higher yield we can earn on our assets, combined with the pricing capabilities that we have across the portfolio, offsetting some of that beta, we believe we'll have continued NII growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I think about what I often point to in terms of the IRE analysis and you have to remember that that is a shock to the current balance sheet and it assumes that the full curve is moving simultaneously, cross currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in that case, the 100 basis point parallel shift downward would be a negative $1.6 billion, with about $1.3 billion coming from non-US dollar.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, that does assume that all of those currencies come down at the same time and doesn't account for the rebalancing of the balance sheet and things that I mentioned like the reinvestment higher yields that we'd be able to earn.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And just one follow-up on the OCC amendment and that's specifically related to the Resource Review Plan.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Do you have a line of sight on how long that'll take you guys to finish because it seems like and is that what we should be thinking about in terms of just understanding like what the side of what you need to get done in terms of the other language that's written in the order?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, Ken, look, the Resource Review Plan is just that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a plan to ensure that we have sufficient resources allocated towards achieving a timely and sustainable compliance to the order.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Essentially if an area is delayed or looking as if it could be, we'll determine what additional resourcing, if any, is required to get back on track and then we'll share that with the OCC in a more formalized way than we do today and we obviously review this pretty constantly ourselves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're already working on the plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: After it's finalized with the OCC it will be confidential supervisory information that we can't disclose.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we won't be able to tell you that the plan is, what the nature of the plan is going to be, but it won't be much more complicated than what we talked about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're expecting to get it, we're not expecting this to take long.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So, I know we talked a lot about expenses.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I just have one kind of overarching question here, which is on how we should think about the path of expenses between now and the medium term, as we have come quite a long way in the simplification process.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Maybe if you could give us a sense as to how far along simplification impact on expenses we are?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And overlapping with the regulatory requirements, do these net out or are we skewed a little bit more towards regulatory requirements being a bit heavier than what's left on simplification from here?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, thank you, Betsy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I guess I'd say a couple things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I think we said it in the past.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the target for the medium term, we think 2026 is somewhere around $51 billion to $53 billion of expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we've said, we'll have about $1.5 billion in savings related to the restructuring that we've done and another $500 million to $1 billion related to net expense reductions from eliminating the stranded costs as well as additional productivity over that medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we've made, I think, very good headway, as Jane has mentioned, in the org simplification and the restructuring charges associated with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Those saves will have started to generate.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Some of those saves in the early part of that, meaning this year, will likely be offset by continued investment that we're making in areas of the business like transformation, but also in business-led or driven growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you should expect in terms of the trend that we would have a downward trend towards 2026 in achieving that range.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I just want to reiterate, we remain confident that we will meet our 11% to 12% RoTCE target over the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've got the, we have the ability to manage the different elements we've been talking about today, making sure that we're investing sufficient resources into the transformation so we can be on track with that, as well as in our businesses, as well as the return of capital to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we feel confident around that and good about it, we can manage this.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I think that's a great point, Jane.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the reality is, as was pointed out earlier, we spent about $3 billion last year, a little bit under that, on the transformation-related work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the plan has called for us to spend a little bit more than that this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And frankly, in the first half of the year, as we work through the transformation work and some of the things that Jane and I have mentioned earlier in the year that we've been focused on, like data and data related to regulatory reporting, we've had to spend more than we had planned for in the first half, right, and we've done that and we funded that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been able to find productivity opportunities that allow for us to still stay within the guidance that we've given for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we are managing this entire expense base, right, so not the whole $53 billion plus of it, we are actively managing that with an eye towards what's required from a transformation point of view to keep it on track, to accelerate in areas where we're behind and to shore up areas where we're tracking in accordance to what the order requires and where are the other inefficiencies that can allow for us to free up the expense base?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, things like the work that Andy Sieg has done with the finance team around that expense base and finding efficiencies there are opportunities that we've been able to tease out of the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Things that we have done in parts of USPB and that we have continued to get after in parts of Banking, which you see in the down 10% this quarter are areas where we've been keenly focused on, where are there duplicative roles, where are there inefficient processes that we can actually drive greater efficiency out of.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, longwinded way of saying, we understand the expense guidance that we've given, we also understand and stress the importance of funding the transformation with what's required and we're doing both.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Great.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Let me just clarify this, Mark and Jane, just to make sure that we all have it right.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The $53.5 billion to $53.8 billion does not include anything thus far on what you think you may need to spend on the Resource Review Plan, meaning what additional resources you would have to put to fix the consent order.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Am I right there?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think as you've heard us talk about, Vivek, for a while now, that we knew the areas that we were behind in elements of our transformation program and that we began addressing those and making the investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Some of that's in people.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Some of that is in technology spend.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's using different tools and capabilities to get areas addressed earlier and we began that earlier in the year and you saw that acknowledged as well by our regulators who pointed to the fact that we've already begun addressing the areas that we're behind.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's right, Jane, and what you have heard is that despite having to spend more, some $250 million or so more, we're not changing the guidance, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we have, as Jane mentioned, we have worked on areas already that we've needed to and we have looked for ways to absorb that and are doing so within our guidance.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: So, going forward, even though this plan is still to be sort of put together and approved by the regulators, we should not expect any change to this expense guidance?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the plan, the Resource Review Plan, as Jane mentioned, is what we're working through now with the regulators.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That will be a process for demonstrating to them that we are spending and allocating the appropriate resources to accomplishing the commitments that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Appropriate resources can range from people to technology to enhancing our processes and ensuring better execution.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you think about what that will entail, it will entail areas where we are delayed or behind as we identify those areas, being able to tease out the root cause of any delay and ensure that we've got proper funding allocated to get it back on track and that's me framing out how I think about what something like this might look like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, what we're saying is that if we identify issues in the quarters to come, that we haven't identified already, that's the process we're going to apply to those issues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you've heard us say repeatedly, we're going to spend whatever is necessary to then get those things back on track.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we've done thus far this year, we're going to look for opportunities to absorb those headwinds.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I hope that's clear.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Operator
sentence: : Hi.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Apologies if I missed it in the opening remarks, but what drove the decline in credit card revenues from 1Q to 2Q?

speaker: Operator
sentence: Looks like they were down about 6% in aggregate even though average loans went up, spending went up.

speaker: Operator
sentence: What was the driver of that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit card revenues, seasonality.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, seasonality.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Seasonality playing through there sequentially.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think if you look year-over-year, you'll be able to see a pretty common trend there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The consumer is slowing in some of the, in the spend, as Mark had referred to, Matt.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And a lot of the spending and the growth areas we are seeing and underlying numbers is being driven by the affluent customer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think there's also the dynamic on the CRS of the reward or across the portfolio of rewards playing through from one quarter to the other, so the combination of those things are playing through the revenue line there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But nothing that's particularly worrying us, Matt.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: : Okay.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then just separately on the very early kind of part of the prepared remarks, you talked about the dividends being capped in terms of what could be upstream from the bank to the holding company because of the OCC that came out this week.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: For all intents and purposes, like does that impact how you run the company or subsidiary or impact liquidity or capital?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I understood the comment, no change to dividends or buybacks at the holding company, but is there any impact from that that we would notice on the outside?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, let's be clear, this action does not impact our ability to return capital to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The dividends that are referenced are just intercompany payments from CBNA to the parent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, first of all, don't confuse what a dividend is here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will, it's not going to impact how we run the company, the subsidiary, the capital, the liquidity at all and the dividends are not capped.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I think, Jane, that's right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think let's not lose sight of the purpose of the orders that are there and the purpose of the orders that are there are to ensure that we're funding and allocating the effort appropriately, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the regulators want essentially the same thing we want, right, is for us to get this done, right, and so that is the primary objective.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The reference to the dividending from out of CBNA up to the parent is certainly referenced there between now and establishing that Resource Review Plan.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as Jane mentions, that does not constrain the parent from doing the things that it will need to do.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as opposed to, it's not a cap.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What it is, is that anything above the debt service of the parent or the preferred dividends and other nondiscretionary obligations would require a non-objection from the OCC.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Until the Resource Plan is agreed and as you'll have seen, the Resource Plan needs to be submitted within 30 days, and as I indicated, we're working on that one and not anticipating that to be a problem.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Saul Martinez with HSBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Just, I guess I just want to follow up on the latter question.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I just want to be very clear.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: So, what you're saying is that the requirement that CBNA receive a non-objection before dividending upstream to the parent, that does not impact how you think about your capital flexibility, how you think about it doesn't restrict you in any way and shouldn't impact, for example, your ability to benefit from, for example, a Basel Endgame rule that is softened or some of the benefits, Mark, that you talked about in terms of simplification.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: So, you don't see this impacting your ongoing level of capital flexibility and your ability to repurchase stock going forward if some of these things actually do play out?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: You don't?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Right.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Fair enough.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: That was as clear as can be.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Second question on, I just want to follow up on USPB.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I still I get the point that you're seeing a normalization in losses in Cards.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: But even if I adjust for reserve builds, your RoTCE is still single digits.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I would think even at these NCL levels, your Cards business is pretty profitable.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: You're a scale player, you're above sort of pre-pandemic levels, but not I don't know if I, it doesn't seem like it's that much higher by a dramatic amount.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: It would seem to imply that the Retail Bank is a huge drag on profitability, even maybe even losing money, I don't know.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: But can you just talk about what you can do to sort of improve the Retail Bank profitability and just give anymore color that you can in terms of the path to get to that high-teen RoTCE you talked about?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, let me kick off there, and let's say, look, clearly, we're very focused on improving the returns in USPB to get us to the high-teens level over the medium term and you've seen us generating healthy positive operating leverage this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've had a number of quarters of good revenue growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark said, we're at the low point of the credit cycle and we knew this year, we would see the pressure on returns from the elevated NCLs and some of the industry headwinds we've talked about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But as the NCL rates approach steady state levels and the mitigating actions that all of us have been putting in place against the industry headwinds, as those take hold, we expect the returns will improve and support the firm-wide medium-term targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the Retail Bank, we're continuing to focus on growing share in our six core markets and we're doing that, leveraging our physical and digital assets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It plays an important role in enabling the wealth continuum and the growth that we're looking at in our Wealth franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're continuing to improve our operating efficiency, being very disciplined in expense management and managing carefully the branch and digital productivity of the Retail Bank network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we're at the high point of the credit cycle.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's driving the low point for USPB, and as I said in my remarks, we're expecting to see those returns improve from here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So, Mark, I have a fairly technical question on DTA utilization and specifically the NOLs.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: The deduction is still fairly significant at $12 billion.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: It roughly equates to about 10% of your market cap.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And the good news here, I suppose, is that it should come back into capital over time, but we've seen very little utilization over the past two years despite the firm being profitable.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And so wanted to better understand this, what's constraining your ability to utilize those DTAs and are there catalysts on the horizon that could help accelerate that utilization beyond organic earnings generation?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I'm going to give you a very simple answer to a very complicated question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It really comes down to driving US income, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we are focused on not just all of the things that we've mentioned, but driving higher income in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That allows for us to utilize the disallowed DTA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We saw some of that in the quarter and we expect to see more of it as we move through the medium term, but that is the major driver of that utilization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we have many of our business heads very much focused around that opportunity as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, winning in the US is a very important leg, for example, of the strategy that Vis is refreshing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, we see opportunities from the Commercial Bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see it in Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see it in, obviously in US Personal Banking and in Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're very, we're focused from a business strategy point of view on this, not just from the financial side.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Thank you, both, for that color.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Maybe just a quick follow-up just on the Retail Services business.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: We are seeing some evidence that your competitors in this space have been more aggressive leading with price in an effort to win some new mandates.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And was hoping you could just speak to what you're seeing across the competitor set and your appetite or willingness to potentially offer better economics in response to increased competition from some of your peers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think you'll be delighted to hear that we're very focused on returns rather than just on revenues.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, when we enter into discussions with a partner who may be a new RFP for their portfolio or looking at new ones such as the one we just agreed with Dillard's, it's all about the returns and the profile of the business rather than the revenue side of things.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's a shift probably from some other ways in the past, but I'm very pleased with how disciplined the team is being around this and we're seeing the benefits of it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that may be different from what you hear and see from other players in the space.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as Jane mentioned, we're keenly focused on ensuring that, yes, we have a good partnership, but that we're generating an appropriate return.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's part of achieving our medium-term targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you know, since you brought up Retail cards, I mean, when we think about how CECL works and the reserves you have to establish for these partnerships, we're establishing full, lifetime reserves that's on the balance sheet where ultimately we end up splitting those through the partner sharing economics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, it's another important consideration as we think about expanding and taking on these relationships and renegotiating partnerships to making sure that returns make good sense for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And Mark and I have no problem saying no to revenue that doesn't come at the right returns and being very disciplined around that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The next question is from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Sorry, just to follow up on this whole consent order stuff, Jane.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: What do you think this does in terms of timing, how much longer for you to sort of get this past you?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Are you talking couple of years?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Is it now longer by a year?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Any sense of that?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Any sense of helping us think through that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, in terms of the consent order and the areas we've had delays, there are four areas to the consent order.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's risk management, it's data governance, it's around compliance and it's around control.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we've said, we were falling behind in certain areas related to data and we've been investing to address the areas that we were behind.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also saw an increase in the scope related to regulatory reporting, so we added some more bodies of work there and we're well underway.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we are not expecting this to extend the original expectations that we have on when we will complete the body of work for the consent order.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a target state for the different areas of it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have the plan to achieve those target states.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll make the investments necessary to ensure that we do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll try and get this done as quickly, but as robustly as possible and we're doing this by making strategic fixes and investments rather than, what I would call, the old Citi way, which is a series of Band-Aids that remediate, but don't actually fix the underlying issue and that way, we are delivering for our shareholders as well as our regulators and our clients because we're putting in strategic solutions that will benefit all, but I'm not expecting this to change the timeframes.

speaker: Operator
sentence: The final question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Just two clarifications.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, this is a very high-profile amendment to the consent order.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I think what I hear you saying that if you can confirm, your risk compliance and controls are getting passing grade.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: It's really the data and as it relates to the data, you're talking about 11,000 regulatory reports, some which had 750,000 lines of data.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Is that really the scope of what you need to fix?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Because people see this externally and say, hey, you're failing in terms of overall controls and resiliency.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But I think I hear you saying it's really more about just the data and the regulatory reporting, which is important, but more of a slice of a broader picture.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Is that correct?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, Mike, maybe I just maybe I you're asking a great and it's an important question, so maybe I try and explain what the data elements because it's an area that Mark and I have pointed to.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, first of all, we use data all over the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We use it to deliver 72 million customer statements every month.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our corporate clients, as you heard about at our Services Investor Day, access account data real-time across multiple countries on CitiDirect.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're moving $5 trillion roughly per day for those clients around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We trade billions of dollars in a millisecond on our trading platforms.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We can see our liquidity positions real-time around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This can only be done if you've got pretty pristine data and highly automated ecosystems.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, but what is the transformation doing?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What it is doing is simplifying how data moves through the firm and it's about upgrading the management and governance over those flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I've said, we're doing a strategic overhaul of large parts of our infrastructure, so what are we doing?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're making sure we're capturing data accurately using smart tools and automation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll often talk about this smart system, makes sure there's no errors when we book a trade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've seen our error rate down 85% as a result of it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're housing our upstream data in two standardized repositories, they're the golden sources, an in-person data hub which you've heard me talk about a few times and they're a golden source now for all of the downstream data use, populating the thousands of regulatory reports Mark talked about and other areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And what a single repository means is that the data models, the data quality rules, the controls you put in place that govern and manage that data, they all sit in one place rather than being distributed all over the firm as they have been historically.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark's been investing in building a standardized reporting infrastructure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've heard us talk about a single full suite reporting ledger versus the six or so reporting ledgers that we had in the past.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're delivering all of this through consolidated systems, through the automation and streamlining of data flows, so instead of being in multiple pipes, the flows go through single pipes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's a, sorry to get a bit plumber on you for a moment, but I think it is important to understand what it is because it's a lot of work.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a strategic overhaul.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not a series of tactical fixes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Where we're behind, as we do the work on data, we identify specific issues we need to fix as we execute the plan that we have in place.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's some more areas to address than we knew back when we did the plan and we've also accelerated the work on improving the accuracy of our regulatory reports and we increased the scope of this work as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's more comprehensive than originally planned.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, what we're doing, we're adding resources and data experts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're learning from best practices and we're using some great AI and other data tools that are helping to identify anomalies in data and data flows much more quickly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're also, to some of the culture side, we're learning from pilots how do we accelerate broader deployment at scale across the firm in a consistent enterprise-wide manner.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, all of these things in the data side are going to enable us to leapfrog competitors, more revenue opportunities, better client service, fewer buffers, drive more efficiencies and hope at the end the end goal here is it becomes a competitive advantage for the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That is the data plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Clearly, there's a very important element of it related to the consent orders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're behind in a few areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're investing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've already begun that investment, as Mark and I've talked about, to get it done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll get it done.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Yeah, just to say real short follow-up to that.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So you're doing all this great stuff, but you still fell short, just in like one sentence, despite doing all of this great stuff that you described, the regulator still said you didn't get it done.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Why, after doing all that, didn't you get it done in the eyes of the regulators and why will it be fixed now?
