speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Just like a one sentence explanation for that if you have it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I always said that a transformation of this magnitude over multiple years would not be linear.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have many steps forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have setbacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We adjust, we learn from them, we move forward and we get back on track.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And Mike, if I could just put one number into context because you played back the 11,000, which was a number of global regulatory reports across the landscape here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are probably 15 to 30 that are core US reports that are pivotal to our US regulators and a lot of what we're discussing here is about ensuring that we're prioritizing the data that impacts those 15 to 30 reports as we work through this.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will now turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Please let us know if you have any follow-up questions.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: And thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectation and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors, including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Before we get started, I'd like to thank Liz Lynn for being such an incredible partner during these last few months.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I really enjoyed getting to know the entire Citi team, and I'm honored to be the next Head of Investor Relations, and I look forward to working with you all.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: With that, I will turn it over to Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So thank you, Jenn, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm delighted to join you today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let's kick off the call with what we're seeing from a macro perspective and the tremendous engagement we continue to experience with clients before I give you an update on our results and priorities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Certainly, the recovery from the pandemic continues to drive corporate and consumer confidence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I particularly like the robust pipelines we see through the rest of the year and beyond.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Corporate client sentiment remains very positive, with healthy cash flows and liquidity driving M&A activity and deleveraging.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And consumer balance sheets remain unusually strong on the back of the increasing consumer net worth during the pandemic.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now all that said, growth has come off the boil a tad.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are watching three things very closely: the slowdown in China and its impact on global growth; inflation and supply constraints in labor, materials, and energy; and finally, what happens next with the US debt ceiling negotiations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These are also the issues which repeatedly surface in our conversations with clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, turning to the quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We reported net income of $4.6 billion and EPS of $2.15.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Embedded in these results is a pre-tax loss related to the sale of our Australia consumer business, which Mark's going to provide the details on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Excluding this transaction, our third quarter revenues would have been up 3% over last year, and our EPS would have been $2.44.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the Institutional Clients Group, we grew revenues by 4% year-over-year, as we continue to see strong client engagement, with momentum in Investment Banking, Equity Markets and Securities Services, more than offsetting the 16% decline in Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm very proud to tell you that it was Citi's best M&A quarter and the second best Investment Banking quarter in a decade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And lending in the ICG grew again this quarter, albeit modestly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also had a very strong quarter in Equity Markets with revenues up 40% year-over-year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So despite that normalization in Fixed Income versus the pretty extraordinary performance of 2020, overall markets revenues were only down 5%, and they were up 11% versus the third quarter of 2019.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to successfully execute on our strategy to grow fee revenue across the ICG businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: For example, while TTS continues to be impacted by interest rate headwinds, our fees this quarter were the highest in a decade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You can also see how our global network uniquely positions us to help our clients navigate the supply chain challenges so many of them are facing, a dynamic that we expect to persist for the near future.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, we drove double-digit fee revenue growth in Securities Services and the Private Bank, as client assets under custody and assets under management continued their vigorous growth trajectory.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Global Consumer Banking, healthy consumer balance sheets and persistently elevated payment rates did mean that loan growth remained under pressure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The other key drivers are a bit more encouraging, however.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Branded Cards purchase sales are well above 2019 levels, and acquisitions across Branded Cards, Mexico, and the Asia hubs are also all now at or above pre-COVID levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, we continue to benefit from double-digit growth in deposits and assets under management across the franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let me briefly touch on our US retail strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, our digital strategy and investments are starting to pay dividends.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Digital deposits stand at $19 billion, having grown 26% in the last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we see more than two- thirds of our digital deposit balances coming from customers outside of our branch footprint, with about half of those deposits from our cardholders who did not previously have a retail relationship with us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, obviously, we were disappointed by Google's decision to discontinue Google Plex, but we learned a lot through the effort, and the vast majority of the investments will be leveraged for our proprietary efforts and future partnerships.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So all in all, we ended the quarter with a common equity Tier 1 capital ratio of 11.7% on a standardized basis, and our tangible book value per share increased to $79.07, up over 10% from a year ago.
Capital Adequacy & Buffers phrase: common equity tier 1, capital ratio, tier 1 capital

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So far this year, we've returned close to $11 billion to shareholders through a healthy dividend and share repurchases.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We remain committed to returning excess capital over and above the amount necessary to invest in our franchise and to maintain our safety and soundness.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So overall, I'm quite pleased with these results given the environment we're operating in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And while we have much work ahead, we're seeing the results of the previous investments that we have made.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, I'd like to update you on our strategic priorities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to slide 3, we've included a page that clearly lays out our top priorities and some of the actions we've taken to date against them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're going to share this page with you each quarter to ensure you're up-to-date on where we are and the milestones and progress along the way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you can see, we've been hard at work acting against the priorities I've laid out: the transformation, the strategy refresh and our culture and talent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, clearly, the transformation is our number one priority right now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And key to that transformation is our safety and soundness and addressing the consent orders by modernizing our risk and control environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we submitted our plans to our regulators and continue to have a constructive dialogue with them as we pivot now firmly towards execution.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're already well underway in the investment in our risk and control environment, and we are really bringing a culture of excellence to this effort, and we are moving with urgency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also continued to make progress refreshing our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In addition to announcing the sale of our consumer business in Australia, we're deep in the second round of bids for the remaining exit markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've begun the work on how these exits will enable us to simplify our operations in Asia and eliminate stranded costs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're really looking forward to bringing all the strategy work together for you on Investor Day and presenting our vision for the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark's going to touch on, we've begun executing on many of the decisions that we've already made, including in TTS, Wealth and Commercial Banking, with investments in front office hires, as well as enhanced digital product and service offerings.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're already starting to see the impact of these investments emerge through key drivers across these businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And finally, turning to culture and talent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to attract high-caliber external talent whilst driving towards our diversity goals, ensuring clear accountability and breaking down the silos that have historically impeded our progress as a company.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a new Citi, and all of this work has one overarching goal: to responsibly narrow the returns gap with our peers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will update you with the metrics and milestones that we'll use to hold ourselves accountable so you can hold us accountable to them as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And with that, let me turn it over to Mark to go through our performance in more detail, and then we will both be delighted to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Starting on slide 4.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned, Citigroup reported third quarter net income of $4.6 billion, EPS of $2.15 and an RoTCE of 11% on $17.2 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in these results is a pre-tax loss of $680 million related to the sale of our Australia consumer business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding this item, EPS would have been $2.44 with an RoTCE of 12.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, while we received a premium to book on the sale of the business, we did incur a pre-tax loss primarily related to the currency translation adjustment that has built up over time and is already included in our capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Upon closing, the capital impact of this loss will be largely neutralized, and we will release approximately $800 million of capital allocated to the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 1% from the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the loss on sale, revenues would have been up 3%, largely driven by Investment Banking fees, as well as strong growth in Equity Markets and Securities Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 5% year-over-year, and constant dollars expenses were up 4% in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a year-to-date basis, our expenses have grown by 5% with two main drivers: investments in the transformation, including the six programs to address the consent orders, which drove about 3% of the growth so far this year; and business-led investments which focus on our front office expansion in the Investment Bank, Wealth and Securities Services and investments to improve our client experience and digitize our network.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So far this year, we added over 500 bankers, advisors and other front office support in Wealth, including the Private Bank, and the Consumer Wealth businesses, and 200 corporate and investment bankers globally in high- growth areas, including senior hires across tech, healthcare, fintech, and private equity coverage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our services businesses, TTS and Securities Services, we continue to improve client experience and digital capabilities, which is enabling us to capture significant new mandates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In consumer, these investments include development and marketing for new offerings like the Custom Cash card and installment lending, as well as investments in our mobile and digital user experience.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition, there were also increases in volume and revenue-related expenses, as well as business-as-usual expenses which were largely offset by efficiency savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, we will continue to analyze our expenses to look for opportunities to self-fund investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And now turning to credit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit performance remains strong, with net credit losses of just under $1 billion, more than offset by an ACL release of $1.2 billion, largely reflecting continued improvement in portfolio quality.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In constant dollars, end-of-period loans were down 1% year-over-year, reflecting the impact of the Australia exit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding this impact, loans would have been up 1% year-over-year, driven by active client engagement in TTS, Private Bank and Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: End-of-period deposits were up 6% year-over-year, reflecting continued engagement with our consumer and corporate clients, as well as continued momentum in client acquisition and deepening across both corporate clients and consumers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, as Jane noted earlier, we returned roughly $11 billion in capital so far this year, and while we remain committed to continuing to invest in our franchise, we will continue to return excess capital to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning now to each business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 5 shows the results for the Institutional Clients Group.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased 4% year-over-year and sequentially, mainly driven by Investment Banking, Equity Markets and Securities Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 9%, with about half of the increase driven by transformation and the other half driven by business-led investments and higher revenue-related costs, partially offset by efficiency savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit costs were largely benign in the quarter, as minimum net credit losses were more than offset by an ACL reserve release.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of $3.4 billion, which grew 21% in the quarter and 60% on a year-to-date basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And ICG delivered an RoTCE of 14.5% for the quarter and 18.8% year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 6 shows revenues for the Institutional Clients Group in more detail.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the Banking side, revenues were up 11%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Treasury and Trade Solutions, continued growth in fee revenues of 20% year-over-year, the highest quarter for fees in a decade, reflected solid client engagement and client acquisition, as well as a recovery in commercial card revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, all of this was more than offset by the impact of lower deposit spreads, driving total revenues down 4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're continuing to see momentum across our payment business, with 15% growth in cross-border flows and 10% growth in clearings transactions over the past year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As of quarter-end, TTS loans grew 15%, mainly in trade loans where our technology investments in supply chain and deep local knowledge are enabling us to meet our clients' needs across the globe.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking revenues were up 39% year over-year, largely driven by M&A, as we continue to see the benefits from our front office investments, which positioned us well to take advantage of increased deal activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned, this was the second best quarter for Investment Banking revenues and the best quarter for M&A in a decade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Private Bank revenues grew 4%, driven by growth in assets under management, loans and deposits, reflecting momentum with new and existing clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This quarter, we added almost 200 bankers, investment counselors and other front office support, and onboarded over 200 new clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our investments in talent continue to drive growth, which bodes well for our overall strategy in Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate Lending revenues were up 17%, primarily driven by lower cost of funds and a modest gain on sale, partially offset by lower loan volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total Markets and Securities Services revenues decreased 4% from last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income revenues decreased 16%, reflecting the continued normalization in market activity across rates and spread products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, we saw strong activity with our corporate clients, engaging with them in foreign exchange products to support their global operations and hedging solutions to assist with their risk mitigation efforts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equity Markets revenues were up 40%, our second best quarter in a decade, driven by cash equities, derivatives and prime finance, reflecting solid client activity and favorable market conditions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This is another business where we see our investments in talent and technology paying off.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Securities Services, revenues were up 10%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Here we saw strong growth in fee revenues as the investments that we've been making in our platform and product capabilities enabled us to grow revenue with both new and existing clients, partially offset by lower deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, looking at year-to-date results in ICG, we've seen a strong contribution from Investment Banking and Equity Markets, as well as solid results in the Private Bank and Securities Services, which help to offset the expected normalization in Fixed Income Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning now to the results for Global Consumer Banking in constant dollars on slide 7.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 14% and 5% excluding the loss on sale, as solid deposit growth and momentum in investment management were more than offset by lower card balances and lower deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 5%, with about half driven by transformation and the remainder driven by business-led investments and volume related expenses, partially offset by efficiency savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a modest benefit this quarter, as a roughly $1 billion ACL reserve release more than offset net credit losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of $1.3 billion, which grew 44%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And GCB delivered a 15% RoTCE and a 21.5% RoTCE excluding the loss on sale.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, looking at year-to-date results, we've seen steady improvement in our drivers over the course of the year, with purchase sales up 5% relative to 2019 and acquisitions nearing pre-COVID levels globally.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the business delivered 22.4% RoTCE excluding the loss on sale.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 8 shows the results for North America Consumer in more detail.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total third quarter revenues were down 4% from last year as we continue to see headwinds from higher payment rates and deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we are encouraged by the trends we are seeing in both Cards and Retail Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Branded Cards and Retail Services, purchase sales were up versus the prior year by 24% and 14%, respectively, with both above 2019 levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Retail Banking, average deposits and within that, checking deposits, were both up 14%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: AUMs were up 16%, and Citigold households were up 13% this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're also making progress on our US digital strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: US digital deposits grew 26% compared to the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And installment loan balances, including our Flex Loan and Flex Pay products have also grown substantially, up 22% compared to the prior year, and over 80% of these loans are originated digitally.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we show results for our international consumer banking in constant dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 30% year-over-year in the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the loss on sale, revenues declined 5%, with a 7% decline in Latin America and a 4% decline in Asia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking at international consumer overall, we're seeing good momentum in investment management, with 10% growth in assets under management, primarily driven by Asia, and the growth is meaningfully higher if you look specifically at the four international wealth hubs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Purchase sales grew 8% versus the prior year, and average deposits grew 3%, albeit at lower deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 10 provides additional detail on Global Consumer credit trends.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit remains favorable again this quarter across all regions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And given the delinquency trends we're seeing today, we do not expect credit deterioration in the US portfolio in 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 11 shows the results for Corporate/Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased by over $300 million, driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses declined by $300 million due to the absence of the civil money penalty which we incurred in the third quarter of last year, offset by an increase in expenses related to the transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Credit costs were still a benefit in the quarter but reflect the lower ACL release in the legacy portfolio relative to last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Finally, EBT was a loss of $330 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 12 shows our net interest revenue and margin trends, as well as noninterest revenues on a reported basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the third quarter, net interest revenue of $10.4 billion declined roughly $100 million year-over-year, reflecting lower loan balances and the impact of lower rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a year-to-date basis, net interest revenue declined by roughly $2.3 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to noninterest revenues on the bottom of the slide, in the third quarter, non-NIR declined by approximately $50 million year-over-year, driven by the impact from the loss on the sale of the Australia consumer business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the loss, noninterest revenues would have grown by over $600 million or 9%, driven by strong growth in fees in ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 13, we show our key capital metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our CET1 capital ratio ticked down to 11.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: During the quarter, Citi returned a total of $4 billion to common shareholders in the form of $1 billion in dividends and share repurchases of $3 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our supplementary leverage ratio was largely unchanged at 5.8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our tangible book value per share grew by 10% year-over-year to $79.07, driven by net income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Before we move to Q&A, let me touch briefly on our outlook for 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the top line, for total Citigroup, we still expect revenues to be down in the mid-single-digit range on a reported basis, excluding any divestiture related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the expense side, we continue to expect full-year expenses to be up in the mid-single digit range, excluding any divestiture-related impacts, as we continue to transform our risk and control environment and invest in our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we will continue to look for ways to partially self-fund these investments over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your first question is from the line of John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Please go ahead with your questions.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, I wanted to ask about the net interest income.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: It seems like overall it came in a little bit better than you might have expected when you spoke at the Barclays Conference in September.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Can you give us a little more color on what drove the improvement in the core ex-Markets NII this quarter and how that makes you feel about the setup for NII growing from here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When we look at, it's on page 12, we came in at about $10.4 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think there were a couple factors that play through here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One were the treasury investments that we've been making contributed to that as we put some of the excess liquidity that we have to work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second, I mentioned earlier that we saw some loan growth in cards sequentially, Branded Cards in particular, up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But also, within that, we saw some of the late fees and balcon fees in cards kind of play through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, there's an extra day in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, the combination of those things contributed to the tick-up here that we've seen.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of kind of the balance of the year, that all feeds into the guidance that I've given for total revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that really hasn't changed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we continue to look to invest in the Cards portfolio through new acquisitions with the long-term perspective of how we grow loans over time there.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And just as a follow-up, on capital returns, while your total return is very healthy, it doesn't look like it increased much from the $4 billion that you did in the second quarter despite the Fed lifting its restrictions.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Is this something you're being conservative on, given a lot of change going on at the company right now?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Or as you free up capital from the business exits, your stock is trading at a low valuation, how are you thinking about allocating that freed-up capital between investing in the business and returning it to shareholders?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, our philosophy really has not changed on this in terms of you've heard me say a number of times that as we generate income, as we utilize our DTA over time, as capital gets released from the transactions that we do, we want to ensure that we're able to serve our clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We want to ensure that we can invest in the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then anything in excess of that, we want to return to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that perspective has not changed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, the SCB allows for us to take those decisions in the given quarter based on what we're seeing in terms of our expected performance and based on all of the other factors I mentioned, including the capital release in SA-CCR and things of that sort.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we'll continue to take those decisions with that philosophy in mind, which is how do we return any excess we have to shareholders over time.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Two interesting things – wonder if we'd get your quick comments on perspective.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: One was, you became the first custodian to receive regulatory approval in onshore custody business in China.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I wonder if you could frame perspective on how material that opportunity is.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And then the same kind of thing on your plans to enter the Australian Buy Now, Pay Later market and what that means for not just Australia but more globally, how you're viewing that in connection with the rest of your consumer business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, why don't I take that one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of our operations and business in China, I'd say, we've been in that country for 100 years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We understand the dynamics in the local market well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're currently serving a very large number of investors in that market, 70% of the Fortune 500 corporates in China, how they operate on the ground and gain access to China's capital markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're looking at – we're very happy to have custody license in China.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It will also help support our operations in Hong Kong, and it's part of the growth of our Securities Services strategy that we've got.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've seen the benefits starting to flow through in this quarter's results from some of those previous investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this is just another one of the investments that we're making in that business that we like a lot and we think we're well positioned in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in terms of Buy Now, Pay Later, I think this is one where obviously we're divesting our operations in Asia on that front, but we've certainly taken – we've taken the learnings from our operations throughout the Asian region, particularly been applying them to the US over the last few years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we've certainly not been sitting still in the US.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been building out our personal lending platform since 2019.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that's part of our broader digitization strategy in US consumer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been seeing very strong growth in our Flex portfolios, both as we leverage some of our existing partnerships such as American Airlines and we work to expand with new partners in POS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And one of the areas I'm particularly excited about is the partnering that we're doing with the largest e-commerce player, Amazon, on point-of-sale lending for our cards customers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And those capabilities are and will be leveraged with many additional partners and channels in the States and into Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And finally, we've been expanding our product suite by developing off-card lending capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think, as you've heard from Mark, our payments on installment loans to existing card customers, 88% of those total sales are in digital channels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So as we look at all of this, I would say, clearly, there's a trend towards multiple different formats of how a customer can and wants to pay, and we're really on the front foot of this and making some strong progress on the back of the investments that we've been making over the last few years, and we'll continue to do so.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Wanted to understand a little bit more about what you think you can do in the US cards business.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I know we just spoke a little bit about some of the things that you have been executing on, but when I look at the card business, while it's up on a year-on-year basis, it is trending a bit below some of the peers in terms of growth rates.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And then you've got the retail partner card program which has some opportunities there to, in my opinion, get a little bit of a refresh to be as dynamic as some of your best-in class peers.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So wondering how you're thinking about that.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And as well on the deposit side in the US with Google now – partnership not going forward, what are you thinking about with regard to leveraging your mobile app across the US in a way that might not be understood well by the investor community?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Because it seems like you've got a great app and it's just under-penetrating your opportunity set with your brand.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Betsy, why don't I get started and Jane may want to jump in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I'll start with kind of your comments related to cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, look, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, particularly when you look at US Branded Cards, we did start to see a tick-up there as it relates to loan balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The loans were up about 1% year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They were up about 3% quarter-over-quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I think is really important here is the market re-entry because as you're seeing, purchase sales are up but payment rates are still quite high.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we've got to see how stimulus and liquidity plays out over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, what we're focused on is how we're re-entering into the market.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're doing that both through our Custom Cash launch, which is helping to drive new acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, our new acquisition volumes are back to 2019 levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Over half of those acquisitions are in proprietary cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're being thoughtful about that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So over the last five years, we've been shortening our promotional periods and adding higher fees for balance transfers and targeting a lower mix of promotional balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And those things, as you know, will feed future average interest earning balances, as our experience is that roughly half of those balances ultimately convert to revolving over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, that's an important step.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing that I'll mention is, just to reiterate what Jane pointed out, which is we're thinking about lending more broadly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're driving growth on card lending products like Flex Pay and Flex Loan.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And those don't have promotional periods associated with them, and they start to generate interest from day one.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we're keenly focused on this.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're obviously a big player here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's obviously an important part of our portfolio and generates healthy returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we need to be positioned to capture growth as the economy continues to recover and behavior normalizes, and we need to be prepared if behavior doesn't normalize as quickly as we'd like with things like broader lending products.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Research.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: My question maybe just focused a little on rates.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I think we're so focused on US rates, but given your global exposure, we've seen rate hikes in Mexico, Brazil, now we're contemplating rate hikes soon in the UK.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How do we think about your rate sensitivity to the rest of the world?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And do you see some benefits coming up over the next few quarters on the NII side?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I mean, we have seen a number of rate hikes and then the talk of rate hikes here in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you look at kind of our IRE that we report, we're not that sensitive to the short end or long end.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But that said, rate increases are beneficial for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we are – we've got a lot of liquidity that's available for us to invest as we see rates increase but, also, have enough dry powder to ensure that we're taking advantage of client demand as that starts to return as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But for our firm, as you pointed out, the global impact to rates is quite important and increases internationally help to fuel our performance in parts of the franchise like TTS and elsewhere.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question comes from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Mark, thanks for your update on just the reiterated cost guide for this year.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And I know probably too early to talk about next year, but can you just help us understand just the moving parts underneath incentive comp transformation and what we should be thinking about in terms of just run rate costs from here.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: If we can even stay away from just kind of like what next year growth looks like.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: But any color, the question is coming up a lot for sure across the large bank group in terms of acquired investments versus other things going on at the bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, let me start by saying, as I pointed out in prepared remarks, our expenses in aggregate are on guidance, so to speak, both as it relates to the transformation expected spend which year-to-date is up 3%, as well as our total expenses which are up 5% year-to-date, again consistent with the guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I think about this, those are two very important categories of spend.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane has pointed out, transformation is our top priority and we're going to spend what's necessary to get that done.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we need to ensure that we're investing long term across the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I would also highlight that expenses is something that we control, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we are very deliberate about the spend that you're seeing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in fact, I'm scrubbing, we are scrubbing every single expense line that we have, right, to ensure that the dollars that we're putting to work are being put to work in an optimal fashion, that they're necessary dollars to be spent.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in doing that, we're also looking for productivity and efficiency opportunities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in fact, we've seen that play through the expense levels that you see today.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look at – if we – as we look at our expenses, we've generated somewhere between $300 million and $400 million a quarter in efficiencies through 2021, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So expense management is something that we're very disciplined about, we're very deliberate about, and we handle that in a very controlled fashion, recognizing the priorities that we pointed out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not going to give you guidance for 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I will tell you that our guidance hasn't changed for the balance of 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're obviously in the middle of our budget season, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we firm that up and finalize that, we'll share that with you and our investors more broadly.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: My question is for Jane.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Jane, you said on this call it's a new Citigroup.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I'm just referring to the 8-K from August where it announced a bonus scheme for top executives.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Apparently, that will be broadened out to many more.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And so, we as shareholders and those who represent shareholders, we see this bonus scheme before we see the targets.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, I guess my question is, do you have the targets?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And if so, can you reveal those?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Although I suspect that won't be until March 2nd.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Or do you not have targets yet or what's happening?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Because either way, it doesn't feel good for us investors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Oh.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, Mike, I'm actually really glad you brought this up, as we obviously saw your note the other day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If you bear with me for a minute, let's just take a step back and start with our compensation philosophy because I think it's really important for our shareholders to understand this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So the compensation of the management team is designed to be performance based.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's aligned with the interest of our shareholders most importantly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, first, any of the deferred awards we have downside built in, and we clearly saw this last year in the PSU performance, which paid out only 28% of its target.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then secondly, the annual process holds management accountable for our results, as we also saw last year with meaningful comp reductions resulting from the consent orders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So then, if we then turn to the transformation program.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I said in the opening, there isn't anything that's more important than the successful execution of the program.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's our number one priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We want to make sure the bank is modernized in its risk and control environment and it will also benefit our shareholders in terms of the performance of the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The board and I hold the senior leaders driving that transformation accountable for its successful execution.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm certainly driving this program with urgency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I also need to retain key talent because it's a pretty tight talent market right now, as we all know.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we need to do this so that we can hit the milestones and to deliver with excellence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So to hold people accountable and drive the outcomes, we need both carrots and we need sticks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And to your question, we're going to put in rigorous metrics to determine if the rewards get paid out at all and, if so, what percentage will be paid out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we laid out the criteria in the 8-K, and the final metrics will be ones that reflect input from the board, from myself, and the other stakeholders involved.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we'll make – and those were obviously disclosed in the proxy, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So you'll see them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So as you can see, I think, the main message from me is there will be consequences if we fall short of what is expected, just as there were last year for the management and the leaders of the program.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm accountable.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: My team is accountable.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And very simply, we must and we will deliver.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I just wanted to, Jane, go back to, you mentioned disappointment at Google Plex pulling out.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just talk to us in terms of, did you view that as a critical client acquisition tool?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And given that that's not moving forward, does that put some urgency in terms of other partnerships that you may strike to improve sort of the deposit gathering efforts?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I – obviously, as I said in the opening, we were disappointed in their decision.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it is just one part of our digital strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We certainly didn't have all the eggs in that basket, as we've been talking about for a few quarters now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And what I am pleased is the strength of the digital engagement that we are seeing across the US, it's lagged other geographies around the world across the industry on this dimension, and also the growth in sticky digital deposits that we're seeing in the US.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The piece I like is we deliberately invested in very reusable capabilities for future partnerships and existing ones that we have, as well as our own proprietary efforts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So if I can try and make that comment a bit alive.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've added 80 APIs, which really make it very easy to operate with partners.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've developed a whole suite of embedded services that are ready to deploy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's things like real-time digital alerts, partner branded communications.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And probably most importantly, maybe this is the geek in me, we put together new tech stacks and we've learned a lot about doing this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's very valuable for what we're doing right now and for partnerships going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So at the end of the day, I think all the things that we've been doing, both in some of the work with Google but also with partnerships around the world, is going to further our digitization strategy in US consumer, continue helping us grow and drive the returns here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And, I would say, we're always feeling urgency in improving the performance, the growth and returns in consumer franchises.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Matt O’Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Hey there, Matt.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: So you submitted a plan to the regulators this quarter.

speaker: Connor
sentence: Can you just give us a sense of when you expect to hear back from them and then what kind of things you'll be able to communicate to all of us.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I know there's always limited abilities in what you can discuss about the regulatory stuff.

speaker: Connor
sentence: But what are some of the data points that you're looking for internally and what – and when do you think you can share?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, I think, as you heard from me, this is our number one priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think it's for the benefit of all of our stakeholders that we get this done with excellence and we get this done right.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as we said, we submitted our plan in the third quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm personally very proud of it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is a multiyear plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As Mark said, it comprises six major programs, and it will position us to operate with excellence in the years ahead in a digital world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in particular, it provides very clear target stakes for our risk and controls and for our core operating model elements.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we've said, we've now firmly pivoted to executing that plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I have to say, we have a very constructive and frankly a really helpful dialogue that's been ongoing with our regulators.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's not as if you submit and then you haven't spoken.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This has been very constructive all the way through.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of execution, we're kind of going full steam ahead here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm really pleased with the caliber of talent we've brought in from inside and outside of the firm, as Mark talked about, so we can ensure that we're executing with excellence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Some of the areas are new hires in data.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think, importantly, we're putting as much effort on culture as on modernization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Karen Peetz and her team are ensuring we have the capabilities and rigorous governance, so we're executing in a very disciplined way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We deliver the outcomes from the investments we're making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We put in a new accountability framework.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I have to say, our board is certainly holding us firmly and regularly to account.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we'll be sharing more details obviously at Investor Day and as we go through this, but I think the main message from me is we pivoted to execution and we're getting on with this.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Vivek Juneja with JP Morgan.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Just wanted to clarify on this compensation 8-K that you talked about.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: You obviously have – you've always had bonuses for short-term and you've had long-term incentive comp that you always paid your executives, similar to everybody else.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: So the transformation project seems to be over and above that.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Shouldn't that be part of what long-term compensation and incentive awards are meant for?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: I'm trying to understand what the logic behind adding an additional payment here is, because that's what management has already been partly compensated for, which is longer-term moves and changes in performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think it's exactly as I – well, first of all, thank you.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think as I said earlier in answer to Mike's questions, we want to drive the program with urgency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We need to retain key talent, and it is a very tight talent market, as you know.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I want to make sure that the – that there's no question from anyone involved in these – in the programs that this is their number one priority for the bank to execute this with excellence.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But there are both carrots and sticks here, and those come through the individual program and the individual assessments that everyone participates in every year, as well as in this piece.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think this is fully aligned with the shareholders' interest.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You want to have management really incented to deliver this with excellence but equally with all the downsides if we fail to do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the program is designed to do just that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question if from the line of Andrew Lim with Société Générale.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: So it's a bit of a technical one.

speaker: Andrew Lim
sentence: Wondering if you could give a bit of a color on the SA-CCR implementation for the CET1 ratio in terms of the quantum of the impacts and the timing of the implementation.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: How are you?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you guys share with us, in looking at your Global Consumer Banking business in North America in your supplement, I think it's page 8, you guys gave us a nice breakdown between the Retail Banking, Citi-Branded Cards and Citi Retail Services.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And I noticed that in Retail Banking, there was a loss in the quarter.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And can you just give us some color on what's maybe driving that and just the outlook for that part of the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the Retail Banking performance, the drag there is in part the higher expenses from the transformation spend that's playing through and impacting income there.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Just wanted to follow up again, a follow-up to my other question and as Vivek expressed.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Jane and Mark, you've mentioned that you have to serve regulators, number one.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I think that's clear to everybody on this call.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then you mentioned serving stakeholders.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But I think the question really gets to what's being done for shareholders?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And shareholders have been left behind at Citigroup over almost any timeframe.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And, Mark, maybe I might disagree with the philosophy a little bit and your philosophy set is first serve clients, then invest in the business, then you do buybacks.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Why should you have any change in your philosophy is because the discount to book value is just getting greater and greater.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Your discount versus peer has increased.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Citi has worst-in-class returns, adjusted efficiency and stock market valuation.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So why not a little change in that philosophy to more buybacks versus investing if you have such a great opportunity with your share price?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So what can you do from a symbolic nature, like, everyone gets paid in stock?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Or what can you do about the capital freed up from the sale of Australia and use all that to buy back stock?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Or what can you do to show that, obviously regulators matter, stakeholders matter, but what can you do to show that shareholders also matter given such the underperformance of the share price?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then, since you're only giving one question at a time, just a little bit more follow-up on your US consumer strategy as far as digital deposits, cross-selling to credit cards, point of sale with Amazon, a little bit more on that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mike, it's Jane, let – obviously.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let me kick this one off.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Unequivocally, our shareholders are incredibly important to us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when we look at where we're trading and the underperformance around that, it is something that we are determined in the strategy refresh, in the transformation work we're doing, and in the culture and talent work we're doing to address this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're going to do what is necessary to narrow the gap with our peers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're going to ensure we have the right business mix and strategies to drive up the returns, and you're starting to see where that is – where we're headed to with that from the different decisions we've already announced.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And obviously, it will all come together on Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But secondly, we're also going to do it by running the bank better.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've laid out on page 3 of the presentation what are the different priorities so that our investors realize the value that we think lies in Citi and what we are going to be doing to unlock that for their benefit.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think it – I hope it's pretty clear in terms of the framework that we're using and the principles around that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in terms of, as Mark said, from a – not only unlocking the value that we see in Citi, which I really do think is pretty tremendous and I'm quite excited about, it's also then what will we do with our excess capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've heard me say, given where we trade, so disappointingly below book, obviously, share repurchases make sense for our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also do have a healthy dividend yield, but that's an important part of the mix.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But there's no question around the attractiveness for shareholder relatively of the stock buybacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we will certainly be returning excess capital to our shareholders and be very mindful of the bar that is required for investment internally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you've seen that with the decisions that we've made on the exits in Asia on consumer and some of the other moves, that we will exit the businesses we think are lower returning and reinvest where appropriate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we'll return that to shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I can see my CFO is champing at the bit here to jump in as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I just – I think you answered it very well, I'll just add a couple of quick things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, that when we invest in the business towards clients or more broadly in the business, we're doing it where returns are above our cost of capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we're making smart decisions about how to redeploy that capital to ensure that we're narrowing that gap to peers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing I'd point out is that in the first couple of quarters of the year, we've maxed out the capital return that was available for us to deliver before the SCB came into play, and that is because our shareholders are so important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the third, as Jane mentioned, is that we have a skew towards buybacks, again, just given where the stock is trading and given where our dividend yield is.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So thank you for the question.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your final question is from the line of Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Thanks for squeezing me in here.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Jane, I was hoping to just ask on the wealth management opportunity.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: This is an area where we have great competitive intensity.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: You have a large – many large peers have been investing heavily in this space for years.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And I know you're going to cover some of this at Investor Day and provide more detail, but just at a high level, I was hoping you could speak to what differentiates Citi's value prop from some of the peers in the space, whether you have the technology or infrastructure in place to support some of your growth ambitions.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And then just lastly, whether you can engage in M&A or is that precluded under the consent order if you were to look to expand into that arena inorganically.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I'm pretty pleased around our opportunities here because we have all the pieces to be very successful.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a strong brand in – amongst the affluent, not just here in the states off our Retail Banking franchise, we've got a very – we've got a pretty heavily affluent base, but around the world and when you go into Asia, in particular, this is the aspirational wealth management brand on the ground there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've also got real breadth of client relationships, and this is where the connectivity points also become important in those four principles that we laid out for the strategy refresh.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have commercial banking operations in 30 geographies around the world that have been operating for many years now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is the engine of wealth creation in the world, and we have the relationship with the owners already.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: so the synergies that we will be able to generate by much more closely connecting them will be very important.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, the elevator from the affluent client base in our consumer franchise, all the way up to the ultra-high net worth in the Private Bank is obviously a natural area to build out that we haven't really invested in that elevator and thinking of it that way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a great – we have some great platforms.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our Institutional Clients business around the world means that we've got top two platforms for our private banking clients, in particular, to take advantage of, but it's also ones that our consumer clients have as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So the opportunity here is to bring all these different pieces together into a single integrated offering across the full spectrum of clients in the US and in the global offshore wealth centers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would also point the fact that we're already the top three player in Asia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not as if we don't have scale and that this is a start-up business here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're already seeing that this is coming into fruition quickly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We obviously announced the focus on Wealth at the beginning of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've already acquired 21,500 new-to- bank clients in Asia so far this year, that we've added over 500 bankers, advisors and other front office support year-to-date.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've done one of the biggest tech releases for Wealth in the third quarter of this year, with over 70-plus features going live on the back of the digital platform we launched last quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think the fact that we've got all these different pieces, we're putting them all together, is really giving us momentum and accelerating the opportunity for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this is a trend.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Wealth trend is going to be one that is one of those unstoppable trends, particularly in Asia in the years ahead.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll look at acquisitions at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, it's more focused around what are digital capabilities, what are other things to enhance the value propositions and the technological side.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And those aren't just acquisitions, it's partnerships and the like that we've been investing in so that we really serve the wealthy clients across the full spectrum of their needs rather than just narrowly as some of the other players are in just the sort of investment products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got the benefit across the board.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you all for joining today's call.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Please feel free to reach out to IR with any follow up questions.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Have a great day.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors, including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: With that, I'll turn it over to Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and thanks everyone for joining us today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, we are certainly still living through interesting times.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And overall, I am pleased with how our bank is navigating through them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you'll hear from me shortly, we continue to focus intensely on executing our strategy and our transformation as we outlined at Investor Day, whilst supporting our clients in this complex environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So before I get into the quarter, let me highlight some observations about what we see going on around the world, given our unique vantage point.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The global macro outlook that we shared with you over the last couple of quarters has been borne out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There is accumulating evidence of slowing global growth, and we now expect to experience rolling country level recession starting this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The severity and timing of these recessions depend where in the world you are.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Although persistently high inflation is driving a global softening of consumer demand for goods.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the Eurozone and the U.K., the supply shocks are most severe.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Growth prospects have deteriorated sharply, and headline inflation is running at nearly 10%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: All eyes are on this winter's weather forecast and the energy supply.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The U.S. economy, however, remains relatively resilient.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So while we are seeing signs of economic slowing, consumers and corporates remain healthy as our very low net credit losses demonstrate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Supply chain constraints are easing, the labor market remains strong, so it is all a question of what it takes to truly tame persistently high core inflation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now history would suggest that, that will be quite a lot and for some time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Therefore, we could well see a mild recession in the second half of '23.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We believe the U.S. economy is well positioned to withstand it all else being equal in the geopolitical arena, that is.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, in Asia, we continue to be concerned with China's COVID lockdowns, which took a bigger bite out of economic activity than anticipated, exacerbated by a lack of intensified macro stimulus.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is geopolitical risks and rates that dominate discussions with our corporate clients worldwide.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd say we're more focused on market liquidity generally and counterparty risk than our credit risk in the near term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Nonetheless, we are planning conservatively, and we are prepared for all environments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Against this backdrop, today, we reported net income of $3.5 billion, EPS of $1.63 and an RoTCE of 8.2%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew revenues by 6%, including a gain on sale of our consumer business in the Philippines.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While we had excellent performance in some areas, our results could have been better in a few others.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services delivered another very strong quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: TTS saw revenues up 40% year-over-year with growth in each business and in fees.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Key drivers of our strategy such as wallet share, trade loan originations and cross border transactions are all trending strongly in the right direction and are ahead of our plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Securities Services was up 15%, despite assets under custody being impacted by the declines in equity markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have onboarded over $1 trillion in AUC and AUA since the beginning of the year and we're seeing good momentum in issuer services, in particular.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Markets, on the other hand, came in lower with revenues down 7%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In fixed income, we matched last year's particularly good showing through our long standing strength in FX, offsetting a weaker quarter in spread products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In equities, reduced activity in derivatives, which is a core part of our platform, led to lower revenues compared to last year's exceptional performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we continued to optimize RWA in markets, consistent with our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking was the business most adversely impacted by the macro environment across the industry, with geopolitics and fears of recession significantly reducing deal flows and the appetite for M&A.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to invest in building out our teams for long-term growth opportunities, including health care, technology and energy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'm really pleased with the high caliber of bankers who are attracted to both our platform and our culture.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The environment for wealth management continued to be less than ideal.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our revenues were down only slightly and meaningfully up outside of Asia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our strategy to capture the synergies with our businesses, such as the wealth referral initiatives between Commercial Banking, Retail Banking and Investment Banking is progressing well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also continue to steadily attract new clients and increase the ranks of our client advisers, as you will see in our KPIs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Nonetheless, we are slowing the pace of some of the investments in this business given the environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking further solidified its growth trajectory.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Card sales, ANR, interest-earning balances and customer acquisition all saw good growth and we continued to increase digital uptake.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Retail Services joined Branded Cards in having double-digit revenue growth this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Retail Banking also grew contributing to a 10% overall revenue increase for the business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you can see in the presentation, our cost of credit reflects the quality of our loan portfolio in both ICG and PBWM.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There were effectively no credit losses in ICG, and U.S. consumer NCLs remain well below the pre-COVID levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Consumer loan growth together with the worsening of our macroeconomic assumptions drove a modest ACL build this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While our expenses are elevated as we continue to invest in our businesses, and in our transformation, we are managing them closely, and we remain on track to meet the full year guidance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, the transformation is a multiyear effort, and we're committed to meeting the expectations of our regulators given the paramount importance of safety and soundness.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to be in constructive dialogues with them and are updating our execution plans as appropriate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Stepping back, I'm generally pleased with the advances we're making in the key drivers of the strategy we laid out for you in March, and these are laid out on Page 3.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing good momentum in realizing client synergies and in attracting talent to grow the franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of simplification, we continue to make progress on the divestitures of our international consumer businesses and the elimination of their associated stranded costs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We closed the sale of the Philippines during the third quarter and are on track to close Bahrain, Malaysia and Thailand during the fourth quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also announced the wind down of our consumer franchise in the U.K. to focus fully on the wealth franchise there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I would also note, we're ahead of our plan in our Korean consumer wind down.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to shrink our operations in and exposure to Russia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: To be clear, our intention is to wind down our presence in that country.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In August, we announced the wind down of our consumer and local commercial banking businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While we have been supporting our multinational clients in Russia, we are now informing them that we will be ending nearly all of the institutional banking services we offer by the end of the first quarter of next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At that point, our only operations in Russia will be those necessary to fulfill our remaining legal and regulatory obligations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to capital, we returned $1 billion to our shareholders through common dividends during the quarter, while buybacks continue to be on hold.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will keep evaluating that decision on a quarterly basis as, due to increasing regulatory requirements, we build our CET1 ratio to 13% or so by mid next year, and that includes a management buffer of 100 basis points.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We ended the quarter at a CET1 ratio of 12.2% as we actively managed our RWA usage throughout our lines of business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Lastly, our tangible book value per share increased to $80.34.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, the bottom line is that while the environment is a challenging one, and we expect it will remain so, we continue to focus relentlessly on executing the strategy we presented to you at our Investor Day and on making steady progress.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now I'd like to turn it over to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then we'd be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm going to start with the firm-wide financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the third quarter, unless I indicate otherwise, and spend a little more time on expenses, credit and capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Then I will turn to the results of each segment and end with full year 2022 guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 4, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the third quarter, we reported net income of $3.5 billion and EPS of $1.63, with an RoTCE of 8.2% on $18.5 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in these results are pretax divestiture-related impacts of approximately $520 million, largely driven by a gain on the sale of the Philippines consumer business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divestiture-related impacts, EPS and RoTCE would have been $1.50 and 7.5%, respectively.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, total revenues increased 6% on a reported basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divestiture-related impacts, revenues were down 1%, as growth in net interest income was more than offset by lower noninterest revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net interest income grew 18%, driven by the impact of higher interest rates across the firm and strong loan growth in PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Noninterest revenues were down 12% on a reported basis and 28% excluding divestiture-related impacts, largely reflecting declines in investment banking, markets, and investment revenues in wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total expenses of $12.7 billion increased 8% and 7%, excluding divestiture-related impacts, largely driven by transformation, inflation and other risk and control initiatives.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.4 billion, driven by net credit losses of approximately $900 million and an ACL build of approximately $500 million, primarily driven by loan growth in PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had $18.7 billion in total reserves with a reserve to funded loan ratio of approximately 2.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 5, we show net interest income, loans and deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
