sentence: In the third quarter, total net interest income increased by approximately $600 million on a sequential basis and approximately $1.9 billion on a year over-year basis across the firm, driven by higher interest rates, management of deposit repricing and loan growth in PBWM.
financial_terms: billion, loan growth, net interest income, million

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were down by approximately 2%, largely driven by the impact of foreign exchange translation and lower balances in Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding FX, loans were largely flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And average deposits were down by approximately 2%, largely driven by declines in Legacy Franchises and the impact of foreign exchange translation, partially offset by the issuance of institutional CDs as we continue to diversify the funding profile of the bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding FX, deposits were up roughly 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And sequentially, our net interest margin increased by 7 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 6, we show an expense walk for the third quarter with the key underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, expenses increased by 8%, and 7% excluding the impact of divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: 2% of the increase was driven by transformation investments with about 2/3 related to the risk, controls, data and finance programs and approximately 25% of the investments in those programs are related to technology.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As of today, we have over 10,000 people dedicated to the transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About 1% of the expense increase was driven by business-led investments as we continue to hire commercial and investment bankers as well as client advisers in wealth, and we continue to invest in the client experience as well as front-office onboarding and platforms.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: 1% was due to higher volume-related expenses across both PBWM and ICG, and approximately 3% was driven by other risk and control investments and inflation, partially offset by productivity savings and the impact of foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across all these buckets, we continue to invest in technology, including systems and hiring people, resulting in our technology-related spend of approximately 16% for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 7, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Over the last several years, we have been disciplined with our loan growth and consistent with our risk appetite framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This framework includes credit risk limits that consider concentrations including country, industry, credit rating and in the case of consumer, FICO scores.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And importantly, these limits apply across the firm in aggregate and we continuously analyze our portfolios and concentrations under a range of stress scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a result, we feel very good about our asset quality and reserve levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, our reserves to funded loan ratio was approximately 2.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And within that, PBWM and U.S. Cards is 3.7% and 7.5%, respectively, both right around day 1 CECL levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In PBWM, the majority of our card portfolios skew towards higher FICO customers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And while we have started to see signs of normalization in both portfolios, NCL rates continue to be less than half of pre-COVID levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our ICG portfolio, of our total exposure, over 80% is investment grade and nonaccrual loans remain low and are in line with pre-pandemic levels at about 40 basis points of total loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we are well reserved for a variety of scenarios and we continuously evaluate our scenarios to reflect the evolving macro environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 8, we show our summary balance sheet and key capital and liquidity metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintained a very strong balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of our $2.4 trillion of assets about 23% or $557 billion are high-quality liquid assets, or HQLA, and we maintained total liquidity resources of approximately $967 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The combination of earnings generation, capital from exits and RWA optimization drove our CET1 ratio up by about 25 basis points to approximately 12.2% on a standardized basis, which remains our binding constraint.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our tangible book value per share was $80.34, up 2% from a year ago.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 9, we show a sequential CET1 walk to provide more detail on the drivers this quarter and our target over the next few quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we generated $3.2 billion of net income to common, which added 27 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we returned $1 billion in the form of common dividends, which drove a reduction of about 8 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, the interest rate impact on AOCI through our AFS investment portfolio drove a 5 basis point reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fourth, changes in the DTA drove a 3 basis point reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, the remaining 14 basis point increase was largely driven by net RWA optimization.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 10, we show the results for our Institutional Clients Group.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were down 5% as strong growth in services was more than offset by lower revenues across markets and banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 10% driven by transformation, business-led investments and volume-related expenses, partially offset by productivity and foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was driven by a reserve build of $86 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While deterioration in certain macro variables did lead to a build, it was mostly offset by the release of a COVID-19 related uncertainty reserve and a release related to direct exposures in Russia.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of approximately $2.2 billion, down 30%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were up 1%, driven by 9% growth in TTS loans, partially offset by the impact of foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits were down 2%, also largely driven by foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And ICG delivered an RoTCE of 9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 11, we show revenue performance by business and the key drivers we laid out at Investor Day, which we will show you each quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In services, we continue to see a very strong new client pipeline and deepening with our existing clients and expect that momentum to continue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Treasury and Trade Solutions, revenues were up 40%, driven by 61% growth in net interest income as well as 8% growth in NIR across all client segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to see healthy underlying drivers in TTS that indicate consistently strong client activity, with U.S. dollar clearing volumes up 2%, cross-border flows up 10%, commercial card volumes up roughly 50% and average loans up 9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So while the rate environment drove about 40% of the growth this quarter, business actions drove the remaining 60%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This includes continuing to manage deposit repricing and deepening with existing clients and significant new client wins across all client segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Through the first half of the year, based on the industry data that we see, we estimate that we gained over 60 basis points of share with large corporate clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And client wins are up approximately 20% across all segments, including wins with financial institutions, which are up almost 50%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These include marquee transactions where we are serving as the client's primary operating bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition, so far this year, we have onboarded approximately 5,800 suppliers, and we recently launched our innovative suite product in the in the U.S. and Asia which allows clients to connect their liquidity and funding to their operating flows 7 days a week.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Securities Services, revenues grew 15% as net interest income grew 73%, driven by higher interest rates across currencies, partly offset by a 6% decrease in noninterest revenue due to the impact of market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to be pleased with the execution in Securities Services as we onboarded approximately $1 trillion of assets under custody and administration so far this year from significant client wins, and we feel very good about the pipeline of new deals.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we estimate that we have gained about 60 basis points of share in Securities Services through the first half of this year, including in our home market.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, the services businesses are central to our strategy and are two of our higher returning businesses with strong linkages across the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets revenues were down 7%, largely driven by spread products, equities and RWA actions as we continue to focus on returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income Markets revenues were up 1% as strength in rates and FX was largely offset by continued headwinds in spread products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And through the first half of the year, we gained approximately 40 basis points of share.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equity markets revenues were down 25%, primarily reflecting reduced client activity in equity derivatives relative to a very strong quarter last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The actions we took to optimize RWA in markets are in line with the strategy we discussed at Investor Day, and we are making solid progress on our revenue to RWA targets so far this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, banking revenues, excluding gains and losses on loan hedges, were down 49%, driven by investment banking, as heightened macro uncertainty and volatility continue to impact client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Also embedded in the results is an impact of approximately $110 million related to marks on loan commitments and losses on loan sales.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So overall, while the market environment remains challenging, we feel good about the progress we are making as we continue to deepen existing client relationships as well as acquire new clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We show the results for our Personal Banking & Wealth Management business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 6% as net interest income grow was partially offset by a decline in noninterest revenue, driven by lower investment fee revenue in wealth and higher partner payments in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 13%, driven by transformation, other risk and control initiatives business-led investments and volume-driven expenses, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.1 billion which included a reserve build primarily driven by card volume growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NCLs were 13% higher year-over-year from near historically low levels, reflecting normalization, particularly in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Overall, we continue to see strong credit performance across portfolios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans grew 5%, driven by strong growth across Branded Cards, Retail Services and Retail Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits grew 1%, driven by growth across retail and wealth, partially offset by foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: PBWM delivered an RoTCE of 9.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 13, we show PBWM revenues by product as well as key business drivers and metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues were up 10%, driven by higher net interest income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to see strong underlying drivers with new account acquisitions up 10%, card spend volumes up 14% and average loans up 12%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues were up 12%, also driven by higher net interest income, partially offset by higher partner payments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So despite payment rates remaining elevated, the investments we've been making contributed to growth in interest-earning balances of 9% in Branded Cards and 7% in Retail Services, and we expect to continue to grow these balances in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues were up 2%, primarily driven by interest rates and deposit growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues were down 2%, as investment fee headwinds, particularly in Asia, more than offset net interest income growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding Asia, revenues were up 4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Client advisers were up 5%, and we are seeing net new investment inflows and strong new client acquisitions across our wealth business with new clients in ultra-high net worth and Wealth at Work up 7% and 27%, respectively, for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are also leveraging our retail network, which has driven almost 50,000 wealth referrals so far this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While the environment continues to remain challenging, we are seeing strong underlying business drivers as we execute against our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 14, we show results for Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased 66%, primarily driven by the Philippines gain on sale in the quarter and the absence of the Australia loss on sale in the prior year period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding these items, revenues were down about 12% largely due to the loss of revenues from the Australia and Philippines closing as well as the impact of the Korea wind down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 6%, driven by divestiture impacts in Asia and Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Loans and deposits decreased as a result of the reclassification of signed exits to other assets and other liabilities, the closing of the Philippine sale and the impact of the Korea wind down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 15, we show results for Corporate / Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased, largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio, partially offset by the mark-to-market on certain derivative transactions and expenses were down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 16, I'll briefly touch on our full year 2022 outlook.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With one quarter remaining in the year, we continue to expect full year revenues to be up in the low single-digit range, excluding divestiture-related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And within that, we continue to see a shift with higher net interest income, offset by lower noninterest revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So for the fourth quarter, we expect net interest income, excluding markets to be up in the range of $1.5 billion to $1.8 billion year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Clearly, where we land within that range will be a function of a number of factors, including rates, loans and deposit volumes, deposit betas and currency impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Regarding full year expenses, we continue to expect expenses to grow by 7% to 8%, excluding divestiture related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of cost of credit, it will be a function of the evolution of the macro environment, normalization that we continue to expect in the cards businesses and loan growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And keep in mind that loan growth tends to be higher in the fourth quarter versus the third given typical holiday spending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Before we move to Q&A, I'd like to end with a few key points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to execute on the strategy that we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are seeing solid momentum in the underlying drivers of the majority of our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we said at Investor Day, the financial path will not be linear, but we are confident we can achieve our medium-term targets in a variety of scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So definitely a good performance out of TTS, rates helped a ton, but I see loan growth and fees, and I heard your comments about growth across all client segments.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I wonder if we could pull back the onion a drop and talk about those two in separate pieces.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: One is 61% year-on-year NII, how do betas factor in and go forward over the next year in terms of higher rates and how that factors through?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And then two, what specifically is growing within TTS across those client segments to drive that high single digit growth?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Glenn, why don't I take that and kind of take it in the 2 pieces that you laid out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So as you know, Glenn, when we think about our business just in aggregate, there's obviously a split between the institutional and the consumer side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our TTS business, which is on the Institutional side, and these corporate clients, they tend to have higher betas in general than obviously, the Retail Banking side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What we've seen is that the betas have been increasing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They are still running lower than what we had expected.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, they have been increasing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with continued expected rate increases, I would expect that those betas will continue to rise in the coming quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have been actively managing deposit pricing and repricing with our clients on an ongoing basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You know that this is more than just a deposit-taking business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This is a business where we are looking to manage the operating accounts of our clients and bring the breadth of what we offer in our franchise to them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's the type of conversation we've been having with them, and we'll continue to do that with an eye towards growing the volume of deposits with both the existing as well as with new clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we, again, expect to see betas rise but also expect to see continued contribution to the NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other aspect of your question is what else has been driving the activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mentioned a couple of those things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So it's not just deepening with existing clients, but it's also onboarding new clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen cross-border transaction value up about 10%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The commercial card spend is up meaningfully.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Trade originations are up 27%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so a lot of active engagement with our clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been winning new mandates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen an uptick in client wins, up about 20%, and we've been gaining share across those client segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so hopefully, that gives you a little bit of examples of where the benefits or momentum is coming from on the NIR side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The NIR growth of 8% is driven really by the cards, the payments and receivables as well as trade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd just jump in and say, I think there's a bit of a miss at the moment that the global environment is detrimental to activity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We see quite the opposite.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Volatility is something in which we're very active in helping our multinational clients around the world manage the local footprint we have and the global network we have is a tremendous asset right now, so we're seeing a lot of positive momentum, which may not always be intuitive to everyone, but I think it's what makes the network, the crown jewel of Citi.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate all that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: A quick one on Markets.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Not quite as good as peers, but that comes and goes, I know that's a function of last year was really strong.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: It's a function of mix in any given quarter.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: What I really want to focus on is your comments on RWA optimization, what specifically are you doing?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I know it's the banking book, but I did see you taking down your capital, call it redemption facility line.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But in markets, what are you pulling back on RWA, just which pieces of that business?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I’d find that interesting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So Glenn, you'll remember at Investor Day, we talked not only about RWA optimization broadly, but specifically as it relates to Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we talked about the idea of increasing our revenue to RWA ratio for markets to about 5.5% over the course of that Investor Day period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we've been actively working across the Markets business in equities, in fixed income and spread products and looking for opportunities where there are low returning uses of RWA to either increase the returns on that or to actually kind of exit it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that includes a host of different structures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It includes working with clients to post additional collateral in some instances and other types of structures like that, that improved the RWA, including hedging and like I said, posting collateral and taking a look at margin that we have and ensuring that we are, in fact, getting the most for that use of RWA.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: JOHN Mc

speaker: Donald
sentence: Mark, I wanted to just clarify what I think the expense guide is for fourth quarter.

speaker: Donald
sentence: It seems like the guidance for the full year implies a fourth quarter step-up to maybe $12.8B and change from $12.75B this quarter.

speaker: Donald
sentence: Is that the right read, a little bit of a step-up in the fourth quarter?

speaker: Donald
sentence: And is that just a pull-through of investments?

speaker: Donald
sentence: And what would be driving that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So again, the guidance on full year expenses hasn't changed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's the 7% to 8% ex the impact of divestitures that would imply a bit of an uptick there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is on the heels of the continued investments that we're making and that's flowing through as well as how revenues kind of play out and the associated compensation activity that goes along with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So nothing extraordinary and consistent with the guidance given.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: JOHN Mc

speaker: Donald
sentence: And I know it's too early to give formal guidance for next year.

speaker: Donald
sentence: But if we look at the Investor Day slides, it seems to imply that expenses go up for a few years until you get to the medium term.

speaker: Donald
sentence: Is that the right read?

speaker: Donald
sentence: And when I annualize where you'll be exiting the fourth quarter here, implies that at $51 billion or so next year as a starting point.

speaker: Donald
sentence: I mean is it fair when I read the Investor Day slides and think about your investments that directionally expenses probably do go up next year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: John, I'd say, as you know, right, we'll give guidance for 2023 next quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think if you think back to the Investor Day and you think about some of the things that, that we just commented on with regard to our services business, we'd expect to see continued tailwinds as it relates to net interest income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We would expect to get to the heart of your question that we will continue to invest in the franchise in the transformation, that would obviously peak and then we would start to see the benefits start to play out from that in that medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so yes, you can probably expect some type of a tick up, but I'll give you more details on that when we talk about the '23 outlook in the next quarter.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I just wanted to take a step back.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Your 11% to 12% medium-term RoTCE target had contemplated an 11.5% to 12% CET1 versus the 13% that you're targeting to by midyear next year, also that you laid out on that same slide that you're targeting 2% Fed funds over the medium term, which seems kind of cute right now.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So I guess I'm wondering, your confidence and you said you're confident you could hit medium-term targets even with this creep in capital.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Is it really that shift in the rate environment that's helping you get there despite the higher denominator?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So thank you for the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I think there are a couple of things to kind of think back on that still hold true, which is the strategy that we've built, I think, is a resilient strategy and it really spoke to top line momentum that we expected not just through rate increases, but also through share gains and also through the business-led investments that we're making and better leveraging the synergies and linkages across the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of those things still hold true to the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You're right, the Fed funds assumption has changed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Back in March, I think we all were looking at a Fed funds rate at the end of the year that was closer to 1.5% or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so now here we are with the hikes that we've seen and looking at something certainly north of 4% or 4.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's changed meaningfully.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But there are a number of other drivers that contribute to achieving that return.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's the medium term, so call it 3 to 5 years, I think, is how we characterized it and starting to see some of the benefits from the transformation investments that we're making.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To your point on capital, we are building to the 13%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Remember, that is a by-product of a 4% SCB for this particular CCAR cycle and the strategy that we described includes a mix in our shift of revenues and earnings over time, a mix towards more stable PPNR and more fee revenues that will contribute to, I think, a balance sheet and a mix that generates fewer losses, stress losses, than our balance sheet might today.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the contribution of those things, we think, will drive that return target that we've set, and we still remain confident about that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now with that said, there are unknowns that are out there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I just spoke to many of the knowns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so what happens with further capital requirements and the current regulatory regime and what have you, it's hard to predict.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we'll manage to that as we learn and know more about it.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And my follow-up question is given Citi's valuation on book, I think your current and prospective shareholders are waiting for buybacks to potentially return.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I guess a two-part question here.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Number one, especially if you think you think you could stabilize your PPNR in the stress test, why 100 basis point management buffer versus one of your peers at 50 that reported today?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And secondarily, as we think about the return of buybacks, I imagine that once you hit that 13%, the buybacks could return.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: But how does the Banamex sale potentially impact the timing, as I recall, there's a currency translation adjustment that could be negative upfront at announcement to CET1, but you get that all back during close.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So I guess the real big question here is how should we think about, what are the mile markers for the return of buyback activity at Citi?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's a lot there to unpack, so if I forget anything, just please remind me.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I'll start at the beginning, which is I know where we trade in terms of book value.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I'd love to be in a position where we were buying back given that valuation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, we're going to take it quarter by quarter, as I think you've heard us say and evaluate what buyback decisions and capital actions make the most sense in light of the environment that we're managing through, we're clearly managing through an uncertain environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I just said and as you kind of mentioned as well, we do see our business mix shifting over time on the heels of our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I do think that over time, that will contribute, as I said, to the capital requirements that we have, but that's over the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we do still see a fair amount of volatility in the stress capital buffer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And part of the reason that we have the management buffer is to deal not only with that uncertainty in the SCB, but also in interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're seeing volatility in both, frankly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we'll continue to evaluate the management buffer as well to see what makes sense as we move towards that medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the Mexico transaction, you're right in terms of we have mentioned before, the CTA component to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is a timing difference.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have factored that in to the path to our 13% by middle of next year and factor that into achieving the longer term targets that we set for ourselves.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Look, I look at the global network as a curse and a blessing.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I guess the curse part is simply the complexity and the expenses.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And Mark, you said expenses should go up higher next year.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You're not going to tell us for a few more months, but I'm just wondering when you think you can grow revenues faster than expenses.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Again it's not new news, the revenues and expenses.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You guided it and you're within that range.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: It’s just do we have to wait a year or 3 years or how long for that complexity to get more simplified so revenues can catch up to that expense growth?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then on the blessing side, Mark, you mentioned, you said gain share in those clients segments, I thought that was little vague.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I mean you talked about trade, you talked about other activities connecting multinational corporations in the spirit of volatility, so if you could a little more meat on the bone as far when you talk about market share and those tailwinds on the revenues while you have the headwinds on the expenses from the global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Hey, Mike, it's Jane, jumping in because I do want to talk a bit about your point on the global network here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I have to tell you, I'm hard pressed to find a negative to the global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We start off with the vision for the bank that we laid out in March.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is to be the preeminent banking partner for clients with cross border needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Who are those clients?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is 5,000 multinationals and their subsidiaries, it's institutional investors and the ultra-high net worth clients with a heavy tilt to family offices.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we serve them on FX, on liquidity management, on their payroll, on their supply chain as well as strategic advice, financing, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's $4 trillion in daily volume, 80% of that credit portfolio is investment grade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So when we're looking at it, it's the multinationals.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: To take a higher risk country, the client base we're serving there are the global multinationals much more than the local players.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so this is a relatively simple, high returning, very well growing as we're seeing at the moment, capability that is exceedingly hard to replicate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me pass over to Mark in terms of what are some of the examples of different areas of the drivers of growth?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is, as I said at the beginning, this is a crown jewel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not a source of complexity for the bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So Mike, I'd say a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, what I said was that we continue to gain share, and I referenced specifically about 60 basis points of share with large corporate clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're also winning mandates and gaining share with other client segments as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You know that the Commercial Banking client segment is one that we are focused on, given the strength of our platform and its applicability to those sized clients as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mentioned that our wins are up and specifically, they're up 20%, the mandates that we're winning across all client segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that specifically with FIs, they're up almost 50%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So hopefully, that gives you some sense of where the revenue growth is coming from.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The takeaway there is it's both existing as well as new clients as we kind of continue to build out the platform and build out our capabilities to reach them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the second part of your question was around expenses and expenses growing and when will we have top line growth that exceeds the expense growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I'd remind you that the work we're doing on the transformation as well as the business-led investments are multiyear almost by definition and important in order to derive savings in our structural cost base over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And at Investor Day, I think I pointed to by the time we got to that medium-term period, we would see our operating efficiency go down to less than 60%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think we've been very deliberate about trying to give you guidance and update you on guidance for the full year and along the way and we'll be consistent in that discipline.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I can certainly give you more color on '23, as I mentioned earlier to John, in the next quarter.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I guess one clarification.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: When you say you've gained 60 basis points of share with large corporate clients, what do you mean by share, share of what?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, of wallet, 60 basis points, not 50, 60.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So market share with them.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess one, just, Mark, I wanted to clarify your NII guide for $1.5B to $1.8B, is just total NII, right?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: It's not ex Markets or anything?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is ex Markets.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: It is ex Markets.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Any perspective or view on where you see Markets heading in fourth quarter, just given what's happened with the rate backdrop?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I very intentionally don't forecast Markets NII in a rising rate environment, you would normally see the markets NII come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It tends to be liability sensitive.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we tend to focus on, as you probably heard me say a number of times, total revenues for this business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I guess what I'd highlight is that in periods of uncertainty and lots of market volatility, our businesses tend to perform well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we'll see how the fourth quarter plays out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's obviously some seasonality to it that has taken place historically.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we have to kind of factor all those things in, but we'll have to see how it further evolves.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Just two things.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: One, just another question on the expense side.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I just wanted to follow up with regard to, Mark, the stranded costs that you had talked about at the Barclays conference.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And I'm wondering if I got the message right there, which is when you exit the consumer businesses, there's 25% that is generally managed through a TSA, so it's a service agreement and that expense will come off over time.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And then there's another 25%, which is likely not to come off.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Is that fair?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Or is there a different message that I'm missing on that?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, that's not fair.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I appreciate the add more clarity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I bucket into 3 buckets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one is when we do these transactions, both Jane and I have deep experience in this.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We tend to see about half of the costs go away to the buyer, so when we do the transaction, when we do the sale.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you pointed out, about 25% is often in place as part of a transition service agreement.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so there's revenues that we get paid to offset that expense until things have totally transitioned and then that goes away.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the third bucket is what I call potentially stranded cost and what Jane calls not stranded cost, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I say potentially because they are regional expenses that get allocated to countries, for example, they're global expenses that get allocated to the region and to the countries, for example, and what we have to do and what we're doing is we're attacking what would otherwise be stranded cost.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're attacking that by telling each of the functions in the business, and here's your portion of that 25% and come back and tell me how you're going to rethink your org structure, simplify your processes in order to drive that cost out of the company, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's what we've been doing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Remember, the expense base here is probably $7 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So you can break down kind of the population that we're talking about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've already stood up a team to work with each of the businesses and each of the functions around getting in front of that cost, so that we can drive that down over the near-term period of time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as a Scotswoman, I just can't help myself but jump in here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think as Mark and I are both pretty maniacally focused around this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I'd say at the moment, we've had a couple of the divestitures close.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have another 3 next quarter, and this continues on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We already started on Australia and the Philippines and getting those expenses down, as Mark said.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There is going to be, and we will not be shy in capturing as an opportunity to simplify our organization further next year when we have more of the divestitures close and streamlining more of our regional management structures, more of the expenses at the global level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So there is more to come on that, and we'll be looking to do that as I indicated at Investor Day that will be an important part once more of the divestitures are closed, starting in '23, going into '24.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Right.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So you were, Mark's potentially stranded costs, and Jane, you are no stranded cost.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: The no stranded cost is in the guide medium term?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the time to get it out – yes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think as Mark talks about expenses, you've got to look at the various different dynamics that are going on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So yes, we've got investments into the transformation at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Many of those translate into better efficiency as well as a safer, stronger firm the divestitures translate into lower cost, but also we eliminate the stranded costs, and we simplify the organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've got a number of different factors that we will make completely transparent to you at play in our expense base from a more structural dimension in the quarters ahead.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: Can you guys talk about the pace of addressing some of the regulatory issues out there?

speaker: Connor
sentence: On the one hand, you got out of the AML consent order earlier this year, which I think was a very big positive.

speaker: Connor
sentence: But on the other hand, there was an article last month, suggesting regulators want you to go faster.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And I think we all know regulators always want things to go faster on these issues, but I did want to ask the question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We all want things to go faster, both our clients, our shareholders, the management team, regulators, the Board, all.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think we're fully aligned there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Maybe if I take a step back on this one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Transformation is our #1 priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It will be a multiyear journey and prioritizing safety and soundness is a very important global bank is a nonnegotiable for all of us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Where are we?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we were delighted to see the AML consent order get closed with the OCC.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to work on the regulatory orders we have.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I have to say we have constant and constructive engagement with our regulators that personally, I find them to be very helpful and essential to our success.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have got a lot to get done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you can see from the hiring numbers, we've been investing heavily in the talent and the resources that we need.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we've also said, this is not only going to benefit our safety and soundness, but also in terms of our client, excellence in delivery and ultimately, for our shareholders as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the foundation that we need for this is largely in place.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so Mark and I and frankly, the whole management team, we're very focused on continuing to execute on the various plans we submitted and the overall transformation of Citi from a strategic and another dimension.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We obviously can't give more details than that because this is confidential supervisory information, but I hope that gives you a good feel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: And I guess when you say the foundation is largely in place, like what are some of the things that are missing?

speaker: Connor
sentence: Or is it just a matter of, say, executing on the divestitures?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's timing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So some of the areas, for example, where we're making technology investments, those ones where we've had fragmented technology platforms, we're migrating them into a single platform or into an industry standard where we've not been on one that we want for the future.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Those things take some time to put in place.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But you can see from the investments we've made, both headcount and the shift from consulting to much more of our own people.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll see the technology increase in that shift as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So some of that is just a natural progression you'd expect over time.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Maybe just on deposits and behavior.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You guys clearly have a different mix by geography and by business.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Deposits ex currency were up 1%.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Your peers were down close to 3%.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So how do we think about deposit behavior going forward given your mix of geography and business?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Is it just the overseas rate hikes have been behind the curve versus the U.S., but we'll start to see more deposit outflows over there?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Or do you think your deposits can hold up a little better.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, it's a great question, and so why don't I take that, so a couple of things, and you started to allude to it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The first is that when you think about our business, you've got about between ICG and our PBWM business of 65%, 35% split in terms of the deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You also have a U.S. dollar denominated versus non-U.S. dollar-denominated split that is pretty meaningful as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then to your point, we've got different currencies and different rate hikes by different central banks around the world.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that then is juxtaposed against different beta behavior from customers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so on the ICG side, we tend to see higher betas.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And obviously, with rates increasing at a more rapid pace, we expect those to get closer to our expectations in the near term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're starting to see many more hikes around the globe or outside of the U.S. And so again, we expect to see betas which operate at a much lower pace level outside of the U.S. but start to tick up.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so over time, I think we will see continued tailwinds from an NII as the differences between U.S. and non U.S. activity play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that has played to our benefit, I think, and should continue to play to our benefit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you think about what I've talked about before in terms of our IRE, our interest rate exposure, and the cash flow approach that we are moving towards taking, in some ways it captures exactly that point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so if you see a 100 basis point move in the curve cross currencies, we're looking at as much as a $2.2 billion increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And when you look at that increase, it skews more heavily towards the non-U.S. dollar than the U.S. dollar.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that is in part because of the different moves in rate curves by currency as well as the different betas by client type in U.S. versus non-U.S.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: That's really helpful.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then maybe just a second question just on the impact in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You’re closing on 3 divestitures, how do we think about the P&L and capital impact of that in the fourth quarter?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think I talked about the idea of the divestitures contributing close to $3 billion for the full year, $3.1 or so billion in terms of the capital impact for the full year 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The combination of Australia and the Philippines gets us to about $2.1 billion or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so the balance of the divestitures that we've scoped out for the fourth quarter should close that gap, Thailand, Malaysia, Bahrain, the signing of China, et cetera, should close that gap to getting us to that $3.1 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With most of that is skewing towards the first 3, Thailand, Malaysia, Bahrain.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Jane, you talked about your global footprint and the strength that gives you as an organization.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And so maybe this question is very appropriate for Citigroup, which is the following.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: You guys have a real good window into the global financial markets.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And there's been some disruption out there, we all know about what's going on in the U.K. pension funds.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: You had the Swiss National Bank come into the New York Fed this week for $6.3 billion of currency swaps.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: We know there's a large broker having challenges over there.So can you guys give us a flavor, what are you seeing from a stress standpoint.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What are the liquidity metrics that you're watching to see if some other stresses pop up how the global financial markets will handle that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a very good question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's one we spend a lot of time on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think as Mark alluded, we're constantly doing different stress tests on the market, on clients on different areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I said in the opening remarks, we're more focused on the liquidity in the market at the moment and the impact on some counterparties much more than we are on our credit risk, that could change over time, depending particularly what happens from a tail risk on the geopolitics here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What are we seeing going on?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think a lot of the focus is in Europe.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Right now, which is sort of at the center of the storm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing some areas where there could be energy supply constraints impacting some clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we're watching industrial production moved to the U.S., for example, which are the places where the cost of production is lower, a potential buffer for some of the slowdown in U.S. manufacturing and the like because the demand for goods softened, for example.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing areas where clients on the collateral front, where there's a situation of intense volatility that hits or a surprise drop as we saw in gilts is having an impact on liquidity and therefore, margining, which is what happens and has been happening with the U.K. pension funds with the derivatives.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So a lot of the areas we look at is what's the collateral behind different institutions as we have done with the commodity players earlier on in the year, we've been looking at some of the LDIs at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as we see different stresses, we're jumping on it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the central banks are also ready to jump in as needed and certainly attuned to the importance of agility in these situations as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As our large global institutions like ourselves as to how do we help support the market, the benefit for our bank is because we're in a strong position on all of our capital, on liquidity, on balance sheet and the credit portfolio, as you can see, is extraordinary at the moment, zero losses in ICG this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Again, we're in a position to be able to jump in and play an important role.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it's a bit of whack-a-mole, I would say.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Very good.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then, Mark, just as a follow-up.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: You touched on your investment banking numbers and your markets numbers.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And yes, investment banking for everybody has been a struggle, obviously, this year.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Your advisory numbers actually were better than your peers on a year-over year basis in terms of growth, but DCM was quite a bit weaker.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you kind of give us a little more color there?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And also, how do the pipelines look going into the fourth quarter?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So look, as we've all seen, the wallets have been under meaningful pressure year-over-year down more than 50%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did show some strong performance in parts of the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been hiring, frankly, as Jane has mentioned before and filling in gaps that we have across the portfolio in health care, tech, energy, et cetera, and feel good about that and are seeing benefits from having made those hires.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: DCM is really more of a function of low deal volume pretty much across the board.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there really isn't a whole lot more to it than that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as you know, investment banking is part of the strategy that we discussed at Investor Day and a key part at that and we'll continue to invest in it and ensure we're getting the productivity out of it that the investment warrants, but really not a whole lot more in DCM beyond the low deal volume across the board.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Couple of questions for you.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Firstly, Mark, I just want to clarify, you said NII ex Markets to be up $1.5 to $1.8 billion year- on-year in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: You were up $1.9 billion year-on-year in the third quarter.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Given that there have been more rate hikes during the quarter and even later in the quarter, any color on what's driving that slightly lower NII accretion rather than actually being up at a faster pace?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, the important factors here include volume, what we see in both the loan volume, the deposit volume and obviously, betas and how betas play out, and we talked about the idea that with the higher frequency and level of rate increases, that's going to put pressure on the beta in terms of seeing it increase across the board.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the third factor is rates and what happens with the rates and the timing for which that happens, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When that happens, matters in the quarter in terms of whether you see that benefit in it or in subsequent quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those are the factors that drive that range that I've given you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it's across both the PBWM portfolio as well as how it plays out in TTS.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And given the world we're managing through, quantitative tightening and the like, and I think the other factor is obviously FX and how that plays out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So those are the main drivers, Vivek, and the range reflects any variety of ways that they could play out in the quarter.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Completely different question for both of you.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Securities Services, you talked about $1 trillion in new business wins seems to be doing really well.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Any color, if you can remind us on which client segments you're seeing this in?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And I remember you're saying on the call that it's domestic also, but any more color into where you're growing and where you're seeing all this?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're seeing this in a number of different areas, the one that is most material was the win we had with BlackRock in a particularly sizable percentage of business there here in the States and in a particularly important and attractive part of the Securities Services business as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we have been winning some sizable business across the board.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And a part of this, I think, comes from the fact that we're able to link the pre and post trade together to drive a lot of efficiencies for our clients and bring some insights that some of the other players are not able to do in helping them manage and get competitive advantage in their businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we're an attractive one from that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, anything else to add?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean we're very pleased with the growth here and the win mandates that we've been seeing across the board, but particularly in the U.S., as Jane highlights.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And some of it is a rate benefit, but a good portion of it is again, those new mandates, those new additional assets that we're bringing in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The final point that I'd make on it is that, and I'd reiterate it, I guess, is that this is not only one of our businesses that's growing quite rapidly, but it's also a high returning business for us as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so consistent with the strategy that we talked about at Investor Day and one that reflects linkages across the franchise, and so we feel very good about that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Just two quick ones.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Mark, you talked about the capital impact of the legacy exits.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Is there a way you can dimension how much in the fourth quarter from revenues and NII perspective comes out from the legacy?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I do not have that in front of me, Ken.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I've got a page in here, page 22 reflects some of the size of the exit markets, but I do not have that in front of me.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd have to circle back with you, Ken.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I would assume that's been a part of the prior question about NII trajectory, right?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: There's a negative impact embedded in that in the fourth quarter as well, right?

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: That's just part of the movement forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, that is reflected in the NII guidance, but the major drivers are largely what I referenced.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But yes, it would be reflected in it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: As a follow-up, why is Citi still banking in Russia when seemingly every other major American company or most of them are out of Russia?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mike, as I mentioned in my earlier remarks, we are now informing our multinational clients who are operating in Russia, so these are the U.S., European and Asian core multinationals or the franchise that we are ending nearly all of the institutional banking services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We offer them by the end of the first quarter of 2023, the cost of which I would add is not material.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so at that point, our only operations in Russia will be those necessary to fulfill our remaining legal and regulatory operations there.

speaker: Jane Fraser

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Transformation remains our number one priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are deep into the large body of work of automating manual controls and processes, consolidating fragmented tech platforms, and upgrading our data architecture.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are committed to doing this the right way, knowing that it will take time to meet our regulators expectations and to deliver a modern, more efficient infrastructure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Last month we announced consequential changes that align our organizational structure with our strategy and changes how we run the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I said at Investor Day that organizational simplification would follow the divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The changes will eliminate layers, duplication, and complexity allowing us to operate the bank more agilely and freeing our people up to focus on clients and execution.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Elevating the five core businesses to my leadership team will enable me to drive greater accountability and sustainable results.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: To bring it alive, the actions we have taken in the last four weeks will eliminate over 15% of the regional and functional roles at the top two layers, and 60 committees, freeing up over tens of thousands of people hours annually.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have identified about 1,000, or 50%, of our internal financial -heads and dual reporting lines to enable faster decision-making.

speaker: Jane Fraser

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We announced the first two layers in September and the next set of changes will be implemented by mid-November, and we aim to bring the entire process to a close by early next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When we speak in January, Mark and I will be in a position to update you on the financial and other metrics showing the impact of the simplification, amongst other details.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While expense is not the primary driver of the organizational changes, they will help us start bending the expense curve in the fourth quarter of next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And at the end of the work, we will have a simpler firm, that can operate faster, better serve our clients and unlock value for our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser

sentence: I want to note how pleased I have been with how the leaders of the firm, especially the next generation, have embraced these changes and are stepping up to implement them.

speaker: Jane Fraser

sentence: Having said that, based on what we have seen play out year-to-date in terms of US and non-US rates and lagging non-US betas, we now expect net interest income to be slightly above $47.5 billion for the full year excluding Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are maintaining our expense guidance of roughly $54 billion, excluding 2023 divestiture-related impacts and the FDIC special assessment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net credit losses in Cards should continue to normalize, with both portfolios reaching pre-COVID levels by year-end.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as it relates to buybacks, we expect to do a modest level of buybacks in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: a few points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are executing on our strategy and delivering top line revenue growth of 5%, year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to invest for the long term with discipline while remaining on track to deliver on our expense

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: And our first question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Jane, you spoke more about the restructuring that you commented on recently.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: The real question is, why is this restructuring different than the other 5 or 10 or 15 restructurings we've heard about since Citi's creation in its current form 25 years ago, I think, just like a week ago?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, I'd say, why is this different?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: We hear the talk about cascading downward and the simplification, reducing dual heads and the committees.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But we've heard this so much that why is this time different?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a very important question, Mike, thank you for asking it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I've said, we view these as the most consequential changes we've made, not just to our organization model, but how we run the bank, in almost two decades.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the first piece is simple, which is our org model was set up for a financial supermarket,that is simply not the bank we are today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we are aligning the organizational model with that simper business mix and strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But what's truly different is we're changing how we run the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And these are permanent changes that will be driven all the way down through the organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me give you some examples to bring it to life.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We talked about delayering the first two or three layers of the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That will continue through the organization, through the spans and layers, particularly getting rid of aggregator roles.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And let me give an example: HR, we had HR in a region, you had the region head, you had the Institutional Client Group head, you had the Banking head, in addition, you had a North Asia head and a South Asia head.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're just going to have the North Asia head and the South Asia head.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And all of those roles collapsed into those two.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're eliminating activities in the geographies that we just don't need anymore, because we are no longer running local consumer franchises in them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, let's take the financial reporting, sorry, the management reporting that Mark and I referred to in the opening remarks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We can reduce our management reports by about 50%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's 1,000 reports.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What does that mean?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Shadow P&Ls by country, quarterly outlooks, monthly performance updates, all the associated tracking and reconciliations that are there that are effectively for a shadow P&L, rather than the one that matters to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, that greatly declutters.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It also means we can eliminate processes for our Transformation, where we are looking at how do we automate those processes, automate those controls.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If they're a duplicative process, we're getting rid of them so we don't need to do that anymore and it will accelerate the work on Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are taking activities out of some of the businesses and centralizing them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A lot of the client activities that will go embedded into a business, we move that up to centralized utilities that the whole firm can benefit from and that will get scale economies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These strategy teams, marketing teams, many of the little cottage industries that build up over time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We can speed up decision-making with fewer committee layers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll take down the number of layers and drive that from some places 13, we're looking to getting to 8 in as many places as we possibly can.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're giving clarity of decision rights and changing decision rights from two or more people to just one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So much more single points of accountability, again more aligned with our shareholder interests, because those points of accountability are more sitting in the products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the types of metrics we are looking at to help us measure this spans layers, revenue producers and non producers, grade mixes, synergies that we're realizing, voice of the client, but I say that our expectations and our execution of the business strategy is also at the heart of what we're trying to drive here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our strength is our global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I don't want our geographies focused on the full monty of management processes that are a duplication of what's happening in the product organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I want them focused on delivering to our clients, engaging with our clients and also managing their responsibilities of the legal entities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The same way for our Banking organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Putting the Investment Bank, the Corporate Bank and Commercial Bank together will really make it easier for us to realize the synergies across them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, the cross sell or the movement of a commercial mid-market company up to a corporate lending company and a corporate banking company, much easier when they're all in the same organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Or selling our Banking products suite into that Commercial Bank customer and other examples.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's really changing decision-making, freeing up people to focus on clients and Transformation, much greater transparency, changing decision-making and rights, driving synergies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We put a huge amount of work all the way through the summer in design as to how do we want the organization to work.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That is now getting driven down into the designing in detail and in depth all of these types of activities through the second and third layers at the moment into the fourth and then until we finish at the end of the first quarter.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, I'm curious, you mentioned that you're still marching towards the 11%, 12%, which is good because everyone was going to ask that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: My question is a little bit different of, with the denominator going up 25%, in other words, a lot of things are working towards your Transformation, but there's sort of a curve ball in there with upping the denominator by 25%.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, you seem to be a beneficiary of higher for longer for sure.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And you also mentioned you're working on mitigation as we speak.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, maybe you could talk about what are the offsets that we don't see that give you confidence still working towards that, because the top line stuff is working?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, good morning, Glenn, it's good to hear from you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Let me make a couple comments on that, and then, Jane, feel free to chime in if you'd like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The first thing is that when I talked about this at the last conference we attended, I mentioned that analysts were somewhere in the 16% to 19% range in terms of a capital increase, and we're likely to be inside of that range, assuming the Basel III proposal as i s structured, as it's written, and obviously that's not the final, there's a period of review that's going on now.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I'd say is a couple things, Glenn.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, we haven't fully executed against the strategy that Jane has just described.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And obviously, continuing to simplify the business, managing through the Transformation, changing that business mix that we have to something that's more consistent and predictable and repeatable as it relates to PPNR, those things matter and impact the SCB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We talked about the exiting of the international consumer businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That will be a factor in what our balance sheet looks like and what stress losses might look like as well as lowering the expense base, which we know is an important factor in that PPNR math as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, those things help, I think, to reduce the amount of capital that might be required as we get into that medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Importantly, as you point out, there are other elements of the proposal that are going to require that we take a hard look at as well and identify mitigating actions to the extent that they make it into the final.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, think about the increase in operational risk and the fact that some of that is already included in SCB as something of a point of advocacy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But that's obviously a big headwind that we'll have to kind of work through, the FRTB and the enhancement of models.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, there's a global market shock as well, but again another point of advocacy that we need to work through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The equity investments, and now that they go from 100% risk weighting to 400% risk weighting, I think we're going to take a hard look at whether those are worth keeping in light of the higher capital associated with them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's going to challenge the returns, that's going to force us to look at those through a different strategic lens, and we're going to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's not to even mention the credit component that impacts both corporates and consumers as it relates to unfunded commitments, for example.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, as we've done with SA-CCR and other types of reg changes, we're going to have to look at what it means for our product mix, the returns associated with those, whether there are opportunities to pull levers like pricing, or whether we have to take other decisions around those.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that's what I mean by the mitigating actions that we're dimensioning and putting on paper and working through, but again, want to be thoughtful because the rule is not final yet, and there are more discussions to be had around those important elements that I mentioned already.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: You've talked a lot about defense, as I like to call it, in terms of the Transformation that Jane had outlined and bending the expense curve.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: But I'm wondering, for both Jane and Mark, if you could sort of address what I think is probably the most debated part of your target, which is that revenue CAGR of 5%.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: You put up a very nice quarter in terms of revenues, both net interest income and fees.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And maybe help us sort of look underneath the surface in terms of that momentum and maybe break it down in terms of what's really going well.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think TTS continues to surprise to the upside, are we going to be, two years from now, we re going to be like, oh, well, TTS is continuing to be doing well.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So, what are the businesses that really sort of strong secular momentum that you feel is being under-recognized versus how you could position cyclically and higher for longer?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And what is still to come as we think about that path to at least the numerator of that RoTCE target?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I love this question, Erika, because I have to say I m really excited about our strategy and the potential it has.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it is, as you say, this is about the revenue potential of the firm and really how do we continue to unlock it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, there s a couple of unstoppable trends that we re going to be riding in the next, I think it s decade-long.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The corporate client of today, and indeed consumer, has to build resiliency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
