sentence: The multinational client is on a long-term trend of building resiliency, be it because of green, be it because of geopolitics, be it because of regulatory, whatever the different reasons may be, and there are multiple, they're having to build resiliency into supply chains, into their own operations as they operate around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: W the bank that is absolutely there for them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think you've seen that in TTS, where we've had such strong drivers of growth in the last few years at the beginning of this trend.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, that is an important one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Wherever the clients want to go, we are there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have been there for decades.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We understand the risk.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We understand the client base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We understand the opportunities there, at that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That micro level and local levels that someone who is flying in with a suitcase can't possibly deliver.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's connected globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, this thing is just a thing of beauty.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Linked into it is what I think of as a hidden gem amongst our crown jewels is Securities Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It equally in custody has this extraordinary global network, the connectivity everywhere.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have been investing behind this business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been growing our market share in North America in asset managers, where we've been underweight, with a number of material marquee wins.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You can see the share gain that we're getting in this business, the pipeline of deals that we've already won as well as the new pipelines going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Very high return.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're investing both in terms of our cloud, our data, our client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this is in a way, let's say, I do view this as a hidden gem with extremely attractive return profile, fee profile, and other dimensions to it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've quite a long way to run here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, similar story to TTS, slightly different client base, competitively advantaged because you've got both the pre-trade and the post-trade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We connect the two.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Huge efficiencies for clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's going to matter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Next trend that's unstoppable, global wealth creation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And there is just going to be massive global wealth creation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I can't tell you how excited Andy Sieg is now that he's in the building and knows the way to his desk and all the floors his people are on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's about to hit the road globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are so well positioned to deliver against that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you can see, we've not been happy with our performance the last couple of years, but this is going to be a very important driver for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll see the recovery in banking wallet eventually.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: None of us are calling when that will sustainably happen.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That will be another driver.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd say cards continuing to go from strength to strength, particularly I think as we look forward, playing to our lending-led model there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And finally the other one I do love, which is our Commercial Bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We serve these entrepreneurs all over the world, who are going to be the drivers of many industries going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're serving them, helping them go international for the first step, tap them into global supply chains and the like.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's almost by definition the fastest growing of the mid-market companies are the ones that tap into what we can offer them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We build great relationships with them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then our private bankers call on them, and then our investment bankers call on them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have our capital market teams calling on them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we help them grow and succeed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that is going to be a big engine in the medium-term of new client acquisition feeding us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, deeper client relationships, more growth in terms of new clients that fit with our proposition fairly uniquely, and some great mega trends that we are going to be riding and pretty uniquely positioned on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we'll keep investing to make sure that where areas we're behind we get into the forefront of and the areas we are crushing it in, like our win rate is 82% in TTS, and we're going to make sure that we continue to do so and innovate that way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, sorry to be so excited about this, the 4% to 5% just feels very, very doable to Mark and I.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey good morning.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Mark, maybe on the revenue discussion there, let's talk about NII a little bit.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You guys have a very unique deposit base, a lot smaller footprint in low-cost consumer.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Betas have been, already been high, so it doesn't seem like there's as much beta catch-up risk for you.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: It's 50% non-US roughly.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How do you think about the trajectory of NII, do you think it stabilizes next year before rate cuts?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How do we think about the puts and takes on your NII into next year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thanks for the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not going to give guidance for 2024, we'll do that obviously at the fourth quarter 2023 earnings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think it's reasonable to expect that some of the trends that we've seen so far will continue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, if you think about what's underneath this, we'll continue to benefit from higher rates across currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think we'll continue to see benefits from card interest-earning balance growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Recall that when you look at our US dollar IRE position, it's relatively neutral at this point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And interest earning balance growth is expected to be driven by continued card spend and lower payment rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I think what's important to remember, as it relates to our business, is that it's global.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That we've got, while you're right in that, on the U.S. dollar side, we've seen betas kind of reach, particularly for our corporate clients, reach terminal levels at the end of last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the non-US dollar side, betas run lower.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They lag.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there's still upside there because it's a different rate curve and a different pace of increases.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, those will be some of the puts and takes to think about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Volumes, the rates, the speed of the curve moves, and then how betas evolve, that will kind of factor in.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Ryan Kenny with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Hey good morning.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: On the capital markets side, I heard the comments around it being hard to predict when deal activity will sustainably rebound.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Can you just give us an update or more color on how CEOs are thinking about bringing deals live across M&A, ECM and DCM?

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: And does the market and rate volatility over the last few weeks have any significant impact on bringing deals to completion or on the pipeline?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, I think a couple pieces.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I actually start with Q3 is the seventh quarter of the current IB downturn.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, since 2000, downturns have tended not to last longer than seven quarters because that's often how long it takes for pricing expectations to fully adjust to new realities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're starting to see that particularly in the debt capital markets, investment grade markets, where the expectation of no longer how high, but how long for rates, we've seen clients who get off the sidelines and just bite the bullet and get into the debt capital markets in a more meaningful way and no longer waiting on that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We still think that how our recovery and return to normal wallet plays out, when you talk to CEOs, is largely dependent on the macro environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's the main piece for them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: ECM, we're seeing increased interest and activity on ECM.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You obviously had several IPOs coming to market in September, three big ones that we were involved in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But the marketis still somewhat fragile.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're watching it closely.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And quite a few questions in Q4, things may move to Q1.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We just have to see how that unfolds.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But there's a good pipeline.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, there's a lot of pent-up demand here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In debt, we had a big pick-up in DCM.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We feel confident that the gradual recovery in DCM and the beginnings of that lev fin one will continue.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You're certainly going the see us more active in the lev fin space in the right situations for our key clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then in M&A, a healthy M&A sell-side pipeline.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A lot of companies with their industries transforming are really wanting to think big.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we'll see that unlocking when sentiment improves further, companies do accept the new pricing reality, which will be helped by a rebound in equity markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That obviously, from our end, takes quite a few quarters to materialize into revenue just given the nature of the product.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, it's there, but I think just given where everything is geopolitically and particularly from the macro, no one is going to make that call as to when we're going to see that sustainable turn in banking at this point.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So, Mark and Jane, I do recognize you'll provide a more fulsome update on expense actions next quarter, but one of the things I was hoping was that you could frame the expense opportunity in the context of your headcount trends.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And prior to COVID, as well as the consent order, mind you, Citi was running with 200,000 direct staff.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: That number is closer to 240,000 today.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: It's an increase of 20%, even with multiple divestitures that you've consummated.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So how should we think about an appropriate target or an optimal level of headcount for Citi versus that pre-COVID baseline of 200,000, and whether the consent order would impact the timing or magnitude of such headcount actions?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, I'm not going to give you headcount guidance, but what I will say is Jane has talked before about the heads associated with the divestitures that are underway.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And obviously as we continue to progress in those divestitures, we've made a lot of progress already, we'll see those heads come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's also important to point out that as part of our effort, there's been in-sourcing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we've captured the extended workforce in the headcount that we have here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then I think the final point is that as we continue to execute against the Transformation work, and as we implement the org simplification that we've just announced, undoubtedly the technology investment, the automation that we're putting in place, the straight-through processing that occurs, the fewer reconciliations that are required, the streamlining from all of those layers that Jane mentioned we'll be eliminating, all of those things will also work to reduce headcount as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, while we're investing and hiring on the front-end to capture the upside as markets turn, but also as we position ourselves to grow with clients, we're also going to realize efficiencies that come out of headcount reduction.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One additional point is that you've heard me mention before that we've taken probably about $600 million or so year-to-date in repositioning charges.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that will come roughly 7,000 or so headcount coming down associated with those repositioning charges.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, and we'll continue to do that, by the way, we haven't even begun to take repositioning charges associated with the org simplification that's underway.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That will come in the fourth quarter and then the first quarter of next year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we will see heads continue to evolve through this process, but keep in mind that there are puts and takes associated with that as we look at where we need to in-source versus use external parties.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Good morning.Just maybe, Mark, following up on that, as we think about bending the curve through the end of next year, maybe if you can talk to around as we think about the puts and takes between investments and expense saves, how much of that cost save or bending the curve is going to happen in Legacy versus PBWM and ICG?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Like, just how do you break, how should we think about that as we think about bending the curve and where the savings are coming from?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Well, look, next year, we talked about expenses coming down from third quarter to fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we think about that, you'll have some of the benefits of the costs going away from the exits that we would have announced.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You have some of the benefit from further reduction in stranded cost, which we've been keenly focused on as we've exited each of these.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then I think as we get to the medium term, you will start to see some of the benefits from the Transformation spend and investments that we would have made start to play out, as well as efficiencies that we start to get in a lower structural cost base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, that's in that medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, all of those things will be drivers to getting the bending of the curve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I haven't broken down, I'm not going to break down here on this call how much comes from each of the pieces, but all are important factors to achieving that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: : Hi.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There were some quotes, I think, in the media, Jane, from you talking about some signs of pressure among the lower end of the consumer, and I appreciate the pie chart that you have in the deck showing it's not a huge percent of the card portfolio.

speaker: Operator
sentence: But could you elaborate on that?

speaker: Operator
sentence: And then also just address the, you mentioned directionally how the payment rates in cards are coming down, but if we look at the growth in spend versus the growth in loans, it is kind of a little disproportionate.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I think spend is up a couple percent year-over-year, and the loans are 11%.

speaker: Operator
sentence: So, as we think about being kind of later-cycle, is that something that you're paying attention to as a potential sign of further weakness in credit?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think most of the pressure in the lower FICO, we don't have a lot of customers in lower FICO, so, we're seeing it out in the market.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got, we obviously have some in the Retail Services business, we also, I would say, have the benefit of that loss sharing agreement that really makes a difference there because we're having to reserve fully for that, but we get it back on the revenue line, as you know.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But as we look at the off-us book, as we look at some of the pressures in the market, as we look at spending, we can certainly see some of that pressure for the lower FICO, whereas when I think about the cards business, it's very much driven by the affluent customer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, the affluent is accounting for almost all the spending growth that we're seeing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that's similar for the numbers that we saw coming out of the Fed from the deposit side, the excess savings are sitting there now primarily with households with over $150,000 of income, and it's down in the rest.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, these are things we're keeping an eye on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I want to be very clear, I'm not that worried about it for Citi given the prime nature of our card portfolio, and then the rest of our PBWM exposure is obviously very affluent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But when I look out at the market, I talk to our corporate clients, that's where we tend to see them being more nervous about the softness in the consumer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And just, I call it they're much more mindful about where they're spending, right?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you're seeing them moving down within a category.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They're certainly looking more on the bargain front.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been hearing that from our retail partners.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been hearing that across the board.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, growth of card loans is good.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our spend is up, but less than loans.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think it's softening, but it's not worrying.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that's spot on, Jane.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add is that when you look at the payment rates in Branded Cards, while they've started to come down, they're still above the pre-COVID level.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we obviously have invested in this business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the other thing that's driving this is the new account acquisitions are obviously important drivers of that spend volume and ultimately that loan growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, there's nothing that we see outside of what we were expecting in terms of how this portfolio is normalizing.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Good morning, Jane and good morning Mark.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Jane, as you pointed out, you're very excited about the opportunities in TTS.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: You're winning some new mandates in the custody business.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you feel is it because the competition is struggling with other issues?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: What gives you, because Citi has always been well-regarded in this area, so what gives you that added excitement that this is even getting better?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think the added excitement is, a lot of it's coming from the investments that we've been making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that we are, if you look at it in terms of Payment Express, which is live in the U.S., Thailand, on track for three more markets, that is really a very differentiating capability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The momentum we have in 24/7 clearing that's been put in place, we've had over $1 billion processed year-to-date.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Putting our Commercial Bank clients onto CitiDirect so they have seamless access to our whole TTS network globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You heard us talking about Citi Token Services, you can see us innovating with the Fed in new capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So really across the board, it's that innovation in cutting-edge, first-in-the-market type of capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But you're putting that on top of a network that's just unprecedented in terms of its presence, its local capabilities, its payroll, cash management, liquidity management, its collections, its receivables, all sitting on one platform connected globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And what that gives a client in terms of efficiency saves, insights on data, what they can do in terms of risk management and how to really optimize their treasury capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, this thing is a thing of beauty.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's very, very hard, it's very sticky,to extricate from this because it's embedded into how our clients do business, it's that critical and into their technology systems.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, when you look at where the world's headed and what's going on in the world, volatility, these other elements, it's hard not to see opportunities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's opportunities as well with our Markets business linked in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One of our really differentiating factors that Andy Morton talks about all the time is his partnership with TTS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The fact that one of our major client bases are corporates and they have a different profile, let's say, to an asset manager or a hedge fund.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we uniquely can serve them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, that's the piece.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's that combination in trends we see.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that's spot on, Jane.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add is that the middle market commercial space is a huge opportunity for us, as you said earlier, leveraging that TTS platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then on the Securities Services side, the reality is that we're finally seeing real traction in North America, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've always had kind of strength in many of the other regions, but we're really winning some major mandates here in North America, which I think is enough to get really excited about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think that, to me, is what then drives a lot of the strategy and what we're trying to do in terms of get to that high quality of earnings, better earnings mix, and other pieces that will help us get to that medium-term return target that we are so focused on.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Vivek Juneja with JP Morgan.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Want to just clarify the reorganization a little bit.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: So, Jane, I heard you say that you're keeping North Asia and South Asia heads.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: So, did you just get rid of the Asia head and get rid of the product heads, where product heads in each country were reporting to a regional product head?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: So, is that that dotted line is no longer there or what's going on there?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And when you get rid of all the monthly management reporting, what are you planning to replace that with from your management, your MIS perspective?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, let me take the second one first.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm not planning on replacing it with anything.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't need them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're no longer running consumer franchises in the countries.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Instead, we've got global businesses that are operating very consistently in the individual geographies, so we just don't need to replace them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it enables us just to have the legal entity, financial management that we need.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then our internal reports get greatly simplified.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Same as they get greatly simplified by taking out ICG and PBWM is another, eliminating that layer also eliminates a lot of different reports.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, the wonderful answer is, nothing, a simpler Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The first question was about, okay, help you understand what we've done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, on the geography front, we have done two main things already.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One is we've eliminated the regions and have just put a single international head reporting to me.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, that makes it much simpler for me.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I have one international head, and then he will help us manage the geographies collectively.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The second piece is we really narrowed the mandate of geography to delivering to our clients and covering our clients in their countries.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And secondly, the legal entity management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And otherwise, before, we had a huge amount of management on shadow P&Ls and different, a lot of very heavy committee structure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That was necessary because the business was still very local, as a retail bank, a local credit card business, a local onshore wealth business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They've gone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's just serving multinationals.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The subsidiaries are multinationals and in some markets the investors and the wealth clients in some markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that's a much simpler business to manage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we could get rid of the regional layer, and we just jump straight down to the clusters that we have today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They too have less of a mandate than they had before, a much more focused one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the bit that I'm excited about is not just, yes, this makes it much simpler to manage, but it also helps us really focus on the global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, our geographies and our banking organizations sitting together on the same management structure are collectively accountable for serving and delivering against our core client base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And they're in one team to do it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It just makes it much easier.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Does that give you a feel?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What else, Mark?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other thing, Vivek, that I think is important here is we really want to spend a little bit more investment in time on the client lens in terms of the financial reporting, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Because, as Jane talked about, we talked about the synergies across the franchise that we can capture, the ability to leverage the offering we have for those different client segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, looking at that P&L, looking at those returns, looking at that growth opportunity through that client lens will be something where we want to enhance the metrics that we have already around that so that we can capture that upside.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And around the other piece that I think is also just an important point, globalization is changing and we're seeing these lanes all changing through trade, financial flows, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: By actually having a single international organization and then the different clusters, North and South Asia, Europe, UK, LATAM, Middle East, Africa, the connection points between them are really changing at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, this makes us much more agile in our delivery of the global network because I think it's much more in line with how the world is operating today.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Saul Martinez with HSBC.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: So, I wanted to continue on the thread of normalization of credit losses.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And you guys have, I guess your guidance is implying that Branded Cards and Retail Services get back to more normalized levels by year-end, which is a decent-sized uptick over the levels you had in the third quarter.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: So, I kind of want to know what's driving that view.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: But more importantly I guess, what does that imply going forward?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And does it imply that we get to more, something more like above trend losses?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Because I would think we still have some seasoning to go on the late 2021 and 2022 vintages.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And not only that, talking about this in an environment where we still have pretty extraordinary labor markets.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: So, if you could just give us a little bit more color on just your expectations on credit losses and whether there's maybe a little bit more risk than we're thinking in terms of losses trending to something that is a bit higher than what we normally, or what are more normalized levels?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, let me start on that, and then, Jane, if you want to chime in, that's fine.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think what I'd point you to is page 24 in the deck that we have because it gives you a nice snapshot of how both the loss rates have been trending but also how the delinquencies have been trending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you can see that the delinquencies have been trending up, and that kind of gives us a good indication of where loss rates are likely to trend in the next quarter or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, at 2.72% on Branded Cards and 4.53% on Retail Services, we can see that we're likely to end up at about that normalized rate by the end of the year getting up to the 3-3.25%, 5-5.50% pre-COVID normalized NCL rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our expectation is that as we go into 2024, to the point that you've made, depending on the macro environment, we're likely to see this tick up above those pre-COVID normalized rates, as we see a slowdown in the economy, again, subject to what the macro looks like, before then kind of settling down at some point, down the path.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, yes, we do see that tick up.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This is again as advertised, so to speak, as we would have expected.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have reserves, significant reserves for both of these portfolios to account for those loss expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, in Branded Cards, we sit with an ACL to loan reserve of 6.3%, and Retail Services, we have 11%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane mentioned earlier that the losses in Retail Services ultimately get shared with partners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, while we would expect this to normalize and mature, so to speak, we feel very well-reserved for what that might look like.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And our portfolio is very prime.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, this is not the old Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's very different in terms of our consumer credit exposure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think what you're hearing from us is, this should all be very manageable.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're not, there's no alarm bells going off at Citi around this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're being prudent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're being conservative around pieces and responsible on it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But there's no alarm bells ringing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think that there may be a bit of a disconnect from some of the questions out there versus how we're feeling.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're just not seeing the data that is overly concerning.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is all very manageable, and we're being prudent about it, as you'd expect us to be.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, look, we remain confident around our ability to hit these targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got, you heard me talk earlier around the revenue growth and what are some of the tailwinds that we've got behind us as well as the core strategy and the drivers that we're in control of and that we've been investing behind to achieve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, our strategy is unchanged, we're confident it will drive the revenue growth of 4% to 5%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not the primary purpose, but the org simplification is the third driver of the expense reductions that we've talked about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would also say that when you look at revenue, expenses, and the targets we've laid out at Investor Day, we've certainly had plenty of headwinds in macro, regulatory, geopolitics in the last couple of years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have delivered on what we said we would do in the revenue, in the expense guidance, and on the strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've made adaptions along the way as we've needed to.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I think that's the piece that we're also really trying to drive into the firm is a culture of we will do what we say we will do, and we'll adapt accordingly to different areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark talked about adapting to the capital requirements, depending on what they are.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have other levers that we can pull, capital allocation, management buffer, DTA.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But my message to our investors is we're just building a proof point.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is a relentless execution.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look at that strategy scorecard page at the beginning of the deck there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've achieved a lot and there is a lot going on, and we're getting a lot done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't pretend we're at the end of the road there, we're there yet.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we're getting done what we said we'd do and building up those proof points so that you can see us achieve those return targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Anything to add, Mark?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you said, building credibility and being transparent, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we're going to keep delivering on the proof points, and we're going to be transparent about how and when and how we're going to achieve it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And our next question comes from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, you mentioned in the credit section that the delinquencies are rising, and as a percentage of loans, they're still very low.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: I was just curious on the corporate loans in North America there was an uptick.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Again, I know relative to the portfolio, it's not that big.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: But anything in particular you can share with us in that area?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the corporate loans, we saw loss, I think losses were $51 million in the quarter, so a small amount.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did see an uptick, as you point out, in the reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That was really driven by some country rating adjustments that were made.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then we did see an increase in the NALs, the non-accrual loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that was really one or two names and one in North America, one in EMEA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Both of them are current.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But they drove the uptick that we saw in the quarter there.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And there are no further questions in the queue.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you, all, for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: If you have any follow-up questions, please contact IR.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and a very good morning to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, we certainly live in interesting times.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And while I usually start our calls with our views on the global macro environment, we are particularly proud of our progress this quarter, and so I shall start there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Indeed, in a pivotal year, this quarter contains multiple proof points that we are moving in the right direction and that our strategy is delivering concrete results.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We saw revenue growth and positive operating leverage for the firm and across all five businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our businesses performed well as the rate cutting cycle began, with a double-digit increase in fee-based revenues, reflecting the growing diversity of our earnings mix.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to have share gains in Services and Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Wealth, we saw a sizeable increase in client investments and flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We brought expenses down whilst continuing to invest in our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we continued to attract top leaders in the industry and successfully combine them with our own teams in Banking and Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, while we are not yet where we want to be, the impact of the changes we are making is clearly evident in our momentum and improving performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to the macro, now while growth is a notch slower than last year, global economic performance continues to be surprisingly resilient.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Whatever you want to call the US landing, the sentiment around it is more optimistic, supported by the recent positive payrolls report.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we see a healthy yet more discerning US consumer, and a US corporate sector on its front foot.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Manufacturing weakness is restraining a modest rebound in Europe which continues to struggle with more structural challenges around its competitiveness, as highlighted by Draghi’s report.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In China, consumer sentiment and the property market remain a concern as markets await details on the expected fiscal stimulus.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: India, Asean, Japan, the Middle East, Mexico and Brazil are all notable global bright spots.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Today we reported net income of $3.2 billion and earnings per share of $1.51 with an ROTCE of 7%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall revenues grew by 3% ex-divestitures, with each of our core businesses delivering growth and positive operating leverage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While we continue to make substantial investments in our transformation, the efficiencies gained from our simplification and other efforts drove a 2% reduction in overall expenses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Turning to the five businesses, Services delivered a record quarter with revenues up by 8%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Fee growth, the best indicator of underlying momentum, was significant.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this, combined with loan and deposit volume growth, drove this quarter’s excellent performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Treasury and Trade Solutions was up 4% year over year reflecting good underlying momentum in the core drivers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And Securities Services was up 24%, reflecting the benefit of new mandates and an increase in assets under custody.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Both TTS and Securities Services achieved over 10% wallet share in our target markets through the first half of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Last week we announced that we are the first global bank to complete the integration of our cross-border services with Mastercard Move.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, this will ultimately enable near-instant, secure payments to the vast Mastercard debit network, starting with 14 markets with more to come early next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this is another great example of our continued investment in market-leading product innovations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Markets, revenues were up slightly on the back of a better-than- expected September.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equities was up 32% with robust performance across all products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our continued strong performance in Equities validates both our strategy and execution to grow Prime and Cash.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Fixed Income however was down 6% — our Rates and Currencies business didn’t match last year’s standout performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It was a particularly pleasing quarter in Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Despite the muted IPO market, Investment Banking fees are up 44% driven by investment grade debt issuance as our clients pulled forward activity ahead of the U.S. election.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Corporate sentiment remains positive as boards pursue strategic transactions, such as the $36 billion Mars acquisition of Kellanova, where we are the sole advisor and lead financier.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our strategy in Banking continues to gain momentum, and we are steadily growing our share in key target sectors such as healthcare and tech, with a healthy pipeline ahead.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the significant upside of our franchise continues to attract the top talent to Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we announced an innovative $25 billion private credit partnership with our longtime client Apollo, giving us the ability to source new transactions without using our balance sheet.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This partnership positions us with another solution for debt financing for our clients, and it allow us to engage in private credit with the same depth and expertise as we currently do with syndicated debt markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are also starting to see the positive impact of the significant changes we’ve implemented in our Wealth franchise, with revenues up 9%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It’s a notable example of the traction I referenced earlier.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As Andy and the team intensify the focus on our investments business, we grew client investment assets by 24%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we were particularly pleased with the performance in Asia and in Citigold.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I continue to be excited by the opportunities and the sheer potential of our franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we signed an agreement to exit trust administration and fiduciary services as we continue to sharpen the focus of our Wealth business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have more to do to reach our medium-term margin and returns targets, but this quarter is a good indicator that we are on the way there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking revenues were up 3%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew Branded Cards revenues by 8% with account acquisitions, spend and payment rates all driving higher interest-earning balances.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Lower discretionary spending is impacting our Retail Services portfolio; however, we continue to see lower payment rates contributing to interest earning balances.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Retail Banking, we are growing our mortgage portfolio as the rate environment shifts, as well as growing overall loans.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The U.S. consumer dynamics remain remarkably consistent with prior quarters.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our customers are healthy but more discerning in their spend, with signs of stress isolated to the lower FICOs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have maintained strong credit discipline, and our card portfolios continue to perform very much in line with our expectations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of capital, while uncertainty about the Basel 3 endgame prevails, our capital position remains very robust, and we ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of 13.7%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the quarter, we returned $2.1 billion in capital, including the repurchase of $1 billion of common shares.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will continue to repurchase stock as we evaluate the right level on a quarterly basis.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, our Transformation is our number one priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This quarter we closed another long-standing consent order which related to the effectiveness of our anti-money laundering systems.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have increased our investments in areas where we have not made sufficient progress, such as data quality management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I and the management team remain steadfast and determined to get this Transformation right and to get this done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will close out this pivotal year with momentum and with determination to continue to improve performance in each business and the firm overall.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are committed to meeting our revenue and expense targets for the year as well as our return target for the medium-term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am very proud of our senior leadership and the entire organization as we demonstrate the potential of our unique global franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It is a privilege to lead this firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that, I would like to turn it over to Mark and then we would be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the firmwide financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons for the third quarter unless I indicate otherwise, and then spend a little more time on the businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 5, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the quarter, we reported net income of approximately $3.2 billion, EPS of $1.51 and an RoTCE of 7.0% on $20.3 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total revenues were up 1% on a reported basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divestiture-related impacts, revenues were up 3%, driven by growth across each of our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you can see on the bottom left side of the page, net interest income excluding Markets was down 1% YoY, largely due to lower interest rates in Argentina.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And non-interest revenue excluding Markets was up 9% as we continued to see strong fee momentum across Services, Banking and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Year-to-date, revenues are up 1% on a reported basis, and are up 3% excluding divestiture-related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were $13.3 billion, down 2%, largely driven by savings associated with our organizational simplification and stranded cost reductions, partially offset by volume related expenses and continued investments in the Transformation and other risk and control initiatives.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Year-to-date, expenses are up 1%, primarily driven by the FDIC special assessment and civil money penalties.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $2.7 billion, largely driven by net credit losses in Cards as well as ACL builds across the businesses, primarily for portfolio growth and mix.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had over $22 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of approximately 2.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And year-to-date, excluding the divesture related impacts, we generated positive operating leverage for the firm, and reported an RoTCE of 7.2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6, we show the expense trend over the past five quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This quarter we reported expenses of $13.3 billion, down 2%, and 1% sequentially.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we’ve said before, we will continue to increase our investments to address data governance and data quality related to regulatory reporting and are committed to spending whatever is necessary to address these areas and the Transformation more broadly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Although a lot more work remains, we have started to see benefits from our prior investments play through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We’ve continued to simplify our technology infrastructure, retiring over 450 applications year-to-date and now over 1,250 since our 2022 Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We’ve upgraded 100% of our over 2,300 ATMs in North America and Asia Pacific to next-gen software for better customer security and monitoring.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have streamlined our cloud onboarding process, reducing time to onboard applications to the public cloud from over 7 weeks to 2 weeks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Each of these initiatives will result in both improvement of our operating efficiency and our safety and soundness.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in terms of our full year expenses, we continue to expect that we will be at the higher end of the guidance range of $53.5 to 53.8 billion, excluding the FDIC special assessment and civil money penalties.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we’ve said before, we, of course, will continue to look for opportunities to absorb the civil money penalties.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show net interest income, loans and deposits where I’ll speak to sequential variances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the third quarter, net interest income declined 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding Markets, net interest income was up 4%, largely driven by volume growth in USPB as well as higher deposit spreads in Services and Wealth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NIM declined by 8 basis points, driven by a decline in Markets due to seasonally higher dividends in the second quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were up 1%, driven by growth in Services and USPB, partially offset by modest declines in Banking and Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits were roughly flat, as growth in Services was largely offset by a decline in Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you think about guidance for NII ex-Markets in the fourth quarter: As short-end rates continue to come down, we expect a headwind on floating-rate assets which will be somewhat offset by disciplined deposit pricing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Further offsetting that will be a continued benefit from securities being reinvested at higher yields.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as a reminder, we expect an ongoing NII headwind as Legacy Franchises’ loans and deposits continue to come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, taking all of this into account, we expect NII ex Markets to be roughly flat sequentially in the fourth quarter, and for the full year to be slightly down, better than we had previously guided.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics, which reflect our disciplined risk appetite framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across our Cards portfolio, approximately 85% of our loans are to consumers with FICO scores of 660 or higher.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Based on what we see, the US consumer continues to remain healthy and resilient.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Spend and payment rates continue to normalize, and underlying credit performance remains broadly in line with our expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NCLs increased year-over-year as card loan vintages that were originated over the last few years continue to mature at the same time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sequentially, NCLs declined while delinquencies increased, both in-line with historical third quarter seasonality.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Absent this seasonality, we continue to see stabilization in early-stage delinquencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We remain well reserved with a reserve-to-funded loan ratio of approximately 8.2% for our U.S. Cards portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our Corporate portfolio is largely investment grade and corporate non accrual loans remained low, at 31 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As such, we feel very comfortable with the over $22 billion of total reserves that we have in the current environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 9, we provide details on our balance sheet, capital and liquidity, which are a reflection of our risk appetite, strategy and business model.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $1.3 trillion deposit base is well-diversified across regions, industries, customers and account types.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: $840 billion are corporate, spanning 90 countries, and are crucial to how our clients fund their daily operations around the world.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The majority of our remaining deposits, about $400 billion, are well-diversified across the Private Bank, Citigold, Retail and Wealth at Work offerings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And of our total deposits, roughly 70% are US dollar denominated with the remainder spanning over 60 currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our asset mix also reflects our strong risk appetite framework.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $689 billion loan portfolio is well-diversified across consumer and corporate loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, deposit growth outpaced loan growth resulting in higher cash balances which contributed to available liquidity resources of approximately $960 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to feel very good about the strength of our balance sheet and the quality of our assets and liabilities, which position us well to serve our clients and execute on our growth strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 10, we show the sequential CET1 walk to provide more detail on the drivers this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we generated $3.0 billion of net income to common shareholders, which added 27 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we returned $2.1 billion in the form of common dividends and share repurchases, which drove a reduction of 18 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, we generated 12 basis points from unrealized AFS gains.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, the remaining 9 basis point reduction was driven by an increase in RWA as we continue to invest in accretive growth opportunities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the third quarter with a preliminary CET1 capital ratio of 13.7% relative to our target of 13.3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, effective October 1st, our new CET1 capital ratio requirement is 12.1%, and we still plan on holding a 100 basis point management buffer on top of that for now.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we think about the coming quarters, there are a few things that we will continue to consider as we manage our capital levels, including client demand as well as how the macro and Basel 3 Endgame evolves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will take all of this into account as it relates to capital levels and the level of share repurchases on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to the businesses on slide 11.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Services, revenues were up 8%, reflecting continued momentum across Securities Services and TTS, both of which continue to gain share through the first half of this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net interest income was roughly flat, as the benefit of higher deposit volumes was largely offset by a decline in interest rates in Argentina.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a sequential basis, net interest income was up 7%, driven by volume growth as we continue to onboard high-quality operating deposits and the benefit from higher deposit spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Non-interest revenue increased 33%, driven by a smaller impact from currency devaluation in Argentina as well as continued strength in underlying fee drivers in TTS and Securities Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the impact of the Argentine Peso devaluation, NIR increased 11%, driven by growth in cross border transactions, US Dollar Clearing volumes and Commercial Card volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 3%, primarily driven by investments in technology, other risk and controls and product innovation, including the expansion of the CitiDirect Commercial Banking platform into additional markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $127 million, primarily driven by a build related to unremittable corporate dividends being held on behalf of clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 5% primarily driven by continued demand for export and agency finance as well as working capital loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits increased 4% as we continue to see growth in operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services generated positive operating leverage and delivered net income of approximately $1.7 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And continues to deliver a high RoTCE, coming in at 26.4% for the quarter and 24.7% year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 12, we show the results for Markets for the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets revenues were up 1%, driven by growth in Equities, partially offset by a decline in Fixed Income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equities revenues increased 32%, driven by momentum in Prime with balances up approximately 22%, growth in Derivatives and higher Cash volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income revenues decreased 6%, driven by Rates and Currencies, which was down 10%, partially offset by Spread Products and Other Fixed Income, which was up 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While Rates and Currencies declined from last year, which was the strongest third quarter in the previous 10 years, we did see good momentum in FX from increased corporate client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Spread Products and Other Fixed Income was higher driven by Financing and Securitization volumes and underwriting fees, partially offset by lower Commodities on lower gas volatility.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 1% primarily due to higher volume related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $141 million, driven by an ACL build primarily related to portfolio mix in Spread Products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 10%, largely driven by asset-backed lending in Spread Products as well as margin loans in Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average trading account assets increased 18%, largely driven by client demand for US Treasuries, foreign government securities and mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets generated another quarter of positive operating leverage and delivered net income of approximately $1.1 billion with an RoTCE of 7.9% for the quarter and 9.7% year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 13, we show the results for Banking for the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking revenues were up 16%, largely driven by growth in Investment Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking revenues were up 31% and fees were up 44%, with increases across Debt Capital Markets, Advisory and Equity Capital Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: DCM benefited from continued strong Investment Grade issuance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Advisory benefited from strong announced deal volume earlier this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in ECM we saw stronger follow-on activity, which was offset by fewer IPOs amid market volatility in August.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Both year-to-date and in the quarter, we’ve driven wallet share gains, including in the Healthcare and Technology sectors where we’ve been investing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate Lending revenues, excluding mark-to-market on loan hedges, increased 5%, primarily driven by a smaller impact from currency devaluation in Argentina.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 9%, primarily driven by benefits of headcount reductions as we continued to right size the workforce and expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $177 million, driven by an ACL build primarily for portfolio mix changes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans decreased 1% as we maintained strict discipline around returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking generated positive operating leverage for the third quarter in a row and delivered net income of $238 million with an RoTCE of 4.3% for the quarter and 7.2% year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 14, we show the results for Wealth for the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you can see from our performance this quarter, we are making good progress against our strategy and expect that momentum to continue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenue was up 9%, driven by a 15% increase in NIR as we grew investment fee revenues on momentum in client investment assets, which grew 24%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NII increased 6% driven by higher deposit volumes and spreads.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 4%, driven by the continued benefits of headcount reductions as we right size the workforce and expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $33 million, largely driven by net credit losses of $27 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: End-of-period client balances increased 14%, driven by higher client investment assets and deposits, both in North America and internationally.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits increased 4%, reflecting the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits from USPB, partially offset by a shift in deposits to higher-yielding investments on Citi’s platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans decreased 1%, as we continued to optimize capital usage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth generated another quarter of positive operating leverage and delivered net income of $283 million with an RoTCE of 8.5% for the quarter and 6.8% year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 15, we show the results for US Personal Banking for the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: US Personal Banking revenues were up 3%, driven by NII growth of 2% and lower partner payments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues increased 8%, with interest-earning balance growth of 8% as payment rates continue to normalize and we continue to see growth in spend volumes, which were up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues were down 1%, due to a slowing growth rate in interest earning balances.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues decreased 8%, driven by the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits to our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 1%, driven by continuous productivity focus, partially offset by higher volume-related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.9 billion, largely driven by net credit losses and a modest build for volume growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to expect Branded Cards to be in the 3.5% to 4.0% NCL range for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Retail Services, we continue to expect to be around the high end of the 5.75% to 6.25% range for the full year, driven by both the impact of persistent inflation and high interest rates as well as lower sales activity at our partners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits decreased 23%, largely driven by the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits to our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: USPB generated another quarter of positive operating leverage and delivered net income of $522 million with an RoTCE of 8.2% for the quarter and 5.2% year-to-date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we’ve said before, the USPB segment creates a lot of value for the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We knew 2024 would be a tough year, as we lap the credit costs, but we have a path to higher returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will continue to drive revenue growth through product innovations while improving the operating efficiency of the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And at the same time, we expect the credit environment to normalize.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of which will ultimately drive USPB to a high-teens return over the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 17 shows our full year 2024 outlook and medium-term guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We’ve generated $61.6 billion of revenue year-to-date, driven by NIR ex-Markets growth of 12%, and are on track to meet our $80 to 81 billion full year guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I mentioned, we now expect NII ex-Markets to be slightly down for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with year-to-date expenses of $40.4 billion excluding the FDIC special assessment and civil money penalties, we continue to expect to be on the higher-end of our full year guidance range.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we take a step back, the third quarter represents another quarter of solid progress and a set of proof points towards improving firmwide and business performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We remain focused on continuing to improve our performance and executing on our Transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These priorities remain critical to strengthening our operations and becoming a more efficient, agile and client-centric company as we continue to make progress on achieving our medium-term targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I will be happy to take your questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: At this time, we will open the floor for questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: [Operator Instructions].

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Good guidance.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate it.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I'm curious on the card losses in Retail financial services, if you could talk to like, the 2024 exit rate seems like it will be higher than the full year guide at 6.25%.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Maybe you could talk to the trajectory there and then the huge reserves that you have built in there and anything you can tell us about the portfolios so we can keep expectations in the right spot.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Why don't I take that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So a couple things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, I think that on Retail Services you're seeing a couple of things kind of play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, you're seeing kind of spend volumes trend down a bit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You are seeing payment rates come down as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That obviously is fueling the average interest earning balance growth that we're seeing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then you are also seeing with the spend volume come down, there's a denominator effect that plays through which pushes up obviously the loss rates that we're seeing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That still in the quarter is in line with our guidance but in light of what we saw earlier in the year and normal seasonality, we would expect that number to be on the higher end of that range and likely higher in the fourth quarter, but the higher in the fourth quarter again depends on what traffic is like and what the holiday spending season looks like through the end of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would say the reserve levels we have are very healthy as it relates to this portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think in the back of the deck we show kind of the reserve to loan ratio at about 11.7% or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So well-reserved for the Retail Services portfolio in light of the environment that we're in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Similarly, we are seeing the stabilization from a delinquency point of view across both portfolios kind of play through and so net-net, we are obviously actively managing this.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The retail partner activity is a critical component of it and that will drive fourth quarter activity or levels, but we do feel as if we'll end up on the higher end of the range here.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Just one quickie On your partnership with Apollo, very interesting and in line with a lot of other things we've seen.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Curious on how you thought about going with one specific partner versus a group and then more importantly, are there other parts of the franchise that could benefit with stronger ties to private markets, I'm thinking specifically in the asset-backed world.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Appreciate it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we're delighted to partner with Apollo because what this does is it's uniting our comprehensive banking reach and expertise together and it's enabling us to offer our clients more innovative and tailored financing solutions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There will be some other partners involved in this as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mubadala is another participant in this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when we look at this, it's very, very beneficial for our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're always looking at how we can best serve our clients, give them the most options and this platform enhances corporate and sponsor clients access to the private lending capital pool at real scale in $25 billion is a very sizable partnership here and it provides funding certainty and strategic transactions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's exclusive for LBOs, non-investment grade in the US.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The US is obviously the bulk of the private credit market, it’s the behemoth globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It would be great to see that market developing in Europe and it wouldn't surprise me to see us doing more partnerships and other pieces going forward.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess maybe, Mark, for you, like looking at slide 7 on NII, and maybe we can break it down into Markets and ex-Markets.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: In the ex-Markets NII, $11.96 billion this quarter, based on what you've said, the back book repricing, deposit flex, is it safe to conclude that the ex-Markets NII bottomed in 2Q 2024?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And I noticed the securities yield actually went lower, 7 bps quarter-over-quarter.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: So was there something one-off that impacted the yield this quarter relative to the expectations you outlined earlier?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So when you look at slide 7, you got a couple of things playing through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So your point around the low number, the low print, $11.46 billion in the second quarter, that really is a combination relative to first quarter of FX translation, some seasonally lower card balances, and lower interest payments in Argentina playing through that sequential 1Q to 2Q.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The third quarter, as I mentioned earlier, is really a by-product of volumes on the lending side and spreads, deposit spreads in Services and Wealth and I think that I've already given kind of the guide for the fourth quarter where that is likely to be flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think it's important to just remind everyone of the headwinds and tailwinds that play through this NII line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And from a tailwind point of view, I would expect to see continued volume from loans, USPB in particular but also Services and we're talking ex-Markets, so Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd also expect to see continued benefit from the reinvestment of securities at higher yields and then we're actively managing beta as it relates to with our clients and if you think about kind of what we saw in the uptick of rates, we're actively managing that on the down tick as it relates to our institutional clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the other point here is let's not forget that our interest rate sensitivity skews more towards non-US and so a lot of what we think about and talk about tends to be how US rates move and the betas around that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're still going to have a bit of beta catch-up outside of the US and so that's one of the headwinds there as well as the Legacy Franchise exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So you've got this long-winded way of saying, I do expect flat into the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not going to give guidance for 2025.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what I will say is to keep the growth momentum to get to our medium-term targets, that's 4% to 5% of a CAGR and that's going to be a combination of NII and NIR but skewing NIR.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I want to point that out because the third quarter and the year-to-date numbers that you see in our performance shows very strong fee NIR growth across each of these five businesses and I don't want to lose sight of that as you all really try to get a handle on how we get to that medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're evidencing that shift towards more fee revenue as we speak.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I'll stop there, but I think that's important and hopefully I've answered your question around the NII forecast here.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: That's helpful.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And agreed on the fee momentum.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just one quick on the Wealth segment.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: We've seen a considerable progress year-to-date in terms of going from zero ROE to about 8.5% RoTCE, significant operating leverage.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I think I heard Jane say that momentum should continue.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Is it fair to assume that RoTCE remains, like Wealth remains a positive story as we think about how Citi's ROE continues to improve from here as we get towards the target?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Any color on the Wealth side would be helpful.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we're all very pleased to see the progress on the strategy we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Wealth target we have in the medium term is 15% to 20% and with that a 25% to 30% operating margin and we're making steady progress there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the first piece was putting the pieces of the global wealth organization together and now we're focused on positioning for growth and reshaping the business to deliver the returns that we all expect.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A very important part of that is shifting our mix by growing investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We had 24% growth in client investment assets this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I would call that a good start to realizing the potential that we have here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And at the same time, Andy continues to right-size our expense base and drive productivity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our advisor productivity increased over 50% in Citigold North America.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So a number of different areas that he's focused on so that we can continue to grow the investment space including some important new talent that we've been bringing in that I'm sure you've noticed.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: What assurance can you give that Citi can both meet its 2026 expense guide, the $51 billion to $53 billion and I note the year-to-date run rate implies $54 billion.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So getting from that $54 billion run rate down to the $51 billion to $53 billion by 2026 and meet its regulatory targets.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: In other words, assurance that Citi can both walk and chew gum at the same time.

speaker: Mike Mayo
