sentence: And I guess I'd highlight as you know, on October 2 Senator Warren asked the OCC to impose growth restrictions because Citi is "too big to manage."

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I would assume you don't agree with that, but still the question that a lot of people have is what assurances can you give that an asset cap won't happen at Citigroup?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So why don't I start with your expense question and I'm sure Jane will chime in on some of the other parts of your question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, we put out medium term targets of $51 billion to $53 billion in 2026, revenue dependent, of course, and that's consistent with the target we gave of less than 60% efficiency ratio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we've got a target this year as you know on the high end of $53.8 billion [ex-FDIC special assessment and Civil Money Penalties].

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we've got to get from $53.8 billion down to $51 billion to $53 billion by 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not giving guidance for 2025 but you can expect that that will likely glide down to that number.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What's driving the reduction?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we've talked before about $1.5 billion in savings largely related to the restructuring and driving down headcount reduction associated with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We talked about another $500 million to $1 billion related to expense reductions from eliminating stranded cost as we continue to exit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're out of nine of these consumer countries already.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we talk about starting to see efficiencies and benefits from the investments and the transformation and technology towards the end of 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And those are the three drivers that are important for us to continue to realize between now and 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Will there be headwinds?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There will be, the transformation is a multiyear process.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're also investing in risk controls and regulatory spend to support improving our operations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of course, there will be headwinds but there will also be things that we shift away from.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There will be tailwinds associated with it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Jane mentioned some of the productivity efforts that both Andy as well as Vis are pushing on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You look across these businesses and you see positive operating leverage across the board.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that means that Andy Morton as well as Gonzalo are too looking at their cost structures, at expenses that they can take out or productivity that they might improve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so there will be additional costs that we have to incur.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We incurred additional costs this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But there will also be additional productivity savings that we continue to tease out to ensure that we get to these targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And, Mike, let me pick up on part of the second part of the question in terms of the progress on the transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, and as Mark's talked to you about, the transformation reverses historic underinvestment in Citi's infrastructure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It enhances our risk and control environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it's a strategic overhaul as we've talked about that goes well beyond the consent order to simplify and to strengthen Citi to the benefit of all of the stakeholders we have.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are already a very different Citi today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've made enormous change over the past three years, dramatically simpler business model, significant org change so we align our structure to that model.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We now have a flatter organization with greater accountability and as Mark talked about through the investments in our transformation, we're focused on simplifying our operational model, modernizing our infrastructure risk and controls and all of that reduces risk as we go.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're well on the way in executing the transformation plans.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've made meaningful progress as was acknowledged publicly by one of our regulators and it's a wide range book of work.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've made significant strides in areas such as risk management, compliance and accountability and that's well beyond the big bodies of work about consolidating our platforms.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we had 1,250 retired since 2022 as Mark mentioned.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Other areas of progress, enhance our stress testing capabilities, they're faster, more frequent, more precise assessments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We put in place new target operating models for wholesale credit risk, enterprise risk, price risk firm wide.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A huge body of work reducing risk and high risk processes such as payments and Markets through systemic preventative controls.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been implementing the XiNG platform, this is the strategic cloud solution for market risk analytics.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Values trades on demand and at scale.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've embedded risk and controls into our performance management framework and tied that to compensation for the full firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So these are just giving you a flavor of these big body of work that we are executing and getting done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I was very pleased that we closed the FRB, AML/BSA consent order particularly given heightened risk and scrutiny in this area.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That is the third consent order we've closed since 2021 and we've been very transparent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Where there are areas in which our execution is delayed against our original timelines as is the case with our data work.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We take a step back, determine what we need to change in those areas and get back on track and make relevant tech and people investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I feel very confident about the strategy we've laid out for the firm, the deliberate path we're on, the huge progress we've already made, and that we will continue making with determination and with clarity going forward.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, just one follow-up.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: When, and you do have the amended consent order that's not new anymore, but is this a problem with your dealing with clients or is this an issue with giving the regulators the information that they need?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And just again, you don't, just to confirm, you don't have an asset cap now, is it fair to assume that you don't expect an asset cap any time soon or could you have an asset cap and we don't even know about that?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't have any problems dealing with our clients, quite the opposite.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're a source of strength for our clients in terms of the provision of their payments businesses, their trading businesses, their consumer credit businesses, all across the board.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I would say quite the opposite.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are a source of tremendous strength for them and you see that in the results of this quarter which were very pleasing across the board in every single one of our businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are working closely with our regulators.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We incorporate their feedback as well as our own lessons learned.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If we fall behind in an element of the consent orders but do understand the breadth of the consent order work as I laid out and the meaningful progress we're making across multiple areas, and when we fall behind in an area we increase the investments needed and look at any lessons learned in the approach and address it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I feel very comfortable.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So again, we don't have – we're not talking about issues as it relates to client information, client data, client reporting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're not talking about information as it relates to financials.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're talking about regulatory reporting, all right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And regulatory reporting as I've mentioned in prior calls, we're a global firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got over 11,000 regulatory reports and we're talking about ensuring that the data that we capture at trade entry is the data that's required to ultimately show up on these various regulatory reports in the way that we need it ensuring that we've got the proper controls on that front end so we don't have to do a lot of the reconciliation and manual adjustments to that data in order to get it how we needed in the report and ensuring we have standardized rules and controls around that process so that we can do it as efficiently as possible.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But this is largely around ensuring that we improve those regulatory reports that we have to produce by starting with the underlying data that's required to do that.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey, good morning.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Mark, consensus expectations, and it's just another expense question in a different way.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: But consensus has you not hitting your revenue growth targets and you're certainly free to disagree and I think that's fine.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: But they also have your expenses at the high end of your $51 billion to $53 billion range in 2026.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I guess, does that make sense or do you feel confident that if revenues do sort of disappoint your targets that you could come in at the – you should or can come in at the lower end of that range to help get to your RoTCE target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, let's take it in pieces.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I think – the first thing is that, I think Jane and I have been very consistent with trying to give guidance on full year performance for the past couple years and we've largely actually delivered on that guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look at the top line growth since Investor Day, it's largely consistent with what we talked about in the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look at the expense guidance that we've given, largely consistent with that including this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Even as I look at the $80 billion to $81 billion revenue guidance we gave for the year, and you look at the $60.6 billion that we've done year-to-date, and you think about what we have to deliver in order to hit that target, that is achievable particularly when you remember that we had a large Argentina devaluation last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That fee momentum required in the fourth quarter is very achievable and we believe that we will obviously hit the high end of the [expense] range for 2024.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I think about that outer year period and the guidance that we gave there, look, you all want proof points before you actually believe that we can deliver on that medium term target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm pointing you to proof points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm hopeful that as you see those proof points through 2024, full year and each of the quarters, that you will start to believe in that revenue momentum that's required in the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The fee revenue is a very good indicator.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What we delivered this year and this quarter is a very good indicator of the momentum we should see across these businesses in the next couple years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I also hope that you would then see that as we deliver on the expense target that we have a path to continuing to deliver on the medium-term expense target, the drivers of which I mentioned earlier.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, if revenues come in short of the target that we've set for ourselves, you would naturally expect for the volume and transaction related expenses and compensation expenses to come down in a commensurate way with that revenue decline and you would also expect that we would look to see if there are other productivity opportunities that we can tease out in order to still deliver on that operating efficiency target that we've set for ourselves.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I appreciate it.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And maybe just as a follow-up on the capital question, I guess one thing that's been a bit of a headwind over the last year has been sort of growth from the DTA deductions.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Do we start to see that become a tailwind again?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How do we think about that accreting back into capital over the next couple of years?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, the main driver of our DTA utilization will be driving higher income in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's going to be the major driver and as we think about – so as you think about each of the strategies that Jane has described for our business, you will often hear the importance of winning in the US.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You'll hear it as it relates to Banking and the activity that we saw, the strong performance we saw this quarter in Vis’s world, you hear it as it relates to the Wealth business and the importance of us growing investments particularly in North America.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You see it in USPB which is largely a US focused business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That DTA utilization is about us increasing net income or higher net income in the US and as we work to execute on our client driven strategy, we are looking for opportunities to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're incenting the business to drive that momentum and that's what's going to give us a higher utilization on a quarter by quarter in the coming years.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think we've slid over to the afternoon.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: The first one is for you, Jane.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: As I speak with longer term investors, they often offer the commentary that clearly the path from the 7% RoTCE this quarter to the 11% to 12% hopefully will be bridged and to be able to initiate a position before that progress is made, they really sort of want to see more capital optimization.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And this question is not really the same question I ask you about buybacks every quarter but really maybe a progress update on Banamex.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So there is chatter in the market about Banamex needed to have four quarters of separate financials before being IPOed and I'm wondering if you could give us specific progress on how that's going?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And Mark, maybe remind us on what Banamex's contribution is as we think about the unlocking that excess capital versus taking it out of the P&L.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'd be delighted to, Erika.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would also just before I jump into Banamex point to a laser focus on capital optimization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's been a mantra for a long time in our Markets business, in Banking and a discipline that we've driven throughout the organization and I would say there isn't anyone at Citi that is not keenly aware of the focus around optimizing our capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Returning to shareholders, particularly given where we're trading, and making sure that we drive to returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So if I turn to Banamex, our singular focus right now is the separation of the two banks which we expect to complete in the fourth quarter of this year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This has been an enormous body of work because we are creating effectively de novo Mexico's eighth largest bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've just now gotten the core regulatory authorizations that we need to proceed with separation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Although there are a few other approvals pending.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are in the very final stages and are working with our clients to prepare them for this switchover later on in Q4.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Once the separation is complete, we will turn our full attention to the IPO itself and the successful execution of the IPO is the highest priority for our Head of International, Ernesto Torres Cantú, to run Banamex.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And our incoming Banamex Executive Chairman who starts this quarter, Ignacio Deschamps.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We plan to be ready to IPO at the end of 2025 based on the factors that we can control but I think as Mark and I have always said, the timing is going to be driven by market conditions to ensure we maximize the shareholder value.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're making the necessary investments to continue growing share and I was very pleased that Banamex outpaced the average market revenue growth year-to-date, good expense discipline being maintained despite the complex separation process and the environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'm pleased with where we are and I hope that gives you a bit of a flavor of what the path ahead looks like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the second part of your question, a couple things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, we've been seeing good growth in our Mexico Consumer business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've also been investing in it appropriately so to make sure that we protect the strength of that franchise as we prepare it for separation, ultimately for the IPO.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Erika, if I understood your question right, if we turn to page 16 of the deck in the bottom right hand side, we show the P&L for Mexico Consumer for 2022 and 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so you can see the contribution from a revenue and expense point of view so about $1.5 billion in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think it's about $4 billion or so of TCE that we have associated with this business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that gives you some sense for the contribution, but it continues to perform quite well as we manage it through this process.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Perfect.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And as a follow-up question, I'm sure it is frustrating for you to see the stock reaction in a quarter where you had PPNR strength and better expectations for net interest income in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So maybe I'll frame the question this way for you, Mark.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: As we think about the gyrations in interest rate expectations globally, may be remind us sort of is it fair to assume that Citi is asset sensitive internationally and neutrally positioned domestically?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: How should we think about late fees?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I know you told us that late fees going to $8 were part of your initial guide for the year.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And additionally, I think perhaps because capital markets is so strong across the board, across all of your peers, maybe that's not why you're getting, "credit for your strength this quarter".

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: So as we look into 2025 and having NIR be that bigger contribution to your revenue CAGR, maybe walk us through what are the other sort of core fee strengths that we should look for other than FICC and Banking remaining strong and coming back that could bring you to that path to 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's a lot there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But thank you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would like to see the stock reacting much more favorably because this really has been a strong quarter for us and in fact as you mentioned, NII when you look through it, we've in fact taken our NII guidance up just a tad bit as we referenced that the full year would be slightly down versus modestly down with the fourth quarter that's flat to the third quarter and so that is an important takeaway.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mentioned the headwinds and tailwinds earlier and we shouldn't lose sight of those.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will get lift from reinvesting the securities as those mature, we will continue to see volume growth and those are important drivers of tailwind activity for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You rightfully mentioned our interest rate exposure analysis that we do on a quarterly basis that reflects the asset sensitivity of our business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And last quarter it was about $1.6 billion or so of a negative, assuming 100 basis point decline across the curve, assuming a static balance sheet and cross-currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you look at that asset sensitivity, again, you rightfully pointed out that we skew non-US in terms of the magnitude of that decline in NII should we see that parallel shift.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in fact, it's as much as $1.3 billion or so of that $1.6 billion is non-US dollar related across 60 currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so you'd have to see all of that move in tandem for that drag and the US dollar drag is about $300 million assuming 100 basis point shift and that's been coming down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you look back over the quarters, we've been thoughtfully managing that down and that's down to about $300 million number.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would expect when we print the third quarter Q, it will be down a bit more.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, again, we are asset sensitive but it does skew outside of the US and thank you for asking the question because I think it's important to remind our investors and analysts of that dynamic which in many ways may be different from that of other Institutions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the late fees, we did say that we were including late fees in our assumptions, in our outlook that we've given.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'll state the obvious Erika, which is that we want people to obviously pay on time and we do everything that we can to assist and ensure that they do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, we don't have a definitive timeline on late fees, nor are we overly reliant on late fees to drive revenue for our firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so it looks like that decisioning will likely kind of fall closer to sometime in 2025 and so there is a small adjustment in the last quarter of our revenue forecast but it's inside of the guidance that we gave and doesn't materially change that in any way.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the last part of your question, I think, was around NIR and the fee revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as I mentioned earlier, I'm not going to give guidance for 2025 but I think your question was around where are we likely to see continued momentum as it relates to fee revenue growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I would start with Services where fees were up some 33% year-over-year and yes we should adjust for the Argentine Peso devaluation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But even if you adjust for that it's double-digit, 11% year-over-year non-interest revenue growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And when you look at those drivers they've been consistently strong.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cross-border transaction value up 8%, US dollar clearing volume up 7%, commercial card spend up 8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the supplement you'll see that it's mid to high single digit year-to-date growth across those KPIs as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect that that will continue with our corporate clients and as we bring on new commercial clients as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'll turn you to – if you look at Banking, we talked about already so I won't kind of lean into that too much but except to highlight a really strong quarter in Banking, in Investment Banking fees, in particular, the rebound that we've been talking about but importantly us capturing share in that rebound and these important partnerships that position us well as sponsors start to lean back into the market the investments that we've been making in talent, in sectors we need to strengthen.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: All of those things are going to play to continued fee momentum as we go into 2025.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth, again, really strong performance this quarter with revenues up 9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But look at the client investment assets, up 24%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The client balances up 14%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's driving fee momentum and it's a keen area of focus for Andy and that team that he's pulled together and it's a real opportunity for us given the $5 trillion or so of assets that our clients hold away from us and we're better positioning ourselves to capture that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then finally, you can see kind of continued momentum on USPB but it's across the board is what I'm saying, Erika, in terms of that fee momentum and it is important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's an important aspect as we think about getting to those medium term targets and that 4% to 5% revenue.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, you touched on in your prepared comments about growing the US Personal Banking RoTCE to higher levels.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And you mentioned two items.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: One, innovative products and the normalization of credit costs.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you elaborate on those two items that will be contributing to the driver aside from the efficiency improvement that you also touched on?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So obviously USPB is a combination of the cards businesses that we have in the Retail Banking business and that cards portfolio has both Branded as well as Retail Services as part of it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And even within Branded, we have proprietary cards where we frankly have been looking to how we can come up with new innovative products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One example of product innovation is the recent refresh that we did of our Strata Premier Card which was designed to drive acquisition and engagement with a new rewards offering.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that acquisitions are up some 7% both quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year for Branded Cards so that's an example of product innovation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Another one is we also launched FlexPay at Costco a few quarters ago and you can see good instalment loan growth as a consequence of that, up some 15% or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that type of product creation is important to acquisitions, it's important to ensuring the card stays top of wallet and important to driving some of that top line performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the other thing that I mentioned, you're right was around cost of credit and that really is the continued normalization of cost of credit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mentioned a couple of times now the idea that multiple vintages are maturing at the same time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that has to play through for us to kind of see a more normal level of credit and that will be important to the returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And again, we are starting to see stabilization in both the cost of credit line but also in delinquencies and that's a good indicator for us.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Very good.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then just following up on credit.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: In the Banking division, you guys mentioned the cost of credit was, I think, $177 million due to ACL build of $141 million.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And it was due to a change in the mix in the portfolio.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you share with us what that mix change was that drove this provision?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's a mix of kind of different asset classes and clients that we've lent against.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's nothing material or significant in that number.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When you look at the nonaccrual loans that ratio still 31 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So it's a mix change of our exposures but nothing material there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we continue to see a very healthy corporate sector really across the world.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from the line of Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Two questions, Jane and Mark.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: One is on expenses and the other is on your response to the asset cap question before.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: So first one, expenses, an easier one.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Earlier in the year you had said you expect about $700 million to $1 billion of severance charges in the $53.5 billion to $53.8 billion.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Did you have any in the third quarter?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Expect any if the fourth?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And do you expect to be done with those this year or any to continue into next year too?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that number was a combination of restructuring charges and severance charges or repositioning charges and we breakout obviously restructuring so that you can see those.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And this restructuring component was largely driven by the org simplification.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That will be done this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The normal severance or repositioning charges that we take as a normal course of BAU you would expect that to occur in any year and it certainly will be part of 2025 and 2026 going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We did have some this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I would expect that we will have some next quarter, but I don't see us being outside of by any stretch the range that I gave and again the range was for the combination of both.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And shifting to the asset cap question, Jane and Mark, we didn't hear a clear answer on, A, do you have an asset cap?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And B, even if you don't, what is the effective implication or impact of what the regulators have said?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And you don't expect anything meaningful, Jane, that will impact business like there was this new story about China, some license that you didn't get approved by the regulators.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Anything more meaningful like that that might be occurring that may be...

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Absolutely – let me be crystal clear, absolutely nothing.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Great.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O'

speaker: Connor
sentence: Just a couple of clarification questions.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I guess first on Banamex, are you on track to still IPO it the fourth quarter of next year or does it just get pushed out by a quarter with the legal separation taking a little bit longer?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, I think as I mentioned in response to Erika's question, we plan to be ready to IPO at the end of 2025 based on the factors we can control.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The timing is going to get driven by how we maximize shareholder value and that will be market conditions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that's where we stand.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: MATT O'

speaker: Connor
sentence: I think that means by the end of 2025, you talk about 1Q 2026, that was kind of my clarification question on that.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I thought you needed four quarters after you legally separated it to officially IPO it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We believe as we stand at the moment we would be ready to IPO at the end of 2025.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's much more a focus on what the market conditions at that point will be and Mark and I are very, very much focused on the shareholder value and maximizing that over – rushing over one quarter versus another quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And there's no hard rule on – sorry, go ahead.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yes, there isn't a hard rule on you have to have got four quarters after you have separated.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: MATT O'

speaker: Connor
sentence: I see.

speaker: Connor
sentence: That's super helpful.

speaker: Connor
sentence: We just haven't had that many of these, so that's helpful.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And then just separately I think in the prepared remarks you guys mentioned a modest provision within Services for some of the unremitted corporate dividends and I just wanted to clarify that and what country is that.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And I guess I thought there wasn't really much liability to you guys from that, so any clarification on that.

speaker: Connor
sentence: I know it's a small amount, but that would be helpful.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's a small amount.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the back of the deck, we have a page on Russia exposure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's related to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: MATT O'

speaker: Connor
sentence: But still feel like there's not risk to you guys from all those kind of trapped dividends, I guess why take a small reserve if there's legally no risk to you guys?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Well, it's the way we treat the exposure there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're following the guidelines on how we need to treat exposures in the country that we aren't able to distribute to clients but we actually have to hold on their behalf.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so we have to book a reserve associated with that and so we do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We obviously show on the page what the exposure is in the event of a loss of control and you can kind of see how that ultimately nets out but we're following the appropriate guidelines for what's required for reserves of that nature.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: MATT O'

speaker: Connor
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Kenny with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: I have one for Mark.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: So you mentioned that Services NII is a tailwind as rates decline.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Can you just unpack how that happens?

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Is there any benefit from swap roll-off or a floating swap that we should be thinking about that's embedded in that statement?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are a couple of things kind of to keep in mind on the Services business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one is, is obviously this is a client business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's not just a deposit taking business and so how we think about pricing to those client becomes really important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've got the US and non-US dynamic that's playing through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For institutional clients, we've largely been holding to the higher betas that we saw as rates have ticked up.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, with the relationship in mind.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we have some offsetting pressure outside of the US as those betas kind of catch up.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think importantly you also heard me mention the reinvestment into securities at higher yields and that reinvestment or those higher yields ultimately play out through the businesses and so that will show up as part of kind of NII as we think about Services but the other businesses as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those are important components of the NII story for Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think when you look at the in-quarter performance and [TTS] NII is down 5%, a big part of that is driven by the Argentina rates movement in the quarter versus last year, so lower rates we're earning in Argentina playing through that line particularly in this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you adjusted for that on the NII line, it would be flat to slightly a little bit better.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's really what it is.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's kind of management of client relationships as well as the higher earnings on reinvested securities contributing to that as well as volume from operating account growth that we expect.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Saul Martinez with HSBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Hey, guys.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Couple quick questions.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: First, just a follow-up on Banamex.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Jane, as you know, there are concerns about judicial reform in Mexico and the implications for rule of law and Mexican asset prices have suffered as a result.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I think the largest Mexican bank trades at something in the neighborhood of seven times earnings.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: If market conditions don't improve and Mexican asset prices remain depressed and these concerns persist, then what?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I mean, do you just wait until market conditions improve or how do you think about this process in the context of what seems to be a deteriorating macro backdrop for Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got to wait and see what the market conditions will be but the North Star for me and for Mark is crystal clear, it is optimizing and maximizing our shareholder value.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So if the conditions are not appropriate at that time then we will wait until they are.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the meantime, the business is performing well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's accretive to our returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not a drag here in any shape or form so there is no need to rush for a suboptimal result here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we will IPO and we will exit Banamex, but we won't do that in a reckless manner.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will be disciplined about it as you would expect us to be and as I think we're demonstrating that we are on multiple different dimensions.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Fair enough.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And then I guess a follow-up on the US Personal Banking, RoTCE improvement and the normalization of the cost of credit seems to be a big component of that.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: But Mark can you just remind us where you are in terms of cost of credit versus what you would think a more normalized level is for Branded Cards and Retail Services.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I guess how much of a tailwind does a more normalized credit environment entail in terms of credit cost?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, I don't want to get into 2025 at this stage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I assure you, we will give more color and commentary on that as we get into the fourth quarter earnings in January.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I will say again, as you think about these businesses, we do see continued top line – we do expect continued top line momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've had eight consecutive quarters of positive operating leverage in USPB, 49% [efficiency ratio] this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we're managing the expense base well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We think there's more upside to the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're very focused on growth across the portfolios and I do think that cost of credit again, if for no other reason but the compounding effect of those vintages maturing as well as kind of inflation starting to come off, rates trickling down, that should be better for the consumer and should start to play out in both the macroeconomic scenarios that we run for CECL purposes but also ultimately in delinquencies and NCLs and we're starting to see that improvement in delinquencies and its stabilization already somewhat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I don't want to get into guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But that's kind of how I think about the drivers or contributors to improve returns over the medium term.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Thanks for the clarification on the asset cap question that I asked earlier.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I know you are limited in how much you can say about regulators but just be clear, because a lot of e-mail traffic going back, you did say there is no asset cap and you don't expect one and you don't expect other additional actions at this time?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Correct.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I guess, look, I have great respect, I'm an ex-regulator, Paul Volcker was my hero.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I respect regulators.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And nobody wants to see you cut corners to get to your $51 billion to $53 billion of expenses.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But I'm just wondering – and you have consolidated systems apps, layers, bureaucracy and you're divesting lots of activities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So it's just even the amended consent order was surprising because you have taken so many efforts and if you should have had an amended consent order or other actions, they probably should have been in place one, five, 10 or literally 20 years ago.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And so that's just confusing on the outside.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So with that said, is this a matter of spending more money or about doing these tasks more intelligently?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: In other words, you put more gas in the tank, the car's not going faster.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So is it amount of resources or just being more intelligent in terms of resolving some of these regulatory issues?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me break it down to a couple of pieces.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I start off just remind everyone the consent orders are very, very broad and the action that was taken was because we're behind in a narrower area which is the data particularly regarding our regulatory reporting where we're behind is the main area of focus.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We moved swiftly to address it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're very transparent about it from early on in the year that we were falling behind on this and overall I'm pleased with our progress.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you say, Mike, I listed a number of areas of progress and trying to make it as tangible as we can, given what we can and can't say as this is supervisory.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm pleased that our businesses continue to improve their performance while the transformation is going on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They're the two priorities we have this year so I think effectively, yes, we can walk and chew gum at the same time and the huge benefit of all of the simplification on the business, on the organization, the other efforts, is making it easier for us to execute and be very focused.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And well maybe, Mark, I’ll pass it over to you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think your question's helpful in the sense that you said is it kind of a rethink on our approach or is it the need to spend more money and one of the things that we've done, Mike, is take a step back and look at how we've been approaching data, for example.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So this is – and we are going to make – we have made some changes to our approach and those changes relate to how we get after resolving data issues that are identified ensuring that there's engagement from the front end business, from the functions that are most relevant and that there's consideration for what's required on reg reporting in order for us to get that process streamlined and correct.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so there are aspects of this that require a change in our approach and we've been taking that change, making that change rather, and we'll make more changes accordingly as we've taken that step back and there are aspects of it that require at a minimum review of what is causing either the delay or us not moving at the pace that we would like to move or that our regulators would like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that is in fact what the resource review plan was that was in the amended consent order.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It was basically a statement saying that you need to ensure that you have sufficient resources and that they're allocated towards achieving the timely and sustainable compliance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so part of our process is in fact that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Taking a regular review of what is on track in the way of our milestones and deliverables where we see things that are being delayed or going red, what is the underlying root cause for why.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Is it a resource issue where we need to put more dollars and people or technology to it?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Is it a process issue where we need to reconsider our approach?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And on the other side of that root cause, taking action to fix it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so your question is spot-on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The answer is that in many instances it will be a little bit of both, but importantly our processes include that type of analysis and assessment so that we can get after the execution on this in an effective way.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I hope that helps.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And all of this drives productivity and other benefits for our shareholders as well as making sure that we're strengthening Citi from the regulatory perspective.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then last follow-up.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: To the extent that you see a disconnect between your performance and the stock price that would seem to create more of an opportunity to buy the stock at $64 when tangible book value is $90.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And so, I hope that – I've used this analogy before, but hopefully you're selling the chairs and the desk and the silverware in the executive dining room to go ahead and buy back stock whenever you can.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's clearly given where we are trading, we're very focused around the opportunities to buy back stock and mindful of the importance of it and equally, yes, we are proud of the performance of the franchise this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It was a very strong quarter and important set of proof points for our investors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are on a deliberate path.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're making the progress that we need to and actually pretty excited about the path ahead of us and the potential that we see.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I'll now turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you, everyone, for joining the call.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Please follow-up with IR if you have any additional questions.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements which are based on management's current expectation and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors, including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: With that, I'll turn it over to Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thanks, Jenn, and Happy New Year, everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am delighted to join you again today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, we've been busy, and we have a lot to talk about today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm going to start with an update on our strategy refresh.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Then, I'll share my thoughts on our fourth quarter, and end on all the progress that we've made against our major priorities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you saw earlier this week, we announced that we intend to focus our franchise in Mexico solely on our Institutional and Wealth Management businesses, and therefore, to exit the consumer, small business, and middle-market banking operations there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This was not a decision we took lightly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We took a clinical look at our franchise in Mexico, and we drew the hard conclusion that the non-institutional businesses do not fit our new strategic direction.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, to be clear, these are terrific, they're scaled, high-returning franchises, but our strategic goal is to invest in businesses that are fully aligned with our core strengths and to simplify our firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we did the work, it was also clear that there continues to be a tremendous opportunity for our Institutional Clients Group in Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Citi is Mexico's leading institutional bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've served corporate clients and investors there for almost a century, and that isn't going to change.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mexico has a bright future, and we are committed to playing an important role in building it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect Mexico will be a major recipient of global investment and trade flows in the years ahead.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Therefore, we plan to maintain a significant, locally-licensed bank there and invest to capture growth in a core and high-returning hub of our institutional network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This won't be a simple transaction.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have spent the last several months working through how to get the best results for our shareholders and be true to our local stakeholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will begin the separation process immediately and expect to begin the sales process in the spring, and of course, there will be an opportunity to return excess capital from the transaction to our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is our final decision in terms of market exits as we conclude our strategy refresh and approach Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm really looking forward to talking to you about the future Citi on March 2.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Today, we are going to talk you through the changes we are making to align our organization and financial reporting with our refresh strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These changes will also allow us to reduce structural complexity and its associated costs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Amongst other things, this is going to help make Citi easier for our investors to understand.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll be able to see and assess more simply the core businesses that make up Citi going forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First, we are creating a new Personal Banking and Wealth Management segment which will be run by Anand Selva.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This will consist of two distinct reporting units, our US Personal Banking businesses and our Global Wealth Management business which is going to include the Private Bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Second, on the institutional side of the house, which will continue to be run by Paco Ybarra, we will begin reporting under three units, services, banking, and markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services will include Treasury and Trade Solutions and Security Services, and this reflects just how important we believe these businesses are to Citi's future.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, we will create a new segment, Legacy Franchises, which will house all the businesses we intend to exit.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're going to begin reporting our financials along these segments and reporting units no later than the second quarter to ensure you have the information you need to measure our progress and hold us accountable, and we really look forward to sharing our strategy and plans for how these businesses will work together and deliver for our shareholders on Investor Day in March.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, turning to earnings, we had a decent end to 2021.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you can see on slide 2, we closed out the quarter with net income of $3.2 billion and EPS of $1.46.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That includes a $1.2 billion hit to EBIT primarily related to the winddown of our Korean consumer business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Excluding those impacts, our net income would be $4.2 billion with an EPS of $1.99.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our net income for the full year of $22 billion reflects an improved credit environment and we had a resulting RoTCE of 13.4%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In ICG, we had another strong quarter in Investment Banking and gained share for the year in M&A, and we continued to make significant investments in talent and we see a very solid pipeline of transactions ahead of us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, while we could have had a better balanced performance in Fixed Income in the quarter, equities finished 2021 up 25% for the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The rebound TTS is seeing in trade flows and cash volumes wasn't quite enough to offset the current rate environment, but it bodes well for 2022.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Indeed, we think the cycle has turned for this business and it is poised to benefit as monetary policy changes and growth accelerates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've heard Mark and I talk about improving the revenue mix of our Institutional businesses as a priority, and it's yielding results with another quarter of strong momentum in fee growth across products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Lots of our consumer businesses are still weathering COVID disruptive impact on customer behavior.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the US, strong purchase sales continued to be offset by elevated payment rates, but we did see loans increase in Branded Cards this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Deposits and AUM continued to grow, with digital deposits up nearly 20% for the full year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: For the year, we returned nearly $12 billion in capital to our shareholders and we grew our tangible book value per share by 7% to $79.16.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We ended the year with a CET1 ratio of 12.2% on a standardized basis as we built the capital needed to absorb the impact of SA-CCR.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now, keep in mind that regulatory change didn't take effect until January 1.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While this caused us to temporarily pause our stock buybacks, we will resume buybacks this quarter now that that impact has been addressed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, as slide 3 shows, we are executing and delivering against our priorities, a strategy refresh, the transformation, and our culture, and we are doing so with a real sense of urgency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First, on the strategy, we are laser-focused on swiftly and successfully implementing the strategic decisions we made over the past year to improve returns to our investors.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have signed deals in six of the Asia consumer markets, including the agreement to sell four markets that we announced yesterday.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This means that within eight months of making the decision to exit these 13 businesses, we have a clear path in a majority of them and we are well into the process in the remaining markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Korea, we were decisive in determining the best path for our shareholders was the wind down our consumer operations and were able to get most of that charge behind us this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Another area where we haven't wasted any time is Wealth Management, where we grew our ranks by a net 800 advisors, relationship managers, and others over the course of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They helped us add about 750 Private Bank clients and 45,000 Citigold clients in 2021.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In what we've known as US Personal Banking, we're seeing good uptake of new products such as the Custom Cash Card and we've been building out digital platforms to capture opportunities in Installment Lending.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in addition to the progress we're seeing in TTS, we've also been building out our Security Services platform.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We couldn't be more pleased to deepen our relationship with BlackRock by becoming the largest custodian with their iShares ETF.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Second priority, we continue to execute on our transformation agenda in order to demonstrably strengthen our risk and controls as well as modernize our bank for a digital world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This work, it's foundational to everything we want to achieve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are enhancing our operating model to improve long-term efficiency and our service to clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As it relates to the consent orders, we are deep into execution mode.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continue to be in constructive dialogue with our regulators as we get their feedback and incorporate it into our ongoing execution and project plans.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Third, and relatedly, we are building a culture that expects excellence and demands accountability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're driving this effort in a variety of ways, including a more robust performance management process at this past year end, shifting the mix of compensation to better align with shareholders' interests, and various culture-changing initiatives.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A culture of excellence also means creating a record of achievement that our people can be proud of.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One area that our people take particular pride in is our ESG efforts.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Later this month, we will share with you our plan to reach net zero by 2050, a commitment I made on my first day as CEO, 10 months ago.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And of course, we are going to do all this with a singular focus on our clients as we help them navigate COVID.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We certainly hope Omicron is the final disruptive phase of this pandemic, but there are also quite a few other issues to navigate, whether macroeconomic such as inflation or geopolitical such as tensions with Russia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have seen the resilience and the importance of Citi as we supported our clients through uncharted waters and we will be with them in the next chapter as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So now, I'd like to turn it over to Mark, and then we would be delighted to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have a lot to cover on today's call.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm going to start by walking you through the financial reporting changes we plan on making in more detail.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Then, I'm going to walk you through the 2021 financial impact from the 13 Asia market exits, as well as Mexico, and changes we are making to our financial disclosure, and then finally, the quarterly results.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As part of our strategy refresh, we've started to make changes to better align with our vision and strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've refreshed our earnings presentation and included additional metrics and key drivers for the ICG businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our goal is to simplify our financial reporting to make it much easier for our investors to understand our performance and our key assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 4, we lay out the details of the changes in financial reporting that Jane mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, we intend to move the consumer, small business, and middle-market banking operations of Citibanamex and the 13 Asia consumer exits under a new segment called Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This will allow you to better understand the financials of the remaining company that will exist post these exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've experienced managing businesses being divested and are putting a dedicated team in place to manage the new segment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This will free up the management teams of the go-forward businesses to fully focus on executing on the firm's strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we are reorganizing our reporting units to help you better understand the financials of our businesses and the value they bring to Citi.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Starting with ICG, we will move TTS and Security Services to a reporting unit called Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These businesses are foundational for us as they have a unique position given their global footprint and full suite product offering.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets will therefore no longer include Security Services and instead will only include equity and fixed income markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And lastly, on ICG, banking will only include advisory, equity underwriting, debt underwriting and corporate lending.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The Global Consumer Bank, GCB, will be renamed Personal Banking and Wealth Management, PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The Private Bank will move from ICG to PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, we announced in January of last year that we created a single wealth management organization under Citi Global Wealth now called Global Wealth Management, which is a distinct reporting unit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The creation of this unit unifies the wealth management teams creating a single integrated platform serving clients across the wealth continuum from the affluent segment to the ultra-high net worth clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: North America Consumer will but renamed to US Personal Banking and will remain a reporting unit under PBWM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This unit will continue to include Branded Cards, Retail Services, and Retail Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We plan on providing the financials for the new reporting units on this page under the ICG and PBWM segments starting no later than the second quarter earnings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our Investor Day will be a natural opportunity to bring together all the work over the past year and lay out our medium-term vision and strategy for the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Slide 5 shows the contribution of the Citibanamex businesses that we plan to exit as well as the contribution from the 13 Asia markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Hopefully, this gives you a better sense of the financial results for the combined exits, and in the appendix on page 18, we have more detail on the 13 Asia exit markets and the deals that we've announced to date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to Mexico, as Jane mentioned, we remain committed to Mexico and will continue to serve our Institutional and Private Bank clients there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, upon very careful consideration and analysis, we decided that we are no longer the optimal owner for the businesses that we're exiting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The Mexico consumer and small business banking operations included in the intended exit represents the entirety of the Latin America Global Consumer Banking unit and the Mexico middle-market banking business that is currently included in Citi's Institutional Clients Group segment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the left side of the page, we show key figures for 2020 and 2021 for the businesses we intend to exit in Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2021, the businesses contributed $4.7 billion of revenue and $1.1 billion of net income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The businesses in total had $20 billion of loans, $31 billion of deposits, and approximately $4 billion of allocated TCE.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, we do not yet have a transaction and are pursuing multiple divestiture paths, so the ultimate financial impact of a transaction is not yet known.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will keep you updated on our progress as we run a thoughtful process that takes into consideration what is in the best interest of our shareholders as well as our clients and employees in Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition to the opportunity to return additional capital to shareholders, these divestitures will also allow us to simplify the management and organizational structure across the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to slide 6, as we've gone through our strategy refresh and simplification, we've been reviewing our disclosure and terminology and have decided that now is the right time to more closely align with our peers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, revenue that we previously referred to as Net Interest Revenue will now be called Net Interest Income, and revenue that we previously referred to as Non-NIR will now be called Non-Interest Revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, as you can see on the page, we've revised how we account for insurance paid on our deposits, including FDIC and foreign deposit insurance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have previously accounted for the deposit insurance as a contra revenue in Net Interest Income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, beginning this quarter, we will report it as an expense and remove it from Net Interest Income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as a reminder, this change is earnings neutral.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've made this change to make it easier for you to compare us to our peers and we have revised prior years to reflect the same reporting treatment to assist with comparability for 2019 to 2021, and the rest of the presentation will also reflect these two changes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned earlier, in the fourth quarter, we reported net income of $3.2 billion and an EPS of $1.46 and RoTCE of 7.4% on $17 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in these results are costs of approximately $1.2 billion primarily related to the voluntary retirement program we offered in conjunction with the wind-down of our Korea consumer business as well as some additional Asia exit impacts which I will collectively refer to as the Asia divestiture impacts going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding these impacts, EPS would have been $1.99 with an RoTCE of approximately 10%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, total revenues increased by 1% from last year as strength in Non-Interest Revenue driven by ICG, specifically TTS, Security Services, and Investment Banking was mostly offset by lower Net Interest Income across GCB and ICG.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our results include expenses of $13.5 billion, an increase of 18% versus the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the Asia divestiture cost, expenses would have increased by 8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Increased expenses were largely driven by investments in our transformation, business-led investments, and higher revenue-related expenses partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a net benefit in the quarter, primarily driven by an ACL release of approximately $1.4 billion related to the improved macro backdrop and continued improvement in portfolio quality.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to the full year, our revenues were down 5% driven by the normalization in markets, as well as elevated payment rates in consumer, somewhat offset by strong Non-Interest Revenue growth across ICG and in particular, in Investment Banking, TTS, and Security Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our full year expenses were up 9%, but excluding Asia divestiture costs, our expenses were up 6%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Also for the full year, we generated RoTCE of 13% and 14% excluding Asia-related divestiture impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, we had a benefit of close to $9 billion in ACL releases for the full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show an expense walk for the full year with the key underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2021, excluding Asia divestiture impacts, expenses were up 6%, in line with previous guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking forward, we recognize that we have a lot more work to do.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The divestitures provide an opportunity to simplify our management and organizational structure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're also taking a hard look at our structural expenses with an eye towards operating as efficiently and soundly as possible and self-funding investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have a lot more to say about this at our Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we show Net Interest Income, deposits, and loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the fourth quarter, Net Interest Income increased by approximately $130 million on a sequential basis driven by North America Consumer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sequentially, net interest margin remained relatively stable.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On a year-over-year basis, Net Interest Income was flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Also on a year-overyear basis, average deposits grew in the quarter as we continued to deepen relationships with our institutional clients as well as our consumer clients, particularly in North America.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were roughly flat year-overyear as growth in the ICG was offset by a decline in GCB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As the probability of higher rates has increased over the last few quarters, let me make a few comments regarding the potential impact from higher rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our 10-Q, we disclosed interest rate sensitivity assuming a parallel shift and a run-off balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This is different from our peers methodology which tends to assume a static balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Assuming a static balance sheet and a 100-basis point parallel shift, we would expect Citi's total Net Interest Income across all currencies to increase by over three times more than what was disclosed in our third quarter 10-Q, or roughly $2.5 billion to $3 billion of Net Interest Income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 10, we show our summary balance sheet and key capital and liquidity metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintain a very strong balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of our $2.3 trillion balance sheet, about 25% or $530 billion consistent of HQLA, and we maintain total liquidity resources of approximately $960 billion, and we continued to optimize our balance sheet deploying excess liquidity into securities as we took advantage of opportunities in the market, as well as reducing our shortterm and long-term debt sequentially and year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the loan side, corporate loans represent approximately 60% of total loans, with loans to corporates outside of the US representing approximately 30% of total loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we've mentioned in the past, about 80% of our total corporate loans are investment grade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we look into the remainder of the year, there are a number of variables with respect to capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These include regulatory headwinds that are impacting us along with the rest of the industry such as elevated GSIB surcharges, as well as the timing and impact from the divestitures of the 13 Asia exits and Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In light of this, you should expect us to manage to a CET1 ratio closer to 12% by the end of the year due to the expected GSIB surcharge increase at the beginning of 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we remain focused on all aspects of capital with the goal of maintaining a CET1 ratio of 11.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you know, under the SEB framework, we can assess on a quarter-by-quarter basis the right level of buybacks and we will continue to do so throughout the year with a goal of returning excess capital to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 11, we show the results for our Institutional Clients Group for the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased 4% year-over-year driven by Investment Banking, Private Bank, and Security Services fees, partially offset by a decline in markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 10% year-over-year driven by transformation, business-led investments, and revenue-related expenses partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a net benefit of approximately $300 million as net credit losses were more than offset by an ACL release.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we continue to see strong credit performance with net credit losses declining on a year-overyear basis and nonaccrual loans down sequentially and year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of $2.5 billion, down approximately 22% from the prior year largely driven by the higher expenses and a smaller ACL release versus the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And ICG delivered a 10.8% RoTCE for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also saw 5% growth in both loans and deposits on a year-over-year basis as we continue to see good momentum and deepening of existing client relationships and new client acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As for the full year, ICG delivered approximately $16 billion of net income on $44 billion of revenue with an RoTCE of roughly 17%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 12, we show revenue performance by business and key drivers for our ICG business for the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Treasury and Trade Solution revenues were slightly down versus the prior year driven by continued headwinds from rates offset by 18% growth in fees.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, our highest fee quarter ever, and revenue did increase sequentially driven by both Net Interest Income and strong fee growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to see strong underlying drivers in TTS on a year-over-year basis that indicate continued strong client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Since this is the first time we're showing key metrics that demonstrate this momentum, I want to briefly walk you through each one and what it represents.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: US dollar clearing transactions are up 4% which reflect the clearing and settlement activity of commercial and treasury flows for financial institutions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cross-border flows were up 15%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These flows represent our global payment flows where we provide cross-border solutions for our clients that are fully integrated across our TTS and Markets business in over 145 currencies, and importantly, this client activity drives recurring fee revenues and generates significant operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Commercial Card volumes, which reflect travel, purchase, and virtual card activity across all clients are up 48%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, these metrics are indicators of client activity and fees, and on a combined basis drive approximately 50% of total TTS fee revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking revenues are up 43% year-over-year driven by growth across products including record advisory performance, the best advisory quarter we've had in over a decade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Private Bank revenues were up 6% year-over-year as we continue to see strong momentum in new client acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
