sentence: Overall markets revenues were down 17% versus last year, and while there were different dynamics that played through Fixed Income and Equity Markets performance, the performance is against a very strong quarter last year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income Markets revenues were down 20% year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While we had solid growth in FX and commodities, this was more than offset by a decline in rates and spread products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equity Markets revenues were down 3% year-over-year as continued growth in prime finance balances and structured activities was offset by a decline in cash.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Security Services revenues grew 5% year-over-year as fees grew 11% driven by higher settlement volumes and higher assets under custody partially offset by interest rate headwinds.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to slide 13, here we show the results for our Global Consumer Banking business for the fourth quarter in constant dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues declined 6% year-over-year driven by lower revenues across regions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 34% year-over-year driven by the Asia divestiture cost.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding these costs, expenses were up 9% driven by transformation and business-led investments partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a $105 million benefit this quarter as an ACL release more than offset net credit losses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The NCL rate for the quarter was 1.2%, a decline of 61 basis points year-over-year and 20 basis points sequentially.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We released over $900 million of ACL this quarter related to continued improvement in our economic outlook and portfolio quality, partially offset by volume growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in a net income decline of 42% and an RoTCE of 8%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the Asia divestitures impact, net income would have grown 44% and resulted in an RoTCE of 20%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As for the full year, GCB delivered $6 billion of net income on $27 billion of revenues with an RoTCE of 17%, and 22% excluding Asia divestiture impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 14, we show GCB revenues by product as well as key business drivers and metrics for the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues declined 3% year-over-year on higher payment rates and portfolio mix.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're seeing encouraging underlying drivers with new accounts up 43%, card sales volumes up 24%, and average loans up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, the fourth quarter acquisitions exceeded the same quarter in 2019 by 2%, the first quarter to do so since the onset of the pandemic.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues declined 10% year-over-year driven by a 2% decline in Net Interest Income due to elevated payment rates as well as by higher partner payments driven by improved credit performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But despite this, we are seeing positive underlying drivers with account acquisitions up 6% and spend up 16% on a year-over-year basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While we're encouraged by these underlying drivers in both cards businesses, payment rates do remain stubbornly high, impacting our loan growth and revenue growth in both cards businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Banking revenues declined 6% year-over-year driven by lower deposit spreads as well as lower mortgage revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, underlying drivers remain strong with deposits up 13%, Citigold household up 9%, and assets under management up 8% year-over-year as we continued to execute on our North America retail strategy with a focus on our Global Wealth unit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Asia revenues declined 7% year-over-year largely driven by rate headwinds and higher payment rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Performance in the wealth hubs exceeded that of the overall region with deposit growth of 12%, AUM growth of 13%, and 16% growth in Citigold and CPC clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Latin America revenues declined 3% year-over-year mainly due to lower loan volumes in both retail and cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 15, we show results for Corporate/Other for the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased year-over year largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses are down year-over-year largely due to the wind-down of legacy assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was benign.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As part of our strategy refresh, our goal is to be as simple and transparent as possible, and I hope you like the new earnings presentation and we will continue to evolve it going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And with that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Your first question is from the line of John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, thanks for all the detail there, and Jane for the strategic update.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, I wanted to ask if you could just go over the restatement of the Net Interest Income sensitivity.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Just want to make sure we caught that.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: What's the difference that's driving the new presentation there, and just what are the key drivers for your Net Interest Income outlook this year?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: You don't have to give a number, but kind of when you think about trading.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And then core NII and card growth, maybe some of the thoughts there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, and good morning, John.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So on slide 9 is where I kind of covered that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You'll recall, John, that historically, we have looked in our disclosure at a run-off balance sheet, and that obviously has deposits running off as they term out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It has loans running off as they mature.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Others take an approach where they look at a static balance sheet, and so we've run the analysis around assuming a static balance sheet and assuming 100 basis point parallel shift in a rising rate environment, obviously across all currencies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We obviously have a mix of US dollar and foreign currencies as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And when we run that analysis now assuming the balance sheet is static, that is the deposit levels, loan levels, et cetera, that delivers three times more than what we disclosed in the Q in the third quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's the $2.5 billion to $3 billion of Net Interest Income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So obviously retaining or assuming that the deposit levels stay the same allow us to generate more Net Interest Income, and that's a major driver in the number range or the range that I provided.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the forward look, I'm not going to give you guidance as you mentioned, but I think there are a couple things that are important to keep in mind that we're looking at for 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is the drivers that we mentioned earlier.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So a lot of the underlying drivers in our franchise look very strong and are driving healthy fee revenue growth, and I would expect with an outlook for positive GDP that that's going to continue to play to our advantage in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing I'd point out is the assumptions around interest rate hikes in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As many as three or four, depending on the economist view that you listen to, and that obviously is going to play to our favor as well when you think about the number of accrual businesses that we have whether it's our TTS franchise or our Private Bank, et cetera, et cetera.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So those are important factors that impact the top line and that we expect to help contribute to some growth coming out of 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mentioned the loan growth on the Branded Cards portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For cards, it's really going to be about payment rates and how they taper off, hopefully taper off.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They've been stubbornly high through all of 2021, so hopefully we start to see some of that taper off and we get a little bit of growth in average interest-earning balances in the back half of the year, but those are important factors that need to play through into 2022.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Great.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And then just as a follow-up, as you're managing capital, you mentioned you'll return to some level of buybacks this quarter.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And you've got a lot of capital that you expect to free up in transactions that haven't happened yet, so I guess how are you kind of thinking about that future capital as something that you'll deploy as you get it as part of your long-term thinking but you're not planning on using that throughout this year, I assume?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so obviously, we look at capital planning with a, in the context of our strategy and our ability to actually deploy that capital, but to return as much excess capital as we can to our shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so as we think about the divestitures which are underway as that capital frees up, we're going to factor that into the capital plan for the year and the quarter and where we can, we're going to return that to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So a number of deals are scheduled to close in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That will be part of our plan, and we'll be looking forward to taking those actions in the outer part of the year.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Thank you for the new presentation.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But the biggest question that I and I think many investors have is, when all is said and done, who is Citigroup?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: What's the most simple statement you can give on who and what Citigroup represents?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Oh, I love that question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I would say that our vision for Citi is to be the preeminent bank for institutions with cross-border needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll be a leader in – global leader in wealth, a major player in consumer payments and lending in the home market, and that is Citi and our vision for it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a simpler firm, more focused, it's much better connected, it's certainly simpler to operate, characterized by a culture of excellence and accountability, and I think as I hope we've shown today one that should be easier for everybody to understand and fully aligned with our shareholders' interests.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And along those lines, you're freeing up, what, about $11 billion of capital now, and intentions, Mark, I always hear you say you're going to invest in the business, you're going to do supply for growth and then you're going to buy back stock, but in terms of a stock price that's this low, I mean, the stock price relative to the financial index is one of the all-time lows.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Wouldn't you move buybacks up in the priority order?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Or what else can you do or say to show that shareholders matter?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Jane, I mean, you've done so much on the E side.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You've certainly done a lot on the S side, but the G in ESG when it relates to shareholders, shareholders have been left back for so long, just seeing what else you might be able to do or say as it relates to recognizing shareholders and their desire to have a stock price that does better.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our shareholders are an enormous priority for us, and, Mike, I know we need to make the bank for shareholderaligned and friendly, and we are doing so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me give you four examples.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our strategy will generate, and we will return excess capital to shareholders, and as you say, given where the stock is trading, it makes buybacks highly attractive.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Second, we're taking the structural and strategic decisions to put the bank in the best position to drive shareholder value, and you can see, we're executing, and we are delivering with urgency and we're very driven to get the valuation in a far higher place than it is today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Third, we're changing many elements of the financial reporting so it's easier for our shareholders to understand the bank and we're going to be as transparent as possible so you can measure our progress and results, and I think the structure that Mark laid out and I gave the high-level on will make that job much easier.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then finally, and a topic I know you've been quite vocal around, we are also making changes to compensation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So more of our senior business leaders will be on the PSUs for this coming year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've moved to 100% deferred stock versus a mix of stock and cash in the geographies that we're permitted to do so, and we're increasing the importance of returns in determining performance evaluations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There is a myriad of paths and lots of different actions that we're taking because our shareholders matter to us, and we want to get our valuation up to one that we think realizes its full potential.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley..

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So a couple of questions.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: One, just thinking through the walk from where you are today in CET1 till the end of the year when you mentioned you'd be ending the year at 12%, you have some businesses that are exiting, which should reduce RWAs I would think, but then you've got debt buybacks as well coming through, and at the same time, I would expect that you'd probably want to grow your RWAs.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I know your RWAs were down 5% Q2 and maybe that was a part of the reason why FICC was a little light, so could you help me understand just how we should think about that trajectory and the drivers of that CET1 change because it will have some impact on how we're thinking about the rev growth in the Markets business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, good question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we are looking at, obviously, how we continue to invest in the franchise, particularly where there are areas of growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the same time, ensure that we're delivering buybacks for return to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I look at the CET1 ratio, we're ending the year at about 12.2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, SACR kicks in or has kicked in on January 1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're ending, therefore, on January 1 at roughly around where our target is, and over the course of the year, we'll be able to absorb growth in the businesses where there's a need to do that while continuing to identify offsets to both SA-CCR, but also low-returning assets that we may have and ridding ourselves of those and generating income as well as the capital from the divestitures that we will be able to close throughout the course of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so as we look at that plan, the start of the year, which is close to our target, towards the end of 2022, we will have to build that back up to about 12% in order to absorb the GSIB headwind assuming there's no relief provided to that, which then kicks in at the beginning of 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so through the course of the year, we'll utilize through RWA, we'll free up capital and return capital to shareholders, we'll generate more earnings, but at the end of the year we'll need to kind of end on the higher end or towards that 12%.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Do you have a sense as to how much the benefit to like GSIB or SCB should be from all the divestitures you're doing?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I was actually thinking when I saw the Mexico news this week that maybe that was one of the reasons why you decided to exit the Mexico consumer businesses as potentially the pickup that you'd get since you mentioned, it makes you a simpler company and that should feed into SCB, I would think.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, it's not a major driver as to the decision, as Jane has kind of framed out, but it does factor into the points that you've raised.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So from a GSIB point of view, there's, I don't know, $31 billion or so of deposits that are tied to our Mexico consumer business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That would drive about 10 basis points or so, or 10 points I should say on the GSIB score.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The total for the divestitures that we've earmarked, it's about $85 billion in deposits, and so you can do the math that we'd get some benefit from that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You're right and we – I don't have numbers that I would share at this point in part because the fed has to run their analysis, but you're right from a CCAR point of view when you think about the stress capital buffer there's an impact to PPNR, but more importantly to stress losses that will play through as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know that impact as well as the deposit impact won't really come into play until we've closed on these transactions, but it certainly is a factor to how we think about the longer-term capital planning, and it certainly is something that I'm going to talk more about at Investor Day on March 2.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And the low-returning assets that you were talking about exiting, is that like – that's basically something like rates in the Fixed Income business and should we expect some impact there, or again, I'm just trying to tie together the 5% decline in RWAs and the comment that Fixed Income business was a little light this quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not looking to be specific on where the low-returning assets we're getting out, but we're certainly looking at our markets franchise to see where those low-returning assets exist as well as to see where their client relationships that are single product and don't necessarily link across the franchise, and so this is something that Jane and I, along with Paco are keenly focused on.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We realize that while we've seen growth in markets and in FICC, it has come with growth in the balance sheet, and we want to make sure that we're optimizing the use of the capital.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: My first question is for Mark, please, and by the way, thank you so much for this new way of disclosing financials.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think this will be very helpful, and the NII sensitivity as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Great question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You know, I'm not going to give guidance on 2022, but let me try and frame out how we're thinking about it, because I think it is important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Both Jane and I recognize that we've got – there's a lot of static we're getting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excuse me.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So in terms of the expenses, we obviously have a large expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've seen growth play out this year, but I think there's some real opportunities over time to attack the expense base and that's exactly what we intend to do.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So if you think about the divestitures, I'll start there for a second.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's some $6.8 billion of expenses tied to divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As those divestitures get closed out, some of that will naturally go away.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The balance of that, which tends to be referred to as stranded costs, we're already putting in place a team to focus on attacking and driving out that stranded costs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second point that I'll bring up around this is the transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The transformation has driven 3 percentage points of growth this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I do expect that there's more growth associated with that, particularly since we're still doing more hiring.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's more tech spend that will be required.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But the transformation over time will deliver efficiencies, will reduce the manual touchpoints, will drive straight through processing, and therefore, will allow for us to bring our expenses down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the final piece that I'll mention is the strategy, and so Jane mentioned in our strategy a focus on core businesses, and that's going to allow for us to look at the organizational structure and identify more simplification opportunities in the way we manage and run the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We do about $300 million to $400 million of productivity savings a quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's not enough.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We think there's more opportunity for efficiencies than that, and it's those opportunities that we're going to chase down in order to fund some of this investment spend that we expect in the next couple of years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: More on that at Investor Day.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Jane, this next question is for you.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: When you responded to Mike's question about your vision of Citi, you led with your vision of Citi as the world's corporate bank, if I could rephrase.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: How is your vision of Citi, what does it include in terms of your funding base?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: There's a lot of conversation particularly in the beginning of a rising rate environment about the natural gap that you have to your largest US peers with regards to your naturally higher rate deposits, right?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And so how do you envision your funding base evolving over time, and do you have any interest in significantly building out your US retail deposit franchise?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, Erika, we've got a pretty diverse funding base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When we look at it from the Institutional side, we've got the number-one TTS franchise globally and that has material funding from our cash management and dominant position in cash management there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our wealth franchise both from the ultra high net worth down to the affluent clients is also a source of material and very attractive deposits and funding for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, we're making the exits on the international consumer banking front, and we've been focused in the retail bank in the US in driving digital deposit growth and continuing to make sure that that business generates a stable, low-cost funding for the firm here in the US and we'll expect to continue growing that going forward.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: That was sooner than I expected.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Just to follow-up on the compensation changes, yes, that's good news that people are paid in stock instead of just cash and stock, but you had the new bonus arrangement.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I did not think that was finalized, but as part of the new bonus arrangement based on the next three-year financial targets, is that still all cash, or is that cash and stock, or is that stock?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm assuming you're referring to the transformation award.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Is that correct, Mike?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, so that one, while it's paid in cash for the first two pieces, the last 50% is pegged to our three-year stock performance and we felt that that was the appropriate balance here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we said, transformation is our highest priority.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We need to successfully address the concerns raised and that's 100% in our shareholders' interest.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One of the pieces that's important in that is that we need to have collective accountability to succeed in addressing these concerns, it's a shift in our culture, and this award is one that is therefore dependent upon shared success versus individual incentives here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So it's an important part of delivering, and of course if we fail to deliver the outcomes of the transformation and are not successful in the execution, there will be no award.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And when will we find – I guess we'll find out about those targets at Investor Day, so answering that question.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: As it relates to PSUs, how much was given in cash before and how many people will this apply to versus where it was before?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The PSUs are given to the executive management team and now we're extending that to the broader operating team which includes the leaders of our major businesses, and you'll see that information delivered in the proxy when we issue that in March.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So you'll get all of that information at roughly the same time.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Mark, I was wondering if you could just talk a little bit about the card business in aggregate.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Definitely starting to see a little bit of that balance, but I wonder if you could touch on, number one, like just how you're expecting that balance trajectory to go.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Number two, spend versus lend and how much you're seeing in that, and then, three, just the losses are obviously just amazingly low and how would you anticipate card normalization.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So as I've mentioned before, I mean, when you look at what's going on with cards, across the board we are seeing increases in spend volume.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So Branded Cards spend volume is up 24%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services spend volumes up 16%, so very healthy spend volume.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: People are using our cards, which is a good thing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the liquidity that's still out there in the market, even though savings rates have started to normalize there's still a significant amount of liquidity that's out there in the market, and that's showing up in payment rates in both Branded Cards and Retail Services and frankly in some of the international card businesses as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that has not subsided, and so we did start to see growth in Branded Cards loans, average loans are up 3% Branded Cards, the end-of-period loans were up 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What matters a lot when you come out of a crisis like this is how you reinvest, and so we've spent a lot of time focused on targeting new customers and driving new account acquisitions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our new account acquisitions are up 43% in Branded Cards, and we've been also driving that just generally across the board in Retail Services as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So getting a very good response in terms of new accounts coming onboard.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've also been focused on how we drive installment lending activity, just kind of to broaden the lending that we're doing with this customer base, and we've seen significant growth in our Flex Loan, Flex Pay products as we've targeted customers who have historically been transactors to really move them on to that product.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So very good growth there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact in 2021, we've not only gotten the growth just in aggregate but if I look at kind of installment lending, we've gotten 90% of the total installment sales are in digital sales, which is another kind of low-cost acquisition approach that we've taken.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So good underlying indicators there, but again, it's not until payment rates start to subside.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We would expect, hope, that that would start to show up towards the back half of 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the losses which was the other part of your question, very low loss levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You heard me mention the delinquency rates earlier.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: When I look at the loss rates earlier, when I look at delinquency trend there's really nothing to focus on there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They remain quite low, and we don't see any signs or any areas of concern, I would say, but I would imagine those two would start to normalize as payment rates start to come down.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Great.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Mark, thanks.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And then just a follow-up, you mentioned the strongest quarter in advisory in a while.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: I was just wondering if you could just comment broadly on Investment Banking pipelines across the product groups.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, the Investment Banking pipeline looks very strong.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the year with significant growth in advisory up 146% year-over-year, well above the wallet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've grown share there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: ECM was up about 16%, again above the wallet and really, that reflecting some of the fees coming from SPAC activity, so very good growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: EMEA and North America are both up year-over-year due to continued momentum in M&A, so we feel very good about it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We think the pipeline still looks very strong.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We think the investments that we've made in bringing on bankers in some of the sectors we needed to beef up, sectors such as healthcare, technology, sponsors group, those investments are certainly starting to pay off, so we feel good about it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: All righty.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: All righty.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, I think we have a good long-term process in motion and measured in more than one year, but what do you think of the sort of – it feels like returns have to go down before they go up.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I know you have the overall goal to close the gap to peers, but between the capital that gets freed up, the GSIB buffer in the denominator, the capital markets partially normalizing some stranded expenses on sold franchises and then continuing to execute on the transformations, is it okay and is it normal, I think it's partially in our models that we go down first and then rise up?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so thank you, Glenn.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So look, if you look at 2021 with a 13.4% RoTCE and reserve releases that get close to $9 billion, I'd have to say yes, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Because those reserve releases drive a considerable amount of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, it's important to compare that to 2020 where we had the opposite effect because we were building meaningful reserves, but as we look at the forward look, which we'll take you through in more detail, as Jane mentioned, we're focused on core parts of the franchise that show the opportunity for growth and the promise for higher returns, and that's where our energies are going to be focused and we think that's what's going to help to drive improved returns over time.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Fair enough.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: The reserve releases have a big impact.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: And then in terms of that growth, I think a couple of questions dance around this, so you could be short, but given your answer to what Citi is and wants to be in terms of premier franchise in all those industries, or business lines, I should say, how do you balance that you're doing what's right for stockholders in the near-term, drive stock return versus making sure you invest for the future, because each one of those is super competitive, each one of them has competitors as early as today, or as recent as today spending a ton of money to compete in those spaces, how do you balance that, invest for the long-term would be great versus improve the stock short term?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So let me start, and then Jane feel free to add in if you'd like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So the first thing I think it's important to remember is the focus that we're trying to put on these core franchises that drive returns over time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we're prioritizing how we're going to allocate our resources and our investments in part through the divestiture activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing I'd say is that we are investing in the franchise for the long-term, right, as opposed to trying to hit some short-term metric, and so that does involve us putting that money to work where there is client demand and where it leverages the competitive advantages that we have developed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that is the way we approach this with again an eye towards ensuring that we're clear and transparent with our investors and that if there's excess that we're returning that to our shareholders so they're not just sitting on the sidelines and not generating returns that they would expect of us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Right.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'd also just jump in when you look at the different businesses that we are investing in, as Mark said, they're high-returning ones.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So our Services businesses are much capital lighter, high return.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Wealth Management, the same, and I think the opportunities that we've been seeing to continually increase share in Investment Banking, another high-returning business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that will certainly be helping us over time on that mix that you're talking about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And not everything needs an enormous investment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If I look at wealth, for example, you put the different pieces together that we've already got and we're putting them into a single integrated business and proposition, it's not things that we're starting from scratch, so a lot of this is incremental.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Ladies and gentlemen, please limit your questions to one question and one follow-up.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: A quick one firstly.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Now that you're exiting Mexico, Singapore and Hong Kong were not part of the exits when you announced the exit from the 13 markets in the consumer business.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Are you going to stay on with the consumer business in those markets, or meaning a traditional consumer business as you've had for years, or is that going to change?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: No, we find that the franchises we have in Singapore and Hong Kong just given the nature of them are really naturally tied to the wealth franchise that we are building and investing in there of our existing very strong platform, as you say.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we expect to continue to provide the range of different services and capabilities that we have because they are so complementary and help support our wealth business in two of the most major wealth hubs in the world.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Great.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And a follow-up question, if I may have.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The NII change, Mark, that you made, what deposit beta are you assuming there?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And how much of the change is coming from US net interest income versus the rest of the currencies?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, so we haven't shared our deposit betas, but as you would imagine, the betas tend to be higher on the institutional side than on the retail side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's that piece.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I'm sorry, the second part of your question was what?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Vivek?

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: The second part was how much of the change in net interest income from the interest rate sensitivity change, Mark that you're making...how much is the US net interest income versus the rest of the currencies?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The increase is roughly skewed towards the international, so I'd say of a $3 billion increase, I'd say about two-thirds/one-third international.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: That's where you were assuming more of the balance sheet run-off?

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Charles Peabody with Portales.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: A question regarding the regulatory and political risk to share buybacks, and I ask that because earlier this week in the Powell renomination hearings, when you listen to the last two minutes of that testimony, Sherrod Brown went on a rail against buybacks in the banking industry.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: And then last year I think President Biden had two speeches in which he spoke out against buybacks.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: So I'm trying to understand, is there – I mean, a transaction tax isn't going to stop you guys from doing buybacks, but are there other things being discussed out there other than just moral suasion to discourage buybacks?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're going to do the right thing for our shareholders, and right now, particularly given where the stock's trading, buybacks are a very, very important and probably top of the stack for us action that we take, so no, we're very clear in terms of the importance of giving our shareholders back our excess capital.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: No, I understand that you want to.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: I'm just trying to understand what the risk to your desires are from the regulatory or political side.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I don't believe there is one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're extremely well-capitalized.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we've heard it consistently from Washington.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The confidence in the capitalization of the banks both coming into and coming out of the pandemic, and we're not overly concerned on that front.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'll obviously adhere to regulatory guidelines as they exist or however they evolve, but that's exactly right.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: All right.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: And then as a follow-up just on that subject, assuming these regulators – just getting into their seats, they're probably not going to be able to do anything this year on buybacks, but I'm assuming that they'll try and do something on buybacks next year.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: So you want to do as much buyback short-term as you can and you've talked about getting back to like a $3 billion pace here in the first quarter.

speaker: Charles Peabody
sentence: How sustainable is that $3 billion pace?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So look, I mean, first of all with the SCB framework, we take decisions on the capital actions on a quarterby- quarter basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, there's another CCAR run that we'll all go through that will determine at least part of the capital stack, and then obviously, there's the GSIB that's coming into play.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So we factor all of those things in.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our case, as we develop the capital plan, we also will take a look at the divestitures and in some instances the divestitures will generate TCE for us to return to shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There may be other impacts from divestitures that are temporary in nature that need to be factored in, but it's part of an entire annual capital planning process that we go through that factors all of those things in.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you guys share with us, when you think about the strategy refresh that is underway, are we 75% complete, 80% complete?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, you alluded to maybe some of the Markets businesses that may not have the returns you want, there could be some area, but were you there, and by the Investor Day, can we assume that it will be completed?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the timeline to this one, this particular exercise is drawing to a close in terms of what I call the big step back as a new CEO.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we said this is the last major structural decision that we're taking in Mexico.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're now focused on pulling together everything from Investor Day and that's where the new reporting structure, I think, that we've announced today is also a very important foundation for that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'm confident that we've made the right big structural decisions and that we're looking forward to Investor Day laying out the vision, the strategies, and the plan for going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And let me be clear, Gerard, just in case I wasn't.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not suggesting we're exiting parts of our Markets business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is not what I'm suggesting at all.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I am suggesting is that as we would always do, we're constantly looking for opportunities to optimize the way we use our balance sheet, capital, RWA, et cetera, and where we identify the need to rid ourselves of low-returning assets that we have, we do that, all right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so with rule changes like SA-CCR and the like, either pricing will adjust or we'll have to take a hard look at some of those assets to see if it still makes sense, and that's more of what I meant than ever suggesting we were exiting part of the Markets business.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And just as a quick follow-up, obviously some of the businesses you're committed to, TTS, the investment banking area, you guys clearly are players there, you have economies of scale.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: When you look at the other businesses that you're committed to stay in, where is the heavy lifting going to come from where you really got to step it up to get those economies of scale, similar to the ones that are quite obvious.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, you're right.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a number of businesses that are already extremely scaled in both markets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If we look at TTS, we are moving $4 trillion of volume daily there, so those are ones where the investments are much more around digitization, around data.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in terms of where are we looking at getting more to – of increasing our scale, commercial bank is obviously one where we have a commercial banking presence in 30 different markets around the world and they're very focused on the same target market I talked about in the vision, which are those mid-market companies with global needs or multi-market needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then the other areas in terms of wealth where we've already begun, as you can see from our earlier remarks building out our frontline scale on the back of the platforms and other investments that we're making.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And to your point, Jane, commercial bank this year, huge opportunity to leverage more of the TTS offering that we have.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're already seeing diversification in the commercial bank in terms of CMO and other markets products, and the revenue this year was up 12% year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And similar strength in acquisition of new clients in wealth, but those are two key areas, I agree.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just quick couple of follow-ups.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Mark, on the capital return, I just wanted to make sure.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: When we think about the $3 billion pace you're going to get back to in 1Q, moving forward, is there more upside risk with that $3 billion, or could that be actually lower?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I just want to make sure we have that right in terms of expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not giving expectations for the quarter-by-quarter capital buyback decisions, in part because as I mentioned, with the new SCB rule, we're able to look at it on a quarterly basis, so I'm not giving guidance beyond that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'll talk more about the capital plan on March 2 broadly, right?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And just I guess going back, Jane, on US retail, I think the question is, is there something more meaningful that we should expect at the Investor Day?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And it's fine if you want to hold it till then, because if I recall correctly, you were a partner with Google, that didn't play out.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: The big question that investors have is, is there a better definition to the US retail franchise.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And I'm just wondering will we get that at March Investor Day, or there's nothing radical that you have in store at least in the near-term as far as US retail is concerned.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll be certainly hearing directly from Anand who is responsible for that business on Investor Day and he'll lay out all of our US Personal Banking strategy of what we're looking at both from our top two cards franchise and our plan – what we're doing in Personal Lending as well as what we're doing in wealth and then obviously the retail bank and the supporting role it is playing for those two core drivers of growth for us in the States.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, yes.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Jim Mitchell with Seaport Research.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey, good afternoon.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Mark, maybe on just the expenses, I appreciate all of the moving parts with the divestitures and you're not going to give us the full year expense guidance number, but can you help on the jumping-off point at the first quarter?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: We had compensation was up about $1 billion quarter over-quarter.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How much of that was just sort of the comp changes, or is that a good run rate to think about, so if you could just help us just the jumping-off point for first quarter would be helpful.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, you know what, I'm not going to be able to give you kind of more guidance on that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, what I would say is, again, you got a couple things that played through 2021 that will be important factors in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, the hiring that we've done we're going to get a full year impact of that, at least for part of that in 2022, so that's going to play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Some of the – if you think about the mix for the transformation spend, which is a mix of both hires, third-party spend, as well as technology, that mix will start to shift over time away from third-party for sure and towards the others, and so we're going to have some of that dynamic start to play out in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the comp specifically in the fourth quarter, we obviously tie the comp performance for the full year is tied to revenues, and so as we would expect to see some forward growth based on the drivers, I mentioned earlier, we would expect to see comp related to that play out over the course of 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I'd rather not get into the specifics here given that we're going to give you a better sense for it in early March.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Just maybe as a follow-up on that, just so I understand the sequential drivers, so you're saying it's mostly incentive comp or was that more new hires, or both?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Just from 3Q to 4Q change.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, in 3Q to 4Q, you've got both hires as well as incentive comp.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: I just wanted to follow up, you had said the sale of Mexico wouldn't be an easy transaction and was just hoping you could elaborate on that.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And then just related, you talked about the capital that's allocated to the business being freed up, but any kind of initial thoughts on whether the transaction, the exit of the business will generate a gain or loss as we think about the combined or total capital impact.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Why don't I kick that off, and Mark jump in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I said, it won't be a simple transaction because we separate the bank into the Institutional business from the businesses that we're exiting, and that's something that we kicked off yesterday, that process.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then we'll be looking to go to the market in the spring and to be active with buyers, potential buyers in a few months' time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So it's more just the complexity of separating the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got good plans behind this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I said in my remarks, these are terrific, these are scaled, these are great franchises, and there's obviously a lot of speculation in the press which is too early to comment on, but we do think this is a jewel for someone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's just not for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I agree, and I think it's premature to speculate on structure of the deal and things of that sort.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You're right, we do have about $4 billion of TCE allocated to the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other layer of complexity is around the CTA, and you've heard us spend some time on that when we talked about the Australia sale and I introduced it as a complexity because there's an accounting treatment associated with the CTA that happens at signing that is separate from the capital implication that happens at closing.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So with a CTA, the capital impact flows through AOCI, but it's neutral once the deal is closed, and in Mexico, the consumer business would have a DTA of a little bit less than $3 billion or so, and so that's another factor that's involved with the transaction.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: A CTA, not a DTA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Did I say DTA?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I’m sorry, CTA.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Currency translation adjustment.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Well, actually even before asking my question, I just wanted to echo some of the earlier remarks.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: The new presentation, the additional detail, it's really helpful, so appreciate the new disclosure.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Mark, I'm going to ask, well, I guess technically one question, but it's really a three parter.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: You might need to grab a pen and paper.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: But I wanted to just unpack some of the comments you made on the NII sensitivity and reporting differences versus peers.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: You noted there more than three times increase in NII assuming a static balance sheet, but there's still a lot of investors that just question your rate sensitivity profile given the fairly modest NII growth that we saw in the last cycle.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And first question, just wanted to start by asking given your heavier institutional deposit gearing, wouldn't it be reasonable for us to expect that your deposit run-off would actually be greater than peers?

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Two, does the NII guidance contemplate liability sensitivity in the Markets business, and could you help us size that potential drag?

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And then just lastly, it's more of a catch-all.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Any idiosyncratic factors that you could speak to that would support a better NII outcome or higher rate benefit versus what we saw in the last cycle?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So look, we provided the sensitivity because we think comparability is important here, and you can see the magnitude of that difference is pretty sizable.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's still going to be a difference between us and peers, but that difference narrows when you put it on a comparable basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We do have a skew towards institutional clients and they do carry a higher beta associated with them, but we also have a skew towards international currencies and we make good spreads there as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the impact through markets, the impact – I think the markets impact can come in any number of ways.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think rate moves and other uncertainty and volatility in the market can drive broader markets revenues which we would potentially see depending on how investors have to reposition their books.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In terms of the last part of your question, I don't think there's anything else that I would point to.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, obviously with the excess liquidity that we've seen and been carrying in the market, we've been putting that to work in investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've increased our investment portfolio by some $70 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expanded the duration to about 2.85 years and we still have significant dry powder to put to work with either client demand or in an increasing rate environment which we expect.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: That's great color, Mark.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Thanks so much for accommodating the multi-part question.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your next question is from the line of Jeff Harte with Piper Sandler.

speaker: Jeff Harte
sentence: Hey, I'm sorry, I just thought I've taken myself out of the queue.

speaker: Jeff Harte
sentence: My questions have been answered, and you all must be getting tired, so I'm done.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your final question is from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Hey.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: One more question.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: What's the hardest part of the culture to change?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Probably it's been breaking down some of the silos, and that the point on the principles we laid out, Mike, of connected is really a key piece of it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've rolled out some new leadership principles last year and it's very much around how do we get the firm very well-connected and really realize the full synergies.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So breaking some of those old habits, I would say.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The new structure is certainly helping us at the different initiatives we're taking.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And how long do you think that will take, because you're breaking down a culture that's been ingrained for quite some time?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, I would say I'm really happy with the progress.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been – one of the first things I did was laid the firm to on our culture out when I took over, and we've got a terrific team of people being working at this for years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'm very happy with the progress we make.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think everyone's clear, we want the culture to be one of accountability, of excellence, and acting with urgency, and part of that is well underway.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But it'll take a little bit longer.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you all for joining today's call.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Please feel free to reach out to IR with any follow up questions.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Have a great day.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Good morning and thank you all for joining us.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: I'd like to remind you that today's presentation, which is available for download on our website, citigroup.com, may contain forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of factors, including those described in our SEC filings.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: With that, I'll turn it over to Jane.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and happy new year to everyone joining us today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are very much off and running as we start 2023.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Today, I'll share our perspective on the macro environment before recapping our performance in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then I will take a few minutes to reflect on our progress in 2022 and our strategic priorities for the coming year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The global macro environment played out largely as we anticipated during the second half of last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As we enter 2023, the environment is a tad better than we all expected, for the time being at least, despite the aggressive tightening by central banks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Europe, a warmer December reduced the stress on energy supplies and inflation is beginning to ease off its peak.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That said, we still expect softening of economic conditions across the Eurozone this year given some of the structural challenges it is grappling with.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Asia, while the public health impacts in China are unfortunately likely to be severe, the abrupt end of COVID zero should begin to drive growth and improve sentiment generally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And here at home, the labor market remains strong and holiday spending was better than expected, in part because consumers have been dipping into their savings.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Fed remains resolute in tackling core inflation; however, and therefore we continue to see the U.S. entering into a mild recession in the second half of the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now turning to how we performed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: For the fourth quarter, we reported net income of $2.5 billion and EPS of $1.16.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our full-year revenue growth of 3% ex-divestitures was in line with the guidance we gave you at Investor Day, as was the case with our expenses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We delivered an RoTCE of nearly 9% and a CET1 ratio of 13%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This quarter, our businesses performed similarly to how they did throughout the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are quite pleased with some, and less happy with the performance of others.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services continues to deliver cracking revenue growth; our Markets businesses are navigating the environment very well, and we are seeing good momentum in U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: On the flip side, Investment Banking is feeling the pain of a drastically smaller wallet in ‘22 and the environment for Wealth remains a challenging one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Unpacking that a bit, Services delivered another excellent quarter and we have gained significant share in both Treasury and Trade Solutions, and Securities Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: TTS, the business most emblematic of the power of our global network, had revenues up 36% year over year, as we execute on the strategy we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thanks to strong business drivers, coupled with higher rates, TTS is performing ahead of our expectations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Likewise, Securities Services was up a strong 22%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We ended the year having onboarded $1.2 trillion of new assets under administration and custody.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Markets had the best fourth quarter in recent memory, with revenues up 18% from 2021.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We had the #1 FICC franchise (1) on the street during the first three quarters of the year and Fixed Income was up 31% in the final quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equities was down, as the mix of client activity again did not play to our strength in derivatives.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With the wallet down significantly, our Investment Banking revenues were off by about 60% this quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While the pipeline looks more promising and client sentiment is improving, it would be hard to predict precisely when the tide will turn in ‘23.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Wealth Management’s performance was disappointing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Revenues were down 6% in the quarter with the macro environment creating headwinds in investment fees and AUM globally, but most acutely in Asia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: However, we have been steadily improving the business, as demonstrated by continued momentum in client acquisitions across the spectrum, and net new investment flows.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, we continue to build our client advisor base, albeit at a slower pace given this environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We would expect to see these investments pay off as the markets recover.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking, both Cards businesses had double-digit revenue growth for the second straight quarter as purchase sales and revolving balances continued to grow strongly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Whilst in Retail Banking, we clearly have some more work to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, we have been actively managing our balance sheet and risk.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our cost of credit increased in line with our guidance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We built reserves in Personal Banking this quarter on the back of volume growth, as well as, in anticipation of a mild recession.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in the U.S., net credit losses in Cards continue to normalize as we had expected, still well below pre-COVID levels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Corporate credit remains healthy, and our low overall cost of credit was similar to last quarter, reflecting the quality of our corporate loan portfolio.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of capital, we increased the CET1 ratio by about 70 basis points to 13% during the fourth quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, our tangible book value per share increased to $81.65 and we returned $1 billion to our shareholders through our common dividend.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Now let me step back and discuss what we accomplished in 2022.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One of our major goals last year was to put in place a strategic plan designed to create long-term value for our shareholders, and to get that plan swiftly off the ground, I am pleased with the significant progress we have already made.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We simplified the bank, closing the sales of our consumer businesses in five markets, including three in the fourth quarter, and we have made rapid progress winding down our consumer business in Korea, as well as our franchise in Russia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We continued to invest in our transformation to address our consent orders and to modernize our bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are streamlining our processes and making them more automated whilst improving the quality and accessibility of our data; this will make us a better bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: 1 Source: Coalition Greenwich Competitor Analytics for the peer group.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Based on preliminary data year to date through 3Q22.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The number 1 rank is based on Citi’s internal taxonomy and internal revenues for Fixed Income, excluding non-addressable products and including products which may not be considered within Fixed Income for other Financial Institutions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Other companies may calculate rankings in a different manner.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Peer Group includes BAC, BARC, BNPP, CS, DB, GS, HSBC, JPM, MS, SG, UBS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We brought in very strong external talent, met our representation goals, and strengthened our culture by increasing accountability and shareholder alignment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: To that end, I am pleased we delivered against our financial guidance for the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also released our first plan to reach net zero emissions by 2050, expanded our impact investing, and announced the findings from an external law firm which reviewed our racial equity efforts in the U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Finally, I am very proud of how our people handled the macro and geopolitical shocks which defined 2022 and supported our clients and our communities with excellence and compassion throughout.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Before I hand over to Mark, let’s turn to the next few years, and in particular the path to achieving our medium term return targets that we laid out on page 5.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At Investor Day, we talked about the path coming in three phases with Phase 1 characterized by both disciplined execution and investment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: 2023 is a continuation of Phase 1, laying the foundation for driving long-term shareholder value.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are focused on changing our business mix to drive revenues and returns, with the expectation that our businesses will close out ‘23 competitively stronger.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services enters ‘23 with strategic momentum and a pipeline of major new innovations and market leading product capabilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Markets should continue to benefit from our active corporate client base, with the franchise further advancing on the back of investments and the business’ focus on capital productivity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking and Wealth are well positioned for when the cycle turns, thanks to the investments we have made in top talent and technology, as well as synergies realized across the franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you saw, we felt this was the right time to make a change in Wealth and we have started a search to identify the next leader of this business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I asked Jim O’Donnell to take on a new role focused on senior clients across the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This will leverage his deep expertise and relationships, and when combined with Sunil Garg’s additional role as North American head, is designed to help us capture more of what is a significant business opportunity in our home market.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking will continue to benefit from the recovery in borrowing, taking full advantage of our market-leading digital platforms and new products, particularly in the Cards space.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will make further progress on our International Consumer exits, enabling us to simplify the firm and reduce our cost base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we will of course focus on our clients – deepening relationships and bringing on new clients in line with our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will continue making disciplined investments in our franchise including the investments in our Transformation and controls, however, we will pace some of our business investments to reflect the operating environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Looking further out, we will begin to bend the curve of our expenses to deliver against our medium-term targets through a combination of our divestitures, realizing the financial benefits of our Transformation, and further simplification.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And Mark will cover this in more detail shortly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We fully recognize this depresses our returns in the near-term, but we are deliberately taking the tough strategic actions and investments necessary to reach our medium-term return target and to create long-term shareholder value.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are carrying not just our momentum, but our determination into 2023.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Despite the macro headwinds, we are very much on track to reach the medium-term return targets we shared with you on Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We intentionally designed a strategy that can deliver for our shareholders in different environments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are running the bank differently, with a relentless focus on execution, and will continue to transparently share our proof points with you along the way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that, I would like to turn it over to Mark and then we would be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thank you, Jane, and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have a lot to cover on today’s call – I am going to start with the fourth quarter and full-year financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons, unless I indicate otherwise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I’ll also discuss our progress against our medium-term KPI targets and end with our guidance for 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 6, we show financial results for the full firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the fourth quarter, we reported net income of approximately $2.5 billion and an EPS of $1.16 and an RoTCE of 5.8% on $18 billion of revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in these results are pre-tax divestiture-related impacts of approximately $192 million, largely driven by gains on divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding these items, EPS was $1.10 with an RoTCE of approximately 5.5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the quarter, total revenues increased by 6% or 5%, excluding divestiture-related impacts, as strength across Services, Markets and U.S.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Personal Banking was partially offset by declines in Investment Banking, Wealth, and the revenue reduction from the closed exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our results include expenses of $13 billion, a decrease of 4% versus the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding divesture related costs from both the fourth quarter of this year and last year, expenses increased by 5%, largely driven by investments in our transformation, business-led investments, and higher volume-related expenses, partially offset by productivity savings and the expense reduction from the exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was approximately $1.8 billion, primarily driven by the continued normalization in Card net credit losses, particularly in Retail Services, and an ACL build of $645 million, largely related to growth in Cards and some deterioration in macroeconomic assumptions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And on a full-year basis, we delivered $14.8 billion of net income and an RoTCE of 8.9%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to the full-year revenue walk on slide 7.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2022, we reported revenue of approximately $75 billion, up 3%, excluding the impact of divestitures, in line with our guidance of low-single-digit growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Treasury and Trade Solutions revenues were up 32%, driven by continued benefits from Rates, as well as business actions, such as managing deposit repricing, deepening with existing clients and winning new clients across all segments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Client wins have accelerated due to the investments we have been making in market-leading product capabilities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These products include the first 24/7 USD clearing capability in the industry, the 7-day cash sweep product that we launched earlier this year, and Instant Payments which is live in 33 markets, reaching over 60 countries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, while the rate environment drove about half of the growth this year, business actions and investments drove the remaining half.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Securities Services, revenues grew 15% as net interest income grew 59%, driven by higher interest rates across currencies, partially offset by a 1% decrease in non-interest revenue due to the impact of market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the full year, we onboarded approximately $1.2 trillion dollars of assets under custody and administration from significant client wins and we continue to feel very good about the pipeline of new deals.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Markets, we grew revenues 7% mainly driven by strength in Rates and FX as we continued to serve our corporate and investor clients while optimizing capital; this was partially offset by the pressures in Equity Markets, primarily reflecting reduced client activity in Equity Derivatives.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On the flip side, Banking revenues, excluding gains and losses on loan hedges, were down 39%, driven by Investment Banking, as heightened macro uncertainty and volatility continued to impact client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Cards, we grew revenues 8% as we continued to see benefits from the investments that we made in 2022 along with the rebound in consumer borrowing levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Wealth, revenues were down 2% largely driven by market valuations and China lockdowns; excluding Asia, revenues were up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate / Other also benefitted from higher NII, in part as the shorter duration of our investment portfolio allowed us to benefit from higher short-term rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as you can see on the slide, in Legacy Franchises, excluding divestiture-related impacts, revenues decreased about $1.3 billion as we closed five of the exit markets and continued to wind down Russia and Korea Consumer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Going forward, we would expect Legacy Franchises to continue to be an offset to overall revenue growth as we close and wind down the remaining exit markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 8, we show an expense walk for the full year with the key underlying drivers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2022, excluding divestiture-related impacts, expenses were up roughly 8%, in line with our guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Transformation grew 2%, with about two-thirds of the increase related to the risk, controls, data, and finance programs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And approximately 25% of the investments in those programs are related to technology.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: About 1% of the expense increase was driven by business-led investments, which include improving and adding scalability to our TTS and Securities Services platforms, enhancing client experiences across all businesses, and developing new product capabilities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also continue to invest in front office talent, albeit at a more measured pace given the environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And volume-related expenses were up 1%, largely driven by Markets and Cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The remainder of the growth was driven by structural expenses, which include an increase to risk and control investments to support the front office, as well as macro impacts like inflation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These expenses were partially offset by productivity savings, as well as the benefit from foreign exchange translation and the expense reduction from the exit markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Across the firm, technology-related expenses increased by 13% this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we show our 2022 results versus the medium-term KPI targets we laid out at Investor Day, which we will continue to show you as we make progress along the way.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Macro factors and market conditions, including those driven by monetary tightening at levels we didn’t anticipate at Investor Day, impacted some KPIs positively and others negatively.

speaker: Mark Mason
