sentence: However, we were able to offset some of the impacts as we executed against our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In TTS, we continue to see healthy underlying drivers that indicate consistently strong activity from both new and existing clients as we roll out new product offerings and invest in the client experience which is a key part of our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Client wins are up approximately 20%, across all segments, and these again include marquee transactions, where we are serving as the client’s primary operating bank.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Through the third quarter YTD, we estimate that we gained about 70 bps of share and maintained our number 1 position with large institutional clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In addition, we have onboarded over 8,700 suppliers this year, helping our clients manage their supply chains to address the evolving global landscape.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Securities Services, we onboarded new client assets, which offset some of the decline in market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we estimate that we have gained about 50 bps of share in Securities Services through the third quarter of this year – including in our home market.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Markets, we strengthened our leadership position in Fixed Income by gaining share while making progress towards our Revenue-to-RWA target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In Cards, loan growth exceeded our expectations in both Branded Cards and Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cards spend volumes were up 14%, end-of-period loans up 13%, and most importantly, interest-earning balances up 14%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, in areas like Investment Banking, we lost share this year, but maintained our market position.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Wealth, while we have brought on new advisors and new client assets, given the impact of market valuations, this didn’t translate into growth in client assets or top-line growth at this point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, in summary, we made good progress against our medium-term KPI targets despite the significant changes in the macroeconomic backdrop since Investor Day.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This highlights that our diversified business model is adaptable to many environments, and we have the right strategy to achieve our return targets over the medium-term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning back to the fourth quarter, on slide 10, we show net interest income, deposits, and loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the fourth quarter, net interest income increased by approximately $710 million on a sequential basis, largely driven by Services, Cards and Markets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans were down, as growth in Cards was more than offset by declines in ICG and Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding foreign exchange translation, loans were flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And average deposits were down by approximately 1%, largely driven by declines in Legacy Franchises and the impact of foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding foreign exchange translation, deposits were up 2%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sequentially, average deposits were up, driven by growth in ICG and PBWM and our net interest margin increased by 8 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 11, we show key consumer and corporate credit metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are well reserved for the current environment with over $19 billion of reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our reserves-to-funded loans ratio is approximately 2.6%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And within that, PBWM and U.S. Cards is 3.8% and 7.6% respectively, both just above day 1 CECL levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we feel very good about the high-quality nature of our portfolios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In PBWM, 45% of our lending exposures are in US cards, and of that, Branded Cards makes up 66% and Retail Services makes up 34%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Additionally, just over 80% of our total Cards exposure is to prime customers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And NCL rates continue to be well below pre-COVID levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In our ICG portfolio, of our total exposure, over 80% is investment grade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of the international exposure, approximately 90% is investment grade or exposure to multinational clients or their subsidiaries.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And corporate non-accrual loans remain low and are in line with pre-pandemic levels at about 39 basis points of total loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That said, we continuously analyze our portfolios and concentrations under a range of scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, while the macro and geopolitical environment remains uncertain, we feel very good about our asset quality, exposures, and reserve levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 12, we show our summary balance sheet and key capital and liquidity metrics.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintain a very strong balance sheet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of our $2.4 trillion balance sheet, about a quarter, or just under $569 billion, consists of HQLA and we maintain total liquidity resources of approximately $1 trillion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our tangible book value per share was $81.65, up 3% from a year ago.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 13, we show a sequential CET1 walk to provide more detail on the drivers this quarter and our targets over the next few quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Walking from the end of the third quarter: first, we generated $2.3 billion of net income to common which added 19 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, we returned $1.0 billion in the form of common dividends, which drove a reduction of about 9 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, the impact on AOCI through our AFS investment portfolio drove an 8 basis point increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, the remaining 56 basis point increase was largely driven by the closing of exits, RWA optimization, and market moves towards the end of the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We ended the quarter with a 13% CET1 capital ratio, approximately 70 bps higher than the last quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you can see, we hit our 13% CET1 target, which includes a 100 bps internal management buffer, that will allow us to absorb any temporary impacts related to the Mexico Consumer exit at signing, while continuing to have ample capacity to serve our clients.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as it relates to buybacks this quarter, we will remain on pause and continue to make that decision quarter-by-quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 14, we show the results for our Institutional Clients Group for the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased by 3% this quarter, with TTS revenue up 36% on continued strength in NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Securities Services revenue up 22%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets revenue up 18% on strength in Fixed Income, partially offset by a decline in Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And Investment Banking revenues down 58%, which is in the range of the overall decline in industry volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 6%, driven by transformation, business-led investments, specifically in Services, and volume-related expenses, partially offset by FX translation and productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $56 million, driven by net credit losses of $104 million, partially offset by an ACL release.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This resulted in net income of approximately $1.9 billion, down 18%, driven by higher cost of credit and higher expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: ICG delivered an 7.9% RoTCE for the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And average loans were down slightly largely driven by the impact of foreign exchange translation and our continued capital optimization efforts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding FX, loans were up 1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits were roughly flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the impact of foreign exchanges translation, deposits were up 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And sequentially, deposits were up 4%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As for the full year, ICG grew revenues by 3% to $41 billion and delivered approximately $10.7 billion of net income with an RoTCE of 11.1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to Slide 15, we show the results for our Personal Banking & Wealth Management business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 5% as net interest income growth was partially offset by a decline in non-interest revenue, driven by lower investment product revenue in Wealth and higher partner payments in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were up 7%, driven by investments in transformation and other risk and control initiatives.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $1.7 billion, which included a reserve build, driven by card volume growth and a deterioration in macroeconomic assumptions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NCLs are up reflecting ongoing normalization particularly in Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 6% while average deposits decreased 1%, largely reflecting clients putting cash to work in fixed income investments on our platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And PBWM delivered an RoTCE of 1.4% driven by the ACL build this quarter and higher expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the full year, PBWM delivered an RoTCE of 10.2% on $24.2 billion in revenues.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 16, we show results for Legacy Franchises.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues decreased 6%, primarily driven by the closings of 5 exit markets, as well as the impact of the wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 38%, largely driven by the absence of divestiture-related impacts last year related to Korea.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On Slide 17, we show results for Corporate / Other for the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues increased, largely driven by higher net revenue from the investment portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses are down, driven by lower consulting expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 19, we summarize our guidance for 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane mentioned earlier, 2023 is a continuation of Phase 1 – we will continue to execute and invest – laying the foundation for the future with an eye toward driving long-term shareholder value.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that as a backdrop, we expect revenue to be in the range of $78 - $79 billion, excluding any potential 2023 divestiture-related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses to be roughly $54 billion, also excluding 2023 divestiture-related impacts.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net credit losses in Cards is expected to continue to normalize.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we said earlier, we met our 13% CET1 target and we will continue to evaluate that target as we go through the next DFAST cycle and close additional exits and announce others.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 20, on the right side of the page, we show our revenue for 2021 and 2022 and our expectations for 2023, excluding the impact of divestitures.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2023, we expect the revenue growth I just mentioned to be driven by NII and NIR.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In TTS, we expect revenue to grow, but at a slower pace, driven by interest rates and business actions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And for Securities Services, we expect a bit of a tailwind from increased market valuations and onboarding of additional client assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also assume somewhat of a normalization in Wealth as lockdowns in China end and market valuations start to rebound.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we expect Investment Banking to begin to rebound as the macroeconomic backdrop becomes more conducive to client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As for Markets, we expect it to be relatively flat given the level of activity we saw in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now, turning to the NII guidance for 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect both ICG and PBWM to contribute to NII growth as we grow volumes, particularly in Cards, and we continue to get the benefit of US and non-US rate hikes in our Services businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, the guidance for revenue includes the reduction of revenue from the exits in Legacy franchises that we closed in 2022 and we expect to close this year in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 21, in 2023, the increase in expenses that I just mentioned reflects a number of decisions we have made to further our transformation and execute on our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the main drivers are: first, Transformation, as we continue to invest in data, risk & controls, and technology to enhance our infrastructure and ultimately make our company more efficient.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, business led investments as we execute against our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Third, volume-related expenses – in line with our revenue expectations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And fourth, elevated levels of inflation, mainly impacting compensation expense, partially offset by productivity savings and expense benefits from the exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we are investing in technology across the firm, with total technology-related expenses increasing by 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: While we recognize this is a significant increase in expenses, these are investments we have to make, and these investments will make us a better, more efficient company in the future.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, let’s talk a little bit about the medium-term targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At Investor Day we said the medium-term was 3-5 years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That time frame represented 2024 to 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, while a lot has changed in the macro environment since Investor Day, our strategy has not, and we are on a path to the 11-12% RoTCE targets in the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to expect top line revenue growth, material expense reductions, and capital levels largely consistent with our medium-term CET1 target range to contribute to the achievement of our 11-12% ROTCE target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So let me walk you through where we stand today.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: From a revenue perspective, rates have moved much higher and at a faster pace across the globe which accelerated NII growth – and that coupled with the execution of our strategy has allowed certain businesses to accelerate.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the same time other businesses, such as Wealth and Investment Banking have slowed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Despite this, consistent with Investor Day, we expect a 4-5% revenue CAGR in the medium term, including the ongoing reduction of revenue from the closing of the exits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: From an expense perspective, as we showed at Investor Day, expenses will need to normalize over the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we now expect to the bend the curve on expenses towards the end of 2024.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The three main drivers of the necessary expense reduction will be benefits from the exits, which will be included in Legacy Franchises, the benefits from our investments in Transformation and controls, and the simplification of the organizational structure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: First, let me remind you that at this point, the ongoing expenses in Legacy Franchises are approximately $7 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Of the $7 billion, roughly $4 billion is transferred to the buyer upon closing or through a transition services agreement that typically lasts about a year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The remaining $3 billion relates to potentially stranded costs and the wind downs, which takes time to eliminate.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Second, as our investments in Transformation and control initiatives mature, we expect to realize efficiencies as those programs transition from manually intensive processes to technology-enabled ones.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And finally, we remain focused on simplifying the organization and we expect to generate further opportunities for expense reductions in the future.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: From a credit perspective, we still expect net credit losses to continue to normalize and any future ACL builds or releases will be a function of macro assumptions and volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, to wrap up, while the world has changed significantly and the components have shifted, we remain on our path to achieve the 11-12% RoTCE in the medium term and Jane, the rest of the firm, and I are prepared to continue to show proof points along the way and demonstrate our progress.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I would be happy to take your questions.

speaker:
Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Glenn Schorr with Evercore, your line is now open.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Definitely appreciate all these outlook slides, they're very helpful.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, my question on the outlooks is if you take a look at the current medium-sized return on tangible and getting to your target.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I heard many comments about the path to getting there is on track.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Is it the expense bend at the end of '24, that is the material step-up from here to there, if you will, and/or is credit like a really big determinant in the process?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I'm trying to bridge the gap just in numbers from today's return on tangible targets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, sure, good morning, Glenn, thanks for the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, we did give you some guidance here, we gave it to you both on the top line and the middle line for '23.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then importantly, when we talk about the medium term, it's both the continued revenue growth, the 4% to 5% CAGR that I referenced, but it's also bringing the expenses down from this '23 forecast.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I mentioned in the prepared remarks, the drivers of what's going to bring these expenses down, the combination of the exit of the businesses and the expenses going away associated with that, with the benefits that we start to generate from the transformation spend and then org simplification that this type of strategic restructuring, if you will, in exiting all these countries, will create an opportunity for.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, it's a combination of revenue growth, expense bending of that curve and coming down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The cost of credit is kind of as we've been talking about for some time now, which is it normalizes over the next couple of years at levels that are consistent with what we've seen kind of prior to this COVID cycle that we've been managing through.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Just one quick follow-up on and totally not my norm, but I normally try to respect this type of process.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But Mark, we consider you a super important part of this transformation.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: There's been news out there that you're talking to one of my other companies.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: But would you be able to make any comment on this?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: You mentioned staying on.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Sorry to put you on the spot, but I think a lot of people care.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I appreciate that, Glenn.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Citi is an important firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm the CFO of this firm and this strategy is something that I'm focused on with Jane, ensuring that we execute on right and in a way that creates shareholder value for our investors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we're committed to getting that done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Together.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Together.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, I wanted to dig into the revenue outlook for 2023.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: You've got about the midpoint, it kind of implies about 4% revenue growth this year, kind of consistent with what you talked about for that 4% to 5%.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: So, for this year, the 2023 guide, it looks like the NII is guided to be up about 3.5% and the Markets you're assuming kind of flat.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: So, what's enabling you to get to the 4%?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Where are the drivers that are above 4%?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Is it some of those fee businesses?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And just a little more color there would be helpful.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So let me make a comment first on the NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Just keep in mind with that number that I've given on the page is both the growth that occurs in some of our important Services businesses, and that really comes from both the annualization of rate increases that we saw in the back half of the year but also expected continued increases, particularly outside of the U.S. And given the make-up of our franchise, that will contribute to the NII growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then keep in mind that we're growing over the Legacy Franchise reductions in NII that we would see in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, underneath that is some real momentum in the NII, notwithstanding a slower pace, the fact that it would be a slower pace than what we saw in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: From an NIR point of view, I did mention that we do expect to see some normalization in market valuation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that would play out both in Banking, normalizing certainly relative to what we saw this year with wallets down 50% to 60%, as well as some normalization in Wealth and those would hit the NIR line, as you point out.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Sorry, if this is clear already.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: But just in terms of the idea of the cost curve bending at the end of 2024.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Is that going to mean that for the early part of 2024, expenses kind of rise above 2023 and then they kind of peak out, plateau, towards the back half of '24, is that how we should envision it?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not going to kind of get into '24 guidance, we'll kind of get through '23, and I'm confident about our ability to get to that roughly 54 number that I put out for '23.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm equally confident that we will bend this curve, and we'll bring it down to the levels that it needs to be in order for us to get to the RoTCE target, but I'm not going to kind of get into, John, the specifics of '24 except to say that by the end of '24, we will see that curve bending.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Erika Najarian with UBS, your line is now open.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: My first question is – again, thank you for all the clarification on the slide.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Great job, Jenn and Tom, and Mark, obviously.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: But as we think about what it means to bend the curve, I think your investors are appreciative that you are accelerating the investments relative to your transformation.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: As we think about when Citi can hit that medium-term RoTCE, how should we think about what bending the curve really means?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I'm not looking for guidance necessarily, but as we think about going past that hump, what's the better way of measuring?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Is it an efficiency ratio?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think you mentioned something like it is the 60% to 63% efficiency ratio against that 4% to 5% revenue CAGR that you think you'll be able to hit by 2025?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Can we think of it that way?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, so at Investor Day, we did talk about it, and we remain consistent and committed to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We talked about getting to an efficiency ratio that's less than 60% in the medium-term period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that certainly will be part of the metric that we deliver on as we bring our costs down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the other thing I'd mention, you mentioned the how, and I think there are a couple of important aspects to that, the exits are obvious in terms of those costs going away, at least a portion of it is.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The portion that's tied to stranded costs, Jane has been very, very clear with our entire management team of the importance of rethinking the organization and ensuring that the potentially stranded costs go away, and that means rethinking the way we do business and the way we operate different parts of our operations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the third piece is technology, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so right now, a lot of what we're doing is manual.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we continue to invest in technology -- and technology is up pretty significantly this year, 14% or so, we expect it to be up 5% next year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That technology build-out, if you will, will allow for us to reduce a lot of that manual activity, and that will bring down the operational cost for running the firm.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those are a couple of examples, I hope, of the how.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think importantly, you will start to see it in an improved operating efficiency over that period of time and getting to the target that we talked about at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would say you can get some confidence around the path on many of these by the urgency with which we're executing the divestitures, for example, on getting those transactions closed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've also tried to provide you as much clarity as possible about the timing of when these will be closing and the speed of the wind downs that we're executing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that will help.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As Mark said, it's 3 big structural drivers of what will bend that curve.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And Mark, I'm sorry, for misspeaking.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I was looking at the wrong bar on efficiency.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I have like 15 slides open on the computer.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: The second question, and maybe this is to you Jane, I think that your investors have appreciated your sense of urgency with regards to divestitures.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think the elephant in the room continues to be, I think, investors sort of expected an announcement on Banamex right now.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I'm wondering if you're still considering just selling Banamex.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Or are you thinking about different options on the table, such as an IPO?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're in active dialogue at the moment, so I'm obviously not going to comment in great detail here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We do continue to pursue a dual path as you'd expect, because both are very viable options here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when we are in a position to give you clarity we will do so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we've been fairly clear about the timing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are also separating out the 2 franchises, our institutional franchise from the consumer franchise that we're selling because we see the institutional franchise as a very important part of the global network.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you can imagine, in today's environment, Mexico is key for many of our corporate clients around the world for their supply chains and we play a very important role there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That is a lot of work in that separation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm extremely pleased with the progress that we're making in that underlying work.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we are pursuing the dual tracks and when we have something to announce, we will be delighted to do so.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I'm still trying to get over at this revenue and expense guidance, so you're implying you'll have at a minimum, flat operating leverage or positive operating leverage for 2023?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Am I reading that correctly?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, on the one hand, you're not bending the cost curve until late 2024.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: On the other hand, you're guiding for positive operating leverage in 2023.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Am I reading that correctly?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Mike, when you do the math, I don't think it will get to the positive operating leverage in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we are, as you see on the slide, targeting a range that does reflect growth in the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That growth will likely be a little bit less than the growth that roughly 54 number would suggest, but we are on the right track, and we are getting there in a way that's consistent with the strategy that we talked about.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we do feel confident in our ability to deliver on the guidance that we've put out here, similar to delivering on the guidance we gave last year, recognizing there are a lot of things going on in the broader environment.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then a second follow-up – or a follow-up, and then I'll re-queue for my other question.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Your CET1 ratio is 13% now and I think that's 2 quarters earlier than consensus had expected, you said it was up 70 basis points.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, doesn't that allow you to repurchase stock now?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Or I understand that if you go ahead and sell Banamex, that could have a temporary negative capital hit.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, I'm just thinking, like don't sell Banamex, don't have that temporary capital hit, start buying back stock at a fraction of your tangible book value.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, what's wrong with my logic or what part of that can you comment on?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm going to jump in on the don't sell Banamex, Mike.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you could imagine, so we are selling the consumer franchise, it does not fit with the strategy that we laid out in Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's an emerging market consumer franchise, and we are clearly focused around the multinational clients and in institutions and high-net worth individuals with cross-border needs as we laid out very clearly and businesses that have strong connectivity between each other.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we don't see Banamex having strategic fit in the consumer franchises in that perspective.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when we run all the math, it is in the shareholders' interest that we sell that franchise and deploy that capital to our shareholders or into some of the investments at higher returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What you're suggesting is a very short-term move.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think as you can see from the actions we're taking, we're very focused on our medium and long term and not taking the short-term path that we would regret in the medium and long term.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess just one question as a follow-up on capital.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: As we think about post the second half of the year, let's say, you've taken the hit from Banamex.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: But coming out of the stress test, any sense, Mark, if there's any reason why Citi would have an outsized negative impact from the Basel end game reforms?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just give us a sense, I'm just wondering hopefully, we don't get another disappointment as we get our hopes high for buybacks in the back half and there's something idiosyncratic about the business mix that could come back to hurt the bank?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Would love any perspective there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, look, as we pointed out, we've built a significant amount of capital over the course of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are ahead of the target we set for the middle of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We do have some exits that will have a temporary impact on that CET1 ratio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we do obviously have a DFAST that's in front of us that we'll have to see what the outcome is of that work.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the Basel end-game and final views and decisions on that are still outstanding.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think we'll have to take those into consideration when they become available.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is an industry dynamic that will play out however it plays out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And similar to SACCR, we'll get after it in a very significant way to make sure that we're able to handle whatever headwinds or tailwinds may come along with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But it really is difficult at this point to opine on exactly what that means for the industry in light of the fact that there aren't final rules out just yet.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And just back to your medium-term targets.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess if we hit that bending the curve at the end of '24, it implies that this company should have an earnings power north of $10 by '25 even at the lower end of the guidance.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Am I missing anything there?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Or does that make sense?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I’d point out is, what I’ve described, what Jane’s described, is the medium term is 2024 through 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we’ve given you guidance for 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We intend to get those return targets in the medium-term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I haven’t given you specific guidance on any of those individual years, and we’ll kind of take that year by year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so just factor in, I think what’s important is you’ve got a view on 2023, and I think we’ve given you additional clarity on how we intend to get to that medium-term, and I think that’s important.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I did want to ask a little bit about the strategy with Personal Banking and Wealth Management.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I know Jane, earlier you talked about the fact that – which you have announced looking for a new head to move that business forward – could you just give us a sense as to where you think the opportunity sets are greatest within that franchise for growth, because there's a bunch of different pieces, some on the advice channel, some of the more fee channels, some of the more balance sheet piece.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And you already indicated U.S. as an opportunity to expand into.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: So, I'd just like to understand, from your perspective, which pieces are the most important to execute on.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And that could help us understand how you're planning on shaping this business going forward?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Great question, Betsy, and Mark and I are both smiling here because I think the answer is all of the above.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, if we break it down, where do we see the various elements of upside?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's an important recovery that's going to occur in Asia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see from our results last year, and across the board with other competitors with an Asian bend, that was materially impacted by COVID in China and the lockdowns and a slower pulling out of COVID in that market compared, broadly in Asia, compared to the U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we see some exciting growth opportunities there from the pure fundamentals in Asia across the board.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You're absolutely right, in the U.S., we start from a smaller scale there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been bringing the different parts of that business together.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The Wealth at Work franchise is one that's had particularly pleasing growth in it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've also been seeing some good growth as we pulled a comprehensive offering together for our customers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The biggest upside there is investment products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think we've got a strong balance sheet franchise as it were, particularly the deposits, some of the margin lending and the like, mortgages, but this is really about the investment offering in the States.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Then finally, I'd say there's also tremendous opportunity in the synergies, and we've been showing you this in terms of linkages between our Commercial Bank, our Banking franchise, the referrals up from the U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking, we've had about 60,000 referrals this year in the U.S. alone from that, Markets also provides important referrals and even TTS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, there are client referrals, there are business synergies between the common platforms, so we really see an opportunity for this multi-dimensional growth drivers in Wealth over and above the recovery in the investment space that everybody in the market should be able to benefit from.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we'll continue investing appropriately in building out that front line as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, this is a very important part of our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're excited about it, it's the key pillar of the shift in business mix as we go forward as well, looking at the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're looking forward to the next phase of growth and focus here.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And would you say that the investment spend required to execute on those revenue opportunities is likely to accelerate from here?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Or you've already done that investment spend and the investment is more sideways as opposed to accelerating?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think in this current environment, as we've said, Mark and I have both said since middle of last year, this is something that we're pacing, but we're continuing to invest behind it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see that growth in our client advisers, and remember that net growth in client advisers includes the divestiture we made in Uruguay, for example, so it's pretty strong.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't have a huge amount that we need to invest because we have many pieces of the platform in place, and it's more been a story of integrating them and then making sure that we're putting the right digital and other investments behind it, but it's not such a large one in order to achieve the upside in the business, and we'll pace that as appropriate with market conditions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, anything to add?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Betsy, and you know this is, in a normal part of the cycle, this is a high margin, high-returning business and we've seen that in the past.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we want to be well positioned for, as the market turns, having brought on client advisers, having brought in new clients through client acquisitions, which were up 24% in 2022.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I think we're well positioned for that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But as Jane mentioned, given where we are, we want to be smart about how we deploy the dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we'll re-pace as necessary, but ensure that we're ready for when things turn.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd just add, it was a couple of years ago that we announced the strategy and started executing on it, so we have the benefit of the historic investments, we're seeing the drivers playing out well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I say, we should be well positioned when the market turns here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: I just want to follow up on the comments about expecting Markets to be relatively flat in '23.

speaker: Connor
sentence: Obviously, a very good 4Q and I know at least I was concerned about some of the RWA management and FICC in recent quarters and I think that proved not to be an issue as you think about leadership and revenue.

speaker: Connor
sentence: But as you think about '23, like the wallets have been strong in recent years.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And to your point, your FICC leadership was strong this year.

speaker: Connor
sentence: How confident are you in kind of that flat Markets?

speaker: Connor
sentence: And maybe what's driving that view?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's a Market business, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, you know very well kind of the volatility that can come with any Markets business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, we've got a very, very strong FICC franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We had a very good year this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think we're well positioned with the client base, and we're well positioned to maintain our #1 position as we go into 2023(1).

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now how that market and market wallet moves, I think, is going to predicate on a number of things, including how the macro continues to evolve and how central bank activity continues to evolve and how currencies move and the like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, I feel like we're well positioned to hold our position, if not gain more share as that plays out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I think flat relative to a year that we've had up as significantly as it is, is a reasonable call based on what we know now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've also seen some depression of areas of strength in this business as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, Equity Derivatives, for example, is a real strength, this was an Equity Derivatives year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, there's some -- and the corporate world with the volatility that's out there from a macro geopolitical environment is another real strength of ours.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And for better or for worse, we're expecting that strength to continue, certainly so far.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Mark, maybe just digging into NII a little bit.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: If you look at 4Q annualized, you have a decent step down, but when you take a look at your deposit franchise, your mix of business versus your peers, where they're seeing probably lagging retail deposits in the U.S., pricing that's going to hurt second half NII, you already have high betas, mostly institutional.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You mentioned the benefit from non-U.S. rates and you're growing deposits.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So why a similar trend in NII versus peers when you have a pretty different dynamic going on?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Just trying to think that through because it doesn't look like the Legacy you drag is very big in your chart.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Similar dynamics you say in '23 or you're talking about the fourth quarter?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not sure I followed.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I'm just trying to talk about versus peers, some have guided similarly to down from 4Q annualized run rates, but you have a very different dynamic in terms of deposit growth, benefits from non U.S. rates and a much higher beta.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean I think I'd point to a couple of things on the NII side, just as it relates to us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, importantly, that I mentioned in, and you point out is when you think about our mix of deposits, we've got about 65% or so in ICG and the balance, 35%, in our PBWM business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We certainly skew to U.S. dollar, but we've got a 30% or so that is a non-U.S. dollar.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And when I think about the potential or the forward curves and how rates will likely move next year, we will get the benefit of further rate increases on the non-U.S. side, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, if I think about our international presence, the betas tend to not be as high as they are here in the U.S. with our Corporate Clients segment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I think there's some repricing opportunities that we'll continue to actively manage as we did here in the U.S. And so, I do think it’s that international footprint, the globality of our franchise that plays to our strength in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The other thing that is apparent to us as we forecast this out, is the continued growth from a volume point of view.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that volume growth – you've seen the momentum already pick up on the Cards side with significant growth in interest-earning balances and we'd expect that to continue, particularly as we see NCLs normalize and as we see payment rates start to temper.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I think those things will be 2 major contributors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Mix is obviously a factor.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you point out, we will be growing over some of the drag or reduction from Legacy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But it's that active management of the client engagement that we have across both portfolios that I think will be important factors to us delivering the growth that I talked about.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: But I guess maybe I didn't phrase my question right, but I felt like ex Markets, I think your forecast for 2023 would be less than the 4Q run rate ex-Markets.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And you shared a bunch of reasons why you have sort of a differentiated franchise.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So, I'm just trying to get a sense of what's driving the decline from 4Q levels.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the thing you've got to pick up is really the Legacy franchise and the NII.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: A large part of the Legacy franchise revenues are NII revenues when you look at the mix of the products and the clients that we cover there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I think that's the important element here that we haven't quantified to a dollar amount, but that is explaining why it seems like muted growth relative to what you would have seen in the fourth quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, there's other factors, but that's important.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, can you share with us on your comments regarding, and this is true for your peers as well, the normalization of credit losses going forward since the industry has experienced incredibly low levels of credit losses.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: So, when you look at Branded Cards or Retail Services, how do you see that progressing through '23?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: One of your peers pointed out that they think that by the end of '23, they may be at that normalization rate that they look to for their numbers, but I'm just trying to see what the trajectory is for what you guys are thinking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yes, let me jump in and then I'll hand it on to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we are expecting, under the current trajectory, to see the loss rates to reach the pre-COVID levels more at the year-end, early '24 level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If you think of Branded Cards, if I was to quantify, it is 20% of the way there now, CRS, we're about 40% of the way there now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, we have the benefit in CRS of sharing of the loss sharing with our partners, that helps us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I hope that gives you a sense around it, probably the most important driver that we've been worried about, it was very uncertain with what was happening with payment rates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think we've got much more clarity as they started that normalization path, so that's driving a fair amount more certainty around what the direction is happening there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Frankly, the big question is more what's happening with spending than it is with the normalization right now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a bigger uncertainty.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But Mark, any other observations?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The only thing I'd add is that, Gerard, you could see just depending on how this plays out, you could see kind of NCL rates tick up above normal levels and then come back down to normal levels in the timeline that Jane described, again, just depending on how the macro factors continue to play out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But again, as we sit here and talk about these NCL rates, it's important to point out as well that we're very well reserved across all of these portfolios, and so to some extent, if you put macro assumptions aside and volumes aside, the NCLs kind of get funded by the reserves that have been established.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But the trend line is exactly as Jane described, just recognizing that you could see a tick-up above normal levels and then it come back down.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Also, this is such an unusual market in the sense that you've got such strong labor market, driven by, frankly, supply shortage almost as much as demand.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've also got the consumers with still very high savings that they're dipping into, and we're seeing a bit more of the movements happening at the bottom end of all of this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But this is not going to be like a normal recession, that’s why you hear us and others talking about the manageability and the mildness that’s likely if we do have one.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And what kind of unemployment rates are you guys assuming going into that kind of trajectory?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Is it we get to 5% unemployment by first quarter '24?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, one, our base case scenario, if you think about what we just talked about includes kind of a mild recession in it, just as we forecasted it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The downside would be something a bit more severe than that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'd say we're reserved for approximately a 5% unemployment rate just kind of overall when you average across the different scenarios that we have.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Just 2 quick questions.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: First one, just on Cards, Card NIM has been kind of flattish and I know that obviously has to do with just how you internally allocate the funding towards it.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: But can you just kind of talk us through what's happening either with rewards or either incremental teaser rates on some of the new relationships and should we see the Card NIM expand from here?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not going to get into, Ken, kind of guidance on NIM.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I will say is that we have seen good traction in the early part of the year as it relates to acquisitions on the Card side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've made very good traction, and Jane, you may want to comment on kind of the relationships that we have with some of the partners, and with American.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we've also launched a number of new products that I think is helping to fuel the growth that we've seen on the heels of those investments and some of the increase that we've seen in spend rates as well as some of the average interest-earning balance and loan growth that we've seen.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I really don't want to get into the NIM guidance at the Card level or the aggregate at this point.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean we have a fabulous Cards franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when we look at strong track record in the digital, the other innovations that are driving growth, driving the profitability, driving the returns both in our proprietary products as well as with our partners.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're really seeing all of those drivers performing very, very strongly at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: From Custom Cash, that was 28% of new account acquisitions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, an important new product refresh that's driving things, 80% of customers engaging digitally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Innovations like American, is just a fantastic partner of ours, really taking that to the next level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see that with the growth in spend in the category.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think there's a lot of reasons to be pretty excited about the growth in the returns and the margins and the other trajectories here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I say, a prime portfolio, which is always a good thing.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: Great, thanks.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And my second question was, there was an article about changing management up in the Wealth Management business this week.

speaker: Ken Usdin
sentence: And I just wonder if you can talk about that, but also just about the progress that you're making inside the Wealth Management relative to your, the KPIs and the goals that you discussed at Analyst Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, sure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean, 2 years ago, I asked Jim O'Donnell to put the Wealth business together from the various components that we had around the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And now, as we move to the next phase, but as we've said, a strategically important business, I thought it was the right time to change the leadership also because Jim is going to play an important role moving forward, supporting Paco with the ICG strategy that we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's got a lot of relationships with investors, family offices, private equity, sovereign wealth funds, and he's going to be helping drive those along with other investors to make sure we bring the firm's full capabilities to these clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I felt the time was right to make the move.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we will be, as indicated, swiftly moving to go out and have a look for our next leader of that business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in the meantime, it’s business as usual as we grow out and follow the strategy that we have, and we're looking forward to the market turning, as I'm sure everyone is, and feel that we're well positioned to do so.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Steven Chubak with Wolfe.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: This is actually Sharon Leung filling in for Steven.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: Just on the topic of credit, one of your peers noted this morning that they would expect to see an incremental $6 billion or so of reserves if they assume 6% unemployment under CECL.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: Just wondering if you could provide some similar sensitivity to reserve levels, and how should we think about the provision trajectory versus the 4Q base based on your macro outlook and potential growth mass headwinds?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I'm not going to kind of do sensitivity scenarios with you here on the fly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I will say is that as we build these reserves, we are building them against 3 scenarios, that base scenario that I mentioned, the downside scenario, and upside scenario, and we weight those scenarios.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the base that we used this quarter built in a mild recession.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in that baseline, unemployment was, call it 4.4% or so in terms of the unemployment assumption.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also had a downside scenario.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Unemployment in the downside scenario got to a 6.9% or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then we had an upside scenario.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The weighted average across the quarters was about the 5.1% that I mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And those were factors that went into the reserve that we established in the quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And largely, when you think about the weightings we put on those scenarios, the weighting skewed towards that base and that downside.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The reserve we built this quarter was largely in the consumer business, PBWM and specifically around Cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that really had to do the change quarter-over-quarter with the change in HPI.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But what I would say is that it also reflects, as I mentioned earlier, a Cards portfolio that remains of a very good quality and with loss rates that are well below what they would be in a normal cycle.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And it does pick up the fact that there's volume growth that we saw in the quarter there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, I'm not going to kind of run scenarios for you, but hopefully that gives you some perspective as to what's underneath the models that we've used to establish these reserves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And obviously, we do that on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'd also just jump in, one of the areas that sometimes gets misthought of about the firm, is on the corporate credit side.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When we look at our corporate client portfolio, don't equate where we take credit risk with the global footprint.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When I look internationally, 90% of our international exposure are with multinational firms and their subsidiaries, and these, all this is investment grade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think that's another area whereas we look at the quality of the corporate loan portfolio, as you saw with Russia and others, we will be conservative in the reserving we take.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But I think important to understand the nature of where we take that corporate credit risk.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: That's really helpful, thanks.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: And then as a follow-up, it seems like a part of your revenue targets for 2023 depends on some improvement in the environment.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: For example, stabilizing equity markets, IB rebound.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: And Jane, you also noted that the medium-term targets are designed to be achievable in different environments.

speaker: Sharon Leung
sentence: So, if the revenue backdrop continues to be challenged like we saw in 2022, can you just talk about some of the levers you might be able to pull that might provide an offset?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Well, it kind of depends on what the drivers are of a different environment, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Because you could have, I don't anticipate this, but you could have continued pressure in Investment Banking, but you could also have continued volatility in rates or currencies and that could mean more upside than flat for the Markets business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, there are a lot of puts and takes that one can scenario out.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think what's really important is that we have a diversified portfolio of businesses that have strategic connectivity to them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so what that allows for is that as the environment shifts in some way that we may not have predicted that we were often able to still drive significant performance as we did this year and so, without calling exactly how it might vary from what’s here, that's what gives us the confidence around the guidance and really to remain steadfast on the strategy that we've talked about and really push execution, and that's exactly what we're doing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And an important part of '23, it's not just the impact of the cycle, but also, you'll see the impact of the different investments that we've been making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you've certainly seen that, for example, in Services this year, and we've been very transparent around the 70 basis point increase we've seen in wallet share in the 12 months leading up to the third quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you've not only got drivers here in terms of what's happening in the market, but you've also got the strategic drivers, also kicking in more and more together as Mark referred to the synergies.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That’s a great point, Jane, because it may not always show up in the top line, which is why we put those KPIs out there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are often indicators of some of the upside that's on the come as the market evolves.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our last question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, one question, one follow-up.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, your slide says you have a CET1 target of 13% by mid year, but you're already there.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I guess, if we go back to the Banamex thing, is that kind of assuming potential capital impact from divestitures or why would you have a target 6 months out when you've already met it?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yes, Mike, I have to tell you I'm surprised that you're asking about Mexico, just given our history together, but I understand it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And what I would say is that a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, we clearly see where we trade, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're not happy about where we trade.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we think our strategy warrants us trading better than where we trade today.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, if we could buy back, right, if we could do buybacks, as soon as we're able to do buybacks, we will, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean that is part of the way we deliver value for our shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing I'd say is we did get to the 13% sooner.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that was, again, in accordance with executing against our strategy.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And our parts of our business, particularly the Markets business, has done a really good job at delivering against the metric we put out of revenue to RWA, and we've been able to get there without damaging the franchise, which is what you see in the continued strength and performance in that business, particularly in Fixed Income.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What's ahead of us, as you rightfully pointed out, is that we've got a number of exits that have to take place, there's puts and takes across many of them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But Mexico, in particular, will have a temporary, temporary impact on our CET1 ratio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we want to be mindful of that as we manage over the next 2 quarters so that we can absorb that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we also want to make sure that we're positioned to continue to serve our clients over the next couple of quarters and always, but certainly over the next couple of quarters, while we manage the temporary headwind from that exit.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So hopefully, that gives you a better sense for it, but we're actively managing this, and we have not lost focus on the importance of returning capital to shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I want to reiterate that as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I mean it's very important to us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as Mark said, we know where we trade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've made a number of moves to align ourselves to our shareholders' interest in compensation and management interest, all these various dimensions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we just want to make sure that we hit what we say we're going to do and continue delivering against what we say we're going to be delivering.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And with the CTA impact essentially in Mexico, we want to make sure that we're taking that into account.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: All right, that's very clear.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then lastly, your NII guide, excluding Markets related, is higher for 2023, but I think that implies a little step down from the fourth quarter level, not as much as JPMorgan was guiding down 10% from the fourth quarter level.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I was thinking there might be some delayed benefits from being outside the U.S. What are some of the ins and outs there?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've got a couple of points here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one is, we won't see NII momentum as we've seen in 2022, just as betas start to increase on the ICG side and get to terminal levels, that's obviously going to slow or put pressure on the pricing as we go into '23.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But some of the other important drivers of the growth will be the annualization of the rate hikes that happened late in the year, and so that will be a plus in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you'll also see, as I mentioned earlier, some of the rate increases that we anticipate outside of the U.S. and given our mix, that will benefit us in 2023.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then there'll be volume that will contribute to that NII growth, particularly as we continue to see good momentum, which we anticipate on the Card side.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The offset will be the Legacy franchise, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, as those exits occur, as the wind downs continue, as I mentioned earlier, that revenue mix does skew towards NII and so we'll have to grow over that, and we will grow over that to kind of get to the target that we've set.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So those are the puts and takes.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions at this time.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will now turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you everyone for joining us today.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: If you have any follow-up questions, please reach out to IR.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and a very happy New Year to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I hope you all had a good break.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At Citi, we are back at it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Given the notable items, and our new financial reporting structure, we have a lot to cover today so I right to it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: 2023 was a foundational year in which we made substantial progress simplifying Citi and executing the strategy we laid out at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that said the fourth quarter was clearly very disappointing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Today I will provide a high-level view on our progress in 2023, discuss our Q4 results, and finish with our priorities for 2024.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We know 2024 is critical as we prepare to enter the next phase of our journey and we are completely focused on delivering our medium-term targets and our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, turning to what we accomplished in terms of executing our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you can see on slide 5, in 2023, we saw a record year for Services, where we maintained our #1 ranking among large institutions in TTS with client wins up 27% and a sustained win/loss rate above 80%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have now gained over 100bps in share in Securities Services since 2021.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Wealth, we added an estimated $21 billion in net new assets during the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In USPB we enjoyed our sixth consecutive quarter of growth, and we began to see the early fruits of our investments in key talent in Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In September, we began the most consequential series of changes to the organization and the running of our firm since the aftermath of the financial crisis.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We restructured around five core, interconnected businesses to align our organization to our business strategy and to provide greater transparency into their performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You now can see in our financials the full-year returns and P&L by business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While they are all impacted by investments and Transformation expense, it is clear where we have work to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The simplification of our organization structure will conclude at the end of Q1 and will result in over $1 billion of run-rate saves from the net elimination of approximately five thousand roles, mainly managers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As Mark will detail, this will contribute to the reduction of our expens simplification, benefits of the Transformation, stranded costs and other productivity efforts, we expect to eliminate 20 thousand positions ex-Mexico, resulting in over $2 billion in run-rate saves.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Simplification is also enabling Citi to be more client focused and less bureaucratic.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Realizing the synergies between our five businesses is one of the key drivers to achieving our medium-term revenue targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With this new structure, I am holding my business leaders accountable for enhancing connectivity across clients and products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In addition, having a Chief Client Officer acts to ensure we are disciplined in bringing the full power of our franchise to our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have now completed the divestitures of 9 of our 14 international consumer franchises and have wound down nearly 70% of our total retail loans and deposits in Russia, Korea and China.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have restarted the sales process in Poland and are well down the execution path for the Mexico IPO next year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are exiting marginal businesses such as Munis and a subset of distressed debt trading to focus on our core strengths and allocate our capital with rigor.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Without doubt, all these changes are difficult, but they are necessary.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At the same time, we continued to invest in our Transformation, risk and control environment and data architecture.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We were pleased to have closed the FX consent order with the Federal Reserve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are committed to fulfilling the expectations of our regulators given the unique role we play in the global financial system.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The modernization of our tech infrastructure is proceeding at pace allowing us to deliver new capabilities to our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: During the year, we consolidated trading and reporting platforms, and retired 6% of our legacy applications for the second year in a row.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These enhancements dovetail with significant investments in our businesses, such as hiring commercial bankers to capture share, improving the digital payment capabilities we offer throughout our global network, and automating processes for our Securities Services clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It was also a year where we upgraded talent with key internal promotions supplemented by selective external hires, including Andy Sieg.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The simplified reporting structure has been embraced by colleagues who feel empowered by the new structure to serve clients and drive value for shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Earlier this week we disclosed additional external headwinds some of which materialized in the second half of December including a $1.3 billion reserve build related to transfer risk stemming from exposures to Argentina and Russia.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also saw a nearly $900 million negative revenue impact as a result of the larger than expected devaluation of the Argentine currency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These items, together with the $1.7 billion FDIC assessment, drove this quarter to a negative EPS of $1.16.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While these items are clearly very painful, they are quite In terms of the performance of our five businesses, while Services was the most impacted by the Argentine devaluation, the underlying growth remains very strong, driven by share gains and client wins.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, Services revenues were up 16% for the full year despite the impact of the Argentine devaluation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In TTS, cross-border transactions were up 15% and AUC/AUA in Securities Services were up by close to $3 trillion for the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Markets, our Fixed Income results were disappointing as we saw a significant slowdown in December particularly in Rates and FX.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Markets was also impacted by the Argentine devaluation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This franchise is well-positioned with our corporate clients and we continue to take actions to improve returns, whether by redeploying capital to high-return We had a decent quarter in Equities, particularly in derivatives, and saw growth in prime balances, an area we have been focusing on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While activity picked up in the fourth quarter with revenues up 22%, overall Banking revenue continued to be impacted by a weak wallet globally.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Investment Banking was up slightly for the year and we finished 2023 as the fifth leading franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We certainly aspire to be better.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are seeing improved confidence among CEOs and we like our pipeline, but of course the timing for a robust recovery is uncertain.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The share gains we have made in areas such as healthcare put us in a good position when this business turns more decisively.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While investment activity in Asia rebounded with quarterly revenues up 21%, and Wealth at Work up 18% where it needs to be.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy is off to a fast start.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In addition to resetting the expense base and ensuring the right utilization of our balance sheet, he is tightening our focus to build fee-based revenue streams and investment AUM.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With $100 trillion in new wealth to be created by 2030, mainly in North America and Asia, and with our clients holding $5.4 trillion away from us, we have an important ability here to drive growth and returns to where they should be.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: USPB was a bright spot with every product up double-digits in the quarter compared to last year, including Retail Banking which benefitted from a rebound in mortgage origination.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: New and refreshed products have increased customer engagement as we see the benefits of the investments we have made.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In Cards, IEB and ANR continued their growth, reflecting a more balanced lend vs spend mix and falling payment rates.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As expected, loss rates are now back to pre-pandemic levels driven by customers in the lower FICO bands.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the full year, in 2023, we grew revenues ex-divestitures by 4%, although the Argentine devaluation essentially prevented us from reaching the $78 billion revenue mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We met our full-year expense guidance and we increased our CET1 ratio to 13.3% during the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew our Tangible Book Value per share by 6% to $86.19 and returned $6 billion in capital to our shareholders in the form of common dividends and share buybacks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We remain committed to continuing to return capital to investors through both of these channels.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As I reflect on the year, I also want to note that we were a source of strength for the system and clients during a volatile period for the banking sector and geopolitically.

speaker: Jane Fraser
