sentence: And I am very proud of how our people around the world performed during challenging times.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: 2024 looks to be similar to 2023 in terms of the macro environment with moderating rates and inflation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect to see growth slowing globally, with the U.S. well positioned to withstand a run-of-the-mill recession should one materialize.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With a strong balance sheet, ample liquidity and diligent risk management, we are well positioned to support our clients through whatever environment comes to pass.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Moreover, we think environments like these play to our strengths.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Given how far we are down the path of our simplification and divestures, 2024 will be a turning point as we will be able to completely focus on the performance of our five businesses and our Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I recognize the importance of this year and am highly confident we will see the benefits of the actions we have taken through the momentum of our businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Backed by investments in key products, we believe we can continue to grow revenues ex-divestitures by 4 to 5% over the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Overall, we remain confident in our ability to adapt to the evolving capital and macro environments to reach our medium-term return targets and return capital to our shareholders, whilst continuing the investments needed in our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that, I would like to turn it over to Mark and then we would be delighted, as always, to take your questions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the fourth quarter and full-year firmwide financial results, focusing on year-over-year our medium-term return target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The presentation of our results reflects the changes we have made in conjunction with our organizational simplification including reporting Legacy Franchises and Corporate/Other in All Other.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, before I go into the results, let me walk you through some of the notable items that impacted the quarter that were included in the 8K we recently filed.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the top right of slide 7, we show these items on a pre-tax basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The FDIC special assessment of approximately $1.7 billion related to the regional bank failures in March.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This impacted expenses in All Other.

speaker: Mark Mason

sentence: Embedded in this guidance includes an elevated level of severance, as well as additional potential costs related to the organizational simplification totaling approximately $700 million to $1 billion.

sentence: discussed in the past, there are three drivers that will reduce our expenses.

sentence: Organizational simplification including the reduction of management layers.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Eliminating stranded costs as we take additional actions to reduce excess overhead in light of the exit markets.

speaker: Mark Mason

sentence: We expect the combination of these three drivers to reduce our headcount by a net 20 thousand, excluding Mexico, and generate a net run rate save of $2 to $2.5 billion over the medium term.

sentence: From a credit perspective, we expect credit costs to be a function of portfolio mix, volumes and macro assumptions.

sentence: Our first question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

Question And Answer

sentence: Your line is now open.

Question And Answer
Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I looked in detail at the earnings presentation, especially slide 4, and I think the question is, on many people's minds, I count 12 restructurings at Citigroup.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I count 12 restructurings that have failed at Citigroup.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: You might disagree with the number 12, It could be 5, it could be 8, it could be 12, it could be more, but I've not spoken to one person of any investor who would say that Citi has succeeded on its prior restructuring.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, the question is, why is this time different?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Number one, who is this new and improved Citigroup.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Number two, why aren't expenses down even move, especially when few people that I talk to think you'll hit your revenue target?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And three, Jane, what is your conviction level of getting to that 11% to 12% RoTCE in 2025 or 2026?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, thank you very much indeed, Mike.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'll start with, who is Citi?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Citi is, I'm delighted to say, finally simple.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: At Investor Day, I set out a vision to be the preeminent banking partner for clients with cross border needs.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That vision was based on five core interconnected businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We set off on a deliberate path to get there, and over the last three years we've done so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Page 4 is who we are today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are five interconnected businesses; no more, no less.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have our organization that now aligns with those five businesses, and this enables us to focus on two priorities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The first is improving the performance and the returns of those five core businesses, so that we can meet the medium-term RoTCE target we laid out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the second is on addressing our regulatory issues through the transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I would also be, I need to note that I fully recognize that 2024 is an inflection year, Mike.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I and the management team are accountable to deliver.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that you and our investors have the transparency you need to hold us accountable.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, why is this time different?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, it's not lost on me that there's been many attempts in the past to change this firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I and the management are fully committed to transforming this company for the long term and we are addressing the issues that have held us back in the past.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you've got proof points of the last three years where we've made a lot of tough decisions and we have put through a tremendous amount of change to get to the simple Citi that we are today.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We completely reset our strategy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we now have a significantly more focused business and operating model.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've announced the most consequential set of changes to our organizational model, and frankly, from my perspective, more importantly, how we run the bank, since the financial crisis, aimed at simplifying the bank and increasing accountability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've seen moved quickly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're on track with our execution of this effort.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it will generate over $1 billion of run rate saves the end of the first quarter, purely from the organization efforts that we've put in that we announced in September.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've done this while investing and I think this is another difference.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've invested heavily in our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And while that was catalyzed by our consent orders, these investments will ultimately deliver benefits from automation, from well governed data, from consolidated platforms.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also have made significant investments in our business to support the 4% to 5% revenue growth and to ensure client momentum.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And those investments have helped us expand our product suite, invest in digital capabilities, automate our processes, capture synergies through the client organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've also brought in some incredible external talent in key strategic areas, including Andy, to lead Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we now have a good balance between experienced Citi people and external talent with fresh perspectives through multiple layers of the organization.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we are doing things the right way, we're doing it for the long term and we're moving with urgency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will need and are spending the money that we need to, to address our regulatory requirements, but that's already embedded in our path to the 11% to 12% RoTCE in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And this already feels like a different bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have more work to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I recognize 2024 is a critical year, and as I said, the decks are much clearer now, so that we can focus on two imperatives: improving our business performance and executing the transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Neither is an entirely linear path as we've seen over the last three years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We all know that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We get we have to build our credibility.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're committed to doing so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we are providing far more transparency around the business performance, so investors have a better sense of how we're doing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I and my management team, to your final question, are fully accountable for getting this all done.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We will.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, expenses?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thanks, Jane.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And why aren't expenses down more?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think to your point, Jane, we've been investing in the franchise both on the front-end, and importantly, on the transformation and the risk and controls.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I would point out is that, in 2023, we delivered expenses of $54.3 billion ex the FDIC charge.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is the guidance that we gave.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I also highlight that we also included $780 million associated with the restructuring charge.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That is more than I had articulated in the way of guidance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, the capacity that we created through our efforts through the year, we use that in a smart way.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We use that to fund the org simplification cost, so that we can realize the savings down the line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're going to continue to manage our expenses in a disciplined and smart fashion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That means spending what we need to spend on the transformation and risk and controls, but driving greater efficiencies and productivities along the way to ensure we get to that 11% to 12%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And to your point, if revenues are to come down or come in lower than expected, we'll adjust the expenses accordingly.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Glenn Schorr with Evercore.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, you're clearly making a lot of progress and I hate to like, ask this question too early, but I think it is important.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Your expense guidance is good, your revenue guide is good, and you have your arms around the expenses.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: The question I have is, how do you think about balancing that near term profitability improvement that we all want desperately with making sure you do make the right investments?

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Because if you look around the world there's a lot of places to grow, whether it be a branch network, or the wealth management aspirations that you have, or the digital investments.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So, how do we know that all the right future investments are being made while you extract costs in all the good ways that you've been doing?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, thanks, Glenn.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I guess, I'll start, and Jane, feel free to add in on it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, it is a balancing act, right, and we do look at each of our five core businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We obviously are clear on the strategy, but where's the growth?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Where are the return opportunities associated with them?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And how do we ensure we're deploying resources after them in order to deliver for the client and deliver on those returns over time?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We have to juxtapose that against the required investment to modernize our operations and we're making those trade-offs on a regular basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But importantly, when we do invest to capture those growth opportunities, we're trying to be agile about it, which means if those opportunities don't play out in the way we're expecting because the cycle just doesn't mature or materialize in that fashion, we've got to be disciplined enough to dial them back, and that's what you've seen over the past year plus, is that we've been investing in the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Where we didn't see the upside that we anticipated, we dialed back that spend, right, and that's the type of iterative process, if you will, Glenn, that we're putting in place to ensure that on the other side of this, we're still positioned to capture growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Investment Banking, for example, we have invested in healthcare, in technology, building out to prepare ourselves for when that market rebounds.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We feel good about that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've done similar things in the way of our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're investing heavily in our TTS franchise to ensure we can remain competitive there, so it's that type of discipline that's required.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is sometimes a trade-off, but it's one that we've been very focused on being smart about.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I appreciate that.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Maybe a quickie on Services.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: Obviously, up 16% and a record is great.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: I don't know if you've dimensionalized how much was rate versus new business, but you have good core business momentum and a pipeline of won, but not yet funded.

speaker: Glenn Schorr
sentence: So I guess the question is, where can Services be over, let's say, the next two years in terms of growth, while rates come down, yet your businesses is winning new wins?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You want me to, sure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah and I'll jump in, too.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let's maybe start with TTS.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: When we think about the performance of TTS, which, as we say, the growth this year up 19% ex-Argentina, came from a combination of both rates and the strong business actions we've taken.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see that in the different drivers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Cross-border was up 23%, commercial cards up 8%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the growth prospects, we've generated 22% in average revenue growth, from 21 to 23, well ahead of the Investor Day guidance we had of high-single digits.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That was not just because of the rate cycle.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It obviously helped.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we certainly expect to grow revenues at mid-single digit now as we lap the prior periods that benefited from those rate increases, and that's going to come from a few different areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: One, the focus on our fee strategy, where we're capitalizing on strong client engagement, market-leading client solutions, and we're delivering on a lot of the different growth initiatives that we've been investing in across all our client segments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll continue optimizing our deposit book and bringing in high-quality deposits.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in a lower rate environment, GDP is typically higher, so you'd expect to see some higher growth in our capital-efficient payment volumes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You'll see us continuing to acquire new clients and deepen relationships with existing clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd point to our confidence here, 27% increase in our new client acquisition this year and a sustained win/loss ratio of 82% on new deals, and that was across different client segments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And revenues from these clients just continues to ramp up, as we expand across the different geographies and product suites with them.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you'll also continue to see us investing in the infrastructure and platforms we've been doing, launching new innovative products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're seeing momentum from some of the things we've recently done: Citi Token Services, Payment Express, 24/7 Clearing, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think, the main takeaway from TTS is that we'll continue to invest in it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect to see strong client momentum.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been getting consistently good client feedback regarding our capabilities, so we expect to see good global growth that will certainly help as the rate cycle comes down.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it is a crown jewel for a reason.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then, just quickly on Securities Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think where we're seeing, we mentioned, we've got a number of marquee wins there across all the client segments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That pipeline is both investors and issuers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And one of the core strategies that Okan put in place was to grow share with the US-based asset managers.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We were at 2.6% share in 2020; we're now at 4.3%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And a lot of the growth in the pipeline has been coming, not only from our global network names, but also from the marquee players in the US asset manager space.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think that's our ability to connect our capabilities that gives these players huge efficiencies for our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, anything I've missed there?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You know I love this business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you should rightfully so, high-returning business, great growth prospects.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: To answer one of your questions, Glenn, about half of the NII growth, we could attribute to interest rates.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And about half, I'd say, is business action, so us working with the clients to drive that momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, if you think about the noninterest revenue, for Services, they're up about 20% in the quarter year-over-year if you exclude the impact of the Argentina devaluation, and up 7% on a full year basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, good momentum in the noninterest revenue growth as well.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from John McDonald with Autonomous Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, was hoping to ask you, how are you thinking about the pacing of capital build?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Obviously, the Basel III proposals are out there, but they could change, of course.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Even if they don't change, you have a couple of years to leg into those with the phase-ins and perhaps some mitigation opportunities.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: How should we think about you kind of building capital, given all those variables and the ability to buy back some stock along the way as you mentioned earlier?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Sure, so look, John, obviously the Basel III proposal's still out there and under discussion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've been very vocal about the potential impact of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've also been very disciplined about how we've been managing our capital.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've built that over 30 basis points over the course of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've seen us actively manage that through the year, and we're going to continue to do that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We obviously generate earnings that contribute to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We want to continue to drive growth across the business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're trading at a 0.5 times book, where we can, we want to buy back as much as we can in shares.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we try to be disciplined about that over the past couple of quarters, doing that as a modest level.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You heard me say, we're going to do that again this quarter at a modest level, but we have to be thoughtful about what those headwinds might look like.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're actively working what mitigation actions we have to put in place, should it turn out closer to the way the current proposal sits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, it's an ongoing active management that tries to balance servicing our client needs, with, obviously, holding a responsible amount of capital in light of the uncertainty that's out there, and with an eye towards buybacks where we can do that.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And just as an expense follow-up, I wasn't clear.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Has the transformation spend peaked, when you think about what you'll spend on transformation this year versus last year?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And are the transformation benefits starting to kick in at this point?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So to be clear, we're going to continue to spend whatever we need to spend on the transformation and on risk and controls.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we did see a tick up this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've got a plan for 2024, and if we've got to spend a bit more than we spent this year, we're going to spend more.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's what the plan calls for, and so that's what we'll do.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's inside of the number that I've given you for guidance, all right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that's important for us.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think it will drive, obviously, operational improvement and saves down the line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It is part of the $2 billion to $2.5 billion, but that is the early stage, if you will, of the transformation spend paying back.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think as we talked about at Investor Day, frankly, we'll continue to see expense benefits beyond the medium term from some of this transformation investment that we've been making.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, I would think of the medium term as the start of the benefits that we'll see from the investments we've been making in transformation and risk and controls.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think, Mark, you're spot on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we'll continue making the investments we need to in the transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a multi-year journey, as we've always been clear around this, ultimately, with benefits to the shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And more of the expense saves that we've been talking about are, I'd separate out transformation from sort of the operating expense base of our businesses, which we want to make sure is as productive and as effective as possible.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the types of benefits we're seeing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is the second year in a row that we've retired 6% of our legacy platform base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you've heard me talking about moving 20 of our cash equity platforms on to 1, 6 reporting ledgers on to 1, 11 sanctioned platforms on to 1.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we start seeing some of the benefits of those come in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Other things, we automated independent price verification for 90% of our prioritized fixed income and equity securities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's reduced manual controls.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's improved valuation consistency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's also had an impact on the efficiency of the business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've loaded 98% of our prioritized wholesale and consumer data into two authorized repositories.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That will also begin to start having some benefits for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So there is a cumulative effect that is beginning to build now from all the work we've done, but it will take some time to really kick into the, as Mark said, when you really feel it, is a few years out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But we'll keep giving you the proof points of things as we're going, so it's not a just trust us that i s coming, you'll begin to see it build.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey, good afternoon.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Mark, maybe just to follow up on the expense, slide 22, where you talk about $2 billion to $2.5 billion of expense saves.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I guess I'm struggling with the numbers there.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I think if you look at exit and wind- down markets, you're probably close to $2 billion in numbers there.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And maybe the stranded costs, you can't get all of that out.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: You're doing about severance is $700 million to $1 billion in 2024.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: So doesn't seem like there's a ton of actual cost saves in that number.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And just maybe I'm wrong, if you could just kind of walk me through the numbers embedded in there and if there's, you've kind of eluded to more to come beyond the intermediate term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I think the thing I'd point out to you is a couple things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One, obviously, we're forecasting revenue growth over this period of time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, there's going to be volume-related expenses associated with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second thing I'd point out, as I just mentioned to the prior question, is that we're continuing to invest in risk and controls and in the transformation over this period of time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, what you see is there's an increase in expenses associated with at least those two things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And that's offset by the savings that we're starting to generate, particularly from the org simplification that Jane has talked about, as well as from the stranded cost reduction that will continue to play out, as well as from some of the rightsizing of businesses that we've referenced in some of the prepared remarks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, important to think about, there are headwinds and tailwinds that kind of net down to this $2 billion to $2.5 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the final point that I'd make is if I look at this medium-term number of $51 billion to $53 billion that still has Mexico in it and one of the other pages we'd point to, expenses around Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But because of where we are, we'll be in the IPO process, that's still going to be part of this expense base, and so you can't lose sight of that.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Well, that's an important clarification that the $2 billion to $2.5 billion includes revenue related volume growth, so that's helpful.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then, just maybe the other, on the slides talking about revenue targets.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: One of the big numbers not talked about was Markets.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: How are you thinking, volatility has come in, macro picture s getting better, maybe that mutes volatility, how do you think about that business in 2024 as it relates to your guidance?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, it's a tough business to forecast, certainly, for a full year, and in some instances for a quarter, and so, we've basically kind of backed that out but we assume markets kind of flat to modestly down, but we've backed it out, and it's roughly flat.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Not of the $80 billion to $81 billion, right, you see the guidance of NIR ex- Markets and NII ex-Markets, so in the $80 billion to $81 billion, we've assumed it roughly flat.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank of America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Morning, afternoon, Jane.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just wanted to follow up on something I think Mark said at the end of his very first response around, it's very hard in my seat to figure out whether you're going to grow revenues or shrink revenues given the macro.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Should we take it based on what you've said today as we look into 2026 getting to that 11% RoTCE, if for whatever reason, revenue falls short and you feel good about the expense flex to mitigate that headwind?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's Jane, obviously.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I want to just jump in on one bit, which is we are committed and we're very confident around the 4% to 5% revenue growth rate, so there isn't any backing away from that number.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that's in various macro environments, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as we look across the different businesses, and the projections we have, we're confident around that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Obviously, if there's a very adverse macro environment, et cetera, we've got other levers we can take, but Mark, let me pass it to you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And by no means was I trying to suggest that we weren't confident in the forecast for the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you think about the strategy and the strength of those five core businesses, we've got a lot of conviction around that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that said, as you point out, Jane, under a circumstance where that doesn't play out, there are obviously volume-related incentive comp expenses and the like that would naturally come down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'd ensure that they came down with the revenue decline or shortfall.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then we'd recalibrate other spend, other investments, spend not related to risk and controls and transformation, but other investments across the platform, we'd recalibrate accordingly.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Well said.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just what I needed.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And one quick question.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: As we think about rightsizing the Markets business, there have been headlines around the muni and the distressed business that you've gotten out.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Is there a risk where the Markets business becomes too small and you lag the scale to be sort of efficient and relevant in certain, or just across the breadth of, be it, fixed income or equities?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just if you can talk about that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The short answer is no.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If you think about our Markets business, we have four businesses, each of which are around sort of $4 billion or so in size.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You have our global FX network, where we're typically number one in any year, just given the strength, and particularly, the corporate client base we've set off.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Rates, typically top three.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Together, these are two of the largest macro pools within FICC.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the spread products, we've been putting our financing and securitization business as part of our simplification, fully within Markets, so that we've created a unified, scaled spreads product business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then finally, equities, where we're focused on improving our prime offering, building balances.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We still have a way to go obviously in that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Prime balances we're pleased they were nicely up this year, driven by client momentum.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're a leading equities derivative franchise.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, you do have these four core businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I'd go back to our big point of differentiation and why we feel we're well-positioned.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a very differentiated corporate client base and very strong partnerships between our core Markets franchise, TTS, and Banking and Securities Services, and that helps us in FX, in commodities and in rates around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, Markets is important both in terms of its leadership, but also, how it fits into the strengths that we have from this simpler Citi of those five core interconnected businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've demonstrated solid returns in the past.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think a lot of the actions we've been taking will help drive returns in the future.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you should be getting confidence when you see the discipline we're putting on to RWA, 5.3%, getting close that target, we said at Investor Day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're moving that up to 6%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The exits we've got of nonstrategic businesses shows our focus on efficiency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've also been doing some good investments in our technology, and that's getting us into a good place there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think, don't be concerned about the shrinking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're just making sure that it really plays to our strengths and we optimize the returns.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Mark, can you share with us, in your revenue guide, in the net interest income, I know you mentioned it's going to be lower and part of it is due to lower interest rates.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Some of your peers have come out with their guides using the forward curve in their net interest income forecast which includes the Fed in our country, six cuts.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you give us some color what kind of rate environment, I know you said lower rates, but any insights around that guide?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, I think what I'd point you to is in the range of the $80 billion to $81 billion, we're assuming three to six cuts, right.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've got a range there and the reason I described it like that is that, if you think about our IRE, as we've shown it in the Qs before, we're positioned such that, with 100 basis point move, parallel shift in rate across the curve, the US dollar impact would only be a couple hundred million dollars, all right, and so, to the negative, obviously, but it's a couple hundred million dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so as we think about that forecast, and as I mentioned, NII being down a bit, that covers kind of three to six cuts over the course of 2024, likely back-loaded, but that's what's in there.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Very good, I appreciate that.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then, Jane, more of a qualitative question rather than quantitative, but obviously, there's numerous moving parts of the strategies that you guys are executing on, exiting businesses, downsizing businesses.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Especially on the downsizing, I think you guys mentioned, the head count of about 20,000 coming down.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: How do you keep the morale of the organization elevated when you have these types of tough decisions that you all have to make?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, we've also got areas which are growing, so that does help, too.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a diversified portfolio here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we're very mindful of, that there is a human impact of the decisions that we're making.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're trying to be as transparent with our people, as we are with our investors about what we need to do, why we're doing it, what to expect and laying that out so people understand the logic behind the decisions, and then they understand what the decisions are as quickly as they can.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think that's the most humane way to do this.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I'm sorry to prolong the call.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Thank you for all your color.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Just one more question.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Jane, when will you feel comfortable giving us a buyback outlook that's beyond just fourth quarter?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I know you still have a little bit of ways to go, but you do have 100 basis point buffer to your minimum.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I know Basel III endgame is still out there, and I'm sure that reducing risk just doesn't mean expenses, but also reducing your or being mindful of your RWA footprint.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And given where your stock is relative to book, when will you be more comfortable about giving sort of a longer-term outlook that was underpinning your RoTCE target with regards to the buyback?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Erika, it's a great question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's one I ask myself every morning when I get up, because given where we trade, the value for our shareholders of buybacks is enormous.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And Mark and I are very committed to doing so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We also know that we're building our credibility.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I don't want to say things that we're not going to deliver against, although we're going to have to change.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think it's one of the values that we're really trying to adhere to very strongly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And with the NPR, I think we'll get a better sense about this soon.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The comment period just got extended, and we want to see what that is.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think you've all heard us at the Senate banking hearings with our concerns about it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I very much hope that it is either completely revised or very materially, so it doesn't have a negative impact on the economy and the US banking system competitiveness, the move for more business to the shadow banks, which I think has got to a point, which is not healthy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, we're going to wait and see where that comes out before we give it to you, but I would be asking exactly the same question in your shoes as well.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I think that it was very helpful that you said on this public forum where you're trying to build credibility, because as I think about what long-only investors have been dying to see from Citi in terms of the previous leadership was that sort of awareness.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I think just having that awareness recognition will be very important to investors, so thank you.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I want to follow up on the Russian exposure on page 34.

speaker: Operator
sentence: It looks like you guys have taken a really good whack on the net investment.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And you also highlighted how the CTA would be capital neutral, even if you did have to write that down.

speaker: Operator
sentence: But what about the remaining exposure?

speaker: Operator
sentence: And just like how prime are you responsible for some of these unremittable corporate derivatives?

speaker: Operator
sentence: I think a lot of us don't understand that type of exposure.

speaker: Operator
sentence: And is there risk to you going forward, or could you hopefully clear it back from the outside exposure going forward?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yeah, actually, I also want to kind of take a bigger picture answer to that before I turn it to Mark.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Because I would have thought that's a question that is on everybody's minds, particularly given the firm's overall low level of returns and our headline numbers this quarter about what we've been doing with Russia and Argentina, the sort of bigger strategic question behind it, and then we'll get to your specifics on the Russia front.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If you think about Citi, we have a differentiated global business model, and that means we're committed to the countries in which our multinational clients operate over the long run.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, that means we hold long-term capital in those countries, upon which we generate solid returns through the cycle.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And let me just point to our leading Services and FX businesses are the heart of that network, and they're generating double-digits, as you can see.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With that footprint comes a set of risks.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, I think of it in terms of credit, currency, transferability of capital.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've proven our ability to manage those risks consistently over a long period of time.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And with respect to the Q4 currency and transfer items, while the timing was unknown and we've highlighted those risks in our disclosures for a couple of years, I'd say, Russia is rather unique.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a war, and for us, a highly unusual liquidation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've navigated it very well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've executed our wind-down in an orderly way with very low losses for our clients and very low losses for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our remaining net assets are now 100% reserved against.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think similarly, if I just touch on Argentina for a minute, because I'm sure, folks have got a few questions on that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Similarly, over the last several years, we've de-risked our business model there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't have a consumer bank, so we've really reduced down our emerging markets exposures to just our institutional presence, focused on the multinational clients, you've heard us talk about that, and select high-grade local clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: If you look at Argentina, it's a very good business for us over the cycle.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And even after the impacts of Q4, we had less than $5 million in credit losses in Argentina over a 10-year period.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's remarkable, $5 million over 10 years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of the currency risk, we all have to book revenues, the official rate versus the parallel market rate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are able to partially but not fully hedge the exposure, but we would certainly always take economic decisions on the business we do and did mindful of likely devaluations and capital controls.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the reserve is a reserve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It centers on the ability to convert and transfer capital as per US banking laws, so I just want to put part of things at this quarter into that context.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have a global business model.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's heavily focused on high-grade multinational clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our track record for managing the various risks associated with our global network has been very strong.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think you're seeing us with a very conservative and reserved profile.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, what would you add?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah, very quickly on the Russia point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know and as the slide points out, we've continued to bring our exposure down there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's down to $6.5 billion, it's down 13% from the previous year and a third from 2021.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've brought down the consumer loans, the consumer deposits in a significant way there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And essentially, what's left is that we have a custody business and we're holding corporate dividends that are our clients' proceeds we re unable to pay those out by law, by regulation, and so we have to hold those and so that's what's being referenced in the slide when we say unremittable Russia corporate dividends.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, that is not a risk of loss for us, but we're unable to kind of clear those because of the state of play in Russia at this stage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, just separately in credit cards.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You and a lot of your peers expect losses to go up from here, but most of you are saying, they're going to peak at this year, including you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Just what gives you confidence that the card losses will peak this year is it just getting back to that a little bit of a normalized level?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Is it some tightening that you've done?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What's driving that confidence, looking out this year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Because you're probably seeing a step-up coming still, right?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We gave a forecast on 2024 (sic), as you point out, to what the full-year estimate for NCLs will be for both Branded and for Retail Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: What I'd point out is, you can see actually on the slide how there was a dip in loss rates during the COVID period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so to some extent, what we're seeing is kind of a catch up of those, as those portfolios go through a longer maturation than what you'd normally see in a cards portfolio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On top of that, we've been originating new card.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: You've noticed our acquisitions have grown, so we obviously have new card loans, and those are going through a much normal maturation period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, as we look at the early buckets and the delinquencies that are playing out, we've got a pretty good sense for when we would expect those to peak and at what level.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we think they'll peak inside of 2024, so that's captured in that average forecast that we've given.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We haven't made material changes to our underwriting.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, there is mix evolution that happens.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Transactors, we have a number of transactors that have kind of come on to our portfolio and are in the mix of our Branded portfolio as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, anyway, those are the drivers that give us confidence and inform the trajectory that we're talking about here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Ryan Kenny with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: So, I have a question on quantitative tightening.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Wondering if you have any early thoughts on how Citi's positioned if the Fed ends QT early?

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Is that a material catalyst for you, and would that help you hit your revenue targets even sooner?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Again, I mean, when I think about our interest rate exposure, and for US dollar in particular, we showed it in our last Q, we'll show it in this Q.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For a 100 basis point move in a parallel shift, we're looking at probably a negative $1.6 billion or so, but important to point out that the US dollar component of that is only a couple hundred million dollars.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Similarly, if rates moved in the other way, positive of 100 basis points, there'd be a small movement as it relates to US dollar exposure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So our US dollar exposure is relatively neutral, again, assuming a static balance sheet, a parallel shift in the curve.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, we're kind of neutral relative to rates moving in either direction and, therefore, the impact there.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Then, there's a lot of optimism and debate around capital markets rebound.

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: Are you seeing that?

speaker: Ryan Kenny
sentence: And can you help update us on Investment Banking pipeline across M&A, ECM, DCM?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We certainly had a much more constructive market environment to the end of 2023.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Interest rate spreads and volatility at lows for the year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equity prices are high.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think we view this as a helpful foundation for activity to accelerate in 2024, assuming the tailwinds persist.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And speaking of our own pipeline, the breadth, the depth, the quality of it's very sound.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's higher than it was pre-COVID.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So when markets are constructive, we expect to move these opportunities forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we're hearing a lot more confidence from the CEOs, CFOs around this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And yeah, we're looking at our own side.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As you know, we've been investing in some higher-growth areas, so we get a good balance between our traditionally strong sectors as well as high-growth areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've been seeing some very good momentum in healthcare and technology, as well as areas of traditional strength, which is energy and industrial.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think we feel very confident in the recovery in DCM.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The beginnings of one in LevFin.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And so, cautiously optimistic here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I wouldn't say that it's going to accelerate enormously and with incredible speed, but I think we're feeling much better about the foundation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mark, anything you'd add?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I completely agree.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from Scott Siefers with Piper Sandler.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: Have you all assumed any revenue attrition just related to the reduction in force?

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: And I guess just broadly, how might that be embedded in the 2024 revenue guidance?

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: And I guess just at a top level, maybe just a shot or two on...

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Sorry, Scott, I didn't hear what it was.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think the phone line cut out.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The revenue attrition?

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: I'm sorry.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: Yeah, just curious if you have assumed any revenue attrition related to the reduction in force over the coming year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think a lot of the moves that we've made from the organization simplification, so the 5,000 or so roles we talked about, they're mainly managerial roles.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And they've mainly impacted the functions and the geographies, not nearly so much the revenue from revenue generators.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the other piece is with the client organization, we're actually putting much more time into the hands of our people to drive revenue forward, so I think what we're looking at here is getting rid of areas of bureaucracy and where we've been too complicated, where we can drive efficiency whilst preserving our frontline and encouraging them to be as revenue-productive and delivering the full force of the firm to the client.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I like to see the opposite actually.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: And then, Mark, can you discuss for a second maybe, just broadly, the flow of expenses through the year?

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: I know that they should begin to decline towards the end, but what happens between now and then?

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: Do they hold kind of flattish with a core rate, or would there be any normal course of business growth?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think what I'd say is that, you should expect it in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'd likely see an uptick in our total expenses relative to the fourth, in part because, as Jane has mentioned, we anticipate that there'll be more to the org simplification and, therefore, dollars associated with that in Q1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then, from there, I would expect that you see a downward trend through the fourth quarter.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: Perfect.

speaker: Scott Siefers
sentence: All right.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Vivek Juneja with JP Morgan.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: Couple of quick clarifications.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: On your NII guide, you talked about you're assuming three to six cuts.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: That's US, I presume, so are you assuming flat, unchanged rates outside the US since you have more sensitivity outside?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Modest declines outside, but yes declines outside as well, but not nearly of the magnitude of what we're talking about in the US.

speaker: Vivek Juneja
sentence: And then, Jane, to your point about the 20,000 head count cuts and I heard you just mentioned 5,000 from managerial positions, where are the rest 15,000 coming there?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So let me just be clear about where the ones that we've just done and that we're working on through the organization simplification.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So when I think about that effort, it will close at the end of the first quarter, as we said.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're expecting to get about $1 billion of run rate save from the org simplification work alone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That constitutes about 5,000 heads.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're just about to, at the end of this month, finish Phase 3, which will mean the first four layers of the organization have been addressed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That's been a net reduction of about 1,500 managers out of a total of 12,000 roles.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's about 13%, and these are mainly manager roles, as I talked about earlier.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Then, when we think about where are other expense opportunities on top of this, as Mark was talking about earlier, the stranded costs, we'll be completing the elimination of the stranded costs from the divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll be continuing, and you've seen us been continuing that, exiting marginal businesses and hobbies and the like and being very disciplined about that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got some businesses where we feel we need to right size the core expense base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy Sieg is going to be kicking off that in Wealth, and you'll begin to see some of the impact of that in the first quarter.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's off to a strong start.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then, we've got others where we'll be creating more utilities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've still got different fragmented activities across the firm that the organization simplification has highlighted.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll be aggregating those, creating utilities, or are consolidating some of those different functions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And that is before we get to, beginning to get benefits from the transformation, where there'll be efficiencies that come through.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll still have areas that we're investing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These are going to be, as we talked about, core business investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's going to be expense growth still in the top, from volume growth that we've got.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we will be investing in our transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And all of this is happening over the medium term to get us to the 11% to 12% RoTCE target we talked about.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that 20,000, it's the number that we estimate of the headcount.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I don't love thinking headcount.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I like thinking about expenses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think it's a more meaningful number.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So as Mark laid out in his presentation, we've got a net expense save that we're expecting to achieve from the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And these are the raft of different areas that will be contributing to it, and we're working hard at it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Steven Chubak with Wolfe Research.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Hi, thanks for taking my questions.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Really just some ticky-tack modeling questions on the revenue side.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Does the revenue guidance for the full year include any reduction in credit card late fees?

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And how large of a contributor is that to revenues overall at Citigroup?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So, let's see, so obviously, the proposal is out there and we've factored in what's knowable as it relates to that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We haven't given guidance externally on what that impact is, but we do believe there are offsets and mitigants that, over time, we'll be able to kind of bring into play.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so, a long-winded way of saying our revenue forecast does assume some basic level of late fee adjustment.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: Got it.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: And just on the earlier comments you made, Mark, around Services NII.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: I am struggling to reconcile the 50/50 NII contribution from rate and volume components, just given average loan to deposits were essentially flat year-on-year, NII grew $3 billion.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: It does imply a much larger contribution from rates.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: I know there's deposit funds transfer pricing and other noise.

speaker: Steven Chubak
sentence: So I was hoping maybe you could unpack that a little bit further.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, there are a lot of factors in there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's obviously, as well, the mix as it relates to what we have in the US versus outside of the US, so there are a number of factors there and probably too much to kind of take you through on the call here.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But we're happy to kind of follow up with you offline and take you through it.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our final question comes from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Yeah, just a clarification.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: When you said medium term on this call as it relates to employee reductions, expense savings, revenue targets, and 11% to 12% RoTCE, does medium term mean by 2026 or does it mean something different?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I will turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Thank you, everyone, for joining the call.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: If you have any follow-up questions, please contact IR.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Have a great day.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Thank you, Jenn, and a very good morning to everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I am going to start with the macro backdrop, and then walk you through our results for the full year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I will share some thoughts on the progress we are making executing our strategy and then conclude with why we have decided to adjust our 2026 return target.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We entered 2025 with strategic clarity and good momentum across all our businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: From the global macro perspective, economies have done a good job tolerating hikes from central banks, and inflation has clearly been receding.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While policies will certainly impact economic activity, whether in the form of tariffs or taxes, 2025 doesn’t look that different from 2024.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The U.S. remains at the heart of the macro picture.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Growth is not only being driven by the higher end consumer, but also by a strong, innovative corporate sector.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: China’s growth has been slower than expected but there is still the prospect of further stimulus.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Europe continues to underachieve.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And many emerging markets have re-emerged as bright spots, a trend which certainly benefits us given our global network and deep presence in countries such as India and throughout the Middle East and ASEAN.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I told you 2024 was a critical year and I am proud of what we accomplished and how our businesses performed.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We finished with a very strong fourth quarter, which Mark will detail shortly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: For the full year, our net income was up nearly 40% to $12.7 billion.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We exceeded our full-year revenue target with revenues up 5% ex-divestitures.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Fee revenue was up 17% and we saw a smaller impact from Argentina’s currency devaluation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We delivered expenses within our guidance and improved our efficiency ratio by 340 bps whilst increasing investment in our Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our RoTCE grew over 200 bps, albeit from a low level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our five core businesses each generated positive operating leverage for the full year, which we also achieved at the firm level.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Services was up 9% and had another record year, despite the lower rate environment, as a result of new mandates and our emphasis on fee growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew share in both TTS and Securities Services.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Capped by our best fourth quarter in a decade, Markets was up 6%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The performance of this franchise in a low-volatility year shows the benefits of our diversified product mix.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Equities was strong throughout and was up 26% in what was a record year for us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Banking was up 32% as we gained share across all three investment banking products.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we announced an innovative $25 billion private credit partnership with our longtime client Apollo.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Under Vis’ leadership, we expect to continue to gain on our competition in 2025 and beyond.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: 2024 was the turning point for Wealth, as we sharpened our focus on investments, right-sized the expense base, and improved the client experience.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Revenue was up 7% for the year, including fee growth of 18%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Citigold and Asia were particularly strong and Net New Investment Asset flows grew a very pleasing 40%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We attracted top talent throughout the year in Wealth, most recently bringing in Kate Moore as our CIO and Anne McCosker as our Head of Lending.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This business has tremendous potential with both new and existing clients, and we are really leaning into it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: USPB revenues were up 6% driven by borrowing across both card portfolios and by fee growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We announced a 10-year extension of our co-branded partnership with American Airlines, ensuring that this valuable relationship enters into its fifth decade.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: With the acquisition of the Barclays portfolio, we will become American Airlines’ exclusive partner in 2026 and we expect to deliver more value for our cardholders and higher returns for our shareholders as a result.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We grew our Tangible Book Value per share by 4% and ended 2024 with a CET1 Ratio of 13.6%, approximately 150 basis points above our regulatory capital requirement.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: After repurchasing $1 billion in common shares during the fourth quarter, we returned almost $7 billion in capital to our common shareholders in 2024.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Given how committed we are to returning capital, I am particularly pleased to announce that our Board authorized a $20 billion share repurchase program.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You can see the very tangible progress we are making in executing the strategy that we laid out at our Investor Day three years ago.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have materially simplified our firm since then.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We exited consumer businesses in nine countries, and near completion of our wind-downs in three and are on track to exit the final two.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This includes Banamex, which we legally separated from our institutional business in December.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are now fully focused on getting ready to IPO, with the timing heavily dependent on regulatory approvals and market conditions of course.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: To align our structure with our strategy, we went through a significant simplification of our organization, removing management layers and the regional construct.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This has accelerated decision making and made us a better partner to our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have strengthened our culture by better aligning compensation with our shareholders’ interests, enhancing our scorecards to ensure we are delivering for clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We attracted top industry talent throughout our organization and that includes new leaders around my table for Banking, Wealth and Technology.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have raised the bar on what we demand from each other and what we expect to deliver to our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have continued to innovate to improve the client experience and our efficiency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are now live with Citi Payments Express in 18 countries, and have converted four million retail bank customers to our Simplified Banking platform in the U.S. We accelerated our use of AI, arming 30,000 developers with tools to write code and launched two AI platforms to make 143,000 colleagues more efficient.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The investments we’re making to modernize our infrastructure, streamline processes and automate controls are changing how we run the bank.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We consolidated our balance sheet reporting to one unified ledger.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We implemented a cloud-based solution for risk analytics to better value trading assets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have closed out three long-standing consent orders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our capital, liquidity and reserves are robust.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our focused strategy, simpler structure and targeted client selection have all reduced our risk profile significantly.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have made considerable progress on our Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: While there are areas that are more advanced, there are others where we still have a lot more work to do, particularly around data and regulatory reporting, as last summer’s regulatory actions reinforced.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have reviewed the entire data program and made changes to its governance and structure as well as increased the level of investment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As CEO, I want this company set up for long-term success and to ensure that we have enough capacity to invest for that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of expense guidance therefore, most of the saves from the org simplification and stranded costs will be used to fund the additional investments we need to make this year in both Transformation and technology.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: As a result, we expect our total expenses in 2025 to be slightly below the 2024 level and to deliver another year of positive operating leverage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We expect our elevated expense level to be temporary and for it to keep coming down beyond 2025.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: However, when we take the required investments into account, we now expect our 2026 RoTCE to be between 10% and 11%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The 2026 RoTCE is a waypoint; it is not a destination.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Our intention is to continue to improve returns well above that level and we are accountable for doing so.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We are relentless in our determination to run the bank more efficiently, fulfill Citi’s potential and meet the expectations of our shareholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Before I turn it over to Mark, I’d like to acknowledge the catastrophic wildfires in Los Angeles.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Many of our clients and several of our colleagues have lost their homes and we will do whatever we can to help them recover from this devastating event.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: They and their loved ones are in all of our thoughts at Citi.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Thanks, Jane and good morning, everyone.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I am going to start with the fourth quarter and full-year financial results, focusing on year-over-year comparisons unless I indicate otherwise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I’ll also focus on our current expectations for 2025 and 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 7, we show financial results for the full firm, which reflect improved performance both in the quarter and the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, in the fourth quarter of last year, revenues were significantly impacted by Argentina currency devaluation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Adjusted revenues and non-interest revenues for the full firm and Services are shown in the appendix of the earnings presentation on slide 36.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This quarter we reported net income of $2.9 billion, EPS of $1.34 and an RoTCE of 6.1% on $19.6 billion of revenues, generating positive operating leverage for the firm and in each of our businesses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Total revenues were up 12%, driven by growth in each of our businesses and a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Net interest income excluding Markets was roughly flat, with growth in USPB and Wealth offset by declines in Corporate/Other and Banking.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Non-interest revenue excluding Markets was up 40%, driven by continued strong fee momentum across Services, Banking and Wealth along with lower partner payments in USPB as well as a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And total Markets revenues were up 36%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses were $13.2 billion, down 18%, largely driven by the absence of the FDIC special assessment and restructuring charge in the prior year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the impact of the FDIC special assessment and divestiture-related impacts, expenses were down 7%, driven by the absence of the restructuring charge in the prior year and savings associated with our organizational simplification, partially offset by higher volume related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $2.6 billion, largely consisting of cards’ net credit losses and ACL build.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: At the end of the quarter, we had over $22 billion in total reserves with a reserve-to-funded loans ratio of 2.7%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And on a full-year basis, we delivered $12.7 billion of net income with an RoTCE of 7.0%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 8, we show full year revenue trends by business from 2021 to 2024.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This year, we delivered $81.1 billion of revenue, up 5% on an ex-divestiture basis, driven by growth in each of our businesses and a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services revenues increased 9% to $19.6 billion, benefiting from a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation, fee growth and higher deposit volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets revenues increased 6% to $19.8 billion, primarily driven by growth in Equities, which had its highest annual revenue in a decade, and Spread Products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking revenues increased 32% to $6.2 billion, largely driven by growth in Investment Banking, with fees up 42% as we gained approximately 50 basis points of share on an increased wallet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth revenues increased 7% to $7.5 billion, primarily driven by a 15% increase in non interest revenue as we continue to grow client investment assets.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: USPB revenues increased 6% to $20.4 billion, driven by growth in cards, as we continue to see strong customer engagement and an increase in interest-earning balances, as well as lower partner payments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Overall, this year demonstrates another year of performance consistent with our medium-term target of 4 to 5% annual growth and the value of our diversified business model.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 9, we show the full year expense trend from 2021 to 2024.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Excluding the impact of the FDIC special assessment, our full-year expenses were $53.8 billion, in line with our target.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expense reduction was driven by savings related to our organizational simplification and stranded cost reduction, as well as lower restructuring and repositioning charges.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Organizational simplification, stranded cost reduction as well as efforts to drive efficiencies across the businesses contributed to a net decline of roughly 10 thousand direct staff.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: These savings were mostly offset by higher volume-related expenses as well as investments in the Transformation and other risk and controls and the Civil Money Penalties.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you can see at the bottom of the page, we spent $2.9 billion on Transformation this year, which includes investments in our infrastructure, platforms, applications, and data.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Transformation investments were up 1%, driven by an increase in certain programs, including data, largely offset by a reduction in the Transformation Bonus Award.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we spent $11.8 billion on technology, focused on digital innovation, new product development, client experience and other areas such as cyber security.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 10, we provide details on our $2.4 trillion balance sheet, which decreased 3% sequentially, largely driven by the impact of foreign exchange translation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the fourth quarter, we deployed some of our excess liquidity into loans, while maintaining a 116% LCR and $933 billion of available liquidity resources.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our $1.3 trillion deposit base remains well-diversified across regions, industries, customers and account types.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We maintained strong capital, ending the year with a preliminary 13.6% CET1 Capital ratio, approximately 150 basis points above our regulatory capital requirement of 12.1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And for the year we returned nearly $7 billion in the form of common dividends and repurchases to our shareholders.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to the businesses on slide 11, we show the results for Services for the fourth quarter and full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services revenues were up 15%, driven by a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation and reflecting continued momentum across Securities Services and TTS, both of which gained share this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
