sentence: NIR increased 61%, driven by a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation, as well as continued strength in underlying fee drivers such as USD Clearing, Commercial Card spend, Cross Border transactions, and assets under custody and administration.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NII was roughly flat, as the benefit of higher deposit volumes was offset by the impact of lower interest rates in Argentina.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses increased 1%, driven by continued investment in technology and platform modernization, partially offset by productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $112 million with a net ACL build of $84 million and net credit losses of $28 million.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 5% primarily driven by continued demand for export and agency finance as well as working capital loans.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits increased 4% as we continue to see growth in operating deposits.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services generated positive operating leverage and delivered net income of $1.9 billion and $6.5 billion for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And continues to deliver a high RoTCE, coming in at 29.9% and 26.0% for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 12, we show the results for Markets for the fourth quarter and full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets saw its highest fourth quarter revenue in a decade and increased 36% with broad based gains across all products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Fixed Income revenues increased 37%, driven by Rates and Currencies, which were up 39%, and Spread Products and Other Fixed Income, up 30%, both reflecting increased client activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Rates and Currencies also benefitted from a conducive trading environment, compared to a challenging prior year quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Spread Products and Other Fixed Income was driven by Credit and Mortgage Trading as well as higher securitization volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Equities revenues increased 34%, driven in part by strong execution of strategic client transactions in Cash Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And momentum also continued in Prime, with balances up approximately 23%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 8%, primarily driven by lower legal expenses and productivity savings.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $134 million, driven by a net ACL build, primarily related to Spread Products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans increased 6%, primarily driven by asset-backed lending in Spread Products as well as margin loans in Equities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average trading account assets increased 15%, largely driven by client demand for US Treasuries and foreign government securities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Markets generated another quarter of positive operating leverage and delivered net income of $1.0 billion and $4.9 billion for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And delivered an RoTCE of 7.4% and 9.1% for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 13, we show the results for Banking for the fourth quarter and full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking revenues were up 27%, largely driven by Investment Banking, with fees up 35% as we saw growth across all products.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: DCM was driven by continued Investment Grade issuance momentum and increased Leveraged Finance activity.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: ECM saw strong issuance activity particularly in follow-on and convertible instruments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In M&A, growth was driven by continued strong client engagement as well as the completion of previously announced acquisitions, given the more conducive macro environment.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: For the year, we gained share across regions, products and several sectors, including Healthcare and Technology.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Corporate Lending revenues, excluding mark-to-market on loan hedges, decreased 24%, driven by lower revenue share and volumes, partially offset by a smaller impact of Argentina currency devaluation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 9%, primarily driven by benefits of headcount reduction as we right sized the workforce and expense base, partially offset by higher volume related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was a benefit of $240 million, driven by a net ACL release of $247 million, primarily driven by improved macroeconomic conditions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Banking generated positive operating leverage for the fourth quarter in a row and delivered net income of $356 million and $1.5 billion for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And delivered an RoTCE of 6.5% and 7.0% for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 14, we show the results for Wealth for the fourth quarter and full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you can see from our performance this quarter, we are making good progress against our strategy and expect that momentum to continue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues were up 20%, driven by a 22% increase in NIR as we grew investment fees, with client investment assets up 18%, including net new investment assets of $16 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: NII increased 20%, driven by higher average deposit spreads and volumes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 3%, driven by the continued benefit of headcount reductions as we right size the workforce and expense base.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: End-of-period client balances increased 8%, driven by higher client investment asset flows and market valuations.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits increased 3%, reflecting the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits from USPB, partially offset by a shift in deposits to higher-yielding investments on Citi’s platform.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average loans decreased 1%, as we continued to optimize capital usage.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth generated a pre-tax margin of 21% and another quarter of positive operating leverage, delivering net income of $334 million and $1.0 billion for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And delivered an RoTCE of 10.1% and 7.6% for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 15, we show the results for U.S.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Personal Banking for the fourth quarter and full year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: U.S.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Personal Banking revenues were up 6%, driven by NII growth of 5% and lower partner payments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Branded Cards revenues increased 7%, with interest-earning balance growth of 7% as payment rates continue to normalize and we continue to see spend growth, which was up 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Retail Services revenues increased 7%, driven by lower partner payments and interest-earning balance growth of 3%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And Retail Banking revenues were roughly flat, as the impact of higher deposit spreads was offset by the impact of the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits to our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 2%, driven by continued productivity savings, partially offset by higher volume-related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Cost of credit was $2.2 billion, largely driven by net credit losses, as well as a build primarily for volume growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Average deposits decreased 18%, largely driven by the transfer of relationships and the associated deposits to our Wealth business.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: USPB generated another quarter of positive operating leverage and delivered net income of $392 million and $1.4 billion for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And delivered an RoTCE of 6.2% and 5.5% for the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: On slide 16, we show results for All Other on a managed basis, which includes Corporate/Other and Legacy Franchises and excludes divestiture-related items.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Revenues decreased 34%, primarily driven by net investment securities losses as we repositioned the portfolio, higher funding costs and closed exits and wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Expenses decreased 51%, primarily driven by the absence of the FDIC special assessment and restructuring charge in the prior year, as well as the reduction from the closed exits and wind-downs.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And cost of credit was $397 million, with net credit losses of $257 million and a net ACL build of $140 million, primarily driven by Mexico.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 18, where I will walk you through our current expectations for 2025.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As a reminder, what underpins our current expectations is a reflection of a number of scenarios that include different macro and capital market environments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And based on what we know today, we expect revenues to be around $83.5 to $84.5 billion, a roughly 3 to 4% increase year-over-year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect a continuation of the NIR ex-Markets momentum we saw this year, driven by: Investment Banking, as we continue to gain share in areas of strategic focus – such as Healthcare, Technology as well as Leveraged Finance and Sponsors – assuming a constructive industry wallet.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Wealth, supported by a continued focus on growth in client investment assets and banker productivity, which will drive investment revenue.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Services, as we execute the strategy we laid out at our Investor Day in June – expanding our leadership position with large institutions and growing our market share with Commercial clients in TTS.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And in Securities Services, continuing to gain share through investments in our digital and data capabilities while deepening with asset managers and asset owners.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 19, we expect NII ex-Markets to be up modestly this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, there are several tailwinds and headwinds that I will walk you through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Looking at the lefthand side of the page, we expect most of the increase to come from volume growth and mix, primarily driven by higher loan volumes in USPB, mainly in cards, and deposit volumes in Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect a continued benefit from lower yielding investment securities rolling off and being repriced into higher yielding assets such as cash, loans, and securities.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Partially offsetting these tailwinds are several headwinds, including various scenarios around: Lower rates, both in US and non-US, which we expect to be mostly offset by repricing actions across the franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As well as the potential impact of card late fee reduction and FX.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Turning to slide 20, we expect expenses to be slightly lower than $53.8 billion for 2025.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Our expectations reflect continued benefits from our organizational simplification, reduction in stranded costs and productivity savings from our prior investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: However, offsetting most of these benefits are increased investments in the Transformation, technology and the businesses as well as higher volume-related expenses.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Embedded in our outlook for the year is roughly $600 million for repositioning, which remains elevated, as we continue to reduce stranded costs, drive efficiencies across the businesses and as benefits from investments in Transformation and technology allow us to eliminate manual processes.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As Jane said, we recognize that our expense base remains elevated.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we remain very focused on bringing down our expenses each year while ensuring that we have enough capacity to invest in the company.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Now turning to slide 21, I’ll talk through our expectations for returns going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we enter 2025 and think forward to 2026, we continue to have a clear path to improved returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Having gone through another robust planning process, and having provided revenue and expense targets for 2025, we want to update our 2026 RoTCE target range.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In 2026 we expect continued revenue growth from both NII and NIR with drivers largely consistent with recent performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We expect expenses to decline from 2025 and are targeting an expense level below $53 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The reduction in our expense base will come from a decrease in legacy and stranded costs, a more normalized level of severance, and an increase in productivity savings from our prior investments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We will maintain strict discipline on the entire expense base, looking for more opportunities to drive further efficiencies as we go into 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We also remain laser focused on continuing to optimize RWA but as you know, the future of capital rules and therefore requirements remain uncertain.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In light of all of this, we are now targeting an RoTCE in the range of 10 to 11% in 2026.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are committed to driving positive operating leverage and improving our returns every year for both the firm and the businesses, and we will do so in a sustainable way which will set this company up for long-term success.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that in mind, as part of the $20 billion share repurchase program, we plan on buying back $1.5 billion of common stock in the first quarter.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As we take a step back, 2024 represents another year of solid progress and a set of proof points towards improving firmwide and business performance, as well as continued execution against our Transformation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as we enter 2025, these priorities remain critical as we continue to make progress on improving our returns.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: With that, Jane and I will be happy to take your questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our first question will come from Jim Mitchell with Seaport Global.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Please go ahead.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Hey, good morning everyone.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Just I think as Jane noted, it seems like a material driver of the reduction in the RoTCE target in 2026 is expenses.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: I think you kind of backed off the lower end of that, given higher investments in the Transformation but also talked about it being somewhat temporary.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: We appreciate the below $53 billion for 2026, but how much more is there to go beyond that in terms of eliminating parallel systems, running parallel systems, reduced consultant spend and all that stuff.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Is there still that path to a 60% or lower efficiency ratio?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Happy New Year, Jim.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I know you want to talk about the guidance, so let me put it into context here.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Last year, you've heard me be very clear about our two priorities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First one is driving the business performance and the second is executing the Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You've seen this quarter, you've seen last quarter, you've seen the full year our businesses are delivering the progress we wanted them to.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The strategy is working.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've changed the business mix.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're generating more fee-based revenues.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You see that in Services with NIR up 37% this year, Wealth NIR up 15%, IB fees up 35%, an important part of the mix around the quality of our earnings.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We said Services as a crown jewel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's delivered growth, high returns, it's taken share.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a crown jewel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We made a strategic play in Wealth, and you've seen us very steadily prove out why we can be a force globally with a clear path to delivering the financial performance that we said we would do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've consistently delivered on our revenue and expense targets.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I see a lot more opportunity and more upside to strengthen our business performance.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're very tangibly getting after it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're pretty excited by it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The second priority, Transformation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I've got to tell you, I'm broadly pleased with the progress we've made in risk and compliance and accountability.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Kind of excited by the work we've got going on in controls for the business as well at the moment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been very transparent.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Data is an area we have more work to do in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We increased our investments last year, as you know.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then as part of the annual planning process, we took a big step back to reassess our plan.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I decided, along with Mark and the management team, we needed to expand the scope and accelerate some of the work to satisfy our regulators' expectations.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm confident that the decision to do that, it was the right one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's the right one for our Transformation efforts, it’s certainly the right one for the firm overall.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I could have taken a short-term decision to cut other investments that are important for our long-term competitiveness, I'm just not going to do that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You shouldn't want me to do that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as I said in the opening comments, this 2026 target is a waypoint, not the final destination.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I just want to address the second part of your question, Jim, in terms of the path to the less than 60%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think Jane framed it out quite nicely in that we're building a franchise that will have continued and sustainable top line revenue momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are focused on driving out the inefficiencies and stranded costs and Legacy Franchise expenses from the organization and the benefits from these investments we've made in the Transformation will yield a lower cost structure over time as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so the combination of those things will get us to that targeted operating efficiency as we come out of 2026 at less than 60%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So yes, there is still a path, and we are focused on that path.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Great.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: That's very helpful.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: And then just maybe pivoting to the buyback, great to see the $20 billion authorization.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Obviously, I can't help but ask about beyond 1Q.

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: If we do sort of get this more certainty maybe no increase in capital requirements, does that start to help you maybe at least temporarily lower the buffer to take advantage of, you’re trading below tangible book and getting the accretion and accelerating the buyback?

speaker: Jim Mitchell
sentence: Or how do you think about the rest of the year on the buybacks?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, I'll make a couple of comments.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one, we're very pleased to have announced the buyback program at $20 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think, in many ways, that is a demonstration, if you will, of continued confidence in the earnings generation and momentum that we have around that as well as the recognition that we are trading below book and not where we want to be.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you've heard both Jane and I speak to the importance of increasing and doing more in the way of buybacks.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've increased that to $1.5 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think that supports that same degree of confidence that we have in the momentum.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We are constantly looking at every year on an annual basis as we go through our planning process at the management buffer that we have of 100 basis points.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And despite the last couple of quarters at running above the 13.1%, our target is the 13.1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so as we go through the balance of the year, as we get clarity on reg rules and what have you, you'll see us continue to manage down to that 13.1% and obviously, the two important characteristics that we keep in mind is the opportunity to invest more in the business at accretive returns, and where we're trading and the need to do more buybacks in order to reflect the underlying value.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So target is 13.1%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We continue to look at that management buffer as the regulatory environment evolves.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we'll continue to do more in the way of capital actions as that makes sense.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of John McDonald with Truist Securities.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Mark, just wanted to follow up on your answer to Jim right there.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: So when you look at the 10% to 11% RoTCE target for 2026.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Is that kind of assuming you'll be around the target or like using the 13.1% as the target?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And then longer term, you hope to bring that target down as rules get clarified and the franchise gets simplified?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Hey John, good to hear from you.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In fact, yes, the 10% to 11% RoTCE target we've set for 2026 does assume that we are running and using a 13.1% CET1 ratio obviously, there'll be an SCB that comes out sometime later this year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The rules are continuing to evolve and what have you, and we'll factor those in as we know more about them.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But yes, it does assume the 13.1% which is our management target, if you will, for CET1.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Great.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And then my next question is, could you clarify what you're expecting this year for card net charge-offs?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Understand the quarterly cadence has seasonality.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: But for the full year, it sounds like you're expecting the charge-offs to be in the range of last year's guidance.

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: Can you just kind of clarify that?

speaker: John Mcdonald
sentence: And then maybe just talk about provision build, which you had a lot of in 2024 and whether that could slow down as the maturation of balances slows down?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So in terms of the net credit losses and the forecast that we have, we are expecting that the net credit losses will be at the high end of the range that we've given.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So in the case of Branded Cards, that 3.5% to 4% is the full year range that we've given.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: In the case of Retail Services, it's 5.75% to 6.25%, excuse me, and so right now, Retail Services is at that high end at 6.28% for 2024.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We'd expect it to stay at that high end, and then on Branded Cards, we're at 3.64%, we'd expect it to creep up to about the 4% level over the course of the year.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But remember, that is a full year NCL rate, and we know that there's seasonality through the quarters.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so you'll see movement through the quarters based on that dynamic.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then just in terms of the provision build, there are a couple of drivers there.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is obviously volume, and we do expect to see volume growth in USPB.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that will be an important factor in how the CECL calculations are done.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then the second driver is obviously, as you know, we run models and the models they have a base scenario, they have a downside, an upside scenario depending on the broader macro factors, unemployment, GDP, et cetera, et cetera, and our weighting towards the likelihood of high or upside or downside scenario, those factors become important considerations in the provisioning.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that's kind of how we think about that going into 2025.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I hope that helps.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So you are guiding for three consecutive years of lower expenses including that $600 million repositioning this year.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So they were down in 2024, you're guiding them lower in 2025 and you guide them lower in 2026 again, and you're also guiding for three consecutive years of higher revenues based on what you said.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I didn't see that in the written materials, but I think I heard you say that, Mark.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So three years of lower expenses, three years of higher revenues to at least 2026.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Is that correct?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think you described it correctly.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We're seeing continued momentum on the top line.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: and we're focused on continuing to bring our expenses down just as we did in 2024, a tad bit in 2025 and then more in 2026.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: All right.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And then I guess this is for Jane.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Well, that beats haggis on toast, if you achieve that.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But I'm wondering why that efficiency might not improve even more.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I mean if you have $5 billion of stranded costs and Transformation costs in 2024 and some of that goes down.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: I heard you're investing in tech and Transformation and volume and the businesses.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And there's always a trade-off between the bottom line results you showed today and the growth you show in the future, and it seems like you're going to get this done, the lower expenses while you're leaning into a little bit extra growth.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So talk about that trade-off and where you're leaning in for growth a little bit more.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: First of all, I'm a little disturbed by your comment about haggis on toast.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's haggis with mashed potatoes and whiskey, just to be clear for everyone.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's Robert Burns night coming up soon.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: On expenses, Mike and everyone, expenses are a focus not just for Mark and I, but for the entire management team.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're making sure that focus and discipline is really getting installed and instilled into the DNA of Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you've seen that, as you referenced, we've been meeting our expense guidance over the last couple of years, we've been driving positive operating efficiency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're all very focused on improving our operating expense base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Consolidating technology, the simplification work, automation, getting different utilities put in place rather than fragmented around the firm, using AI tools now our, location strategy, right?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that core operating expense base is something that we're really looking at how do we drive to be more efficient, more modern and getting it to the level it should be for the revenues that we generate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We all want Transformation to get done quickly, and we want it to get done right.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So that is why our expenses are temporarily elevated to make the investments that needed there.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is not all run rate.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as you say, as CEO, I will not sacrifice the right long-term investments in our growth and competitiveness for short-term expediency.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: This is a way point.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's not a destination.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we know what we need to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got our arms around all of this, we're just getting on with execution.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: Jane, just to follow up on what you mentioned, as you do execute, we all expect, or at least I do, that the market will be giving you credit for that execution, and meaning multiples should increase.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I have a few questions here on the buyback, because right now,today, as we all know, you're trading below book, it has got to be, buying back stock has got to be the most accretive use of capital today.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And why wait on the buyback when you can lean into it today and keep your 2026 guide, I mean, the old guide was 11% to 12% RoTCE, new guide, 10% to 11%.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: I'm kind of confused why you don't pull that lever more aggressively because buying back the stock, the accretion to tangible book, it’s got to be the easiest thing to do to help that RoTCE go up.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: When you compare and contrast against all the hard work you've been doing, which will obviously be very important to getting the RoTCE up.

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: But why not lean more into that buyback?

speaker: Betsy Graseck
sentence: And can you give us a sense of the timing of that $20 billion?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Yes, Betsy, I love the passion.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I've got to say I can hear the determination in your voice.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think it's the same determination we feel.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Look, we're very committed to returning capital shareholders period.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Full stop.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We’ve got a $20 billion buyback program, as Mark said, that is reflective of the growing earnings power that we have and our confidence in the path ahead.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been increasing the amount of capital return over the last few quarters.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm also happy to see a more aggressive Basel III scenario firmly off the table.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have, nonetheless, a 13.1% CET1 ratio that we put in the plan that can change over time as well.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: But there's not, there's not complete certainty around where the capital requirements are going to go.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We hope there will be a holistic one that is reflective of the risk profile of the bank that's been improving significantly over the last few years.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we have some great growth opportunities.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I look at the different areas.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm excited by what we see in Wealth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got a great runway with our clients who want to do business with us in Banking.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got some very important investments and an investment agenda that we're putting in to help us continue growing the bank, gaining competitiveness in a responsible way.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'll just conclude with exactly your point.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The bar is high on those investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We don't make them unless we see extremely attractive marginal RoTCE.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And there's a lot of things we say no to in order to put the $20 billion program in place.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In terms of timing, like our peers, we're not committing to a particular time frame from this, but you can see our commitment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You can hear our commitment.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from the line of Ebrahim Poonawala with Bank America.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I guess maybe, Jane, I wanted to follow up on a couple of segments.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: I think you said 2024 turning point for Wealth, and we've seen very steady progress on the RoTCE in Wealth.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just talk to us in terms of, Andy Sieg’s being in the seat for a year now, you've seen progress.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: What needs to happen?

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just talk to us a little bit about the franchise positioning competitively both in the U.S. and abroad as you think about going head-to-head with some of your global competitors and where are the most likely growth opportunities over the next year or two?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So, our vision, my vision is that we become a global leader in wealth management.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There are not many firms that have the globality of Citi.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have all the assets, especially the client relationships all around the world, which were just not tapped for investments in the past.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's a big opportunity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We have $5.3 trillion “off us” from existing clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think the fact that I would find interesting is 55% of it, it's almost $3 trillion with affluent clients in our branch network in America, in the U.S. We're also very well-positioned to capture new wealth, just think about what Citi does in terms of our footprint, our capabilities really supports the wealth creation, from the Commercial Bank, our Investment Banking side, Markets, obviously, Services supporting it, too.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These are all great feeders for us to strengthen wealth relationships with our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we brought in Andy.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Andy greatly sharpened the focus on the investment business, this is where we see the big upside.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He's been building a differentiated value proposition around wealth creation.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: He’s been leveraging a lot of the leading capital market capabilities, the different relationships we have with PE firms, asset managers around the world.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Get a great platform in place and importantly, improving our client experience, again, particularly around investments, asset allocation, performance, et cetera.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What I have also got to love is the surgical approach that he's taking to the expense base and driving productivity, something that we're doing across the firm.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm also excited by the talent he's bringing, in the market leaders like Kate Moore and Keith Glenfield in the investment space.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we've made a lot of investments in training and building this investment culture that we didn't have before.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So to your point, the proof points are working.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Q4 revenue up 20%, operating margin at 21% on its way to 25% to 30%, 10% RoTCE on its way to 15% to 20%.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: These last few quarters, you've just seen us on that march.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And the number I'm most excited by, net new investment asset inflow of $42 billion, up 40% year-over-year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The strategy is working.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're going to be a leader in wealth, the growth opportunities,Asia U.S., Middle East, all the places where we are with our existing clients and the new wealth generators of the future.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: And if I can draw a parallel to the Banking segment with the RoTCE is about 5% to 6% last few quarters.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: There you brought in Vis Raghavan from JPMorgan.

speaker: Ebrahim Poonawala
sentence: Just give us a sense of could we see a similar trajectory in that business over the next 12 months and where the opportunities are to improve that ROE?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think absolutely, a strong performance, the strategy we have in place is delivering nicely.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So if you look at the revenues, the investment banking fees, positive operating leverage all through the year and gaining share.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: All three products gaining share in all three in all of the geographies we're in, I'm really excited and happy to see the health care and technology,two areas that we've been investing heavily behind.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you're also seeing us playing a leading role in some of the key transactions, the biggest transactions last year.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Mars Kellanova, single adviser, big role in Boeing, and then just this week, the J&J acquisition of Intracellular.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So the deals that matter, this is where you're seeing Citi playing a leading role in.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So when Vis joined, the mandate, a bit similar to Andy, becoming a top three investment bank, deliver the full potential of One Citi to our clients.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we've got a lot of upside there, instilling some more discipline in capital allocation, client coverage, some of the cross-firm linkages.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We're getting a lot more from our people.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've been bringing in some great new talent we've also been cutting some of the unproductive spend.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think what you can see is we're just on a path of systematically growing our wallet.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We'll be improving our operating margin, generating higher returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: That should be your expectation over the next couple of years of what you'll see from us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And as we head into great environment in 2025 that should be pretty conducive for a lot of client activity.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm very confident we're well positioned.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We've got the groundwork done to take advantage of it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Ebrahim, I thought I heard you say RoTCE of 5%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: It's actually 7% for the full year for Banking and on its way to the target that we've set of mid-teens for our Banking business.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with UBS.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Hate to ask the umpteenth question on the buyback, but clearly, the way the stock is reacting today, the buyback is very important to your shareholders.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I guess my first question, if I could have the two questions, is it's very clear that you want to return capital to shareholders.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: It's very clear that you have excess capital.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: It's very clear that your PPNR trajectory is positive.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And so what are the specific mile markers that that Citi needs to see in order to increase that pacing from that $1.5 billion a quarter to something is more suggestive of a pace that that would be in line with that $20 billion authorization?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: And I know that's been asked of you already, but is it the consent order?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Is it the stress test?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: We had some news over the holidays that were positive for the sector.

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Like what are those specific mile markers?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: I mean you're doing it on the PPNR side, right?

speaker: Erika Najarian
sentence: Like what do you need to see to have even more confidence, again, like leaning into Betsy’s words, to go all in on the buyback?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So thank you for the question.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Let me make clear a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So one, and I've said this already, so I apologize for repeating myself, but one, our target for CET1 is 13.1%, and so what you're going to see over the course of the year is us managing down to that target?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's kind of one point.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The second point I want to be clear is that it's not the consent order.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: That's not something that that is impacting the capital actions and decisions that we take.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We obviously forecast out the performance.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I've said, Jane has said already, we see very strong continued earnings momentum, managing towards a 13.1% CET1 ratio.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And you'll see the buyback trajectory reflect getting down to that CET1.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The one thing I will mention, and you mentioned already is that we obviously have another CCAR process, stress test that we will go through.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And none of us can predict kind of what's on the other side of that from an SCB point of view, but that will be an important factor as we get through the first half of the year and into the second half of the year in terms of kind of the level of buybacks that we will be taking on a quarter-by quarter basis.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I hope that helped.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are no artificial constraints, so to speak, that are in place.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: This is us planning and forecasting the performance of the franchise ensuring they can fuel high-returning growth opportunities so that we're building a sustainable franchise, looking at the capital requirements that we have and the management buffer that we put in place and therefore, taking that excess capacity and putting it towards buybacks, but with an eye towards the regulatory environment that we're in, and what I mean by that are the capital requirements that come out of the annual stress testing process that's run.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So that's the basics of it as we sit here today.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I guess I'm just trying to think about everybody is super focused on what you had said previously, now you have different targets, but is it just really like, look, it just takes longer, we'll get there, but just takes longer.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And maybe just an addendum to that, how should we expect Banamex to impact that 10% to 11% RoTCE in terms of the immediate impact after IPO and then after you deploy that excess capital that you get back?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Erika, we chose the words very carefully to say that 2026 is a way point, it's not the destination.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And when I'm looking at it, I'm looking out to 2027, 2028, what is the bank we want to be in terms of our strategy, our performance, our culture, all those different dimensions.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And we just relentlessly keep going down that path, but we're going to take the right and responsible decisions as we go down it.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So our potential is for more than our medium-term target RoTCE, the potential of the bank and the journey that we're on is to improve our returns beyond there, for sure.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And just in terms of the impact and the timing that Jane referenced, just keep in in mind that the financial impact of exiting Banamex comes two forms.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: One is the gain or loss on sale and two is the risk weighted asset release.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The gain or loss on sale will run through the P&L at deconsolidation, so that's the point where we've gotten, or we've IPO-ed more than the 50%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And the ultimate benefit will be driven by the RWA release when we fully divest our stake.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so hopefully, that helps, but it's not until we’ve deconsolidated that we see that P&L impact and the CTA and other things like that kind of flow through the P&L for Banamex.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Jane, I'll pass on the haggis, but I'll take you up on the whiskey.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I didn't say I was buying just to be clear.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Our expense report on this end.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Anyway, just following up, Mark, on your comments about the IPO with Banamex.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Can you guys remind us, or refresh our memories, on when the IPO process starts, once it goes public, what percentage ownership do you guys expect to have?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And second, have you given us any color on whether you expect to report a gain on this transaction or a loss as you just referenced, that will go through the P&L?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We haven't given any sense for the exact timing of that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As you know, this is a process.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so Jane just spoke to the timing of that process, the first step, having been completed on December 1 with the separation, we are now obviously gearing up and readying ourselves for the IPO.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There'll obviously be important filings associated with that given our intent to dual list, there will be regulatory approvals that are required kind of as we make headway with potential investors as part of the IPO process.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so there are a series of IPO steps that we will need to take over the course of the year in order to continue to ready ourselves and there are things that we don't control.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Like as Jane mentioned, the regulatory approval process and timing for that as well as the market conditions.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so all of those factors are important.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then how the IPO occurs in terms of percentage that is taken on at that first tranche versus follow-on tranches are important factors on when we get to deconsolidation.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so I haven't given you an exact timing on that but you can envision kind of 15% tranches that happen over kind of a 12-, 18-month, 24-month period.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then obviously reaching a point of deconsolidation at which point that currency translation adjustment starts to flow through the P&L.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There's no material impact on capital, but it does flow through the P&L.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then ultimately, we exit 100% over the course of time.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I'm sorry, I'm not giving you precise dates and percentages.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And part of that is because we are obviously on the front end of not only readying ourselves but considering alternative IPO structures and potential investors/shareholders as part of that process.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Well, I appreciate the insights.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And then as a follow-up question, and I really don't mean this as a ‘what have you done for me lately?’ type of question because you guys have made so much progress in what you're doing in your strategic changes here.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: But can you talk about the U.S.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: Personal Banking, many of your questions today is about the RoTCE consolidated and how you can improve that, and this business has a very low RoTCE as you guys know, below your cost of capital.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And structurally, when you look at it, if you look at the loans at the end of period just over $220 billion, your deposits about $90 billion, which is quite a bit different than your peers who have much higher ROEs.

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: So how do you approach this business?

speaker: Gerard Cassidy
sentence: And again, I know you've been very busy divesting a lot of the businesses that are not important, but it seems to me that this is a giant hurdle that you guys have to approach at some point in the near future.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Let me just chat a bit through this.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So what’s the path to the higher returns in U.S.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Personal Banking, it’s coming from top line revenue growth, improved expense base and also a lot more normalized credit environment, and that gets us to the mid- to high-teen returns in the medium term.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think we feel very confident and comfortable in that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You're seeing the proof points I talked about Banking, Wealth earlier, we’ve had another good quarter of revenue growth, had the ninth consecutive quarter of positive operating leverage.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I think you should be getting some comfort around that.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: What's going to drive that growth?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Co-brands, we just extended with American to be their sole issuer.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: It's going to give exciting benefits to the American Airlines and the Citi cardholders.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And it will be beneficial for both our growth and our returns.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: In the proprietary front, we're investing.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's a lot of investment in innovation to drive growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The refreshed Strata Premier Card, we've been enhancing the reward offerings and you're seeing us often now #1 in recognitions and awards around that area.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Retail Services being forensically focused on improving the partnership economics and driving top line growth.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And then Retail Banking,therewe're driving primary checking growth, we’ve putin simplified banking, so we get a much more streamlined customer proposition that's driving more of a relationship-based banking approach as opposed to a transactional one.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Importantly as well, the Retail Bank has been feeding our Wealth business.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I think you heard me earlier talking about that almost $3 trillion “off us” investment opportunity that we have from the retail banking customer base.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We transferred $17 billion of deposits from USPB to Wealth, so you've got to take that, those dynamics into account.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I hope you're taking from me, I feel confident in our ability to get to the medium term targets we set for the business of mid- to high-teens.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I feel comfortable about the growth trajectory that we've got based off the innovations we're putting through and the changes.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And good expense discipline and a better credit environment.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So when you look at the mix of our business, Ithink you'll see us performing nicely here.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Operator
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: Hi, I just want to follow up on Page 9 where you break out the technology and Transformation investment spend.

speaker: Connor
sentence: And sorry if I missed this, but did you talk about the pace of those two levels in your 2025 and 2026 expense guidance?

speaker: Connor
sentence: I know directionally, you said it's going up.

speaker: Connor
sentence: But did you give a magnitude?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I did not.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Obviously, for both technology and Transformation those are areas that we are going to continue to invest in for all the reasons that we've mentioned.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: They obviously contribute to the number in 2025 being slightly down from the $53.8 billion, but they also represent, as I mentioned, what we believe is required to kind of get the work done that we need to get done.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so those numbers will increase.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are lots of puts and takes, as you know, through an annual expense forecast, right, including, as you would expect, we've got volume, we’ve got revenue growth here that's going to come with volume growth.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Volume, incentive comp, there's merit increases that go with that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then we also have a series of productivity actions that are playing through to offset those headwinds, whether it be the additional carryover from the org simplification and full year impact of that, or some of the Legacy/stranded coming down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so there are puts and takes, but Transformation and technology specifically, we are continuing to invest in, in order to achieve what we need to get done here and also ensure the businesses have what they need to drive sustainable growth going forward.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: MATT O’

speaker: Connor
sentence: And I guess, like how do you know that the recent increase that you're modeling internally in these areas, how do you know you're spending enough and in the right ways to address your goals in the Transformation and also satisfy the regulatory requirements?

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Well, if I jump in, I feel very confident indeed that we know what we need to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We know what we need to be spending on.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Through the annual planning process that that concluded last month, it was clear we did need to invest more.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We increased the scope of some of the work on the data front.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We brought some other work forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We looked at what we needed to do on the technology front and some of the critical investments.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So this is pretty forensic and when we're looking at Transformation, we're looking at technology, we know what our target states need to be, and we know what we need to do to get there and the outcomes we need to be delivering.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So we've got our arms around this, and I think you're hearing that confidence from us around what we need to do.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: We know the investments we need to make.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: You know what the outcomes and the benefits for shareholders and the regulatory side need to be.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our next question comes from the line of Saul Martinez with HSBC.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Mark, the NII ex-Markets outlook, if I just take the fourth quarter and annualize that, I get to something in the neighborhood of, I think, around $47.4 billion, $47.5 billion which is above the full year 2024 level.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: I'm not sure exactly what “up modestly” means, if that's 1%, 3%, 4%, but, and correct me if you think I’m wrong, but it seems like maybe there's a little bit of conservatism built in?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: If you can just comment on how you think, and how we should think about the quarterly trajectory of NI ex-Markets?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Obviously, there's a day count issue in 1Q, but maybe how do you think through like, how we should expect that NII to evolve over the course of the year?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I mean, why don't I just kind of cut to the chase on it a little bit, Saul, in the sense that, “up modestly”, call it a couple of percentage points, 2 to 3 percentage points or so, right, in terms of how I think about it.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And I think I've taken, I’ve gone through kind of the tailwinds and headwinds, so I won't kind of take you through that again.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But I think the important takeaway should be that we're going to see continued momentum across the franchise driven by loan growth in the Branded Card side of the business and continued deposit momentum, particularly operating deposits in Services.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're going to do everything that we always do around the management of pricing, and we'll get a benefit from how we've been managing our investment portfolio as those things mature.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: The combination of those efforts will offset, more than offset some of the headwinds that you'd expect in a declining rate environment, and modestly is, call it, 2% to 3%.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Fair enough.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: And then on the expense outlook getting to below $53 billion in 2026, I know that's consistent with what you've said in the past, does imply a pretty sharp reduction in 2026, especially in light of continued revenue growth, it's pretty material operating leverage.

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Just I mean, how much benefit do you get from a more normalized severance?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: In other words, how much are we thinking about severance coming down?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: What's sort of the impact or how to think about the Legacy, stranded costs coming down?

speaker: Saul Martinez
sentence: Just maybe a little bit more meat on the bone in terms of how much these items will benefit 2026 versus 2025?

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: Look, a couple of things.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: As I look at our severance costs, which, as I mentioned, has been running high, it was $700 million, we're forecasting $600 million in 2025.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think kind of normal through the cycle is probably, call it, $300 million or so.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so that gives you some sense for that.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: I think the other thing is, if you look at the other page, and again, there are a number of drivers or levers that we intend to pull to bring that down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But in the All Other page where you look to the right, we show wind-downs and what's remaining in terms of Legacy Franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: If you add those numbers together, $1.9 billion or so of expenses and think about a subset of that being stranded.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And we're going to continue to focus on how do we bring down stranded costs over the next couple of years.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So those are two important factors or contributors to the decline from the slightly lower than $53.8 billion to the $53 billion.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: There are additional productivity saves from prior investments that we've made.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But those are important factors.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And then as we look at the Transformation spend, that will continue to, or start to pay dividends or help to bring down costs as well.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So you've got really those four variables that contribute to us bringing that number down.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And as Jane has mentioned, we're going to even post 2026, continue to bring, or drive out more inefficiencies around the organization to fund required investments for the business growth and all with a continued focus on getting to less than 60% as we exit 2026, less than 60% operating efficiency.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Our final question will come from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo.

speaker: Operator
sentence: Your line is now open, please go ahead.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: Hi, this is your first full year of having the five line of business structure.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: So, Mark, do you still have the same line of business targets that you had last year?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And Jane, with all the, it must have been a degree of hell to organize this way, get rid of your two intercompany holding companies, eliminate five layers of management, expand span of control and you guys went through a lot last year.

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: And I'm just wondering, is the worst over in terms of that kind of reorganization internally and the culture and the sentiment and how you see that continuing?

speaker: Mike Mayo
sentence: But first, the concrete question about the targets, please.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So I guess I'll start first.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So in terms of the targets, look, we set the targets across each of the lines of business for the medium term.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: We've obviously brought down the 2026 to 10% to 11%.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: And so you'd imagine there's some movement, at least for the 2026 in terms of those targets, Banking will likely be a little bit lower than the mid-15%, if I think about 2026 as being that medium-term target date.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: But over time, I expect that the targets that I've set are the targets that we will achieve and even more because, as Jane mentioned, 10% to 11%, while that's our 2026 target, it is not our longer-term target as we think about RoTCE and the strength of these businesses in the aggregate franchise.

speaker: Mark Mason
sentence: So hopefully, that answers your question.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And in terms of org simplification, culture, the best is still ahead,that is for sure.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The org went through a lot.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm really proud of how people responded.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And I think we're really proud of how each of the lines of business are driving the business performance forward.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: The bank is simpler.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There is tremendous transparency for our investors as well as for me.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: There's much greater proximity to the businesses now.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: And you can see that the benefits that we're starting to realize from the strategy as we get closer and closer to the RoTCE targets and beyond for each of the businesses.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: So I'm pleased to have 2024 behind us.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: I'm proud of what we achieved in 2024.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: All the focus is on the future.

speaker: Jane Fraser
sentence: Onwards.

speaker: Operator
sentence: There are no further questions.

speaker: Operator
sentence: I'll now turn the call over to Jenn Landis for closing remarks.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Please call us or email us if you have any follow-up questions.

speaker: Jennifer Landis
sentence: Have a great afternoon.
